title: Attention-Based Neural-Augmented Kalman Filter for Legged Robot State Estimation_supp1-3664311.mp4
authors: Kyung-Soo Kim
publish: N/A
abstract: In this letter, we propose an Attention-Based Neural-Augmented Kalman Filter (AttenNKF) for state estimation in legged robots. Foot slip is a major source of estimation error: when slip occurs, kinematic measurements violate the no-slip assumption and inject bias during the update step. Our objective is to estimate this slip-induced error and compensate for it. To this end, we augment an Invariant Extended Kalman Filter (InEKF) with a neural compensator that uses an attention mechanism to infer error conditioned on foot-slip severity and then applies this estimate as a post-update compensation to the InEKF state (i.e., after the filter update). The compensator is trained in a latent space, which aims to reduce sensitivity to raw input scales and encourages structured slip-conditioned compensations, while preserving the InEKF recursion. Experiments demonstrate improved performance compared to existing legged-robot state estimators, particularly under slip-prone conditions.

title: Experimental Demonstration of a DC Excited Coreless Planar PCB Coil Actuator Targeted for Lateral Micro-actuation in MEMS
authors: Praful P. Kabadi, Abhijit D. Kamble, Vinod Belwanshi, S. E. Talole, Bhubon Ch. Mech
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: Electromagnetic micro actuators in microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) applications have an advantage for large displacement and quick actuation. However, most of the micro-actuator designs require permanent magnets or ferromagnetic cores to concentrate magnetic flux, which leads to complicated integration. To the best of our knowledge, this work presents the first experimental proof-of-concept demonstration of a coreless planar printed circuit board (PCB) coil actuator, which is capable of achieving lateral displacement of a ferromagnetic dipole made of nickel sheet using only magnetic field gradients generated by the coil, without any permanent magnets or ferromagnetic cores. This work is also significant as the concept is highly suitable for implementation in MEMS micro actuators fabricated using metal UV LIGA process. The work presents a 15-turn planar spiral coil fabricated on flame-retardant 4 (FR4) substrate using optimized ultraviolet (UV) lithography, showing a case of lateral micro-actuation. The work also focuses on optimizing the process to achieve track widths of ∼80 μm after resolving challenges of lateral etching and resolution limitations. Experimental testing with a Nickel dipole of dimensions approximately 13.5 × 1.5 × 0.02 mm with ∼12 mg weight demonstrated smooth and repeatable lateral displacement of ∼0.75 mm at 0.425 A DC drive current, closely matching the behavior that was predicted based on the magnetic profile that were obtained by simulations. The theoretical force analysis predicts magnetic forces of 1163.6 μN, which significantly exceeds the gravitational force (∼117.67 μN) and kinetic friction forces (41.185 μN), with experimental validation confirming consistent displacement performance across multiple trials. Compared with piezoelectric and electrostatic MEMS actuators, which achieve micrometer-scale motion, the proposed device demonstrates two orders of magnitude higher displacement.

title: Psychophysically-Guided Training for Fingerprint Presentation Attack Detection
authors: Samuel Webster, Walter Scheirer, Adam Czajka
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biometrics, Behavior, and Identity Science
abstract: Psychophysically-guided training, which directs model learning based on human-perceptual annotations, has demonstrated generalization improvements across various vision tasks, including biometric presentation attack detection (PAD). In saliency-guided training, model’s decision-making is aligned to image regions marked by human annotators. In perceptuallyweighted training, human psychophysical measurements weigh per-sample loss, prioritizing samples with greater ‘difficulty’. This paper presents the first application of both strategies to fingerprint PAD. We conducted a 50-participant study to perceptually annotate 800 fingerprint samples, producing human-sourced saliency maps and annotation-duration-based perceptual weighting coefficients. These are utilized alongside algorithmically-generated “pseudosaliency” (minutiae-based, quality-based, and autoencoder-generated) and additional perceptual weighting coefficients derived from minutiae count and sample quality. Evaluating on the 2021 Fingerprint Liveness Detection Competition testing set, we explore various configurations within nine distinct training scenarios to assess the impact of psychophysically-guided training on accuracy and generalization. Our findings demonstrate the effectiveness of psychophysically-guided training for fingerprint PAD in both limited and large data contexts, and we present multiple configurations capable of earning the first place on the LivDet-2021 benchmark. Our results highlight psychophysically-guided training’s promise for increased model generalization capabilities, its effectiveness when data is limited, and its potential to scale to larger datasets in fingerprint PAD. All collected saliency maps, perceptual weighting coefficient sets, and trained models are released with the paper to support reproducible research.

title: Explaining Robust Quantum Metrology by Counting Codewords
authors: Oskar Novak, Narayanan Rengaswamy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Quantum Engineering
abstract: Quantum sensing holds great promise for high-precision magnetic field measurements. However, its performance is significantly limited by noise. The investigation of active quantum error correction to address this noise led to the Hamiltonian-Not-in-Lindblad-Span (HNLS) condition. This states that Heisenberg scaling is achievable if and only if the signal Hamiltonian is orthogonal to the span of the Lindblad operators describing the noise. In this work, we consider a robust quantum metrology setting where the probe state is inspired from CSS codes for noise resilience but there is no active error correction performed. After the state picks up the signal, we measure the code's $\hat{X}$ stabilizers to infer the magnetic field parameter, $\theta$. Given $N$ copies of the probe state, we derive the probability that all stabilizer measurements return $+1$, which depends on $\theta$. The uncertainty in $\theta$ (estimated from these measurements) is bounded by a new quantity, the Robustness Bound, which ties the Quantum Fisher Information of the measurement to the number of weight-2 codewords of the dual code. Through this novel lens of coding theory, we show that for nontrivial CSS code states the HNLS condition still governs the Heisenberg scaling in our robust metrology setting. Our finding suggests fundamental limitations in the use of linear quantum codes for dephased magnetic field sensing applications both in the near-term robust sensing regime and in the long-term fault tolerant era. We also extend our results to general scenarios beyond dephased magnetic field sensing.

title: TrapFlow: Controllable Website Fingerprinting Defense via Dynamic Backdoor Learning_supp1-3663989.pdf
authors: Siyuan Liang
publish: N/A
abstract: Website fingerprinting (WF) attacks, which covertly monitor user communications to identify the web pages they visit, pose a serious threat to user privacy. Existing WF defenses attempt to reduce attack accuracy by disrupting traffic patterns, but attackers can retrain their models to adapt, making these defenses ineffective. Meanwhile, their high overhead limits deployability. To overcome these limitations, we introduce a novel controllable website fingerprinting defense called TrapFlow based on backdoor learning. TrapFlow exploits the tendency of neural networks to memorize subtle patterns by injecting crafted trigger sequences into targeted website traffic, causing the attacker’s model to build incorrect associations during training. If the attacker attempts to adapt by training on such noisy data, TrapFlow ensures that the model internalizes the trigger as a dominant feature, leading to widespread misclassification across unrelated websites. Conversely, if the attacker ignores these patterns and trains only on clean data, the trigger behaves as an adversarial patch at inference time, causing model misclassification. To achieve this dual effect, we optimize the trigger using the Fast Levenshtein-like distance to maximize both its learnability and distinctiveness from normal traffic. Experiments show that TrapFlow significantly reduces the accuracy of the RF attack from 99% to 6% with 74% data overhead. This compares favorably against two SOTA defenses: FRONT reduces accuracy by only 2% at a similar overhead, while Palette achieves 32% accuracy, but with 48% more overhead. We further validate the practicality of our method in a real Tor network environment.

title: Adaptive V-I Fusion SLAM: Multi-Constraint Optimization for Illumination Robust Localization
authors: Haibin Sun, Xuetong Ye, Weilong Song, Fan Yang, Chao Wei, Xueyuan Li, Chaoyang Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive visible-infrared (V-I) multi-constraint fused SLAM system for illumination robust localization. It organizes the two modalities into a primary/ auxiliary scheme: the primary stream is selected by feature-tracking stability with a hysteresis mechanism, while auxiliary features are continuously weighted according to their incremental spatial complementarity measured by the surprisal of the primary feature-density distribution. The resulting weighted visual factors are jointly optimized with IMU preintegration and vehicle-motion constraints (forward velocity and kinematic constraints with zero-velocity updates when applicable) in a tightly-coupled sliding-window framework to reduce drift under degraded vision. We further adopt an illumination-adaptive hierarchical relocalization pipeline to improve place recognition across day-night transitions. Experiments on public and custom datasets demonstrate consistently improved robustness and accuracy over single-modality and direct fusion baselines under both stable and varying illumination.

title: A Scoping Review of Machine Learning Approaches for Predicting Lower Extremity Joint Contact Loads: Current Trends, Common Pitfalls and Future Directions
authors: Philipp Krondorfer, Djordje Slijepčević, Andreas Kranzl, Matthias Zeppelzauer, Brian Horsak
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Human gait analysis quantifies locomotion and assesses gait performance, particularly for patients with musculoskeletal disorders. While instrumented 3D gait analysis is the gold standard, advancements in physics based musculoskeletal modeling offer deeper insights into body mechanics. However, its complexity and resource demands limit clinical use, prompting interest in machine learning (ML) as a surrogate for traditional simulations. This scoping review synthesizes ML approaches for estimating joint contact forces in the lower extremities. A systematic search was conducted according to PRISMA-ScR guidelines, covering English language publications from January 2014 to August 2024 across PubMed, IEEE Xplore, Scopus, and SpringerLink. Studies were eligible if they applied ML techniques to estimate lower extremity joint contact forces in human participants and provided sufficient methodological details. Data extraction used a standardized charting form capturing study populations, movement types, input data, ML methods, validation procedures, and performance metrics. 27 studies met the inclusion criteria. The studies showed variability in populations, movement types, input data, ML methods, validation procedures, and performance metrics. Small datasets, often underrepresenting females, limit model generalizability. Inconsistencies in validation approaches and performance metrics, along with the lack of published data and code, hinder reproducibility and comparability. Despite challenges, ML models show potential in accurately predicting joint contact loads and forces. Future research should focus on expanding and diversifying datasets, standardizing methodologies, embracing open science practices, and integrating physics-informed approaches to enhance clinical applicability.

title: Optimal Client Sampling in Federated Learning with Client-level Heterogeneous Differential Privacy_supp1-3661913.pdf
authors: Rui Dr. Hu
publish: N/A
abstract: Federated Learning with client-level differential privacy (DP) provides a promising framework for collaboratively training models while rigorously protecting clients’ privacy. However, classic approaches like DP-FedAvg struggle when clients have heterogeneous privacy requirements, as they must uniformly enforce the strictest privacy level across all clients, leading to excessive DP noise and significant degradation in model utility. Existing methods to improve the model utility in such heterogeneous privacy settings often assume a trusted server and are largely heuristic, resulting in suboptimal performance and lacking strong theoretical foundations. In this work, we address these challenges under a practical attack model where both clients and the server are honest-but-curious. We propose GDPFed, which partitions clients into groups based on their privacy budgets and achieves client-level DP within each group to reduce the privacy budget waste and hence improve the model utility. Based on the privacy and convergence analysis of GDPFed, we find that the magnitude of DP noise depends on both model dimensionality and the per-group client sampling ratios. To further improve the performance of GDPFed, we introduce GDPFed+, which integrates model sparsification to eliminate unnecessary noise and optimizes per-group client sampling ratios to minimize convergence error. Extensive empirical evaluations on multiple benchmark datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of GDPFed+, showing substantial performance gains compared with state-of-the-art methods.

title: Adaptive Lipschitz Constant Learning for PPG Signal Denoising: A Data-Driven Regularization Approach
authors: Shang-Wei Chao, Feng-Li Lian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Photoplethysmography (PPG) signals are essential for non-invasive cardiovascular monitoring, yet dynamic noise, including motion artifacts, significantly degrades downstream deep learning applications such as arterial blood pressure prediction by inducing latent space discontinuities. This work employs Lipschitz continuity to quantify and constrain these discontinuities, ensuring representation learning stability during denoising. We present an adaptive Lipschitz constant learning framework that dynamically predicts regularization strength through multi-modal feature extraction across temporal, frequency, and physiological domains, with an adaptive loss function promoting effective denoising and representation continuity. Experiments yield an 83.2% mean squared error (MSE) improvement and a 10.08 dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) on synthetic PPG, alongside an MSE of 0.62 and an SNR of 1.94 dB on real MIMIC-III PPG with simulated artifacts. The adaptive framework reduces hyperparameter sensitivity, eliminating grid search needs, and enhances stability, as evidenced by an 80% reduction in noise suppression score ζ within 200 epochs and lower average ζ (∼0.05 versus ∼0.3) compared to fixed methods. Our theoretically grounded solution bridges the gap between signal denoising and representation learning stability, enabling robust and adaptive processing of time-series signals across diverse applications.

title: Practical Methods for Distance-Adaptive Continuous-Variable Quantum Key Distribution
authors: Jonas Berl, Utku Akin, Erdem Eray Cil, Laurent Schmalen, Tobias Fehenberger
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Continuous-variable quantum key distribution (CVQKD) is a promising quantum-safe alternative to classical asymmetric cryptography that enables two authenticated parties to establish a shared secret over a potentially eavesdropped quantum channel. A key step in CV-QKD post-processing is information reconciliation, which leverages forward error correction (FEC) techniques to extract identical bit strings from noisy correlated data. In this work, we analyze the strict limitations on operating distance that are imposed by constant-rate FEC, severely limiting the practicability of CV-QKD systems in deployed optical networks. To overcome the distance limitations, we evaluate three strategies: (i) tuning modulation variance, (ii) adding controlled amounts of trusted detector loss, and (iii) the use of rate-adaptive FEC. All approaches are validated experimentally, compared in terms of performance, and we discuss implementation aspects. Our results show that while methods (i) and (ii) extend the operational distance of constant-rate FEC without the need for additional hardware components, they incur a significant penalty in secret key rate (SKR). In contrast, rate-adaptive FEC enables CV-QKD operation with performance close to the asymptotic SKR over a wide range of distances, provided that the reconciliation efficiency is chosen appropriately.

title: Optical Image-Assisted Zero-Shot Learning for Unknown Target Recognition in SAR Images_supp1-3657908.pdf
authors: Yong Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: Zero-shot learning (ZSL) for unknown target recognition in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images is of great significance as the training samples of certain targets may not be available under real-world scenarios. Existing ZSL algorithms usually integrate SAR images with semantics for unknown target recognition in SAR images. However, for these ZSL algorithms, semantics can only provide very limited information and some semantics may not be helpful compared with optical images. To this end, we develop an optical image-assisted ZSL (OZSL) algorithm, which includes three loss terms. Specifically, the first loss term explores intermodal correlation between SAR images and optical images. Subsequently, the second loss term explores the interview correlation among SAR images. However, combining these two loss terms is still unable to recognize unknown SAR images. Considering this, the third loss term is designed by exploiting additional optical images to assist the above two loss terms. Afterward, these three loss terms are jointly optimized to acquire the optimal solutions of the related variables involved in them by the corresponding optimization algorithms. Finally, according to the Kullback–Leibler divergence, OZSL exploits the optimal solutions to achieve unknown SAR image recognition. The results verify the superiority of OZSL.

title: Integral Reinforcement Learning-Based Tracking Control for Nonlinear Markov Jump Systems With Unknown Dynamics
authors: Wenhai Qi, Yuxin Sun, Guangdeng Zong, Zheng-Guang Wu, Yan Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: In this work, a new tracking control algorithm based on integral reinforcement learning (IRL) is proposed for nonlinear Markov jump systems (MJSs) represented by interval type-2 fuzzy (IT2F) model. The adoption of IT2F approach to describe nonlinear objects can overcome the uncertainty problem of traditional Takagi–Sugeno (T-S) fuzzy model. The control input and external disturbance are considered as two opposing competitors, and the optimal control problem is transformed into a zero-sum game problem. Furthermore, a mode-free IRL algorithm is designed to solve the fuzzy-coupled algebraic Riccati equations without the system dynamics information. The stability and the convergence of new scheme are demonstrated through Lyapunov theory, and the desired tracking goal is achieved. Finally, the designed model-free IRL algorithm is applied to a typical mass-spring-damper mechanical system and the implementation results demonstrate the practicality and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: MDCDNet: A Frequency-Spatial Dual-Domain Collaborative Image Deraining Network
authors: Kunxuan Li, Xiaomin Li, Xinghui Chen
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Existing transformer-based deraining methods typically operate either in the spatial or channel dimensions, with each dimension-specific approach suffering from inherent limitations that hinder optimal rain removal performance. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multi-scale dual-domain collaborative deraining network (MDCDNet), which introduces three key innovations. First, we design a new collaborative feature enhancement module (CFEM) that integrates two complementary components: the frequency-focused enhanced convolution block (FFECB) and the dual-stream sparse interactive transformer block (DSITB). In particular, the FFECB enhances both feature discrimination and global spatial representation by extracting and integrating complementary high- and low-frequency features in the frequency domain. Building on this, DSITB operates in the spatial domain by compressing channels to sparsify the attention map, which introduces a dual-stream structure to recover missing information and leverages an adaptive integration mechanism for effective feature aggregation and enriched multidimensional representation. Second, to facilitate the fusion of deep semantic features with fine-grained texture details, we put forward a multi-scale spatial interaction feature fusion module (MSIFFM). This module progressively refines features across multiple scales and uses spatial interactions to enhance representations in critical regions, which enables precise separation of rain streaks from background textures. Finally, extensive experiments on several benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed MDCDNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods in both quantitative and qualitative evaluations, confirming its superior deraining capability.

title: Vertically-Excited High-Order Guided Shear Vertical Surface Acoustic Wave Resonators for 5G and Beyond
authors: Xiaoli Fang, Jinbo Wu, Pengcheng Zheng, Xinjian Ke, Juxing He, Mijing Sun, Kai Huang, Shibin Zhang, Xin Ou
publish: Journal of Microelectromechanical Systems
abstract: This work reports novel solidly mounted acoustic resonators based on the high-order guided shear vertical surface acoustic wave (SV-SAW) mode. The design utilizes a high-velocity supporting substrate to suppress the leakage of the main mode, while incorporating a bottom electrode to establish a vertical electric field for acoustic wave excitation. Using the finite element method (FEM), structural parameters were optimized to achieve a resonator with large electromechanical coupling coefficient (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${k}_{t}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), low loss, and weak spurious modes simultaneously. The layout and dimensions of the bottom electrode are optimized to minimize bulk acoustic wave leakage. Subsequently, two specifications of resonators based on X-cut LiNbO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sub>/patterned metal/SiO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>/SiC substrate were fabricated via a secondary transfer process of piezoelectric single-crystal film. The fabricated resonators aiming at the C-band exhibit <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${k}_{t}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> ranging from 6% to 16%. Resonators operating at higher frequencies near 9 GHz were also fabricated, achieving <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k_{t}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> value up to 16%. With further optimization, this novel high-order guided SV-SAW resonator will offer a promising filtering solution for 5G New Radio (NR) and future 6G.[2025-0194]

title: Manipulating Static Characteristics of Reverse Blocking IGCTs via Local Lifetime Control
authors: Chunpin Ren, Jiapeng Liu, Su Yan, Zhitao Huang, Xiaoyuan Liu, Xiaozhao Li, Xingchen Wang, Jinpeng Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: The reverse blocking integrated gate-commutated thyristor (RB-IGCT) is a promising candidate for high-power applications due to its low loss and high reliability. However, the nonpunchthrough structure of RB-IGCT leads to a strong tradeoff between reducing leakage current and reducing <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state voltage in its design, limiting further performance optimization. This article proposes a local lifetime control (LLC) strategy to manipulate these two static characteristics of RB-IGCTs. By introducing defects with varying depths and concentrations, the carrier lifetime can be spatially controlled, thereby enabling desired modulation of device characteristics. An optimal defect position near the junction is identified to simultaneously suppress emitter efficiency and base transport factor, achieving a lower leakage current with negligible impact on the <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state voltage. Furthermore, the effect of defect concentration is evaluated using the maximum DC <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state current as the primary metric, revealing a nonmonotonic relationship with a well-defined optimum. Experimental validation through proton irradiation confirms that a fluence of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times 10^{{9}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> cm<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${}^{-{2}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> at <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\sim 5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> MeV achieves a favorable balance between leakage current and <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state voltage.

title: IV Drip and Flow Level Monitoring System
authors: C. Sivamani, Gokulraj P, Balavishnu M, Kesavan S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This project is basically about making IV drip monitoring way smarter and less stressful using IoT tech. This project consist of load cell sensor with an HX711 amplifier that keeps track of the IV bag’s weight to see how much fluid is left, and an infrared (IR) sensor that watches the drip to catch any blockages or if the flow stops. To collect all the received data from the sensor ESP32 microcontroller is used, which triggers the LED light and the buzzers when abnormal changes happen and also sends immediate alerts to a mobile app through the Blynk platform. Through this way, nurses always know when to change the IV bag, avoiding issues like backflow or air getting into the vein and makes the work less for the nurses. It’s low-cost, accurate, super easy to set up, and really helps make patient care safer while making hospital work a lot smoother.

title: A Thermally Insulating Cryogenic Medium-Frequency Transformer for use in a Cryogenic GaN Dual Active Bridge
authors: Frank S.R., Ehrlich L., Schwendemann R., Hiller M.
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: A key challenge in cryogenic applications is managing heat input from the warmer environment. This paper presents a novel Medium-Frequency Transformer (MFT) concept designed for converter integration as a thermal insulator at cryogenic temperatures. First, the basic idea of the thermally insulating transformer is outlined, followed by electromagnetic dimensioning and thermal design considerations. Detailed simulations illustrate the effects of critical design parameters on thermal and electromagnetic performance. Based on these insights, a prototype MFT is developed and integrated into a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 ~\text{kW} / 100 \text{kHz}$</tex> Dual Active Bridge (DAB) converter topology. Measurement results validate the functionality of the developed MFT in conjunction with the DAB, demonstrating its potential for efficient thermal management in cryogenic environments.

title: A Lightweight and Scalable Blockchain Authentication Scheme for IoT Mesh Environments
authors: G.Banupriya, P.Logeswari
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) mesh networks has raised concerns about data integrity, device authenticity, and scalability of systems, especially in a resource-constrained environment. Centralised authentication techniques, such as the mechanisms used on the Web, do not work with IoT due to issues of latency, single points of failure, and computational overhead. In this research, a Blockchain-Based Lightweight Authentication (BLA) framework is presented for decentralised, secure, and low-latency identification and authentication of IoT devices working in mesh networks. The BLA framework incorporates a permission blockchain approach for managing device identity (device ID) and utilises Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) for mutual authentication in a lightweight approach. To minimise the computational and communication overhead, the design incorporates an HSS scheme (for signature generation and verification of the device ID) and a Merkle tree approach for efficient verification, and a consensus protocol that is lightweight and protocol-agnostic, which supports decentralised trust and mitigates pre-image attacks and common attacks targeting networks. Experimental evaluations conducted on both simulated and real-world new IoT mesh environments confirm the hypothesis that the BLA framework offered a reduction of authentication latency of 45% and a reduction in energy consumption of 35% against traditional techniques. The BLA framework has enhanced security by giving improved mitigation to spoofing, Sybil and replay attacks. The security of identity management in IoT Mesh Networks is practiced and scaled by blockchain-based lightweight cryptography protocols. The described BLA framework may be utilized as a guideline, in the process of implementing a secure system of decentralized IoT, which can be designed around a low-resource framework.

title: Smart Waste Management: A CNN-based Approach for Automated Plastic and Material Classification
authors: Bathina Vishnu, D.Tanuj, G. Saranya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Segregation of waste is a vital issue encountered by most nations, necessitating efficient and automated solutions for effective recycling. Manual techniques are labour-intensive and time-consuming. The current project proposes an AI-based system for plastic waste classification based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). The system uses image processing methods to automate waste classification into types like plastic, paper, iron, and others. By using machine learning, real-time classification, and an optimized model, the system guarantees efficient and precise waste identification. An interface allows users to upload photos for immediate classification. The novelty of this process is the use of CNN for image-based waste classification, combined with an optimized dataset and real-time processing. The system enhances automation in handling waste, supporting ecofriendly methods by less dependency on manual sorting. Its more efficient model gives 91% accuracy, increases speed, and provides safe data handling, thus further supporting its practical use in the real world.

title: Evolutionary Computing-Driven Evapotranspiration Modeling for Precision Irrigation Scheduling
authors: Pakala Venuteja, Dhiyaaram S, Akkina Aateesh, Pandiri Bhaskar Praneeth, Jeyakumar G
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The Agricultural water management depends on evapotranspiration (ET), which is critical to the sustainability and effectiveness of irrigation. The slowness and imprecision of traditional ET estimating procedures hamper effective decision-making. To solve this, the study presented in this paper builds a highly flexible prediction model that considers different varieties and weather patterns using Evolutionary Computing (EC) and Machine Learning (ML) algorithms. To increase the prediction accuracy and to optimize computing efficiency, the proposed model combines sophisticated ML frameworks with EC algorithms. Long training times, overfitting, and high computing costs are still problems, though. In agricultural settings, efficient water management is still essential since traditional irrigation schedule inefficiencies can result in crop damage or water waste. To address these problems, this paper also suggests a simplified approach to data integration and modeling, which guarantees improved ET forecasting performance, increased accuracy, and flexibility.

title: ML – Powered Malware Traffic Detector
authors: N. Jothi, C.C.S Navin Neta, P. Sahithya, K. Susithra
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The drastic increase in sophisticated cyberattacks explains why traditional network defense systems are commonly incapable of detecting advanced and evolving malware present in network traffic. This paper proposes an ML-Powered Malware Traffic Detector, a lightweight web-based architecture to classify malicious network behaviors through a machine learning technique. The proposed model extracts flow-based features from PCAP files with a tool called CICFlowMeter and pre-processes the flow files into clean structured datasets. A Random Forest Classifier is trained on the CICIDS 2017 dataset with malicious traffic flow patterns incorporated into the model. The trained model is serialized with Pickle and integrated into a Flask web-based interface to provide real-time traffic detection upon user-uploaded PCAP files. Testing results illustrate that the proposed model achieves high detection accuracy, as well as high reliability, when detecting malware traffic. The proposed framework will provide a foundation toward intelligent network monitoring, and can eventually be extended toward real-time intrusion detection systems and adaptive cybersecurity frameworks.

title: YOLOv5-based Intelligent Traffic Control for Density and Emergencies
authors: Raffi A, Yogesh R, Murugan Krishnamoorthy
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Rapidly increasing population growth and higher vehicular density increasingly worsen urban traffic congestion, posing a challenge to effective traffic management. In this paper, an intelligent traffic management system that combines a computer vision-based object detection with deep learning-based traffic optimization is proposed to maximize real-time traffic flow. Object detection is carried out with a YOLOv5-based object detection algorithm to detect vehicles in lanes at intersections and offer lane-based traffic density estimates. On the basis of these estimates, green signal allocation is optimized to allow congested lanes to be served first with an overall increase in traffic volume. Moreover, to tackle unusual traffic trends and emergency vehicles, such as ambulances, detection is also carried out to facilitate real-time action with adaptable signal control and right of way. Experimental results validate that proposed solution mitigates peak hour congestion, increases vehicular movements, and enables faster clearance for emergency vehicles compared with standard preprogrammed-time traffic signals. These results indicate that incorporating AI-based vehicle detection with adaptable traffic management can remarkably benefit urban mobility and traffic safety.

title: Sentiment Analysis of IMDB Movie Reviews using LSTM and BERT
authors: E. Prabhakar, M. Kavin, S. Kishore, M. Sanjith, V. Swetha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This study basically checks out the emotions in IMDb movie reviews. It pulls in deep learning models to figure out if opinions lean positive or negative. The IMDb dataset works pretty well as a starting point for testing model performance. You know, it’s a huge collection of labelled reviews already. LSTM networks handle the sequence of words in the text. They catch those contextual patterns along the way too. BERT brings in attention mechanisms. That lets it pick up on deeper sentence meanings. Both get trained and tested on the same dataset. Keeps the comparison straightforward and fair. The whole setup handles predictions in real time. It displays results via a basic Stream lit app. Comparing them points out strengths and weaknesses, especially with those context-heavy reviews that trip things up. BERT usually nails higher accuracy. Still, LSTM does solid work on the sequence side of things. Pairing deep learning with visuals like this opens up practical spots in customer feedback or breaking down reviews. Overall, the project puts together a scalable system for sentiment analysis. It’s pretty effective for real-world decision making.

title: AI-Powered Real-Time Road Condition Monitoring System and Alert System
authors: Joe Pushparaj J, Martin Victor K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: With the fast development process of urbanization and traffic, road infrastructure deterioration problem has been exacerbated, and the real-time monitoring of road conditions has become an important component of intelligent transportation systems (ITS). Conventional inspection methods are labor intensive, time poor and subject to human error. This paper describes a real-time road condition monitoring and warning system that uses AI-based deep learning-based object detection methods for automatic detection of potholes. The proposed work has taken an ensemble of two state-of-the-art object detection models, namely, YOLOv5 and YOLOv8 which has been trained on a curated repository of road surface images. Streamlit-based front end and backend inferencing and visualization and effective location-based alert mechanism are implemented to eventually supply on-time alerts to the concerned authorities. Quantitative evaluations show that YOLOv8 has a better performance with accuracy 93%, recall 0.92, and detection performance is improved with mAP 0.92 which is greater than YOLOv5 with both inference time and detection robustness. Our system is containerized and hence scalable across smart city outsized infrastructures with functionalities for proactive maintenance and optimization of road safety. In this regard, the proposed work represents a realistic, low latency, and deployable solution to sustainable monitoring of urban transport.

title: Artificial Intelligence-Enhanced Adaptive Taylor Series Methods for Robust and Tunable Numerical Integration and Differentiation
authors: Eppili Jaya, B.Rama Rao, K S Chakradhar, Pendyala V Muralidhar, S Sridhar, D.Nataraj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Fractional mathematical techniques, which have been studied and used for over three centuries, are crucial for accurate and trustworthy technological modelling. Specifically, fractional integrators and differentiators have evolved into effective methods with a broad range of uses in domains like control engineering, robotics, mechatronics, biomedical systems, and signal processing. In many real-world situations, they outperform conventional integer-order models due to their capacity to capture memory and the inherited properties of processes. However, approximation errors and stability problems frequently make it difficult to put these operations into practice. We examine the literature on fractional differentiators and integrators in this paper, emphasizing their significance, mathematical underpinnings, and constraints. theoretically sound foundation for increasing precision. Approximate techniques based on Taylor series expansions are used to solve the accuracy problem, offering a computationally effective and theoretically sound foundation for increasing precision. By introducing suitable assumptions, the Taylor series approach allows for the derivation of more accurate discrete-time models for fractional-order systems. A systematic approach to mathematical modelling that increases the reliability of fractional operators in practical situations is also described in the study. Apart from enhancing existing approximation methods, the proposed approach lays the groundwork for more intricate applications in signal filtering, adaptive systems, and real-time implementation.

title: Time-Responsive Deep Learning for Multimodal Survival Prediction in ATRT
authors: Nadenlla RajamohanReddy, G Muneeswari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Atypical Teratoid Rhabdoid Tumor (ATRT) is an uncommon yet highly malignant pediatric brain tumor, noted for its molecular complexity and poor patient prognosis. Personalized treatment strategies hinge on accurate survival prediction models. In this work, we introduce PrognosticATRT, an innovative machine learning framework designed to unify tumor subtype classification with survival prediction that accounts for temporal dynamics. The framework incorporates multimodal data sources including MRI scans, clinical variables, and histopathological inputs and applies advanced deep learning models. Specifically, Vision Transformers are utilized for detailed subtype classification, while time-dependent survival analysis is conducted using a combination of Cox Proportional Hazards models, DeepSurv, and attention-based LSTM networks to capture both longitudinal and static risk factors. Our multi-task learning architecture improves overall predictive performance, yielding a classification AUC of 0.94 and a survival prediction concordance index (C-index) of 0.82, outperforming conventional approaches. Kaplan-Meier analysis, based on risk stratification from the model, reveals a statistically significant difference in survival outcomes between the high- and low-risk groups predicted (p < 0.01), emphasizing its clinical relevance. Strategies such as data augmentation and transfer learning are implemented to address the challenges of limited and imbalanced datasets, improving generalizability. Furthermore, interpretability is achieved using SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations), allowing for the identification of influential clinical and imaging characteristics in survival prediction. This transparency supports informed decision-making by healthcare professionals. PrognosticATRT represents a significant advancement in ATRT outcome modeling, offering a pathway toward more tailored and effective treatment planning in pediatric neuro oncology.

title: Deepfake Detection in the Era of AI: Insights into Detection Performance and Model Interpretability
authors: Sreeraj K, B.Arun Kumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Deepfakes are artificially generated media that manipulate visual and auditory content to create highly realistic but fabricated images and videos. With rapid advances in generative technologies, deepfakes have become increasingly convincing, posing severe threats such as misinformation, identity theft, political manipulation, and cybersecurity risks. Early and accurate detection is therefore essential to preserve the authenticity of digital content and public trust. Traditional detection methods relying on handcrafted features and classical machine learning (ML) techniques have shown limited generalization across datasets and poor adaptability to evolving manipulation methods. This study presents a comprehensive overview of recent advances in deepfake detection using ML, deep learning (DL), and hybrid frameworks. It critically analyzes the strengths and limitations of existing approaches while addressing challenges such as computational cost, dataset bias, adversarial vulnerability, and lack of interpretability. The paper emphasizes the need for frameworks that balance accuracy, scalability, and transparency while enhancing robustness against emerging threats. By integrating key findings and identifying research gaps, this study contributes to the development of efficient and trustworthy deepfake detection strategies.

title: AI Powered Autonomous Network Security
authors: V.V.A.S. Lakshmi, Udumula Venkata Muneeswar Reddy, Manu Hajari, Bogyam Jagadeesh, Kotu Siva Sankar Reddy, Sujana Oggu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This project introduces an autonomous network security system that leverages artificial intelligence to detect and respond to a wide range of cyber threats without human intervention. The system combines both supervised learning, using algorithms like Random Forest, and unsupervised methods such as autoencoders, to effectively identify known attacks and uncover anomalous behavior that may indicate zero day threats. By integrating realtime traffic analysis with intelligent feature extraction, the system is capable of adapting to dynamic network environments. The use of explainable AI techniques enhances transparency by allowing security network datasets demonstrate high detection accuracy, low false positive rates, and effective handling of polymorphic and stealthy attacks. Additionally, the system includes modules for threat categorization, visual reporting, and tamperproof logging to support forensic investigation. Designed with scalability and performance in mind, this AI powered framework is suitable for deployment in enterprise networks, critical infrastructure, and cloud based systems. The results suggest that combining automation with intelligent detection techniques can significantly strengthen modern cybersecurity defenses. Future work will focus on incorporating adaptive response mechanisms and distributed learning to further improve the system’s resilience and autonomy.

title: Adaptive and Explainable Deep Learning for Automated Retinal Disease Diagnosis Using OCT Images
authors: Finny V Jacob, Gethsia P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Early and accurate detection of retinal diseases is critical for preventing vision loss and enabling timely treatment. This study presents a novel automated and explainable framework for detecting retinal abnormalities—including Choroidal Neovascularization (CNV), Diabetic Macular Edema (DME), Drusen, and Normal cases—from Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) images. To address challenges such as intensity variations, speckle noise, and class imbalance, the framework incorporates Adaptive Illumination Normalization (AIN) to enhance local contrast and Elastic Deformation with Adversarial Perturbation (EDAP) for robust data augmentation. Feature extraction is performed using a Multi-Scale Residual Attention CNN (MSRA-CNN), which captures fine-to-coarse pathological patterns while emphasizing disease-relevant regions. For interpretability, Hierarchical Grad-CAM++ with Uncertainty Weighting (HGCUW) produces clinically meaningful heatmaps, highlighting structures such as subretinal fluid and drusen. Experiments on the Kermany OCT dataset demonstrate a classification accuracy of 92.2%, surpassing baseline models. Quantitative evaluation and inter-observer analysis indicate strong agreement with ophthalmologists, confirming the clinical relevance of the explainable outputs. The proposed framework provides a robust, end-to-end solution combining high diagnostic performance with trustworthy visual explanations to support informed clinical decision-making in ophthalmology.

title: Privacy-Preserving Donor Matching for Bone Marrow Transplant
authors: P. Mathivanan, M. Gopika, M. Praveen Raja, V. Rubana, P. Sivaneshwari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Accurate matching between donors and recipients via Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) profiling is necessary for bone marrow transplantation. Large-scale participation is, however, limited by significant issues with traditional donor registries, including inefficiency, lack of interoperability, and privacy concerns. In order to prevent hospitals from exchanging sensitive genomic data, this study suggests a donor match- ing framework that protects privacy by combining Federated Learning (FL) with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for HLA data classification. To improve compatibility prediction, the system uses multi-metric similarity scoring with the Cosine, Euclidean, and Siamese algorithms. Using Differential Privacy (DP-SGD) and Secure Aggregation, the experimental evaluation shows a 93.4% matching accuracy, a 15% improvement in donor ranking precision, and full compliance with data privacy standards.Faster donor identification, increased trust between healthcare organizations, and the creation of safe, AI-powered medical systems for life-saving bone marrow transplants are all benefits of the suggested solution.

title: Operational Analysis and Control of a Multi-Port Solid-State Transformer with Integrated Batteries
authors: Zhen Huang, Thomas Langbauer, Marcus Vieira Soares, Wajahat Khan, Roberto Petrella, Michael Hartmann
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The modular multilevel type multi-port solid-state transformer (SST), is a promising topology to connect and control the bidirectional power flow among the MVAC grid, the MVDC grid, and LVDC bus simultaneously and with full degree of flexibility. Identical monolithic isolated DC-DC converters containing medium-frequency transformers are thereto embedded in the submodules to provide voltage conversion and galvanic isolation between medium-voltage and low-voltage sides. This work introduces a medium-voltage battery energy storage variant with battery packs directly integrated into each cell of the system. The basic operating principle and system control is discussed based on an analytical average model. And performance of the approach is demonstrated by simulations. Special focus is put on energy balancing control between the MMC cells, where leg circulating currents of the MMC are used. Finally, the converter operation, proposed energy balancing methods and control approaches are validated by simulation of the average model of a 3 MVA, 4kV MVAC, 8kV MVDC and 1500V LVDC system.

title: AI-Powered Video Summarizer And Knowledge Assistant
authors: Megala R, Narayani S, Srinidhi P S, Yalini S, Dhanushpriyan S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This study introduces an AI-powered video summarization and retrieval system specifically designed for the education industry. The system uses multimodal analysis—contextual analysis, visual detection, and audio transcription—to produce rich and accurate summaries. Learners are provided with raw outputs (transcripts) and the abridged versions (audio highlights, text notes, and summarized video clips). A keyword search module with timestamp synchronization enables learners to easily retrieve particular segments of a lecture, saving time on lengthy recordings. In addition to supporting learning further, a chatbot tutor is also incorporated in conversational form, providing lecture-related question answers, suggesting key topics, and linking students to external learning resources. The system is made efficient with low computational complexity and high upload/download speeds, making real-world deployment a possibility. Through enhancing accessibility and tailored study, the research helps achieve SDG 4 (Quality Education) and by facilitating improved AI-driven video analysis, it helps achieve SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure).

title: Efficient Sensor Utilization and Advanced Elastogram Image Generation Methods in Ultrasound Imaging
authors: Sai Konda, Hicham Chaoui
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Ultrasound is an important imaging technique mainly due to its non-intrusive nature. Due to high frame frequency in plane wave ultrasound imaging, a large number of raw data frames are being generated within a few seconds. In this technique, all transducer sensors are being used for imaging purposes. As a result, the amount of channel data acquired is large. Because of which, saving this data and transmitting it from ultrasonic system to processing computer is presenting a significant problem. To address this large data volume problem, we proposed the design of a novel transducer and implemented it. The proposed transducer is equipped with switching networks, which help in generating a minimized version of raw data in the front-end ultrasonic system, followed by reconstructing that missing channel data using Fourier and Inverse Fourier transforms inside the computer block. Next, in order to further reduce the amount of channel data capturing, sampling rate of that transducer was reduced. While the prior lowered the size of raw data by 50%, the latter reduced it by 75%. Note that the data transfer efficiency has also increased by same amounts, when compared to full data. These savings come with a slight increase in computer’s processing time, presented as software run time. Inside the computer block, beamformed, displacement and elastogram images are generated after Fourier based data reconstruction. Lastly, we focused on elastogram imaging and generated better quality elastographic images when compared to existing method, by means of quantization and colormap adjustment. While the soft and hard structures are clearly distinguishable in all our elastogram images, this is difficult in images generated using ground truth.

title: FedHRA: A Joint Optimization Framework for Fast Convergent Decentralized Federated Learning in LEO Satellite Networks
authors: Xiaomin Chen, Tao Meng, Zejun Li, Qiang Sun, Dong Li, Chunxiao Jiang, Bo Ai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites are playing an important role in earth observation, providing valuable images for training machine learning (ML) models used in tasks such as environmental monitoring and pattern recognition. However, due to unstable communication links and limited downlink bandwidth, it is economically impractical to transmit all raw images to ground stations (GSs) for model training. Federated learning (FL), a privacy-preserving distributed machine learning method, can reduce the communication overhead by exchanging model parameters. Generally, FL needs a fixed central server to aggregate the global model, which is challenging in LEO satellite networks, given the dynamic nature of satellite orbits. To overcome this, we propose a decentralized federated learning (DFL) framework that enables efficient model aggregation through satellite collaboration. Specifically, the proposed framework, named FedHRA, is based on model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML), which jointly optimizes hyperparameters and resource allocation to mitigate straggler effect and address statistical heterogeneity. Extensive numerical results on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets demonstrate that FedHRA achieves shorter learning time and higher model accuracy compared to the benchmark frameworks.

title: Phase Robustness Analysis for Structured Perturbations in MIMO LTI Systems
authors: Luke Woolcock, Robert Schmid
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: The stability of interconnected linear time-invariant systems using singular values and the small gain theorem has been studied for many decades. The methods of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>-analysis and synthesis have been extensively developed to provide robustness guarantees for a plant subject to structured perturbations, with components in the structured perturbation satisfying a bound on their largest singular value. Recent results on phase-based stability measures have led to a counterpart of the small gain theorem, known as the small phase theorem. To date these phase-based methods have only been used to provide stability robustness measures for unstructured perturbations. In this paper, we define a phase robustness metric for multivariable linear time-invariant systems in the presence of a structured perturbation. We demonstrate its relationship to a certain class of multiplier functions for integral quadratic constraints, and show that an upper bound can be calculated via a linear matrix inequality problem. When combined with robustness measures from the small gain theorem, the new methods are able to provide less conservative robustness metrics than can be obtained via conventional <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>-analysis methods.
