title: Effects of low-intensity transcranial ultrasound stimulation on cortical functional network connections and epileptic seizures in a mouse model of epilepsy
authors: Na Pang, Qianqian Wang, Hailin Zhang, Rui Su, Jiaqing Yan, Yi Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Exploration of the epilepsy cortical network is helpful for understanding the pathophysiological mechanisms of epilepsy and optimizing the treatment direction of epilepsy. Low-intensity transcranial ultrasound stimulation (TUS), characterized by non-invasiveness, high penetration depth, and high spatial resolution, has the potential to modulate brain functional networks. Nevertheless, the specific mechanisms by which TUS influences the cortical network in awake epilepsy model mice remain inadequately understood. Here, we observed that TUS significantly decreased the power of the whole cerebral cortex, diminished the phase lag index functional connectivity strength of the whole cerebral cortex, reduced the strength of cortical network connections, and accelerated the transition process from the epileptic seizure state to the normal state. Taken together, these findings indicated that epileptic seizures were suppressed after TUS modulated cortical functional network connections in mice.

title: Measurement and Analysis of Multistate Ferroelectric Transistors in 28 nm CMOS Process
authors: Sayma Nowshin Chowdhury, Alex L. Mazzoni, Xiaohang Zhang, Andreu L. Glasmann, Halid Mulaosmanovic, Stefan Dünkel, Gunda Beernink, Sven Beyer, Sina Najmaei, Sahil Shah
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: Ferroelectric field-effect transistors (FeFETs) are strong candidates for synaptic devices in neuromorphic and in-memory computing due to their multi-level programmability, non-volatility, and complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) compatibility. In this work, we experimentally demonstrate multi-bit operation of FeFET synapses integrated on GlobalFoundries’ 28nm CMOS process. Specifically, the work uses an incremental pulsing scheme, showing stable access to intermediate polarization states and long-term retention. We further examine the role of device size, read-out gate voltage, and array topology as fundamental design trade-offs, showing that larger-area FeFETs provide more deterministic state programming, while smaller devices favor integration density. Finally, we compare 1-FeFET and nT–1FeFET array architectures with static random-access memory (SRAM), outlining the density, selection, and scalability implications of each. These findings provide both device-level insights and circuit-architecture considerations, guiding the co-design of FeFET-based synaptic arrays for future neuromorphic accelerators.

title: SMA-EL:a Minimal 1-cycle Construction Algorithm with Simplicial Maps Annotation and Edge Loss for Emotional Brain Networks Analysis_supp1-3664093.pdf
authors: Bin Hu
publish: N/A
abstract: The brain patterns of emotional perception remain a pivotal research domain in affective neuroscience. Modeling the brain as a complex network has become a crucial approach to understanding its functions. However, traditional brain network research based on graph theory primarily focuses on dyadic interactions between brain regions, which cannot effectively characterize the information exchange process among multiple brain regions during emotional cognitive processes. To address these limitations, we shift our perspective from graph theory to the topological data analysis (TDA) of minimal 1-cycles. The 1 cycles or loops within a network represent the fundamental high order interactions in complex networks and serve as essential pathways for information transmission and integration among the distributed networks of brain regions. By focusing on cycle structures in affective brain networks, we propose a novel SMA-EL method based on the collaborative optimization of the Minimal 1-Cycle with Simplicial Maps Annotation (SMA-M1C) method and linear programming, which balances computational efficiency and method performance to reconstruct the optimal cycles in the brain network. This method is applied to the analysis of emotional brain networks in response to positive and negative emotions induced by naturalistic viewing. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that the 1-cycle structures of the brain's functional patterns exhibit differences at both individual and group levels, aligning with prior research. Furthermore, the 1 cycles we proposed can serve as a biological marker for emotion recognition. These findings may provide new insights into the organization patterns of functional brain networks under diverse emotional states.

title: Stabilizing Multi-Task Latent Spaces: Recursive Refinement with Coordinators in Partially Labeled Learning
authors: Wooseong Jeong, Jegyeong Cho, Youngho Yoon, Jaeyoung Lee, Kuk-Jin Yoon
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Multi-Task Learning (MTL) is a widely used paradigm that enhances generalization by training multiple tasks simultaneously. However, it requires large datasets where each sample must have labels for all tasks, making it costly and impractical. Partially labeled MTL alleviates this issue by enabling models to learn from data with sparse task labels. A key challenge in this setting is the instability from partial supervision, which misaligns task representations and degrades learning, yet remains largely overlooked in existing works. To address this, we propose Recursive Multi-Task Latent Refinement with Coordinators (RLRC), a framework designed to mitigate instability in partially labeled MTL. RLRC introduces coordinators, learnable projections that refine the shared multi-task latent space by dynamically adjusting task representations to reduce the impact of partial supervision. By stabilizing the latent space through recursive refinement, RLRC enhances learning efficiency and achieves strong performance in partially labeled settings.

title: Discontinuous Space Vector Modulation Strategy for Three-Phase Series-End Winding PMSM
authors: Yuming Yi, Hui Yang, Chenggang Wang, Z. Q. Zhu, Heyun Lin, Feng Yu, Shuilian Xue, Feng Xie, Wei Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: The concept of multiplexing power legs makes series-end winding permanent magnet synchronous machines (SEW-PMSMs) has the merits of high DC-link voltage utilization, low volume, and high efficiency. However, the increased leg current of multiplexing power legs inevitably leads to high power loss of converter. Besides, the multiplexing power legs also have large weight in the common-mode voltage from machine sides, which leads to large amplitude and dv/dt stress of common-mode voltage, compared with non-multiplexing ones. Therefore, although multiplexing power legs bring apparent superiorities to SEW-PMSM, they lead to several impairments as well. Consequently, an optimized discontinuous space vector modulation (ODSVM) strategy is proposed in this paper, where the switching action reduction focuses on the multiplexing power legs to reduce the power loss and amplitude of common-mode voltage caused by the above legs. Moreover, a spatial near state SVM (NSSVM) scheme is proposed to reduce the common-mode voltage from converter/machine sides. Two proposed DSVM strategies are verified and compared with traditional continuous SVM (CSVM) and three existing DSVM methods by experimental results. The effective common-mode voltage and/or power loss reduction are verified experimentally in the proposed DSVM strategies.

title: Edge Harmony Attention Network for Semi-Supervised Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Manti Lu, Yang Liu, Yunzhu Chen, Feng Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In the Medical field, image segmentation plays a crucial role in the identification and quantification of lesions, tumors, and other abnormal structures. However, obtaining a substantial quantity of well-annotated, high-quality images remains a significant challenge due to the high cost and labor-intensive nature of annotation. To address this issue, some studies have attempted to augment datasets by generating synthetic images, but discontinuities at the boundaries of synthetic images can negatively impact segmentation accuracy. In this work, we propose the Edge Harmony Attention Network (EHA-Net), a novel semi-supervised model for medical image segmentation. The proposed model incorporates an Edge Harmonization Module that mitigates the edge artifacts commonly associated with copy-paste augmentation techniques, ensuring smooth and natural transitions along image boundaries, thereby improving segmentation accuracy. Additionally, we introduce a Foreground Attention Module to enhance feature alignment between the foreground and background, promoting spatial consistency and focusing on coherent image details. Experimental results demonstrate that EHA-Net significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art semi-supervised approaches across four publicly available medical imaging datasets. The code is accessible on GitHub at https://github. com/Manty1998/EHA Net.

title: Multimodal Fusion-Based Channel Prediction and Characterization for mmWave UAV A2G Communications
authors: Zhichao Xin, Yu Liu, Jianping Xing, Jie Huang, Ji Bian, Zongkai Bai, Chuanteng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: A channel prediction modeling method based on multimodal fusion perception is proposed for complex environments in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) air-to-ground (A2G) communications. Two-dimensional (2D) environmental information and three-dimensional (3D) point cloud data are fused to enhance the model’s ability to capture environment blockage, reflection, and multipath effects. The 2D information provides target objects’ planar distribution and texture features, while the 3D point clouds supplement spatial position, size, and height information. These complementary modalities comprehensively describe the geometric structures present in complex environments. A multimodal modeling network is constructed to explore the nonlinear mapping between environmental perception data and channel data. The network takes 2D building distribution, 3D point cloud data, global image features, UAV and receiver positions, and communication parameters as joint inputs. Feature extraction and fusion modules achieve effective joint encoding of heterogeneous multimodal features. A spatial feature decoupling (SFD) module is designed to address interference caused by coupled features. It separates the data distributions corresponding to different channel characteristics, improving the accuracy of channel impulse response (CIR) prediction. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves the reliability and adaptability of UAV channel modeling in complex urban scenarios.

title: Secure Mobile Edge Generation (MEG): Privacy Preservation in the Presence of Eavesdroppers
authors: Bingqing Wang, Xiaoxia Xu, Man Ouyang, Jiang Liu, Yuanwei Liu
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: Mobile edge generation (MEG) enables low-latency AI-generated content (AIGC) by decentralizing large generative AI (GAI) models across the edge server (ES) and user equipment (UE). However, the distributed collaborative generation raises significant privacy concerns under potential communication eavesdropping. To address this issue, a novel secure MEG framework is proposed for image generation, which integrates a customized privacy-aware encoder-decoder module into the decentralized GAI architecture. Then, latent diffusion features can be securely transmitted from the ES to the UE via joint source-channel coding (JSCC), which supports cost-efficient and privacy-preserving ES-UE collaboration. To assess privacy leakage, a new metric termed privacy-preserving structural similarity (PP-SSIM) is introduced. The proposed modules are jointly trained in an end-to-end manner to optimize both reconstruction fidelity and privacy preservation. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves low-latency and secure image generation for legitimate users, while effectively mitigating information leakage to eavesdroppers. Despite a slight degradation in visual quality, the perceptual fidelity is well preserved.

title: Towards More Adaptive Fusion: Sample- and Region-Aware Dynamic Fusion Network for full-and missing-modalities Land Cover Classification
authors: Haodi Zhang, Kuiliang Gao, Yongqi Sun, Xuefeng Cao, Wenyue Guo, Weiqi Lian, Anzhu Yu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In recent years, research on land cover classification (LCC) utilizing optical (OPT) and synthetic aperture radar (SAR) images under full- and missing-modalities scenarios has garnered considerable attention. Nevertheless, existing methods face challenges in sufficiently fusing multimodal features and re constructing missing-modality features. Specifically, conventional fusion methods typically utilize fixed, uniform, and inflexible strategies across all sample pairs, thereby lacking the capacity to select the most targeted fusion method for distinct pairs. Furthermore, these methods rely unconditionally on generated features without considering variations in generation quality across different regions. To address these limitations, this pa per proposes the Sample- and Region-Aware Dynamic Fusion Network (SRDFNet), an architecture that enables more adaptive fusion of features at both the sample and region levels. First, the Multi-Expert Adaptive Fusion (MAF) module is proposed, where each expert functions as an independent fusion unit, allowing dynamic activation of expert combinations tailored to individual sample pairs and thus facilitating adaptive feature fusion at the sample level. Second, the Confidence-based Adaptive Feature Generation (CAFG) module is proposed, which simultaneously produces confidence maps during feature generation to evaluate the reliability of generated features across regions, thereby enabling their refinement. Ultimately, a fusion mechanism in tegrates the refined features with regular modality features, enabling adaptive fusion at the region level. Experiments on the WHU-OPT-SAR and DFC2020 datasets demonstrate that SRDFNet achieves an improvement of 2.30% to 2.90% in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) under full-modality scenarios, and an enhancement of 0.90% to 3.30% in scenarios with missing-modality. These results substantiate the robustness and effectiveness of the SRDFNet.

title: Multi-Class Intracranial Haemorrhage Detection using Attention-Enhanced Deep Learning Models
authors: Sabnekar Asha Jyothi, Nalini N J
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This paper is an examination of deep learning models, U-Net, and CNN, used in the detection and segmentation of intracranial hemorrhage (ICH) in CT scan imagery. The study capitalizes more on image preprocessing, augmentation, and multi-class segmentation to improve the performance of the model. The proposed study enhances the diagnostic efficacy and helps medical workers find and localize hemorrhage in brain scans as it compares the performance of the U-Net encoder-decoder structure with that of a simpler CNN to help diagnose and improve patient care due to the early intervention.

title: Hybrid Battery Balancing Utilizing Temperature Control for Second Life Batteries
authors: Alvin Huynh, Chandan Chetri, Sheldon Williamson
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a dual-stage hybrid battery balancing control strategy designed for lithium-ion battery packs in electric vehicles (EVs). The proposed system integrates thermal management to minimize temperature rise while ensuring effective voltage balancing. An intelligent control algorithm dynamically adjusts the balancing currents in real time based on individual cell voltage and temperature, promoting battery longevity. The control architecture combines active cell-to-pack (C2P) balancing which is engaged during significant state-of-charge (SOC) imbalances along with passive balancing for finer adjustments, simultaneously operating within the safe voltage and thermal limits. This system is intended to complement existing Battery Management Systems (BMS), significantly accelerating the balancing process in second-life applications.

title: Accuracy Analysis of the Fundamental Harmonic Approximation for LLC Resonant Converters
authors: Juan Glicerio Manlapaz, Arvin Escultero, Carl Michael Odulio
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Recent trends in DC-DC power conversion trend towards <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L L C$</tex> resonant converters as such topologies offer benefits such as high efficiency, wide operating region via frequency control, and high frequency operation resulting in higher power densities. In addition to these benefits, the analysis of this topology is made relatively simple using fundamental harmonic approximation (FHA) which assumes that the fundamental harmonic solely contributes to the power transfer and practically eliminating all smaller harmonics, allowing for elementary circuit analysis to describe quantities such as voltage gain. However, the introduction of other complexities to the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L L C$</tex> resonant converter affects the accuracy of its frequency response. This paper aims to examine the accuracy of FHA in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L L C$</tex> resonant converters and the results from the simulations show that the inductor ratio, characteristic impedance, and loading conditions in the form of quality factor affect the accuracy of FHA.

title: Progress Analysis of Yoga Pose Detection using Media Pipe for Old Age People and Gout People
authors: Indhuja E, Y Jagan Mohan Reddy, Md Firdose Jaha, P.Goutham P. Goutham, Hari Preetham
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The difficulties in body flexibility and movement are a common problem among elderly people during the aging process. Aging, combined with certain health conditions such as gout, creates a lot of pain and swelling in body joints, such as toes and fingers. It is really challenging for them to practice yoga safely, although yoga improves mobility and reduces discomfort. Based on this, a system will be developed using computer vision to detect and analyze the yoga postures of elderly people suffering from gout in real time and give feedback regarding safety and correctness. This framework proposes a system that uses the MediaPipe framework for accurate identification of key body joints and analyzes postures based on standard yoga poses. The methodology involves pose estimation, real-time error detection, and feedback generation in order to guide the users towards proper alignment. It also tracks user progress with time to gauge improvements in flexibility and posture accuracy. Key results show that the model performs very well in detecting joints and giving feedback, enhancing the safety of yoga exercises. It is a huge step toward integrating artificial intelligence with healthcare to support personalized, safe physical wellness for the elderly.

title: SCNN-PKO: A Deep Learning Framework for Accurate Bone Marrow Cancer Detection using Spherical CNNs and Pied Kingfisher Optimization
authors: Cuddapah Anitha, Anitha S Sastry, Divya Sugathan, Vijay Jagdish Upadhye, Harishchander Anandaram, S. SriRagavi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Bone marrow malignancies—including variants of leukemia, lymphoma, and myeloma—compromise normal hematopoietic lineage production and can incur life-threatening consequences if diagnosis is deferred. Traditional interpretation relies on expert hematopathologist review of stained aspirate smears, an approach that is inherently slow, subject to inter- and intra-observer heterogeneity, and habitually restricted by sample complexity. This work presents SCNN-PKO, a composite machine learning architecture that synergizes Spherical Convolutional Neural Networks with a novel optimization paradigm—Pied Kingfisher Optimizer— engineered to afford precise, automated recognition of blood malignancy from marrow particulates. Within SCNN-PKO, a comprehensive preprocessing pipeline maximizes optical definition on low-resolution acquisitions; a segmentation head carefully delineates regions exhibiting atypical morphology; and a scale-adaptive feature extraction block fortifies invertible invariance to variation in spatial or rotational resolution. The spherical convolutions in the core SCNN are specifically formulated to exploit the anisotropic metric physiology of nuclei and cytoplasm, thus retaining volumetric anisotropy; concurrently, the auxiliary PKO dynamically calibrates learning rate schedules, momentum, and regularization, leading to robust convergence and augmented model generalizability. Leveraging the publicly released, expert-annotated SN-AM corpus, external validation experiments reveal and statistically confirm that SCNN-PKO exceeds alternative handcraftedfeature or pion deep-learning baselines in classification sensitivity and specificity, whilst concurrently manifesting substantially diminished false-positive and false-negative fractions across leukemia, lymphoma and myeloma subclasses. These consistent performance gains, aligned with efficient inference and user-friendly interactivity, accentuate SCNN-PKO’s translational readiness towards routine hematology laboratories, with the promise of substantially expediting diagnosis and containing observer-cognitivetranscription error rate.

title: Generative AI for Real-Time Emotion- and Culture-Aware Storytelling
authors: Shagufta Parween, Punit Pathak, R.Subhashini, Sathishkumar P, D. Jyothi Preshiya, Prema S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The traditional AI storytelling, emotional elements and culture are not often represented or can have a pervasive bias, decreasing user interaction. This paper outlines a Generative Neuro-Linguistic AI model for English storytelling in real time, based upon emotion and cultural context, that models and produces immediate narrations. This system implements a Transformer based GPT with emotion labelled datasets. Furthermore, a context detection module was developed to capture both emotion and culture. Preprocessing steps were performed to support context embedding, which directed the story-telling on tone, action, and character actions, without any required human input. In the experiments, emotion based and context-based models achieved accuracy of 96.2% and F1 score of 93.1%, exceeding those exhibited in previous models for storytelling based on emotional context. The Neuro-Linguistic AI framework has implications for scalable experiences across education, mental health, entertainment and cross-cultural contexts whereby unique and personalized experiences explore immersive storytelling experiences for each user.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning Framework for Insider Threat Detection and Response
authors: Sanjay S, R Selvaraj, V Suresh, I Gugan, Yogesh D
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Insider threats have emerged as a huge Insider threats are also a significant issue in cybersecurity as too much power and trust is given to internal users, and conventional systems cannot detect them. The paper will present a hybrid machine learning model that can be used to improve the detection and response of insider threats through the combination of anomaly detection and supervised classification. Isolation Forest and Autoencoders are used in the architecture to identify the abnormal patterns in unlabelled activity information, whereas the Classification is done on the labelled user information using the Random Forest. The activities of users like log-ins, accessing files, and network behaviour would be constantly monitored and abnormalities would result in real-time alerts on a visual dashboard. The experiments with the CERT Insider Threat Dataset have revealed that the given system is more accurate and yields less false positives in contrast with the traditional rule-based ones. These results demonstrate the success of hybrid AI strategies in protecting business against bad, irresponsible, and thoughtless insiders.

title: IoT-based Precision Farming with Remote Control Access for Low Scale Farmers
authors: Rajakumar S, K Shanthi, Kisho Varma M, Mohamed Suhail N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Agriculture is the base of the world economy, and it is now subjected to threats like water shortage, unsteady weather, and inefficient irrigation. The proposal points out the idea of IoT-based precision irrigation system Mugai that intends to achieve the objectives by multi-point real-time sensing, AI-based scheduling, and a farmer-centric mobile application. The objective of the device is to be a low-cost, resource-efficient, and scalable solution to farmers in the mountains or the desert if they are three hundred kilometers away from the nearest town.The solution is equipped with onboard IoT devices (NodeMCU) and multi-modal sensors (soil moisture, temperature, humidity, sunlight, pH) along with hybrid (LoRa and Wi-Fi/GSM) connectivity, all of which are solar-powered. The data is sent wirelessly to a local processing unit or edge device (Raspberry Pi) in a gateway and then uploaded to the cloud for storage and synchronized with an app on a smartphone or computer.The idea of the system is to develop a water-saving method that could be employed to optimize water usage. The project is therefore expected to bring about water conservation of about 30-40% besides the reduction of manual labor and increase of crop yields.

title: Prediction of Diabetes patients using Machine Learning with Data Balancing, K-means Clustering and Genetic Algorithm
authors: G.A. Pethunachiyar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Diabetes has become one of the most critical health concerns, affecting both adults and younger populations due to abnormal blood glucose levels and inadequate insulin activity. Early detection is crucial for reducing complications and improving patient survival. A hybrid framework approach is developed for earlier detection of patients with diabetes. The balanced data is essential for accurate prediction. As a first step, the dataset is balanced, next feature selection and clustering is used for improving algorithm efficiency.Research Objectives: (i) Balance the dataset to improve stability in model training, (ii) Identify the most influential features using Genetic Algorithm (GA) (iii) Apply K-Means clustering for representative sample refinement (iv) evaluate the classification algorithms to identify the best model for prediction.Findings: The balanced dataset improved class distribution, GA successfully selected the key predictive attributes and clustering reduced data redundancy. Among the classifiers, ensemble methods achieved higher performance with XGBoost consistently providing the best accuracy, sensitivity and specificity. These findings confirm that combining balancing, feature optimization and clustering significantly enhance prediction reliability for early diabetes detection.

title: Advanced Temperature Measurement System using Ultrasonic Time-of-Flight and AI-Driven Prediction with Failsafe Mechanism
authors: Dr.B.Priya, Harunicshini Navarathinam, Hema Bushani S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper presents an advanced temperature measurement system using Ultrasonic Time-of-Flight (TOF) technology and Artificial Intelligence (AI) for real-time monitoring in extreme environments. Traditional sensors face limitations such as degradation and inaccuracies in high-humidity or high-temperature conditions. The proposed system integrates ultrasonic sensors with barometric pressure compensation for precise measurements. AI-driven models enhance reliability, including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for forecasting and Isolation Forest algorithms for anomaly detection. IoT-based real-time monitoring enables continuous oversight and rapid response. Simulation results show ±1°C accuracy within -100°C to 2000°C and a response time of 1 ms.

title: AI Model for Automated Content Moderation: Integrating Hugging Face Model for Text and Image Processing
authors: Chandra Naik, Akhifa Sheik, Apoorva, Charan Kumar V, Chethan D B
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The exponential growth of user-generated content on social media has raised the need for automated moderation systems that are dependable, scalable, and objective. AI-driven solutions are necessary because offensive images and dangerous text usually evade manual review. This paper presents a multimodal moderation framework that integrates Hugging Face Transformers with Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers (BERT) for textual analysis and a Vision Transformer (ViT) for visual evaluation. We use pre-trained Hugging Face models for both text and image content moderation, which have been refined on benchmark datasets for offensive language and inappropriate imagery, in contrast to the majority of previous works that rely on custom architectures or unimodal pipelines.Using developments in image–text reasoning, meme classification, and hate speech detection, the combination of linguistic and visual embeddings allows for more reliable identification of content that violates policies. Using Hugging Face’s ecosystem for scalable and reproducible content moderation is effective, as evidenced by experimental results showing that this multimodal framework performs noticeably better than unimodal baselines in terms of accuracy and F1-score.

title: Auto-Genie: Unified AI for Automotive Cost Intelligence and Decision Support
authors: G. Jeevana Manikanta, K. Dinesh, G. Bala Koteswararao, M. V. Yaswanth, Yannam Bharath Bhushan, Nerella Harini
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: We present AutoGenie, a multi-purpose AI automotive cost solution, which combined (i) gives parts-sensitive visual repair-cost prediction (ii) predictive maintenance cost forecasting, (iii) tire-life prediction and (iv) vehicle comparison, based on total cost of ownership (TCO). AutoGenie solves instance-level damage detection/segmentation in collision/impact cases jointly with a taxonomy of parts and a part-specific material/labor regressor, best-store shop rates, and confidence interval reports. We apply time-series regression involving uncertainty in order to predict the maintenance cost as a predictor of odometer, its usage patterns, climate and service history. The mileage, load, rotation/balance history and road class predictors are used to predict the tire longevity with a survival/remaining-useful-life head. A TCO module integrates repair/maintenance prediction with fuel/energy utilisation, depreciation, insurance and taxes enabling cross vehicle comparisons (i.e. ICE vs. EV) with user-defined assumptions. We report a repeatable evaluation process of image-inventory associations, logbook history, and tire wear history; report statistics about accuracy and calibration; and qualitative/error analysis to be a decision support (auto-approve or manual processing). AutoGenie is built on top of interpretable parts and time schedules, assumptions, and the addition of statistically significant confidence limits, and is aimed at estimating end-to-end claims automation, service planning, and purchase decisions.

title: Measurement of Continuous Glucose using Antenna as Sensor in Non Invasive Method
authors: Jebasingh Kirubakaran S J, Anto Bennet M, N. R. Shanker, Pravin P
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: In this paper, Measurement of Continuous Glucose (MCG) is proposed using the circular microstrip patch antenna as a sensor. In existing methods, blood samples are used, which leads to infections and psychological stress during routine glucose level monitoring. Frequent picking of blood samples leads to infections such as septicemia and viremia. Drawback of existing non-invasive method are (i) Continuous holding sensor on body, (ii) Random measurement only can be done and (iii) Continuous radiation exposure to the body. In this paper, the antenna as a sensor detects the galvanism of arm cells and tissues in the human body and measured the diabetes levels through acquired signals. The antenna acquired galvanism signal is analyzed using time series method and calculated the signal mean and median energy. Linear regression is applied to the signal's dynamic range, mean, median, and laboratory value for diabetes measurement. The proposed circular patch antenna measures the MCG with 95% accuracy.

title: Emerging Trends in Object Detection for Autonomous Transportation Systems
authors: Kanagamalliga S, Anbusuhantha S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This paper offers a comprehensive evaluate of the methodologies, models, and sensor integration strategies used for object detection and recognition in self-riding motors. We categorize the prevailing strategies into conventional knowledge of strategies and modern-day primarily based frameworks, highlighting their relative strengths and obstacles. Additionally, we explore multi-sensor fusion techniques concerning LiDAR, radar, and camera systems to decorate belief robustness. The evaluate additionally evaluates benchmark datasets, performance metrics, and deployment challenges in actual-time situations. Finally, we outline emerging tendencies, such as transformer-based architectures and area computing, which are shaping the destiny of self sufficient notion. This survey goals to serve as a foundation for researchers and practitioners in search of to understand and make contributions to the evolving field of wise vehicular notion. Autonomous riding has emerged as a transformative paradigm in modern transportation, pushed with the aid of rapid improvements in sensor technologies, AI and computational power. At the core of self-using systems lies the functionality to as it should be hit upon and apprehend objects in a noticeably dynamic and uncertain environment. Object detection and recognition allow self sustaining automobiles to perceive their surroundings, interpret site visitors elements, expect movement trajectories, and make secure navigation choices.

title: Graph Neural AI with Temporal Dynamics for Comprehensive Anomaly Detection in Microservices
authors: Qingyuan Zhang, Ning Lyu, Le Liu, Yuxi Wang, Ziyu Cheng, Cancan Hua
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of anomaly detection and root cause tracing in microservice architectures and proposes a unified framework that combines graph neural networks with temporal modeling. The microservice call chain is abstracted as a directed graph, where multidimensional features of nodes and edges are used to construct a service topology representation, and graph convolution is applied to aggregate features across nodes and model dependencies, capturing complex structural relationships among services. On this basis, gated recurrent units are introduced to model the temporal evolution of call chains, and multi-layer stacking and concatenation operations are used to jointly obtain structural and temporal representations, improving the ability to identify anomaly patterns. Furthermore, anomaly scoring functions at both the node and path levels are defined to achieve unified modeling from local anomaly detection to global call chain tracing, which enables the identification of abnormal service nodes and the reconstruction of potential anomaly propagation paths. Sensitivity experiments are then designed from multiple dimensions, including hyperparameters, environmental disturbances, and data distribution, to evaluate the framework, and results show that it outperforms baseline methods in key metrics such as AUC, ACC, Recall, and F1-Score, maintaining high accuracy and stability under dynamic topologies and complex environments. This research not only provides a new technical path for anomaly detection in microservices but also lays a methodological foundation for intelligent operations in distributed systems.

title: Comparison of Soft Magnetic Core and Ferrite Based Rotary Transformers in EVs
authors: Stefan Botha, Nkosinathi Gule
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Electrically excited synchronous motors (EESMs) present a promising alternative to permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) in electric vehicles (EVs) due to their high power density and wide flux-weakening range, though their reliance on slip rings and brushes limits reliability at high speeds. Contactless energy transfer (CET) systems, particularly rotary transformers (RTs), offer a viable solution for replacing these mechanical components while maintaining stable excitation power. This paper presents a comparative study of ferrite and soft magnetic composite (SMC) cores for axial RT designs optimized within a resonant LLC driving circuit. The materials are evaluated in terms of frequency capability, flux density, manufacturability, and efficiency, with optimization performed using the NSGA-II algorithm. Results show that both materials are suitable for EESM excitation, though ferrite cores achieve higher efficiency, reduced volume, and better mechanical integrity.

title: Lifetime Assessment of Grid-Connected PV Inverters Considering Electrolytic DC-Link Capacitor Degradation and Climate Conditions
authors: Adamou Moussa, Mohamed Yasko, Diego Acevedo-Bueno, Bangli Du, Wilmar Martinez
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The reliability of grid-connected photovoltaic (PV) inverters is critically influenced by the degradation of electrolytic DC-link capacitors, whose ageing modifies both thermal behaviour and semiconductor lifetime. This work evaluates that impact under two contrasting climatic conditions Belgium and Niger by combining one-year mission profiles with electrothermal simulations and a four-dimensional junction temperature estimator. Although the temperature swings <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta T_{j}$</tex> observed here remain modest compared with the high-amplitude conditions typically reported in the literature, clear climatic differences persist. After five years of capacitor degradation, Belgium remains within a relatively mild thermal range, with mean junction temperatures between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$323-350\ \mathrm{K}$</tex> and temperature swings <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta T_{j}$</tex> typically below 10 K. In contrast, Niger reaches substantially higher mean junction temperatures of around 370 K and exhibits much larger thermal-cycle amplitudes of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-25 ~\mathrm{K}$</tex>. These thermal differences lead to distinct lifetime consumption (LC) trajectories: Belgium accumulates LC slowly due to its moderate climate, whereas Niger experiences markedly higher LC driven by elevated temperatures and stronger cycling. When extrapolated to 20 years, Niger reaches nearly 45% cumulative LC compared with about 22 % in Belgium, underscoring the strong climatic influence on inverter wear-out. The proposed framework enables climatespecific lifetime assessment and supports more robust design strategies for future PV inverters.

title: Towards Tamper-Resistant Digital Media: An AI and Blockchain Approach for Deepfake Detection
authors: K Sakthivel, Harine N, Chandra Mohan G
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Deepfake technology poses severe risks to digital security and content authenticity due to advancements in generative models. Traditional detection methods rely on either visual or auditory cues, making them vulnerable to evolving forgery techniques and lacking secure validation. This study proposes a multimodal deepfake detection framework integrating Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Blockchain for tamper-resistant verification. The system employs MTCNN and InceptionResNetV1 for visual forgery detection, and a CNN model on mel-spectrograms for audio deepfake identification. SHA-256 hashing and blockchain storage ensure the immutability and traceability of detection results. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed model achieves a detection accuracy of 93%, outperforming conventional CNN and hybrid CNN-LSTM systems in precision, recall, and F1-score. The framework provides a secure, scalable, and decentralized solution to detect synthetic media while preserving integrity and transparency, contributing to safer digital media ecosystems and reliable content authentication.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning for Retinal Disease Diagnosis using Paillier Homomorphic Encryption with Multiple Encryption Keys
authors: Avirneni Veda Sri, Mahesh Kumar Morampudi, Mallikarjun Reddy Dorsala, Sriramulu Bojjagani, Muhammad Khurram Khan
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Medical image analysis is crucial for diagnosing retinal diseases like diabetic retinopathy (DR), Retinal Vein Occlusion (RVO), and Glaucoma. This study aims to develop a secure and accurate privacy-preserving federated learning framework for retinal disease diagnosis. Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative training without sharing raw data, mitigating privacy concerns in deep learning. However, inference attacks on model updates pose significant risks. Homomorphic encryption (HE) is widely used for privacy preservation in FL but is limited by requiring all encrypted data to use a single encryption key, increasing vulnerability. To address this, we propose a privacy-preserving FL framework integrating paillier HE with multiple encryption keys (PPFLMPHE). Each client encrypts model parameters using all client’s public keys before transmission, ensuring data security even if one key is compromised. The server aggregates encrypted local parameters per key while preserving privacy, ensuring only authorized clients can decrypt it. Additionally, we enhance classification performance and address class imbalance using data augmentation techniques such as rotation, flipping, shifting, and zooming. Our approach is evaluated on retinal image datasets, including APTOS 2019, RVO, and Glaucoma, using pre-trained models such as VGG16, ResNet50, DenseNet121, MobileNetV2, and InceptionV3. Among all models, ResNet50 provides the highest performance with 98.90% accuracy and 98.70% F1-score for DR, while DenseNet121 achieves 96.66% accuracy for RVO and InceptionV3 achieves 98.32% accuracy for Glaucoma. These results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively balances privacy preservation and model performance, offering a robust and secure FL framework for retinal disease diagnosis.

title: Aligning Higher-Order Graph Structure for Unsupervised Domain Adaptation in Remote Sensing Scene Classification
authors: Qing He, Erzhu Li, Alim Samat, Wei Liu, Xing Li
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA) is crucial for remote sensing (RS) scene classification under pervasive domain shifts. Many existing UDA methods primarily emphasize inter-domain transferability via global alignment, including adversarial learning, yet under-exploit intra-domain structure, which can degrade discriminability. This paper proposes Graph Structural Moment Alignment (GSMA), a structure-regularized UDA framework that complements adversarial adaptation with graph-based structural constraints. GSMA introduces High-order Spectral Moment Alignment (HOSMA) to align source and target feature graphs constructed from random-walk transition matrices via trace-based, decomposition-free moment statistics, encouraging the preservation of high-order local connectivity patterns. Moreover, GSMA integrates Neighborhood Consensus Learning (NCL) with a memory bank to refine target pseudo-labels through neighborhood agreement and local consistency regularization. Experiments on cross-domain RS benchmarks demonstrate consistent improvements over representative baselines, validating the effectiveness of GSMA for robust RS scene adaptation.

title: SyncPlay: Synchronized Video-on-Demand Playback with MOQ
authors: Kerem Bekmez, Ahmet Pehlivanoglu, Zafer Gurel, Ali C. Begen
publish: Proceedings of the conference on Proceedings of the 5th Mile-High Video Conference
abstract: None

title: Safe reinforcement learning-based guidance strategy against active defense target in three-player engagement_supp1-3664048.pdf
authors: Yuanli Cai
publish: N/A
abstract: In the three-player engagement, the missile must confront an active defense target—comprising both the target and the defender—while simultaneously pursuing the target and evading the defender. Existing intelligent missile guidance strategies against an active defense target integrate the reward for pursuing the target with the reward for evading the defender to improve guidance performance. However, setting the appropriate weights for these rewards poses a significant challenge. As a result, these strategies struggle to effectively optimize mission performance (i.e., pursuing the target) while simultaneously ensuring safety (i.e., evading the defender). Therefore, we propose a safe reinforcement learning-based guidance strategy against an active defense target in three-player engagement, enabling the missile to pursue the target while evading the defender efficiently. First, we model the kinematic and relative kinematic equations in a three-player engagement scenario. To apply safe reinforcement learning in the missile guidance against an active defense target, the Constrained Markov Decision Process framework for the missile is constructed. Next, from a probabilistic inference perspective, we propose a safe reinforcement learning-based guidance strategy in an Expectation Maximization style to efficiently guide the missile: the optimal non-parametric variational distribution is calculated using convex optimization (E-step), and policy parameters are updated through supervised learning (M-step). Finally, a wide range of simulation experiment results show the feasibility and superiority of the proposed guidance strategy in both static target and dynamic target environments.

title: Toward Energy-Sustainable Networked Blue Economy via Underwater Acoustic Backscatter
authors: Long Zhang, Shangze Lu, Jingwen Tong, Choong Seon Hong, Dusit Niyato, Zhu Han
publish: IEEE Network
abstract: The Networked Blue Economy (NetBE), including maritime activities from emergency response and infrastructure inspection to smart aquaculture, depends on pervasive underwater sensing and communications. However, the energy constraint of battery-powered underwater nodes continues to be a performance bottleneck, limiting the scale and sustainability of deployment. To address this limitation, underwater acoustic backscatter (UAB) has emerging as an ultra-low-power communication paradigm that enables a scalable and energy-sustainable Internet of Underwater Things, as a sensing platform of the NetBE. Nevertheless, the shift from theoretical investigation to practical application remains a daunting task. Therefore, this article gives a thorough overview to explore how UAB can empower the NetBE. First, we present specific energy problems of underwater systems. Then, we detail the fundamental operational principles of UAB, covering its system components, communication process, and configuration mode. On this basis, we propose a concrete technological pathway for the deployment of UAB into the NetBE, which discusses network architectures and key enabling techniques, supported by an analysis of its associated use cases. A case study confirms a significant improvement in system energy efficiency with an acceptable per-backscatter node average rate, demonstrating the potential of UAB for sustainable future of the NetBE. Finally, we conclude by some research challenges and prospective directions for future explorations.

title: TransLiDAR: A Dataset and Benchmark for Cross-Sensor Point Cloud Translation
authors: Yilong Chen, Zongyi Xu, Xiaoshui Huang, Shanshan Zhao, Zhongpeng Lang, Xinbo Gao
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Autonomous vehicles are typically equipped with one primary and several auxiliary LiDAR sensors to generate point clouds of the environment. However, differences in structural design, resolution, and scanning mechanisms among LiDAR types lead to significant modality gaps, which hinder cross-sensor adaptation and joint learning. To address this challenge, we aim to enable effective point cloud translation across heterogeneous LiDAR sensors. To this end, we construct a cross-sensor point cloud translation dataset, TransLiDAR, containing paired point clouds from mechanical and hybrid semi-solid-state LiDARs captured in the same scenes. Based on this dataset, we further investigate point cloud translation methods and propose a framework called TransLiDAR-Net. Specifically, point clouds are projected into 2D range images, and a dual-stream network is used to separately extract foreground and background features. A feature interaction module is then introduced to facilitate information exchange between the two feature streams. Experimental results demonstrate that TransLiDAR-Net effectively translates point clouds between mechanical and hybrid semi-solid-state LiDARs, providing a practical solution and strong baseline for cross-sensor adaptation and joint learning.

title: RTF-Skip-GANomaly: A Novel Deep Learning Framework for Anomaly Detection in Run-to-Failure Data Using Skip-GANomaly Backbone
authors: Hyeon-Uk Lee, Suhwan Im, Seungjae Ham, Il-Min Kim, Jae-Mo Kang
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Anomaly detection in run-to-failure (RTF) data is one of the pivotal tasks in a variety of real-world signal processing applications. Vast majority of the existing anomaly detection methods in the literature are based on generative adversarial networks (GANs), but they are ineffective and problematic when applied to the RTF data. To break through such a limitation, in this paper, we propose RTF-Skip-GANomaly, a novel and high-performing deep learning (DL) framework for anomaly detection in the RTF data, by leveraging the off-the-shelf Skip-GANomaly as backbone. Key innovations in our approach are two-fold: (i) we introduce an extra dual-stream DL network called Weibull-Net and integrate it into the Skip-GANomaly backbone such that a pseudo Weibull function is predicted from the latent representation of the reconstructed RTF data with time embedding, and (ii) we also devise an effective strategy to train the Weibull-Net jointly with the Skip-GANomaly backbone through a customized loss function design. Experimental results validate the superior performance and enhanced efficacy of our framework over the existing approaches.

title: DFGLIoT: A Dual-Fusion Graph Learning Framework for Cross-Institutional Mobile IoT Device Identification
authors: Xuhui Wang, Guanglu Sun, Xin Liu, Libao Zhang, Wenjie Yao
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Accurately identifying IoT devices connected to a network is crucial for improving network management and ensuring network security. As IoT devices increasingly move across institutional boundaries, identifying devices that migrate among institutions has become a significant challenge. However, existing studies assume that IoT devices remain stationary. As a result, they are inadequate for addressing the security risks introduced by device mobility across institutions. Therefore, we propose an IoT device identification framework named DFGLIoT. The framework adopts a decentralized fully connected architecture to enable knowledge sharing among institutions. This design avoids single points of failure while effectively supporting the identification of cross-institutional mobile IoT devices. We model the communication traffic between IoT devices and their gateways as communication interaction graphs. These graphs provide a comprehensive view of the interaction process between the communicating parties. Based on this representation, we design a graph classifier that integrates a dual-scale dependency modeling module with a spatial feature extraction module. The classifier captures interaction patterns in the communication traffic and constructs behavior fingerprints of IoT devices, enabling accurate device identification. Experimental results on three public datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DFGLIoT in identifying IoT devices that move across institutions. The source code can be accessed at https://github.com/traveler-wang/DFGLIoT.

title: A Free-Positioning and Compact Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Wireless Charging System Based on Two-Stage Energy Peak-to-Valley Matching Output Fluctuation Suppression
authors: Yuyao Wang, Can Zhang, Shuai Wu, Chenxu Wang, Chunwei Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: This paper proposes a wireless charging system for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) that achieves high tolerance to misalignment through a novel two-stage energy matching technique. In the first stage, the orthogonal receiving coils within each receiver capture complementary horizontal and vertical magnetic flux components generated by reverse-series transmitting coils, achieving magnetic energy peak-to-valley matching through rectification and superposition, effectively eliminating energy dead zones. In the second stage, the outputs of two receivers are combined to achieve electrical energy matching, effectively reducing output fluctuations and enhancing system efficiency. The design incorporates a mode-switching strategy and fundamental wave analysis to meet power transmission and charging control requirements. Experimental results demonstrate that the system can deliver a constant current of approximately 6.1 A with a consistent DC-DC efficiency of 82.2%. Within a deviation range of ±90 mm, the output efficiency fluctuation is limited to 4.57%, and with varying angular misalignment, the output current fluctuation is only 0.98%. This indicates the system's high effectiveness in UAV wireless charging, even under misaligned conditions. The proposed approach provides a valuable technical reference for the engineering deployment of UAV wireless charging systems.

title: LLM and DRL Collaborative Optimization for Flexible Resource Scheduling in Integrated Energy Systems
authors: Guangzheng Xing, Xinyue Zhao, Tianying Yu, Haiyun Wang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Increasing renewable energy penetration imposes stringent requirements on flexible resource scheduling in Integrated Energy Systems (IES), yet conventional methods face significant challenges in computational efficiency and modeling complexity under multi-energy coupling, high-dimensional uncertainties, and multi-constraint operations. Here we propose a novel scheduling strategy that synergistically integrates Large Language Models (LLM) and Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) to address these challenges. Specifically, LLM leverages few-shot learning for intelligent reasoning of Battery Energy Storage System decisions with a three-layer Safety-Guard ensuring constraint satisfaction, while DRL optimizes Combined Heat and Power units and Gas Boilers through enhanced state space incorporating executed battery actions. This hierarchical collaboration effectively reduces action dimensionality while maintaining responsiveness to dynamic disturbances. Comprehensive simulations demonstrate substantial improvements in battery responsiveness to time-of-use tariffs and renewable fluctuations, achieving significant reductions in operating costs and cycling intensity. Multi-scenario tests validate robust performance under high-intensity perturbations and fault injections with zero constraint violations. This approach provides a promising pathway for intelligent multi-energy coordinated scheduling in IES.

title: Gold Nanoflowers Sensitivity and Selectivity Improvement by Thiolation to Detect Breast Cancer Volatile Organic Compound Biomarkers
authors: Malkari Sravani, Aniruddh Bahadur Yadav, Rahul Checker
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Breast cancer is a malignant disease, and patient prognosis significantly improves when detected at an early stage. Therefore, various advanced chemiresistive sensors have been adopted to detect Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs), which are byproducts of cellular metabolism exhaled in breath, for early breast cancer detection. In this work, gold nanoflowers (AuNFs) with a high surface area to volume ratio and a face centered cubic (FCC) crystalline structure of 203 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$nm$</tex-math></inline-formula> were synthesized, as confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and High resolution scanning electron microscopy (HRSEM). After dispersion in deionized (DI) water, the AuNFs were drop coated onto interdigital elliptical aluminum electrodes patterned on glass substrates, forming a continuous film (neighboring AuNFs closely packed) with an initial resistance of up to 2 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathit {K\Omega }$</tex-math></inline-formula>. The AuNFs films were then functionalized with phenylethyl mercaptan and 2-methyl-1-propanethiol using a simple and controllable drop coating method offering an advantage over conventional ligand ion exchange techniques. The large electrode spacing significantly reduces noise compared to traditional low spacing gold electrodes, which require costly photolithography. Furthermore, thiolation enhances both sensitivity and selectivity. The sensors exhibited very high sensitivity, attributed to the high conductivity of the AuNFs films and the sharp petal like active sites promoting strong VOC interactions. To the best of the authors' knowledge, this is the first report demonstrating high sensitivity for breast cancer related VOCs using aluminum electrodes on a glass substrate.
