title: Time Will Tell: Criss-cross Transformer for Encrypted Traffic Analysis
authors: Hua Ding, Lixing Chen, Bo Zhang, Shenghong Li, Hao Peng, Zhe Qu, Yang Bai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
abstract: The widespread adoption of encryption across web-based services is compelling both malicious attackers and network defenders to tailor their tool repositories to encrypted traffic. For various security applications in encrypted networks, the analysis of encrypted traffic lies as the fundamental basis. Due to the inherent concealment of content-related information in encrypted packets, the dynamics of encrypted traffic emerge as the discernible variable warranting comprehensive analysis. This paper explores inherent temporal correlations within the encrypted traffic and proposes a novel algorithm called Criss-cross Traffic Transformer (CTT), tailored to address unique challenges in encrypted traffic analysis. CTT distinguishes itself by employing a specialized time series Transformer that innovatively utilizes patching and criss-cross attention module (CAM) to dissect and interpret encrypted traffic, with the “criss” part mining the long-/short-term temporal correlations across time, and the “cross” part capturing temporal correlations across multiple feature dimensions of encrypted traffic. CTT provides a unified framework capable of accommodating diverse analytical granularities, including packet-level, flow-level, and packet-to-flow level. Notably, CTT not only encompasses encrypted traffic classification but also extends to encrypted traffic forecasting, an area that remains largely underexplored in existing literature. We evaluate CTT in the context of fingerprinting attacks and malware detection over 5 real-world datasets against 13 benchmarks. The results indicate that CTT achieves up to 15.56% performance improvement over SOTA solutions for encrypted traffic classification. Particularly, CTT demonstrates over 92.5% forecasting accuracy, which is comparable to SOTA performances in the seen-and-classify scenario, suggesting its potential applicability to broader domains like social network behavioral analysis. Our code is available at https://github.com/Amanda-HuaDing/Criss-cross_Traffic_Transformer.

title: Random Number Generation Based on Dual-Emission Random Fiber Lasers: performance and image encryption applications
authors: Yalan Li, Qin Yang, Xiaolong Ban, Xiangjun Meng, Zhangfei Chen, Siqi Li, Weiwei Fu, Benli Yu, Feng Xu, Zhijia Hu
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: True random numbers occupy a core role in the field of encryption and security by virtue of their properties such as unpredictability and independence. In this paper, we propose a high-speed physical random number generator based on a dual-emission random fiber laser. The system improves the spectral bandwidth characteristics of the output signals by adjusting the pump power and the feedback length of the single mode fiber. This study effectively suppresses the autocorrelation feature by performing exclusive-OR operations on the forward and backward random laser signals, and obtain the random number sequence with a generation rate of 20 Gbps by post-processing with high-order finite difference and least significant bit extraction. In order to verify the practical application performance, we apply the random sequence as encryption key to digital image encryption, and the experimental results show that the generator has both theoretical security and practical application value.

title: Experimental Demonstration of Narrow-Band and Broad-Band UV Third Harmonic Generation in Silica Microfibers
authors: Xiujuan Jiang, Qiang Fu, Yuqiang Huang, Manjing Chen, Aurélien Coillet, Philippe Grelu, Lin Xu, Timothy Lee
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Third harmonic generation (THG) via intermodal phase matching in fibers provides a convenient way to generate ultraviolet (UV) wavelengths. In this study, we systematically compare three THG configurations based on 1089 nm pumping to demonstrate UV output characteristics and dependencies on pump parameters and microfiber layout: (i) narrow-band conversion using a single long microfiber, (ii) narrow-band conversion using cascaded short microfibers, and (iii) broad-band conversion with a Raman-broadening pump. In the narrow-band case using a relatively long silica microfiber (waist diameter 520 nm, waist length 6 mm), third harmonic at 363 nm is generated at 1.14 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>W average power, making a notable record in similar works. With multiple short silica microfibers (waist diameter 520 nm, waist length 3 mm), the idea of cascading the interaction media to improve THG performance is experimentally tested; the results show that the crucial phase relation required for coherent overlap of third harmonic components is satisfactorily achieved, while signal enhancement is counteracted by serious losses in the system, indicating that efficient signal delivering is a key issue in fiber-based optical frequency conversions. With the broad-band pump including the specific 1089 nm wavelength, the intermodal phase matching model for THG is verified, and a non-destructive approach is suggested to check the waist diameter of a fabricated microfiber.

title: Diffusion Multimodal Distillation Collaboration: A Generative Equilibrium Framework For Efficient Vehicle Networking Intrusion Detection
authors: Shengcai Zhang, Jiangtao Wang, Dezhi An
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Real-time intrusion detection with millisecond response is critical for Internet of Vehicles (IoV) security but is challenged by extreme class imbalance and high computational costs. This paper proposes a novel multimodal framework integrating Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (DDPM) and Knowledge Distillation (KD). First, multi-source data is transformed into RGB images. A conditional DDPM with timestep and class embeddings balances datasets by generating minority-class samples. The teacher model (DiffuGuardian) fuses text-image features for training. Subsequently, a lightweight student model, LiteSentinel, is designed employing depthwise separable convolutions and inverted residual blocks to reduce parameters. Results on three datasets demonstrate that DiffuGuardian consistently achieves around 98–100% precision, accuracy, recall, and F1-score under 5-fold evaluation, while LiteSentinel maintains approximately 95–99% across all metrics with substantially reduced complexity. DiffuGuardian reaches an inference time of 3.80ms with a model size of 0.10 MB, whereas LiteSentinel further reduces latency to 0.79ms with a size of 0.07 MB, enabling efficient edge deployment for IoV security.

title: Robotic Assistive Optimization and Control Using Neural Dynamics and Adaptive Neural Network
authors: Chao Cun, Liangrui Xu, Guoxin Li, Zhijun Li, Yu Kang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: Humans can naturally learn and adapt to walking patterns in a variety of terrains. To simulate this learning characteristic, this article introduces a neural dynamics-based impedance optimization and trajectory adaptation approach for our designed soft exosuit, with a dual-driven configuration to assist both ankles of individuals. This method adaptively learns the impedance of the human ankle joint using measured interaction forces and dynamically adjusts trajectories to align with real-time human–robot interaction. Additionally, an adaptive control framework integrating neural dynamics-based optimization with several adaptive laws is developed to achieve stable tracking of updated reference trajectories, with Lyapunov stability analysis confirming uniform ultimate boundedness (UUB) of the closed-loop system. The designed controller offers the benefit of concurrently addressing trajectory adaptation, force control, and impedance tuning for soft exosuits. Experimental validation on human subjects across various terrains demonstrates that the proposed method reduces maximum trajectory tracking error to 0.016 rad (lower than PID and ADRC controllers) and enables impedance parameters to converge within 3 gait cycles. The controller concurrently addresses trajectory adaptation, force control, and impedance tuning, offering a lightweight (8 kg) and wearability-optimized solution for walking assistance.

title: An Adaptive Feature Enhancement Method Based on Optimized Spectrum Period Estimation and Sparse Bayesian for Bearing Fault Identification
authors: Huaqing Wang, Jingjing Yan, Wei Lu, Changkun Han, Liuyang Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Under complex working conditions, it is difficult to accurately obtain the fault feature period of bearings in complex equipment for fault diagnosis. Period estimation based on peak detection and feature parameters is prone to high false detection rates due to periodic interference and random pulse effects, which pose a challenge for fault diagnosis. Therefore, this paper proposes an adaptive feature enhancement method based on optimized spectrum period estimation and sparse Bayesian for bearing fault identification (OSPES). First, adaptive weighted spectrum optimization (AWSO) calculates the weights of fault data spectrum lines based on healthy data to obtain a weighted optimized spectrum (WOS), thereby suppressing the impact of periodic interference components. Second, low-amplitude components are removed from the WOS and harmonic product spectrum analysis is performed to suppress the effects of random pulses and noise, and obtain the fault pulse period. Finally, a sparse Bayesian learning (SBL) framework incorporating period constraints and group sparsity constraints is employed to reconstruct sparse signals and achieve adaptive feature enhancement. OSPES suppresses periodic and random interference based on the characteristics of fault data and impact sparsity, thereby improving the problem of inaccurate period estimation that arises from peak detection and feature parameters. It also eliminates the need for manual parameter adjustment and enhances universality. Simulation, vibration, and acoustic signal experiments, as well as comparative experiments, verify the effectiveness and superiority of OSPES. A Periodic-to-Interference ratio (PIR) is designed to evaluate the superiority of OSPES quantitatively.

title: Evolutionary Generative Optimization: Towards Fully Data-Driven Evolutionary Optimization via Generative Learning
authors: Tao Jiang, Kebin Sun, Zhenyu Liang, Ran Cheng, Yaochu Jin, Kay Chen Tan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: Recent advances in data-driven evolutionary algorithms (EAs) have demonstrated the potential of leveraging historical data to improve optimization accuracy and adaptability. Despite these advancements, existing methods remain reliant on handcrafted process-level operators. In contrast, Evolutionary Generative Optimization (EvoGO) is a fully data-driven framework designed from the objective level, enabling autonomous learning of the entire search process. EvoGO streamlines the evolutionary optimization process into three stages: data preparation, model training, and population generation. The data preparation stage constructs a pairwise dataset to enrich training diversity without incurring additional evaluation costs. During model training, a tailored generative model learns to transform inferior solutions into superior ones. In the population generation stage, EvoGO replaces traditional reproduction operators with a scalable and parallelizable generative mechanism. Extensive experiments on numerical benchmarks, classical control problems, and high-dimensional robotic tasks demonstrate that EvoGO consistently converges within merely 10 generations and substantially outperforms a wide spectrum of optimization approaches, including traditional EAs, Bayesian optimization, and reinforcement learning based methods. Code is available at: https://github.com/EMI-Group/evogo.

title: AI for Everyone: Engaging Middle Schoolers through Collaborative, Ethical, and Multimodal AI Learning
authors: Kayleigh Stallings, Nicole Tian, Elif Yayla Ercek, Haven Kotara, Devin Marinelli, Pragathi Durga Rajarajan, Dan Schumacher, Ismaila Temitayo Sanusi, Fred Martin
publish: Proceedings of the 57th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education V.1
abstract: None

title: Blockchain Integration in IoT: A Comprehensive Review of Security, Algorithms, and Applications
authors: Pradeep Nazareth, Sathyaprakash T, Sharan S Shetty, Shrihith S Poojary
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) devices are constrained by limited storage and processing capabilities, creating open entry points for cyber threats. These constraints limits the establishment of robust security using conventional, centralized methods. Blockchain technology presents a promising solution by offering a decentralized, secure, and tamper-proof method for storing data. This paper examines modern research directions for implementing blockchain to enhance the security and quality of IoT systems. The core strength of blockchain lies in its ability to protect information from corruption and unauthorized access through encrypted, distributed ledgers. However, a significant challenge remains where many standard blockchain implementations are computationally expensive and demand high processing power, making them unsuitable for lightweight IoT devices. Therefore, the primary issue is not the applicability of blockchain’s security principles to IoT, but rather the prohibitive cost and resource requirements for many practical use cases. This research focuses on overcoming these barriers to enable efficient, featherweight blockchain solutions for the IoT landscape.

title: Tracing Shifts in Social Mentality in the Intelligent Era: Redefining the Boundaries of Human-AI Collaboration
authors: Qiang Fu, Ping Ren, Yue Xiao, Jun Hu, Bin Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Early Cardiovascular Disease Prediction: SDCN-CHDMO-ResVGG Approach
authors: Manohar Babu Barla, Aravind Kumar Madam
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Early detection of Cardiovascular Diseases (CVD) is required by the proper detecting methods as it is the major concern for the deaths caused in the worldwide. This work suggests a deep learning-based method to improve diagnostic performance by combining feature selection, classification, and optimization. Chaotic Dwarf Mongoose Optimization (CH-DMO) selects optimal features, while Self-Attention Assisted Dense Capsule Network (SDCN) ensures robust feature extraction. Harris Whale Residual VGG Network (ResVGG) improves classification accuracy using residual learning, with M-Square normalization enhancing feature homogeneity. Experimental results on benchmark CVD datasets show superior classification accuracy, lower computational complexity, and improved generalization over existing methods. The findings highlight the model’s potential to assist healthcare professionals in early CVD detection, improving clinical decision-making and patient outcomes.

title: Measurements in Cybersecurity: Recent Trends and Examples of Application [Roadmap for Measurement and Applications]
authors: Muhammad Afzal, Domenico Capriglione, Gianni Cerro, Luigi Ferrigno, Benedetta Masone, Gianfranco Miele, Antonio Nardone, Luca Tari
publish: IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Magazine
abstract: Cybersecurity is a crucial topic in modern and future applications ranging from Internet of Things (IoT) to healthcare and biomedical devices, from Industrial to transportation, from manufacturing to critical infrastructures, such as power plants and smart grids. CISCO Systems gives a possible definition of cybersecurity: the practice of protecting systems, networks, and programs from digital attacks. These cyberattacks are usually aimed at accessing, changing, or destroying sensitive information; extorting money from users through ransomware; or interrupting normal business processes [1].

title: Discovering Optimized Energy Efficient Protocols for Wireless Sensor Networks using Soft Computing
authors: Sathiyanathan S, Mahendran N
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) consist of spatially distributed sensor nodes deployed over extensive areas to monitor environmental conditions. These nodes collect data and transmit it to a centralized base station for processing. Due to the limited energy capacity of battery-powered sensor nodes, energy efficiency remains a huge challenge in WSN design and deployment. Excessive energy consumption leads to premature node failures, resulting in reduced network coverage, connectivity fragmentation, and ultimately degraded performance. Optimization techniques in WSNs apply mathematical, algorithmic, and heuristic approaches to improve energy-efficient operation while maintaining communication reliability and network longevity. The primary goal of optimization strategies is to maximize network lifetime, reduce communication overhead, and maintain balanced energy consumption among nodes to avoid network partitioning caused by uneven workload distribution. These strategies collectively contribute to extending the operational lifetime and robustness of sensor networks. Energy efficiency is a critical issue in Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) due to the limited power resources of sensor nodes. The Improvised Pelican Optimization Algorithm (POA), a recent nature-inspired metaheuristic optimizer based on pelican hunting behavior, offers a promising approach to optimize energy consumption by intelligent cluster head selection or routing path optimization in WSNs. This paper explores POA to reduce energy consumption and extend the network lifetime of WSNs using MATLAB simulation.

title: AI Agent based SaaS Platform (AIBSP)
authors: MsAnju, Abhimannew Vinuroy Smitha, Arya.J, Madhav K, Bachu Skanda
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This work presents a web-based AI-powered platform named AI SAP Tools, designed to deliver intelligent SaaS-based utilities such as research paper summarization, subtitle generation, PDF-based question answering, and data analysis. The system integrates multiple AI models, including large language models (LLMs) and speech-to-text engines, to power and improve user output in academic, professional, and enterprise contexts. Each tool acts as an independent AI agent, interacting via a combined interface that allows users to select and use tools as needed. The platform works on coin-based subscription model using Coins, allowing micro-payments for tool usage instead of traditional fixed plans. System performance is evaluated in terms of response accuracy, processing time, and user efficiency. Results indicate improved task automation and accessibility when compared to conventional manual processes. This approach aims to democratize AI access for a wider user base and establish a scalable framework for deploying AI utilities in SaaS environments. Future improvements includes adding performance analyzer and increasing multilingual support.

title: AI-Powered XGBoost and LSTM-based Insulin Dosage Prediction for Diabetes Management
authors: Akash Pujari, Rachana P, Asha H. D, Surabhi Surabhi, Guruprasada Guruprasada
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Effective diabetes management requires administering the appropriate dosage of insulin at the appropriate time. Serious health issues including high or low blood sugar levels might result from even a minor dosing error. In this work, we propose a novel hybrid method that enhances the accuracy and dependability of insulin dosage predictions by combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks with Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost). While median imputation is used to fill in missing data and lessen bias, XGBoost assists in identifying the most significant features from clinical data and creates a powerful classifier. The system may therefore produce accurate time-based predictions because the LSTM model records the variations in blood glucose levels over time. By merging both static clinical information and time-series glucose data, the proposed model gives personalized dosage suggestions. Tests on standard diabetes datasets show that our hybrid XGBoost–LSTM model performs better than traditional methods in terms of accuracy, precision, and mean absolute error. This AI-based approach can help both patients and healthcare professionals improve insulin management and maintain better glucose control.

title: Area and Power-Optimized Pipelined Wallace Tree Multiplier for High-Speed DSP Applications
authors: Erugu Suhitha, C.Paramasivam, Ganapathi Hegde
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Fast and efficient multiplication is also a pillar of contemporary digital signal processing (DSP) and cryptography as well as edge computing architectures. Traditional Wallace Tree multipliers provide greater speed with parallel reduction, but in many applications have high area and power overhead, thus they are typically not applicable in low-power SoC and IoT applications. To address these issues, an optimized pipelined Wallace Tree multiplier is designed that has a small two-stage carry-save adder (CSA) pipeline, a single 8-bit carry-lookahead adder (CLA), and power-conscious register activation using stage-enable signals. The proposed architecture, synthesized with Cadence Genus with slow process conditions, is 75 percent smaller (reducing 7224.94 μm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> to 1814.29 μm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), 80 percent less power (down to 168 μW) and has a 26 percent shorter critical path delay (down to 256 ps) than the conventional design. These findings show a balanced multiplier architecture that is optimized in terms of speed, area and power consumption, which is most appropriate in low-power ASIC and FPGA accelerators in next-generation IoT and edge-AI systems.

title: Optimizing Retinopathy Detection using Deep Learning Techniques: A Focus on ResNet50
authors: Narenthirakumar Appavu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Using an originally trained ResNet50 network topology as a basis, the goal of this study is to create a reliable and effective algorithm for diabetic damage to the retina diagnosis. The model successfully concentrates on clinically relevant retinal areas by retraining as well as fine-tuning its final layers utilizing attention processes, increasing diagnostic accuracy and reliability. While improved data sampling techniques are used to guarantee model generalization and avoid data leakage across training and validation sets, high-resolution retinal pictures are used to collect detailed visual properties. Improved diagnostic consistency is further enhanced by appropriately normalizing demographic variables, which are known to affect the course of diabetic retinopathy. The suggested methodology makes use of pretrained models' benefits to facilitate efficient learning from a small number of labeled datasets. Additionally, the model is directed toward the most pertinent retinal areas by attention-based methods, which reduce noise and improve interpretability. Through the integration of cutting-edge deep learning advances in healthcare imaging, this research promotes SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, along with Infrastructure) and SDG 3 (Good Health as well as Well-Being) by encouraging the early diagnosis and management of diabetic retinopathy. By encouraging scientific cooperation with the implementation of open-access medical datasets, the strategy also supports SDGs 4 (Quality Education) and 17 (Partnerships for the Goals). The suggested approach offers a sustainable and clever method for prompt intervention and detection in diabetic retinopathy that improves global healthcare outcomes by striking a compromise between diagnostic precision and computational economy.

title: AI-Powered Health, Safety & Insurance Sentinel
authors: G. Vasu, Kardeepa Ponnuchamy, M. Madhu Pavankumar, G. Charan Kumar Reddy, K. Vijay, M. Monica Bhavani
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: In the current medical ecosystem, ensuring prompt access to healthcare, raising awareness of safety issues, and facilitating clear insurance procedures continue to be obstacles. This paper introduces the AI-Powered Health, Safety & Insurance Sentinel, a comprehensive intelligent platform that integrates personalized health education, real-time safety monitoring, medical consultation services, and insurance claim processing. The system uses artificial intelligence to analyze symptoms, offer both virtual and in-person consultations, and suggest local hospitals based on availability, specialization, and location. With an emphasis on safe long-term medication practices, preventive care, and emergency preparedness, it features a health information module that offers verified educational content. The platform requires medical back- ground verification through affiliated diagnostic labs to improve insurance dependability, guaranteeing correct medical records and reducing claim denials. It also offers clear communication and eligibility guidelines specific to the policy. Additionally, it clarifies non-applicable conditions and offers eligibility guidelines specific to the policy, which enhances user comprehension and lowers disputes. The AI-Powered Health, Safety & Insurance Sentinel seeks to increase patient trust, expedite medical decision- making, and improve accessibility to high-quality healthcare by combining AI-driven health recommendations, safety insights, and transparent insurance workflows into a single solution. This strategy provides a scalable model for patient-centeredly bridging the gap between safety awareness, insurance compliance, and medical services.

title: Store Sales Forecasting using a Novel LSSVM-based Predictive Model
authors: Suman Vij, K. Rajesh Kumar, Prarthana Joshi, Allahverdiyeva Madina Arrahman, J Jesintha Princy, Shashank Singh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Despite the importance of store sales forecasting for efficient inventory management and company planning, preprocessing is an essential initial step since real-world sales data is frequently inaccurate and imprecise. Better predicting is possible with better data quality, which may be achieved by preprocessing and getting it ready for machine learning models. Cleaning, transforming, and feature engineering are some of the data preparation methods that are essential for extracting useful insights from sales records that go back a long way. Integrating the GBO with a LSSVM forms a hybrid LSSVM-GBO technique, which is intended to improve prediction accuracy. This blend forms a new forecasting model. In order to better manage the complexity of sales data, the model makes use of GBO's optimization skills and LSSVM's regression strength. According to the results of the performance evaluation, the LSSVM-GBO model routinely achieves a higher predicting accuracy of 96.24% than the conventional approaches. These outcomes validate the model's capacity to generate trustworthy and precise predictions, even when dealing with intricate datasets. The suggested LSSVM-GBO hybrid model proves, finally, that a strong and scalable solution for real-world retail settings can be achieved by combining modern hybrid machine learning techniques with comprehensive data preprocessing, greatly improving shop sales forecasting.

title: Wear Rate Modelling in Bamboo Fibre Polymer Composites by Pin on Pin-on-Disc Method using Tree-based Regression Algorithms
authors: Lavanya M, A.Prasad, C.Ramesh Kumar, G B Santhi, R.Dilli Babu, R.Nandhakumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This study focuses on modeling the wear rate of bamboo fibre reinforced polymer composites machined using the pin-on-disc method. Wear behavior was predicted with the use of machine learning algorithms, including Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), and XGBoost (XGBoost). The models were trained and validated with experimental data. XGBoost algorithm performed the best with the highest R 2 value of 92.22 percent and the best RMSE. Decision Tree also demonstrated competitive accuracy, having the least MAE of 0.1152. The findings establish that tree-based models, especially XGBoost, are effective in predicting wear rate in natural fibre composites accurately. The results of the three regression models of trees, Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), and XG Boost, on predicting the wear rate of bamboo fibre polymer composites using the pin-on-disc technique. XG Boost had the best RMSE (0.2054), which means that it has better predictive accuracy than the other models. The DT also scored fairly well with RMSE of 0.2731 and a minimum MAE of 0.1152. RF and XGBoost had the same value of MAE (0.2263). Regarding R-squared, XG Boost was the best (92.22%), DT (86.25%), and RF (84.16%). In general, XG Boost turned out to be the most efficient model to predict wear rates in the current study.

title: Analysis of Switching Behavior of SiC MOSFETS Driven by an Adaptive Current Source Gate Driver
authors: Tim Lange, Johannes Kuhn, Erik Wehr, Ralf Wunderlich, Stefan Heinen
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Adaptive gate drivers (AGDs) promise to improve the inherent trade-off between switching loss reduction and emitted electromagnetic interference of wide-bandgap power transistors. Additionally, dynamic adjustment to temperature or load can facilitate optimal switching across a wide range of operating conditions. In this paper, a current-source-based AGD is analyzed in its capability to drive SiC MOSFETs. Initially, the switching process is examined in order to derive the requirements for an optimal switching transition. These are, firstly, the quick triggering of reverse recovery, and secondly, ensuring a suitable gate-kelvin-source voltage and a low gate current during the drain-source voltage zero crossing. Next, three gate driving strategies are investigated: constant current reference, a high-low-high pattern and an algorithm-based current sequence. Compared to reference, the simple high-low-high pattern can adhere to the requirements well enough to speed up the switching transition by up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.1 ~\text{ns}(8.5 \%)$</tex> for a given drain-source voltage overshoot. Further, the proposed optimization algorithm mostly outperforms the high-low-high strategy. On average, it improves switching speed by another <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.52 ~\text{ns}(4.3 \%)$</tex> in a wide range of cases. Finally, discrete gate current sequence selection and continuous execution of the optimization algorithm are discussed as approaches for dynamic adaption to operating conditions.

title: Low-Distortion Dual-Cell Power Amplifier with Ultra-High Small Signal Bandwidth
authors: Marziyeh Hajiheidari, Bas Vermulst, Jeroen Van Duivenbode
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a dual-cell hybrid power amplifier with an ultra-high small-signal bandwidth. A control strategy is introduced that maximizes the achievable bandwidth while decoupling the operation of the power-amplifier cells. To validate the concept, a two-phase full-bridge prototype is implemented, with the main switching devices operating at 200 kHz and the auxiliary switching devices at 4 MHz. Step-response tests show an output current rise-time of about 1.5 µs and a settling time of roughly 90 µs in closed-loop operation. When tracking a 64 Hz, 24 A-peak sinusoidal current reference, the amplifier achieves a total harmonic distortion of approximately -100 dB across the first 150 harmonics. It is demonstrated that the approach enables the combination of about 6.45 kW output power and an 8 MHz effective switching frequency while maintaining high conversion efficiency.

title: AI-Driven Close Process Optimization in Global Financial Systems: An ML Approach
authors: Puneet Thakkar, Rahul Chawla
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The monthly financial close for large, multinational companies has become complicated, cumbersome, and prone to errors with ever-increasing regulatory requirements and a volume of data involved. Long cycle times, inconsistent compliance, and limited transparency are a few of the negative results of traditional manual processes. The present work proposes a transformational improvement in the global financial close process through machine learning and an AI-based framework. The analysis of 6,800 close cycles across the Americas, Asia Pac, and EMEA was able to achieve 96.76% prediction accuracy with Support Vector Machine and K-Nearest Neighbors algorithms. Predictive analytics, automated anomaly detection, and resource optimization are performed in the model for predicting outcomes to reduce cycle times. The quantitative findings have indicated that the reduction in closure cycles by 23-35%, improvements in compliance up to a maximum of 18%, and improved error rates above 40% are possible. It therefore demonstrates the ability and efficiency of machine learning in improving the accuracy and efficiency of financial close and, at the same time, provides a reproducible AI-based method for smart close management.

title: Multi-Objective JVM Optimization Framework with Enhanced Machine Learning Techniques: An Automated Approach to Performance Tuning
authors: Dheaneshwar P, Brindha G, Jenitha T
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Java Virtual Machine (JVM) parameter tuning is a crucial part of a performance and memory utilisation optimization of application execution in the enterprise environments. This paper outlines a detailed multi objective optimisation model in which the use of Optuna in self-guided tuning of JVM parameters is made. Our approach simultaneously maximises execution latency and memory usage through Pareto front program analysis, thus dealing with the complex trade-offs with which JVM configuration is replete. The framework incorporates a powerful graphical user interface to monitor and provide the necessary decision to determine optimisation progress in real- time. The experimental findings indicate considerable performance improvement: the automated variant achieves a reduction of 56.4 percent in execution time and a reduction by 78.8 percent of memory consumption as compared to the comparative default JVMs. The system provides exhaustive analytics, such as the impact of the parameters assessment, performance trend assessment, and configuration recommendations, thus, making the instrument available to both non-expert and expert users.

title: Lifecycle-Wide AI Security Enhancement using Generative AI: A Unified Framework for Robustness, Privacy, and Self-Healing
authors: V.V.A.S.Lakshmi, U.Usha Rani, P. V.Sateesh Kumar, A.Pavithra, Ch.Sudharshan Reddy, Bala Veeravatnam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The rapid rise of artificial intelligence (AI) in key industries has created significant security challenges that affect the entire AI process. This includes collecting data, training models, deploying systems, and maintaining them over time. While Generative AI (GAI) provides useful tools like synthetic data generation and adversarial scenario modeling, most current methods focus only on protecting individual stages instead of the entire lifecycle. To fill this gap, this paper presents a unified, end- to-end GAI-enabled security framework aimed at providing ongoing, flexible protection at every stage of AI development. The framework combines high-quality synthetic data generation, realistic adversarial threat simulation, and automated self-healing features to build AI systems that are both resilient and safeguard privacy. Evaluations on a large healthcare dataset show significant improvements, including a 14.7% boost in adversarial strength, under 3.5% difference between real and synthetic data, and a 96% success rate in recovering from performance issues. These results demonstrate the practical benefits and technical importance of incorporating GAI throughout the security lifecycle, providing a scalable and flexible foundation for protecting next-generation AI systems in sensitive and high-risk areas.

title: HCTD3: A Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning Approach for Mixed-Action Resource Allocation in Multi-UAV Cooperative Jamming
authors: Yu Deng, Yong Xu, Chunhui Liu, Rui Yan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: Resource allocation for multi-UAV cooperative jamming in modern electronic warfare faces significant challenges due to high-dimensional mixed action spaces, complex constraints, and dynamic environments. To address this, this paper introduces a hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm, HCTD3. The algorithm mitigates complexity by decomposing the task into two sub-problems: target selection (discrete actions) and power allocation (continuous actions). It employs the Gumbel-Softmax technique for high-level discrete selection and the Twin Delayed DDPG (TD3) algorithm for low-level continuous optimization, enabling efficient learning in the mixed action space. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to traditional optimization and single-layer reinforcement learning methods, HCTD3 achieves a 37.2% average improvement in jamming effectiveness and converges 45% faster, showcasing its superior performance.

title: Integrating Machine Learning with Traditional Tongue Diagnosis for Diabetes Screening
authors: Janeesh J, Jushmitha Jayamurugan, Syed Abu Thahir, Kamalra Subramaniam
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Diabetes mellitus is one of the greatest global health challenges, which is usually silent and may cause the damage to the body. Traditional diagnostic techniques like blood glucose monitoring and lab testing are invasive, time-consuming, and hard to access in low-resource areas. Traditional diagnostic techniques like those in Ayurveda and Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) have long made use of different tongue features (color, coating, and texture). Assessment of these features is used as an indication of the systemic health of the patient. Nevertheless, these methods are subjective and non-standardized. Due to new advancements in artificial intelligence, it is possible to digitize such diagnostics. Through the analysis of tongue images, a deep learning-based framework for noninvasive diabetes detection has been proposed in this paper. The approach uses some preprocessing techniques, extract features and classify the final result through convolutional neural network architectures ResNet50 and VGG16. The experimental results show that ResNet50 has a higher accuracy of 94%, proving that it is more generalized and robust compared to VGG16. Also, a dietary recommendation module is included in the framework to ensure long-term control of the disease. Keywords - Diabetes Mellitus, Tongue Image Analysis, Machine Learning, ResNet50 and VGG16, Non-Invasive Diagnosis

title: An Intelli UbiAware: An Intelligent Autonomic Framework for Context-Aware Ubiquitous Computing and Smart Resource Management
authors: Satyanarayana Nimmala, R Sahith, Vikram Narayandas, K Madan Mohan, Pallati Narsimhulu, Ratnam Dodda
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Ubiquitous computing has emerged as a catalyst for facilitating intelligent, context-aware services in many situations. However, current systems encounter difficulties such as dynamic contextual variations, suboptimal resource allocation, energy inefficiencies, and limited adaptability. To rectify these deficiencies, we offer Intelli UbiAware, an intelligent autonomic framework for context-aware ubiquitous computing and efficient resource management. The methodology consists of three stages: (i) the capture and modelling of multi-layer contexts from diverse data sources, (ii) adaptive decision-making through reinforcement-driven autonomic control, and (iii) fuzzy-based optimization for energy-efficient and sustainable resource allocation. Experimental validation is conducted via the Intel Lab Sensor Dataset and the SmartSantander IoT Dataset, with performance assessed based on latency, throughput, energy consumption, and resource utilization. Findings demonstrate that Intelli UbiAware attains 28% reduced latency, 22% enhanced throughput, 31% energy conservation, and 19% advancement in resource utilization relative to baseline models like LEACH and HEED. In summary, Intelli UbiAware offers a scalable, safe, and sustainable solution for advanced ubiquitous information systems, demonstrating significant relevance in smart cities, healthcare informatics, and intelligent automation.

title: Edge-based Fail-Safe Automation for Air Traffic Control in Remote Airports with Optimized Bandwidth Utilization
authors: Rajasekar L, Srijai Kubendiran, Pongiannan R K, Telugu Maddileti, S. Palanikumar, Brindha R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The Edge-Based Fail-Safe and Bandwidth-Aware Air Traffic Control architecture (EFBA-ATC) system aiming the critical issues in the areas of delays in response times, Unreliable accessibility and heavy data loads. When the Remote Air Traffic controllers (RTS) manage flights operation by acquiring visual feeds and sensor data from the airport in real time, this may lead to delays that might impair safety decisions due to latency. If the central system fails, entire airport networks will lose operations. This study proposes EFBA-ATC, a novel architecture that processes crucial information locally at airports rather than forwarding to all remote centers. The system integrates edge computing nodes with real-time sensor fusion to enable local decision-making, significantly reducing network dependency and response latency. To ensure fault tolerance, EFBA-ATC employs Triple Modular Redundancy (TMR) combined with Byzantine Fault Tolerant (BFT) consensus algorithms, maintaining operational integrity during component failures. To ensure consistent network performance in real time, bandwidth optimization is performed using data prioritization and compression techniques. The simulation-based evaluation, with initial data collection, showed a 70% reduction in response time, a 70% decrease in transmission overhead, and safe, uninterrupted operation during network disruption.

title: Overcoming Barriers to Adopting Peer Instruction
authors: Xingjian (Lance) Gu, Memuna Tariq, Zihan Wu, Barbara J. Ericson

title: Modern, Multi-Tier Apps using Amazon Web Services
authors: Joseph Hummel
publish: Proceedings of the 57th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education V.2
abstract: None

title: ISO/IEC/IEEE International Standard - Systems and software engineering-- Life cycle management--Part 10: Guidelines for systems engineering agility
authors: N/A
publish: N/A
abstract: Systems engineering agility is a strategy-based method for designing, building, sustaining, and evolving purpose-fulfilling creations when knowledge is uncertain and operational environments are dynamic. Strategies are abstractions for what needs to be accomplished and why, without constraints or directions on how to achieve them. This part of ISO/IEC/IEEE 24748 specifies strategic aspects supporting systems engineering agility. It includes guidelines for the application of the strategic aspects as well as relevant examples. Individually and collectively, the aspects can improve capability to deal with uncertain knowledge and dynamic environments.

title: Joint Route Selection and Radio Resources Allocation for Caching in Multi-Hop Networks
authors: Emre Gures, Pavel Mach, Zdenek Becvar
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: In this paper, we focus on a cache-enabled networks, where a content requested by user equipments (UEs) can be delivered by means of multi-hop relaying via unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and/or via other UEs exploiting device-to-device (D2D) communication. For such scenario, we optimize transmission power allocation, bandwidth allocation, and route selection to minimize the content delivery duration. The formulated problem is a mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem and, thus, it is hard to solve. Hence, we first solve the power and bandwidth allocation by a cooperative game among all transmitting nodes involved in the content delivery process and we prove that this game is a potential game. Then, we introduce a fast-converging iterative algorithm employing an approximate better-response mechanism for the resource allocation (i.e., power and bandwidth). After that, we design a low-complexity greedy algorithm jointly handling route selection and power and bandwidth allocation. The algorithm selects transmission routes to deliver the requested contents to the UEs and, after each selection, the resource allocation at the transmitting nodes involved in the content delivery process (i.e., GBS, UAVs, and relaying UEs) is updated. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme reduces the average content delivery duration by up to 23.2% compared to the best-performing benchmark algorithm.

title: Coupling Suppression in Compact Microstrip Lines Using Sinusoidal Geometric Modulation
authors: Hongxin Zhou, Dingfei Ma, Chen Ding, Zhen Zhang, Fan Jiang, Qingfeng Zhang, Yi Fang, Guojun Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Effective suppression of cross coupling in densely integrated transmission lines is crucial in compact electromagnetic systems. Conventional approaches often entail increased structural complexity or reduced fabrication compatibility. In this work, a geometrically driven coupling suppression technique is proposed based on sinusoidal modulation of the transmission line trajectory. This spatial modulation induces a spatially varying complex coupling coefficient, enabling complete destructive interference over one modulation period. Theoretical analysis reveals that the net coupling coefficient follows a zeroth-order Bessel function with respect to the modulation amplitude, allowing precise nulling at designed conditions. Full-wave simulations demonstrate over 30 dB of coupling suppression at the null frequency in a tightly spaced microstrip line pair, along with significantly reduced coupling across the operating band, while maintaining minimal degradation in input matching and near-end crosstalk. Experimental validations on three-line configurations confirm simultaneous suppression of both nearest-neighbor and next-nearest-neighbor coupling, along with efficient recovery of energy into the intended transmission path, in excellent agreement with simulation results.

title: Adaptive Contrastive Learning for Semisupervised Facial Expression Recognition
authors: Bin Sun, Meiqi Liao, Shutao Li, Fuyan Ma, Zhenhua Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Semisupervised deep facial expression recognition (FER) tries to learn better representations from both labeled and unlabeled data to avoid the huge manual labeling cost in the supervised methods. Due to the imbalanced distribution of facial expression data and the varying difficulty in recognizing different expressions, conventional semisupervised FER methods that directly discard low-confidence unlabeled samples may exacerbate the deficiency of the minority classes, and trap the model into the Matthew effect. Therefore, an adaptive contrastive learning-based semisupervised deep facial expression recognition framework is proposed to utilize both high and low confidence unlabeled samples by two different contrastive learning strategies according to an adaptive threshold. The threshold varies from different classes and iterations, considering both the difficulty of different classes and current learning state of the model during the training process. After the adaptive thresholding, the class-aware contrastive learning is applied to the high confidence samples, while the distance-aware contrastive learning is to the low confidence ones. Our proposed method achieves the state-of-the-art performance through extensive experiments on two widely-used datasets RAF-DB and AffectNet.

title: DFCN-CE3: A Three-way Clustering Algorithm Based on Deep-Fusion Clustering Network
authors: Huibing Lin, Jing Zou, Pingxin Wang, Weipeng Zhou
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: As an unsupervised learning method, deep clustering has received widespread attention and shown remarkable results for processing high-dimensional samples in the fields of data mining. However, most of the existing deep clustering algorithms define one cluster by a set with sharp boundary, which fails to capture the uncertainty and ambiguity prevalent in real-world datasets. To address this problem, this paper introduces a contraction-and-expansion based deep fusion three-way clustering network (DFCN-CE3 for short). The proposed method uses deep fusion clustering network to obtain hard clustering result of the universe. Base on the hard clustering result, DFCN-CE3 shrinks each cluster to the core region through a contraction operation, and enlarges each cluster to the support set through an expansion operation. By the contraction–expansion strategy, a three-way clustering result is formed. Comparisons of experimental results with 8 clustering algorithms on 6 data sets validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Synthesized Phantom: From Composition Types to 3D-Printed Versions
authors: Nur Farah Afiqah Asmadi, Aduwati Sali, Nurul Huda Abd Rahman, Suriati Paiman, Muhammad Zamir Mohyedin
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Recent advancements in wireless communication technologies have significantly increased the levels of electromagnetic radiation (EMR) in the surrounding environment. With the rapid adoption of these technologies, public concern regarding their potential impacts on human health has been growing. Tissue-mimicking phantoms are essential tools for experimental validation particularly in the era of fifth-generation (5G) technologies. This review provides a comprehensive overview of the composition, characteristics and techniques for measuring dielectric properties of liquid, semisolid, solid and 3D-printed phantoms in various applications such as specific absorption rate (SAR) testing, implantable antennas and microwave imaging across a wide range of frequencies. The advantages and disadvantages of each phantom are also discussed. Key performance factors, including homogeneity and stability are critically analyzed. While earlier reviews primarily focused on fabrication techniques and dielectric characterization of tissue-emulating phantoms for radio-frequency experimentation, this work extends the literature by providing a unified, comparative analysis across liquid, semisolid, solid, and 3D-printed phantoms, explicitly linking material composition, stability, and homogeneity to application-specific performance, particularly for emerging 5G, millimeter-wave, and sub-terahertz scenarios. Overall, this review aims to guide researchers in the selection, design, and application of phantoms, while identifying research gaps that must be addressed to ensure reliable and standardized testing frameworks across many applications.

title: Point Cloud Based Visual Planning and Servoing for Autonomous Vine Pruning
authors: Fadi Gebrayel, Thomas O'Brien, Martin Mujica, Patrick Danès
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: This paper addresses vision based autonomous vine pruning with robots. The complex structure of vines makes visual servoing difficult due to challenges in feature extraction and 3D pose estimation. A novel approach interweaving visual servoing and vision based planning is proposed. An online planner features a Nonlinear Model Predictive Control to compute on-the-fly suitable 3D waypoints. These are navigated by a Position Based Visual Servoing integrating Iterative Closest Point based point-cloud alignment. Qualitative and quantitative evaluations are conducted on live experiments where a Franka Emika manipulator embedding a eye-in-hand stereo camera performs a sequence of pruning actions on seven increasingly complex vine stocks, in spite of unexpected motion of the vine and/or the robot's base. Outdoor experiments are also carried out in strong wind conditions.

title: Computational Investigation of Abstraction in Claude Monet's Water Lilies through Brushstroke Analysis_supp1-3664028.pdf
authors: Jia Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Claude Monet's late paintings of Water Lilies exhibit stylistic transformations that are often characterized by art historians as increasingly abstract and gesturally expressive. However, it remains challenging to define and systematically identify this stylistic shift. Here, we introduce a machine learning framework for analyzing Monet's evolving brushwork using streamline curves: computational representations that capture the dynamic movement patterns inherent in brushstrokes. From 554 image patches sampled from 47 paintings spanning early (pre-1913) and later (post-1913) periods of Monet's output, we extract streamlines and compute geometric features for each, including smoothness of curvature and directional variability. Each image is represented as a set of streamline feature vectors, a data type referred to as distributional. A new deep neural network architecture named Composition to Attribute (C2A) is designed for classifying distributional data. We hypothesize that Monet's so-called 'abstract' style does not uniformly characterize all late period Water Lilies, and that non-abstract flowers, regardless of period, share similar brushwork qualities. Under these assumptions, building on C2A, weproposeanovel learning paradigm namedDiscover Embedded Group with Asymmetry (DEGA) which enforces a shared distribution of DNN-extracted features for non-abstract flower patches across both pe riods while distinguishing the abstract ones. DEGA reveals a meaningful two-dimensional feature space, where one dimension differentiates abstract from mimetic Water Lilies, while the other separates abstract f lowers from close-up flowers of the early period. Our findings suggest that the so-called 'abstract' qualities of Monet's late style retain certain visual affinities with his earlier approach to depicting close-up floral motifs. When this brushwork is used in more expansive scenes, the depiction of flowers shifts away from realistic renderings of individual petals toward a looser, more allusive expression, conveying a sense of floral presence rather than botanical detail. This study highlights the value of computational analysis for a more accurate understanding of an artist's stylistic development.

title: Curvature-Modulated Fiber-Optic SPR Sensor with Au/GST Composite Coating for Tunable Resonance and Enhanced Refractive Index Sensitivity
authors: Xuhao Ji, Nailiang Yu, Xin Lv, Yu Zhang, Xiaoting Wu, Zhuo Ren, Chunbiao Liu, Xingkai Wang, Wei Jin, Yifan Qin, Zhihai Liu, Libo Yuan
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for modulating the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) response through optical fiber curvature. A plastic-clad silica fiber (PCSF) is used as the sensing platform, with the cladding removed to expose the core. A 50 nm Au layer is deposited followed by a 30 nm Ge2Sb2Te5 (GST) layer to create a composite plasmonic interface. The inclusion of the GST layer enhances the local dielectric contrast near the metal surface, improving the refractive index (RI) sensitivity of the SPR sensor. Unlike conventional fiber-optic SPR sensors, this method allows continuous and reversible modulation of optical coupling by mechanically adjusting the fiber curvature within a range of −1/70 m−1 to 1/70 m−1. This modulation facilitates dynamic tuning of essential resonance characteristics, including resonance wavelength and full width at half maximum (FWHM), without requiring structural modifications or complex functionalization. Experimental results show a resonance wavelength tuning range of 186 nm at a fixed RI of 1.403 RIU. For RI values between 1.333 and 1.403 RIU, the Au/GST-coated sensor exhibits enhanced performance under curvature modulation, with the sensitivity increasing from 5877.1 nm/RIU to 7971.4 nm/RIU and the figure of merit (FOM) improving from 7.9 (−70 m-1) to 45.7 (70 m-1), accompanied by a reduction in FWHM from 746.3 nm to 174.6 nm. This curvature modulation technique offers a flexible, compact, and cost effective means of tuning SPR performance, making it a promising solution for miniaturized, high-performance SPR sensing applications.

title: A Framework to Detect, Classify, and Prioritise Student Quality Defects
authors: Shiman Cui, Paul Denny, Andrew Luxton-Reilly

title: Where are the Disabled Students?: A Literature Review of Disability Inclusion in Computing Education Research
authors: Isabela Figueira, Josahandi M. Cisneros, Jason Lee Weber, Wendy Sanka, Karen Phan, Jennifer Wong-Ma, Stacy M. Branham
publish: Proceedings of the 57th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education V.1
