title: Link Rate Prediction Modeling for MIMO-OFDM Wireless Systems
authors: Yilin Wang, Changzhong Chen, Ping He, Han Lin, Bo Liang, Kui Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: Accurate link rate prediction in MIMO-OFDM wireless systems is essential for adaptive modulation and coding as well as efficient spectrum utilization. This paper proposes a modeling framework combining physical-layer abstraction and data-driven techniques to estimate transmission rates under realistic channel conditions. First, we calibrate the Exponential Effective SNR Mapping (EESM) model parameters on measured datasets without transmit beamforming. Then, we develop an enhanced data-driven estimator to overcome the limitations of traditional EESM, improving robustness and prediction accuracy. Furthermore, in scenarios with transmit beamforming, we design a beamforming-aware rate prediction model based on singular value decomposition and dominant eigenmode selection. Experiments conducted on real-world datasets demonstrate that our proposed models outperform conventional physical-layer abstraction in terms of both accuracy and generalization capability. The proposed framework provides a unified solution for multi-scenario MIMO-OFDM link rate prediction.

title: Identifying Abnormal Behaviors in a Large Crowd using C3D and MobileNetV2
authors: Seguru Samaikya Reddy, G Rahul, T Nischitha, K. Narsimha Reddy
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Monitoring crowds has become more important than ever, especially at busy places like festivals, religious events, and stadiums. In this work, we’ve built a smart system that uses MobileNetV2 to understand how things look in each frame and a 3D CNN (C3D) to catch how movement changes over time. We also apply frame differencing to help highlight motion, and then use an Isolation Forest algorithm to spot anything unusual in the crowd’s behavior. We tested the system using the MOT20 dataset and it performed well in terms of speed and accuracy. What makes this method stand out is how efficiently it works in real-time — without needing expensive equipment — making it a solid fit for real-world crowd monitoring.

title: APO: Metaheuristic Driven Reliability-Aware Task Scheduling in Cloud Environment
authors: Rameshwaraiah Kurupati, S Radhika, Ch Ramya, Ramagalla Suchitra, Rampally Vaishnavi, Thirumalakonda Trinadh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Task scheduling remains a critical challenge in cloud computing, where the dynamic and heterogeneous nature of resources demands intelligent optimization to ensure reliability and efficiency. This study addresses the problem by proposing the Artificial Protozoa Optimizer (APO), a novel bio-inspired metaheuristic that models the adaptive survival and foraging strategies of protozoa to achieve balanced exploration–exploitation during scheduling. The algorithm was implemented and evaluated using CloudSim with Google Cloud workload traces, ensuring a realistic and scalable test environment. Comparative experiments were conducted against established approaches, namely Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA). Results demonstrate that APO consistently achieves superior performance, reducing the VM failure rate by 18.6%, enhancing the task success rate by 22.4%, and improving system throughput by 19.7%. These outcomes confirm APO’s ability to minimize resource underutilization, mitigate execution failures, and maximize task completion under dynamic workloads. By delivering robust, efficient, and fault-tolerant scheduling, APO contributes a significant advancement toward reliable and sustainable cloud infrastructure management, offering promising potential for deployment in next-generation cloud systems.

title: Fisherman Safety Predictions using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Udhaya T, Kavipriya V, Sangavi S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: In addition to the unpredictability of weather and equipment reliability, fishermen face many risks, so safety is of utmost importance. In order to forecast the safety of fishing trips, this project creates a machine learning-based system that combines historical accident data, vessel condition measures, and real-time weather data. Through the analysis of variables including wind speed, wave height, boat age, and engine health, the system generates risk assessments to assist in decision-making. High accuracy and recall are provided by a hybrid model that combines the Random Forest and Logistic Regression methods, guaranteeing that important threats are successfully detected. Practical features like a pre-trip safety checklist, a visual sea route risk map that highlights dangerous areas, and real-time SMS alerts that advise fishermen whether to continue or stay ashore are also included in the system. This solution, which was created with easily accessible technologies like Python and Twilio, improves maritime safety by providing fishing communities with timely, data-driven guidance, which may lower accident rates and save lives along coastal regions.

title: Robust Transformer Autoencoder for MIMO Radar Signal Reconstruction with Dropout
authors: Abdelrahman Abdelsalam Mohammed Osman, Faustino Elias Vumbi, Iliya Abdullahi Aliyu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper presents a Transformer Autoencoder (TAE) architecture for robust signal reconstruction in MIMO radar systems affected by random antenna dropout and noise. The proposed model employs a self-attention-based Transformer encoder to capture temporal correlations across radar pulses and a lightweight decoder to recover complete antenna responses from partially observed data. Unlike conventional interpolation or compressed sensing approaches, the TAE learns complex dependencies between spatial and temporal dimensions, enabling accurate reconstruction even under severe antenna masking and low-SNR conditions. The method is evaluated on a simulated radar dataset comprising 2000 scenarios with varying target counts (1–5) and dropout rates (10%, 30%, 50%). Experimental results show that the proposed approach achieves significantly lower mean-squared error and higher SNR compared with state-of-the-art methods, confirming its effectiveness and gen-eralization capability. These findings demonstrate the potential of Transformer-based models to enhance reliability and performance in real-world MIMO radar signal processing.

title: Applying Transfer Learning and Deep Learning Methods to Stroke Prediction
authors: Basi Reddy.A, Sandhya.S, Mokshitha.N.V, Pavan Sai Reddy.S, Leela Tarangini.N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Stroke is one of the leading causes of death and disability worldwide, with ischemic stroke caused by a blockage in blood flow and hemorrhagic stroke caused by a blood vessel rupture. Early prediction is necessary to reduce mortality, but identification is challenging due to mild symptoms and highly uneven data, of which stroke patients comprise a small percentage. The objectives of this research are to: (1) use Random Under-Sampling (RUS) and Expectation-Maximization (EM) imputation to address class imbalance in stroke datasets; (2) develop and evaluate deep learning models (CNN, ANN, and DNN) for stroke risk prediction; and (3) investigate whether transfer learning can further improve predictive performance. The tests were conducted using the Kaggle Cerebral Stroke dataset, and the assessment metrics included accuracy, F1-score, AUC, G-Mean, false negative rate (FNR), and false positive rate (FPR). The proposed transfer learning-enhanced deep neural network (TL-DNN) achieved a 95.9% accuracy, an AUC of 0.959, an F1-score of 0.959, and a reduced FNR to 0.144, outperforming the CNN, ANN, and DNN baselines. These findings demonstrate that when combined with deep learning and imbalance handling, transfer learning significantly enhances stroke prediction capacity and presents a viable approach for early detection in clinical practice.

title: AI Powered Answer Sheet Evaluator using OCR and Large Language Models
authors: Niran Subramanian, Joseph Anthoni R, Hareshkumar G, K. Tharageshwari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper introduces an alternative approach to the long-standing difficulties faced in conventional academic grading, particularly for descriptive and open-ended student responses. Traditional evaluation practices, although widely used, are often criticized for being time-consuming, inconsistent across evaluators, and increasingly impractical in classrooms with large student numbers. To overcome these challenges, the proposed framework integrates Optical Character Recognition (OCR) for digitizing handwritten content with the contextual reasoning ability of Large Language Models (LLMs). OCR technology is applied to convert written answers into editable digital form, while the LLM interprets meaning, evaluates correctness, and generates structured feedback aligned with reference rubrics. This dual-layer strategy is designed to improve efficiency, reduce subjectivity, and provide learners with more immediate and constructive feedback. Beyond system design, the paper also examines the effectiveness of the approach by considering the reliability of OCR across varied handwriting styles and the ability of LLMs to produce grading results comparable to human teachers. At the same time, the study highlights essential concerns such as algorithmic bias, data security, and the necessity of maintaining human oversight to preserve academic fairness and accountability. By balancing the benefits of automation with the irreplaceable role of educators, the proposed solution is positioned not as a substitute for teachers but as a supportive tool that can streamline evaluation, reduce workload, and enhance the quality of learning outcomes.

title: Detection of Degradation with Junction Temperature Monitor and Extended Kalman Filter During Operation of Converters
authors: Michael Gleissner, Mark-M. Bakran
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The junction temperature monitor, based on the internal gate resistance as temperature sensitive electrical parameter, enables the measurement of the semiconductor temperature during normal converter operation. The measured temperature signal and the model-based operating point-dependent power dissipation are used as input variables for an extended Kalman filter, which estimates the thermal resistances of a multistage, one-dimensional network model. The network model is based on different time constants that correspond to either near-chip or near-cooling system layers in the thermal model. Utilizing simulations and hardware measurements on an IGBT inverter, it has been demonstrated that the extended Kalman filter possesses the capability to identify the location at which a degradation of the thermal resistance has occurred within the cooling path.

title: Plant Growth Monitoring System using Image Processing
authors: Pradeep Nayak, Lavanya Moger, Navya Y.R, Nikitha Shetty, Sukanya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Keeping tabs on crop health pretty much every day counts for a lot in farming these days. It keeps productivity going steady, without all those wild swings. And it really supports that long-term sustainability farmers are after. The usual ways to check plants involve too much hands-on work. They take up time. Errors from people happen easily. All that makes them tough for big operations. This work looks at a system for monitoring plant growth. It uses image processing to handle things automatically. The setup assesses how plants are developing and staying healthy. It grabs images of the plants first. Then it does some preprocessing. Segmentation comes next. Feature extraction follows to check details like leaf size. Color plays a role too. Structural changes get noted. A kind of virtual method measures height. That tracks trends over periods of time. It lines them up against standard charts for growth. When something seems off, alerts pop up. Farmers can act fast to fix issues. Tests on this show solid results. Accuracy holds up well. Reliability is there. Manual labour drops quite a bit. Efficiency goes up as a result. Overall, the approach fits right into precision agriculture. It backs sustainable ways of doing things. Resources get used better. Crop yields improve in the end.

title: Dual Defend: Secure ATM Access with Layered Authentication
authors: M. Jamunarani, Anitha Sree R, Sreemathi E, Sukitha S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: As the world becomes more dependent on ATMs for transactions, strong security protocols are necessary to avoid fraud and unauthorized access. Conventional PIN-based authentication is susceptible to attacks like card skimming, PIN theft, and unauthorized withdrawals. To overcome these challenges, this paper suggests an advanced ATM authentication system that incorporates biometric fingerprint recognition, IoT, RFID, and GSM technologies to enhance security and enhance user experience. The system uses a two-factor authentication process, wherein users initially insert their RFID-based ATM card, which sends a real-time alert to their registered mobile number for verification. After approval, users have the option of entering their PIN or fingerprint authentication, providing an additional layer of security. Through the use of RFID-based card verification and biometric authentication, the system is able to prevent card trapping and unauthorized access, with transactions being carried out only by authorized users. Moreover, GSM-based real-time alerts provide security, enabling users to track and manage their transactions. Cost-effective and scalable in its design, the system can easily be integrated with existing ATM infrastructure, making it a viable solution for banks and financial institutions. Using IoT-based authentication and dual-factor security procedures, this system sets the platform for future improvements like AI-enabled fraud detection, and blockchain-secured transaction validation. As new threats emerge from the cyber front, embracing newer and more dynamic methods of authentication will be paramount in providing safe and fraud-free banking transactions.

title: Machine Learning-Enhanced Management Information Systems for Strategic Management Decision-Making
authors: Urmi Haldar, Md Mohibur Rahman, Mohammad Hasibul Hasan, Latul Hasan, Md Anamul Islam, Hriday Chandra Shil
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Management Information Systems (MIS) enhance strategic management by organizing data, data analysis, and decision support tools. In contrast, standard MIS frameworks often offer only descriptive or diagnostic analytics, diminishing their usefulness to dynamic strategic issue solutions. This study aims to explore how Machine Learning (ML) methods may be incorporated into MIS to enhance strategic management decision-making. Based on a structured consumer demographics and financial information dataset, the research uses two ML approaches — Random Forest for credit risk assessment and K-Means for segmentation. The outputs are set into MIS Dashboards to highlight actionables for the management ultimately. These findings demonstrate that ML integration provides value to MIS by providing predictive and prescriptive models, greater predictability of choices, and supporting data-driven strategic actions. This study contributes to the current growth of the artificial intelligence MIS sector by offering a pragmatic approach that mixes machine learning with strategic management procedures.

title: Empowering Learners with Dyscalculia through Airwriting Techniques
authors: Divya Chennupalle, Desham Mahitha, G Nithin, Penumarty Krishna Mohan, Supriya M.
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: An inability to comprehend numbers and perform mathematical tasks is known as dyscalculia. As per surveys, around 3% to 7% of school children are affected by this and require targeted support and intervention. By using hand gestures and air-writing, a computer vision-based web app can offer a more intuitive, hands-on way to understand numbers - something that could really help students connect with math on their own terms. This work enables real-time hand tracking by Media Pipe, and machine learning and deep learning models are integrated to guarantee precise handwritten numerical input identification and classification. The application is user-friendly and accessible by anyone. Among the proposed models, CNN+LSTM achieves the best results, with an accuracy of 99.08%. The solution thus obtained offers an adaptive, accessible and inclusive resource designed to help individuals with dyscalculia by improving their arithmetic skills through the integration of computer vision and artificial intelligence techniques.

title: Low-Voltage Ride-Through Operation of a Modular DC-DC Converter Water Electrolyzer Power Supply
authors: Fadi Abughazaleh, Rik W. De Doncker
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The operation of power converters during grid faults can lead to blackouts if their fault responses are not coordinated. When studying the converter's response to grid faults, the operational constraints of the load must also be considered. This is important in the case of water electrolyzers, as they have strict minimum loadings and maximum ramp rates. In this paper, the operation of an isolated DC-DC converter supplying an electrolyzer from a medium voltage direct current grid is optimized during low-voltage grid faults. A controller is proposed that leverages the modularity of the converter to maintain softswitching operation of the power supply during faults, and to keep the current supplied to the electrolyzer above its minimum loading during low-voltage faults.

title: Loss-Optimal Modulation for an MMC-Based Triple-Active-Bridge Topology
authors: Diego Vera, Maurice Roes, George Papafotiou
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a loss-optimal modulation strategy for an MMC-based triple-active-bridge (TAB) converter that guarantees zero-voltage switching (ZVS). A switching pattern that blends penta phase-shift (PPS) and pulse-amplitude control (PAC) is proposed, and a generalized harmonic approximation (GHA)-based optimization is formulated to minimize total losses using device-calibrated switching and conduction loss models under power-balance and ZVS constraints. The optimization is solved offline over a grid spanning the operating space (power setpoints and dc-link voltages), and the resulting angles are stored in look-up tables for online deployment. Simulations demonstrate up to 44 % lower total losses than Phase-Shift Modulation and PPS, as well as lower conduction losses than PAC. In addition, the method expands the feasible operating region of the converter to power points that are not supported by PAC.

title: Comparative Study of Traditional and Hybrid Machine Learning Model for Heart Disease Prediction
authors: Sivva Yalamarthi, Krishna Nukala, Shilpa Adla, Hemanth Reddy Manasani, N. Nagasoudhamani, Dadinaboina A.K.Rao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of heart disease continues to be a major healthcare priority, especially given the complex nature and limited availability of medical data. In response, this research introduces a hybrid machine learning methodology that merges dimensionality reduction, patient grouping, and uncertainty-based classification. An autoencoder is first used to generate a lower-dimensional set of meaningful features from the raw data. These refined representations are then processed through clustering techniques to identify inherent subgroup patterns within the dataset. For the final prediction stage, Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) is applied, and its performance is enhanced using Natural Gradient Boosting (NGBoost), which delivers confidence estimates along with classification results. Tests conducted on a standard heart disease dataset show substantial improvements in metrics such as accuracy, F1-score, and AUC over conventional techniques. By combining modern feature learning with probabilistic decision-making, the proposed system improves diagnostic reliability and contributes to more informed and dependable medical assessments.

title: A Cloud-based Model for End-to-End DSCSA Compliance in Pharmacy Inventory Management
authors: Rajesh Karvannan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Drug Supply Chain Security Act (DSCSA) compliance protocols in more than 9,000 retail pharmacies and 11 micro-fulfilment centers for pharmacy prescription management platform aligns. The platform provides automated drug replenishment, real-time inventory monitoring, and end-to-end product authentication. The proposed Hybrid Ephemeral Diffie-Hellman (ECDH) with Key Encapsulation Mechanism (KEM) facilitates secure transfer of T3 data, lot-level traceability, suspect product investigation methodologies, and product serialization and verification design and validation at the package level. The integration collaborated with legal, compliance, and third-party serialization solution suppliers to be DSCSA-ready prior to the federal deadline. System testing, performance engineering, and quality assurance maintained RxI scalability and operational integrity even when under extreme stress. The study offers an accessible DSCSA compliance strategy that enhances patient safety, regulatory compliance, and supply chain visibility without disrupting pharmacy processes. The novel method have the encryption time of 2 sec as well as decryption time of 0.1 sec which is good compared to the existing techniques.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Mammogram-based Breast Cancer Detection Techniques
authors: Kumari Jelli, Dr.Pavan Kumar Pagadala
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Breast Cancer (BC) is a life-threatening disease where abnormal cell growth in the breast can metastasize if not detected early. Mammography (MG) is widely recognized as one of the most effective imaging techniques for early BC detection; however, accurate diagnosis remains challenging due to technical limitations and variations in imaging quality. This survey systematically reviews 25 recent research studies on BC detection using mammogram images, focusing on parameters such as analytical tools, performance metrics, techniques, and publication trends. The reviewed works are categorized into Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), Transfer Learning (TL), and hybrid approaches. The review identifies prevalent challenges, including model generalization issues, dataset limitations, and performance inconsistencies across studies. The analysis highlights existing research gaps and outlines potential directions for developing more accurate and robust breast cancer detection models. The insights aim to guide future research toward designing efficient methodologies that enhance early diagnosis and clinical outcomes. The study emphasizes the technical significance of integrating advanced computational approaches to improve the reliability and accuracy of breast cancer detection in mammography.

title: Resilient Cloud Architectures with AI Agents for Enhancing Cybersecurity in Health Information Systems
authors: Anjan Gundaboina, Abhilash K S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The growing adoption of electronic health records (EHRs), Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) devices and cloud-hosted platforms have not only improved healthcare efficiency but also expanded the cybersecurity vulnerabilities by expanding the attack surface. This highlights the need for resilient, adaptive and robust security frameworks in cloud environments. This study presents a resilient cloud architecture with AI agents for enhancing cybersecurity in healthcare information systems. The framework integrates an Isolation Forest (iForest) as a first-layer anomaly detector and XGBoost classifier for supervised intrusion detection, forming a two-layered defense mechanism. The iForest module isolates abnormal traffic patterns and filters potential intrusions, while the XGBoost classifier performs fine-grained classification of retained traffic flows. Together, this hybrid design minimizes false alarms, reduces misclassifications and ensures that benign and attack traffic are accurately distinguished in real time. Using the CIC IoMT 2024 dataset, the hybrid framework achieved an accuracy of 98.48%, a precision of 99.23%, a recall of 98.85%, and an F1-score of 99.04%, outperforming standalone baselines. ROC analysis further confirmed the framework’s superior detection capability with an AUC of 0.99. The framework’s layered adaptability and scalability make it well-suited for securing sensitive medical data and ensuring the continuity of healthcare services.

title: Applications of Deep Learning in Medical Imaging: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Yash Bhardwaj, Pranay Meshram
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Medical imaging is a lifeline of contemporary healthcare, but conventional analysis techniques are frequently hampered by manual reading, inconsistency, and subjectivity. Deep learning (DL) has become an effective answer, streamlining operations such as detection, segmentation, and classification to improve diagnosis accuracy and productivity. The current review presents an in-depth evaluation of DL applications in primary imaging modalities, namely X-ray, CT, MRI, ultrasound, and histopathology. We outline the application of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), generative adversarial networks (GANs), and transformer models, with emphasis on their functions to address varied clinical problems. We also critically review enduring challenges like data paucity, model interpretability, and clinical integration hurdles. We conclude by stipulating promising future directions like explainable AI, multimodal learning, and privacy-preserving methodologies that are key to narrowing the space between research ingenuity and actual clinical implementation.

title: Hybrid Eye Disease Prediction using Fundus Images and Patient Metadata in MATLAB
authors: S. Sheeba Jeya Sophia, Kandi Naga Pavithra, Guttikonda Ajaykumar, Nimmakayala Manasa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Early detection of diseases of the eye is necessary to avoid the loss of vision and provide early intervention. The majority of automated diagnostics systems rely only on retinal fundus images without taking into consideration other important clinical data, like patient age, gender, blood pressure, and history of diabetes. This restriction can decrease the precision of disease forecasting models. We report a mix-method of visual characteristics of fundus pictures with formal patient data in this paper to improve the diagnostic outcomes. The system is coded in the MATLAB language, with pretrained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) being used to extract features and machine learning methods being applied to clinical data. The two sets of features are then fused and categorized through support vector machines (SVM). Tests using the ODIR-5K data show that the use of patient metadata in conjunction with image features provides a high level of accuracy in classification as compared to the image- only models. The novelty of this work lies in its lightweight, explainable fusion framework, making it suitable for deployment in low-resource or rural healthcare environments.

title: Physical Layer Authentication Scheme Based on Compressive Sensing under the Massive MIMO
authors: Yuemei Wu, Hang Zhang, Liqi Zhuang, Fei Ji
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: In Massive MIMO communication systems, the channel matrix has a large dimension, resulting in high complexity of physical layer authentication. This paper proposes using compressive sensing to reduce the dimensionality of the channel matrix, which greatly reduces authentication overhead while maintaining high authentication performance. Specifically, the channel is modelled, taking into account antenna coupling, antenna correlation, channel correlation, and channel fading. Then, PCA and SVD are used to reduce the dimensionality of the channel matrix. Theoretical derivation was conducted on the performance of the authentication scheme. The simulation results show that the proposed scheme reduces the cost by about 98% while ensuring the same authentication performance.

title: Real-Time FPGA-Based Hardware-Algorithm Co-Design for Monocular Visual Odometry on Edge Devices
authors: Li-Yang Huang, Yu-Kai Hsieh, Shao-Yi Chien
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Spatial computing has become a cornerstone of consumer electronics in the metaverse era, powering augmented reality (AR), virtual reality (VR) head-mounted displays (HMDs), and smart glasses. A key enabling technology for these mobile platforms is visual odometry (VO), which supports accurate motion tracking for seamless navigation and interaction. However, deploying deep learning-based VO on resource-constrained edge devices remains challenging due to high computational complexity, memory usage, and power demands. Moreover, critical operations such as feature matching, triangulation, and nonlinear optimization are notoriously intensive for embedded processors, underscoring the need for application-specific acceleration. This work presents a hardware-algorithm co-designed VO acceleration system for edge deployment, implemented on a Xilinx UltraScale+ MPSoC ZCU104. The system integrates an ARM Cortex-A53 processor, a neural network accelerator, and custom modules for feature matching and pose refinement. With hardware-aware algorithmic optimizations, the proposed design achieves a 255.6× speedup in neural inference, 13.7× acceleration for geometric modules, and an additional 2.1× gain through task-level parallelism, sustaining 30.6 FPS in real time. Compared to existing FPGA-based VO designs, our system offers the highest localization accuracy while maintaining real-time performance, demonstrating its practical viability for spatial computing in real-world scenarios.

title: Dielectric Breakdown Characteristics of Silicone Gel for (U)WBG Power Modules Under AC, DC, and High-Frequency Square Wave Stress
authors: Pujan Adhikari, Ya Sun, Mona Ghassemi, Jun Hu, Jinliang He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: As the adoption of (ultra) wide bandgap ((U)WBG) power modules accelerate, ensuring reliable dielectric performance in soft encapsulation materials such as silicone gel (SG) has become a pressing challenge. Existing studies on SG have primarily focused on partial discharge (PD) and electrical treeing under DC or low-frequency AC excitation, with limited attention to dielectric breakdown—despite its critical role in defining insulation failure thresholds. Moreover, few efforts have explored the effects of high-frequency waveforms that closely mirror the fast-switching transients typical of practical (U)WBG applications. This study investigates the dielectric breakdown characteristics of SG under three voltage stress conditions: DC, 60 Hz sinusoidal AC, and high-frequency bipolar square waveforms (10–50 kHz) with a fixed 50 ns rise time. Experimental results reveal a significant, frequency-dependent reduction in breakdown voltage under square wave stress, underscoring the vulnerability of SG to rapid voltage reversals. A two-parameter Weibull statistical analysis further quantifies this degradation, showing increasingly clustered failure distributions at higher frequencies. The breakdown behavior is interpreted through the interplay of space charge dynamics and the time-dependent self-healing response of SG. These findings highlight the importance of accounting for waveform characteristics—not just field strength—when evaluating insulation reliability in UWBG power modules and provide a data-driven basis for future encapsulation design strategies.

title:
STaR-PM: An Interpretable Spatiotemporal Transfer Learning Framework for PM
                    <sub>2.5</sub>
                    Retrieval Using Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks
authors: Mingxiang Hao, Bin Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate monitoring of ground-level PM2.5 is essential for air quality management, yet sparse in-situ observations limit large-scale surveillance. Although satellite-based retrieval has become indispensable, existing methods often struggle to simultaneously achieve high resolution, high accuracy, and physical interpretability under spatiotemporally heterogeneous conditions. To address these challenges, we propose STaR-PM, an interpretable spatiotemporal adaptive framework for PM2.5 retrieval. The core of STaR-PM is an attention-augmented improved Kolmogorov–Arnold Network (iKAN), which represents the input–output relationship through variable-wise spline-based nonlinear response functions. This structure enables direct inspection of feature-specific effects and reveals regime-dependent, physically interpretable relationships between satellite observations, meteorological drivers, and PM2.5 concentrations. To enhance robustness and generalization across regions and seasons, spatiotemporal transfer learning is integrated, allowing shared low-level representations to adapt to diverse spatiotemporal regimes. STaR-PM achieves superior performance, with an R2 of 0.89 at 1-hour/0.05◦ resolution and 0.84 at 10-minute/0.02◦ resolution, outperforming multiple baseline models. Sensitivity analyses further demonstrate stable behavior under extreme pollution levels, varying cloud conditions, and across daytime and nighttime illumination regimes. Interpretability analyses based on iKAN response functions and interaction diagnostics identify key physical drivers, and elucidate their regime-dependent impacts on PM2.5. Overall, STaR-PM effectively reconciles accuracy, resolution, generalization, and interpretability, providing a practical and physically grounded solution for large-scale, near-real-time air quality monitoring. Our source codes are available at https://github.com/HaoMingxiang/STaR-PM.

title: 50 Years of Automated Face Recognition
authors: Minchul Kim, Anil Jain, Xiaoming Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Over the past five decades, automated face recognition (FR) has progressed from handcrafted geometric and statistical approaches to advanced deep learning architectures that now approach, and in many cases exceed, human performance. This paper traces the historical and technological evolution of FR, encompassing early algorithmic paradigms through to contemporary neural systems trained on extensive real and synthetically generated datasets. We examine pivotal innovations that have driven this progression, including advances in dataset construction, loss function formulation, network architecture design, and feature fusion strategies. Furthermore, we analyze the relationship between data scale, diversity, and model generalization, highlighting how dataset expansion correlates with benchmark performance gains. Recent systems have achieved near-perfect large-scale identification accuracy, with the leading algorithm in the latest NIST FRTE 1:N benchmark reporting a False Negative Identification Rate (FNIR) of 0.15 percent at False Positive Identification Rate (FPIR) of 0.001 on a gallery of over 10 million identities . Larger galleries increase false positive rates and deployments at greater scales will see higher error rates. We delineate key open problems and emerging directions, including scalable training, multi-modal fusion, synthetic data, and interpretable recognition frameworks.

title: Contouring Error-Bounded Control for Biaxial Switched Linear Systems
authors: Meng Yuan, Ye Wang, Chris Manzie, Zhezhuang Xu, Tianyou Chai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Biaxial motion control systems are widely employed in manufacturing industries, where improving throughput and reducing machine costs are critical goals. To achieve these, lightweight materials are increasingly being used in structural components, though this often introduces higher flexibility in the machine links, leading to position-dependent precision loss in the end-effector. This article addresses the challenge of maintaining contouring accuracy in such systems by proposing a novel contouring error-bounded control algorithm for biaxial switched linear systems. The algorithm employs model predictive control (MPC) to enforce state, input, and contouring error constraints across different system modes, even when mode switching is not known in advance. While the exact switching signal is unknown, the controller assumes knowledge of the minimum dwell time the system remains in each mode. The proposed algorithm guarantees recursive feasibility and ensures closed-loop system stability. The effectiveness of the method is validated through a high-fidelity simulation of a dual-drive industrial laser machine, demonstrating that the contouring error is consistently maintained within the specified tolerance.

title: A CNN network for coronary chronic total occlusion state classification using image data
authors: Zi-tong Guo, Liangliang Liu, Haoyan Jiang, Jing Tao, Yining Yang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Chronic total occlusion (CTO) is a critical determinant of treatment efficacy in coronary artery disease, but its accurate diagnosis remains heavily reliant on the expertise of experienced physicians. The scarcity and complexity of annotated CTO image data present significant challenges for conventional deep learning methods. Therefore, this study presents a prior knowledge-based network (PKNet) that integrates physicians' expertise with an asymmetric fusion mechanism to enhance CTOdiagnostic performance. PKNet dynamically fuses image features and structured prior knowledge through a cross-attention block, which improves feature representation and classification accuracy. Evaluated on a multi-institutional dataset of 510 CTO patients and an independent external validation set, PKNet achieves an AUC of 80.02%, a sensitivity of 80.28%, and a specificity of 81.03%. External validation further confirms the generalization capability of PKNet, with anAUC of 77.56%. Ablation studies confirm the positive contribution of prior knowledge, while visual analysis demonstrates strong alignment between model attention and clinical insights. The proposed framework presents a promising computational approach for CTO classification, reducing dependence on large annotated datasets while improving interpretability. These findings warrant further validation in prospective clinical settings to assess their potential for aiding clinical decision-making.

title: Rotatable Antenna-Enhanced Beamforming: Signal Enhancement and Interference Suppression
authors: Jie Feng, Zhenbing Liu, Junjie Dai, Hongbin Chen, Fangjiong Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Conventional beamforming with fixed-orientation antenna (FOA) arrays often struggles to effectively enhance signal and/or suppress interference due to significant variations in antenna directive gains across different steering angles. To overcome this limitation, this paper investigates the rotatable antenna (RA)-enhanced beamforming by leveraging the new spatial degrees of freedom (DoFs) via antenna orientation optimization. Specifically, the antenna rotation angle vector (ARAV) and antenna weight vector (AWV) are jointly optimized to maximize the minimum array gain over signal directions, while constraining the maximum array gain over interference directions. For the special single-/double-beam forming case, the optimal ARAV is derived in closed-form, which reveals the relationship between the antenna rotation angles and the antenna directive gain. For the special case of single-beam forming without interference, the optimal ARAV is derived in closed-form with the maximum ratio combining (MRC) beamformer applied to the AWV. For the general multi-beam forming case, we propose an efficient alternating optimization (AO) algorithm to obtain a high-quality suboptimal solution by alternatively optimizing the ARAV and AWV in an iterative manner. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed RA-based scheme significantly outperforms the traditional FOA-based and isotropic antenna (IA)-based schemes in terms of array gain.

title: ISO/IEC/IEEE International Standard - Systems and software engineering -- Development and production of instructional videos
authors: N/A
publish: N/A
abstract: This document provides requirements and guidance for the effective planning, design, and development of instructional video for information technology systems, products and services. Videos can present instructions for installation, operation, maintenance, and disposal for skilled or unskilled users. This document includes the use of video, interactive or hypervideo, animation, and virtual or augmented reality to explain how to use software and systems including hardware. This document covers both short video segments and the use of video in larger information products. Instructional videos can include concepts, instructional steps, and reference material. This document specifies content elements, structure, and use of media, including music, narration, captions, titles, and graphics. This document is applicable to instructional video developers, including a variety of specialists such as: information architects who plan the structure and format of information products, user experience specialists, customer experience specialists and business analysts who identify the tasks that the intended users can perform, reviewers/testers of instructional videos, graphic designers with expertise in electronic media, and experts working together to design the usage and presentation of the system or service. This document is also a reference for those with other roles and interests in the process of developing instructional videos.

title: StructFuse-Net: A Structure-Aware Multimodal Fusion Network for Geometry-Consistent Optical–SAR Image Segmentation
authors: Xin Li, Xianbin Wen Haixia Xu, Xinyu Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Multimodal remote sensing segmentation remains challenging due to modality discrepancies, structural inconsistencies, and sensor-induced noise, which often lead to blurred boundaries and geometric distortions. To address these issues, we propose StructFuse-Net, a structure-aware multimodal fusion framework for geometry-consistent optical–SAR image segmentation. The framework comprises three complementary modules: (1) a Structure-Driven Directional Fusion (SDDF) module that enhances low-level representations by suppressing speckle noise and reinforcing geometric cues through cross-modal attention and wavelet-based directional decomposition; (2) a Semantic Refinement and Alignment Fusion (SRAF) module that improves high-level consistency by refining channel–spatial responses and aligning cross-modal semantics via residual guidance and frequency-aware enhancement; and (3) a Structure-Aware Cross-Level Fusion (SACLF) module that connects low- and high-level features through adaptive gating and orthogonal directional encoding, ensuring multi-scale geometry-consistent feature representation. Extensive experiments on the WHU-OPT-SAR and YESeg-OPT-SAR datasets demonstrate that StructFuse- Net consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving overall accuracies of 82.7% and 81.5% with mean IoUs of 54.5% and 62.4%, respectively. Moreover, experiments on a cloud-disturbed subset of the Pohang dataset further validate the robustness of StructFuse-Net under severe optical degradation, where it maintains coherent geometry and boundary continuity with smaller performance degradation than competing methods. Beyond quantitative improvements, the proposed network delivers superior boundary fidelity and spatial coherence, particularly for elongated and structure-sensitive objects such as roads and rivers. These results indicate that StructFuse-Net provides a robust and generalizable solution for geometry-consistent optical–SAR semantic segmentation.

title: Reversible Data Hiding for JPEG Images Based on Gap-Driven Histograms Generation with Coefficient-Wise Selection
authors: Qi Chang, Lukai Zhang, Haorui Wu, Mengyao Xiao, Ye Yao, Xiaolong Li, Yao Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Reversible data hiding (RDH) for JPEG images remains relatively underexplored, with key challenges lying in coefficient selection and modification strategies. Existing methods select coefficients for embedding through block-wise or frequency-band-based operations, resulting in coarse-grained decisions that constrain embedding performance. In this paper, a novel RDH scheme for JPEG images based on gap-driven histograms generation with coefficient-wise selection is proposed. First, a multi-metric weighted complexity and coefficient-wise selection approach is proposed, integrating four local feature criteria to assess each coefficient individually, enabling more precise per-coefficient selection. Then, a gap-driven adaptive multi-histogram generation strategy is introduced, leveraging gap pairs to minimize shifting distortion by segmenting histograms via bisection and avoiding modifications to high-magnitude coefficients. Experimental results confirm that the proposed method achieves improved visual quality and more efficient file size control compared to existing state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Design and Experimental Validation of a Macro-Micro Robot With Cable-Driven and Underactuated Joints
authors: Michele Tonan, Matteo Bottin, Daniele Businaro, Alberto Doria, Giulio Rosati
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: This paper presents the design, modeling, and experimental validation of a macro-micro robot featuring a 2-degrees-of-freedom (DOF) serial underactuated mechanism mounted on a cable-driven pulley. The main contribution consists in demonstrating that, by ensuring a specific mass distribution, the system achieves differential flatness, enabling accurate point-to-point and via-point trajectory planning without feedback from the passive joint. The dynamic model incorporates damping effects and is validated both numerically and experimentally. Results confirm the feasibility and benefits of the proposed system in terms of dexterity, trajectory control, and reduction of workspace occupation, particularly when obstacles are present.

title: Consensus Control of Multiagent Systems Under DoS Attacks: A Dynamic-Key-Based Secure Scheme
authors: Yang Zhang, Lifeng Ma, Chen Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: In this article, the secure consensus control problem is investigated for discrete-time multiagent systems (DTMASs) subjected to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, where a model-free controller is proposed based on the Q-learning (QL) method. In an attack-free case, a dynamic decaying encryption key is designed to enable secure state transmission over communication channels through quantization-based encryption to prevent unauthorized access. Under DoS attacks, the system switches to a safe mode that partially halts communication, where the key transforms into a local scaling parameter to prevent quantizer saturation through dynamic expansion. The QL-driven algorithm is introduced to autonomously synthesize control gain matrices, without requiring system dynamics models. Moreover, sufficient conditions on the frequency and duration of DoS attacks are derived to ensure that the model-free controller guarantees consensus in DTMASs. Finally, simulation studies involving highly maneuverable aircraft technology vehicles (HiMATVs) are conducted, demonstrating that DTMASs equipped with the proposed approach exhibit significantly enhanced attack resistance compared to conventional methods.

title: Multi-Functional Reflection Modulation Design for Multi-RIS Empowered Symbiotic Radios
authors: Chao Zhang, Hu Zhou, Ying-Chang Liang, Boon-Hee Soong, Chau Yuen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: This paper investigates a multi-user multiple-input single-output (MU-MISO) symbiotic radio (SR) system empowered by multiple reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs). In this system, each RIS adopts a multi-functional reflection modulation scheme to simultaneously transmit data from Internet of Things (IoT) sensors and enhance the primary transmission. However, allocating all reflected power exclusively to IoT data transmission could compromise the capability of RISs to enhance the primary transmission. To address this issue, we propose a flexible power allocation scheme that partitions the power reflected from the RISs into two components: one for enhancing the primary transmission and the other for supporting IoT communication, fully exploiting the multi-functional potential of RISs. Subsequently, we formulate a joint optimization problem aimed at minimizing the transmit power subject to the rate requirements for both primary and RIS transmissions, involving the joint optimization of the beamforming at the base station (BS) and the reflection modulation design at the RISs. Given the non-convex constraints and the coupled variables within the problem, we develop an alternating optimization algorithm combined with difference-of-convex programming to efficiently solve the problem and determine the power allocation scheme. Furthermore, to reduce computational complexity, we consider uniform power allocation across all reflecting elements and introduce weighted parameters to flexibly balance between assisting primary transmission and supporting IoT communication. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed power allocation scheme effectively balances the demands of the primary and RIS transmission, significantly reducing the required transmit power.

title: A Scalable and Secure Cloud Framework for AI/ML Workload Management using Crayfish and Beluga Whale Optimization
authors: Nagabhushanam Bheemisetty
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: the rapid incorporation of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Deep Learning (DL) applications over cloud ecosystems has risen the need for effectual workload scheduling and scalable parallel computing models. The key objective of this research is to improve the security, efficiency and scalability of workloads in cloud environments using DL model. For achieving optimal computing proficiency, the paper presents an adaptive resource allocation model that requires the diverse and evolving needs of DL models. Effective allocation reduces latency and prevents resource conflict, ensures steady throughput under high demand conditions. The proposed system combines advanced parallel computing models using Crayfish Optimization Algorithm (COA) for resource tuning and adaptive scheduling. COA enhances computational stability and convergence speed by balancing the stages of exploration and exploitation, guarantees intelligent decision making. The Beluga Whale Optimization (BWO) algorithm ensures secure and optimal workload distribution over virtual nodes to further minimizing the risks of data leakage and unauthorized access. These optimization driven modules work together to enhance the operation efficiency and data security of DL based cloud processing. With higher accuracy and throughput rates, the proposed model Adaptive Batch Stream Scheduling and Management Model (ABSS-SMM) performs well. This study extends cloud based DL infrastructures by generating a scalable and secure optimization driven architecture.

title: Design and Simulation of Core Image Processing Techniques Using MATLAB and Verilog
authors: Bala Sindhuri Kandula, G. Challa Ram, Sangeeta Singh, Subhashini Tata, R. Prameela Devi, M. Aravind Kumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Image processing enhances visual information for effective analysis in domains such as medical imaging, satellite observation, and digital media. This work presents the fundamental pre-processing operations such as Posterize, Red Channel Extraction, Red Tint, and Warm Red Tint—on test images using a MATLAB–Verilog co-design approach.. MATLAB is used for file conversion while Verilog models the algorithms for functional verification. Simulation results confirm the correctness of the operations and highlight the framework’s potential as a scalable foundation for real-time image enhancement applications.

title: Modelling a STATCOM with Limited Energy Storage and PV Generation to Provide Grid Forming Capability to Enhance the Stability of a Distribution Grid
authors: Nuha Mohd Nazri, Christian Klumpner
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: STATCOM technology was proposed three decades ago to address the voltage instability of power systems by employing standalone power electronics that can produce the required amounts of reactive powers whilst absorbing only the losses. Newer challenges for power system stability require grid forming capabilities to be available and since some of these require more significant amounts of energy and active power, integration of limited energy storage and also small amount of renewable energy generation to cover losses and provide black start, becomes necessary. This paper will evaluate by simulations the capabilities of a STATCOM with integrated limited energy storage and PV generation to provide grid forming capabilities

title: A Compact High-Voltage Pulse Generator Using Series-Connected Mosfets and a Non-Isolated Boost Converter
authors: S. M. Mortazavi, T. Huiskamp
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The method of generating high-voltage (HV) pulses plays a crucial role in pulse power systems, directly determining their performance and reliability. Various implementation approaches involve trade-offs among size, flexibility, cost, efficiency, pulse fidelity, and overall robustness. This paper presents the design and realization of an ultrafast HV nanosecond pulse generator using series-connected MOSFETs as the switching module and a non-isolated boost converter. Key features include active fall-time control, compact and low-cost construction, inherent voltage boost, and ultrafast switching capability. Experimental results verify reliable operation with output voltages, repetition rates, and pulse widths of 10 kV, 10 kHz, and 60-600 ns, respectively, achieving a boosted output voltage up to twice the input level.

title: Design and Evaluation of Transient Suppression Circuits for Solid-State Circuit Breakers in Dc Ev Charging Systems
authors: Kushan T. Lulbadda, Tarlochan Sidhu, Sheldon S. Williamson
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Solid-state circuit breakers (SSCBs) are gradually recognized as a key protection technique for modern DC power systems such as EV charging stations, due to their ultrafast response and arc-free operation. Snubber circuits must be used to provide dependable operation and device protection since fault current interruption causes strong voltage transients. In this research, various snubber configurations, such as RC, RCD, MOV, and hybrid arrangements applied to SSCBs in DC systems, are designed and evaluated. Energy dissipation, clamping voltage selection, and leakage current considerations are discussed in the mathematical framework for snubber circuit design. Simulation analyses were performed to evaluate the transient voltage and current waveforms across the breaker switch under various snubber configurations. To validate the simulation results and confirm the design methodology, an experimental setup implementing multiple snubber topologies was subsequently developed and tested. The findings demonstrated a high degree of agreement with simulations. The outcomes of this research provide valuable insights and practical guidance for the design and optimization of snubber circuits in SSCB applications.

title: Lissajous and Quadratic Modeling for Unbalanced Operation Analysis in Multilevel H-Bridge Inverters for Large-Scale Solar Applications
authors: P. M Lingom, Ideal O. Libouga, Roland Unruh, Joseph Song-Manguelle, Mamadou L. Doumbia, Joao Pereira Pinto
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel analytical framework for evaluating unbalanced operation in solar-fed multilevel Hbridge (CHB) inverters. A combined Lissajous-based and quadratic geometric modeling approach is proposed to characterize voltage imbalance and fault conditions under asymmetric DC source voltages typical of photovoltaic systems. The developed models analytically derive key ellipse parameters, including major and minor axes, eccentricity, and orientation, to quantitatively represent the degree and nature of voltage imbalance in the inverter. Furthermore, a rebalancing condition is established to facilitate compensation modulation and adaptive control, ensuring stable operation under unequal solar string voltages or partial shading conditions. The proposed modeling framework enables direct visualization of imbalance evolution in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\alpha} \boldsymbol{\beta}$</tex> voltage plane and provides a diagnostic tool for condition monitoring. Comprehensive simulation and experimental validations on a three-cell-per-phase CHB inverter confirm the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed Lissajous and quadratic models, demonstrating improved system reliability and operational resilience in large-scale solar power applications.

title: Exploring the Role of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and Generative AI for Synthetic Data Generation and Augmentation in Machine Learning
authors: Shoeb Ali Syed, Kaushik Jangiti, Anusha Joodala, Mohammed Shafi Kundiladi, Reddieswara Naidu Kalla, Siva Koteswara Rao Katta
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and generative AI models are explored for synthetic data generation and augmentation in machine learning tasks. Benchmark datasets like CIFAR-10, MNIST, and UCI Credit Card are used to compare models trained on real, GAN-generated, and augmented data. Performance is evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and Fréchet Inception Distance (FID). Results show that GAN-generated data yields slightly lower accuracy compared to real data, but combining synthetic data with real data improves model performance, especially in data-limited scenarios. The study demonstrates that GANs produce data with high structural similarity to the original datasets, confirming their potential to enhance model robustness and enable privacy-preserving analytics.

title: Multimodal Engagement Estimation for Online Teaching through Facial and Postural Analytics
authors: Sivasangari V, Saranya G, Uma Maheswari B
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The trend toward online learning has brought attention to the need for efficient ways to evaluate the caliber of instruction and student engagement. The subjective nature and delayed nature of traditional feedback systems limit their applicability in real-time applications. Using multimodal behavior analysis and facial expression recognition, this study suggests a real-time teaching evaluation system that provides automated and objective evaluation. The system makes use of effective and lightweight models, such as EfficientNetB3 for emotion classification and RetinaFace for face detection. The models are refined using classroom specific datasets gathered from online class sessions in order to increase accuracy. In order to provide a thorough engagement score, the system also uses tools like MediaPipe and OpenFace to analyze body posture, estimate head pose, and track eye gaze.

title: A Personalized Education Path Recommendation System using Collaborative Filtering and Reinforcement Learning
authors: Sankara Mahalingam M, N Suresh Kumar, Chirlamcherla Charan Teja, Chebolu Ganesh Pavan Sai, Bhadri Akhileswar Reddy, Pinniboyina Harish Babu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Conventional e-learning systems typically present standardized material without regard to the pace of each learner, prior background, or affect. To overcome this limitation, this research puts forward a Content Recommendation System for Adaptive Education that combines Collaborative Filtering (CF), Reinforcement Learning (RL), and real-time recognition of emotions with Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The system receives data such as scores on quizzes, durations of engagement, and real-time webcam-emotional cues to adaptively suggest learning material. CF generates initial recommendations based on similarity, while RL dynamically adjusts sequencing based on trial-and-error interaction represented as a Markov Decision Process. Real-time detection of affects ensures that difficulty levels of the contents and pace of presentation reflect the learner's emotions. Experimental findings establish 20-35 % higher scores in the post-test, 25 % quicker completion, and 40 % longer engagement compared to static baselines. The results establish that the integration of cognitive, behavioral, as well as affective modeling delivers an emotionally intelligent, scalable, as well as adaptive learning framework that can be applicable to the next-gen digital classrooms.

title: Deep Learning-Driven ECG Classification using CNN-LSTM-Transformer and Metaheuristic Optimization
authors: Manohar Babu Barla, Aravind Kumar Madam
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The main basis for the death and sickness across the globe is Cardio vascular diseases (CVDs) therefore, accurate diagnoses at an early stage are needed for treatments that work well. Electrocardiograms (ECGs) are a key way to find heart problems, but reading them by hand is time-consuming and can lead to mistakes. This paper suggests a deep learning-based method that makes use of a hybrid CNN-LSTM and Vision Transformer (ViT-LSTM) architecture for fully automated ECG categorization. CNN catches spatial features from ECG signals, and LSTM/Transformer modules allow a strong classification of cardiac arrhythmias and CVD indicators by catching temporal dependencies. The model was trained on benchmark ECG datasets like MIT-BIH Arrhythmia along with PTB-XL. For optimal feature selection, the model uses M-Square normalization in addition to Chaotic Dwarf Mongoose Optimization (CH-DMO). According to the experimental data, the suggested method outperforms traditional CNNs and LSTMs in terms of classification accuracy, achieving 94–98%. The system's quite high sensitivity and truly outstanding specificity make it a completely viable solution for actual real-time, IoT-based smart health monitoring. Future work will thoroughly broaden dataset diversity and considerably optimize model efficiency for advanced edge computing to greatly improve generalization.

title: A Hybrid Ensemble Model Combining Machine Learning and Fuzzy Logic for Robust Stress Level Detection
authors: Utkarsh Thakur, Hubert Shanthan, Vijay Arputharaj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Accurate stress detection remains challenging because stress manifests differently across diverse populations. This research presents a novel hybrid approach that combines four machine learning classifiers—XGBoost, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Logistic Regression—with an enhanced fuzzy logic system through weighted voting. The study employed a comprehensive dataset comprising over 1,100 samples containing more than 45 features that capture psychological, academic, social, physical, and environmental stress indicators. The results demonstrate that the ensemble achieves 87.27% accuracy with statistically significant improvements over individual models (p¡0.001). The approach maintains strong performance when 10% noise is injected or missing data is simulated, and provides well-calibrated probability estimates that could support clinical decision-making.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Brain Tumor Prediction
authors: Vijai Anand Ramar, Yashwant Kumar Kolli, Priyadarshini Radhakrishnan, Venkataramesh Induru, Karthik Kushala, S K Pravin Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Deep learning-based brain tumor prediction has been in high demand in medical diagnosis because of its ability for early detection and correct classification. This paper presents a record-breaking deep learning model that combines ShuffleNet for feature extraction, Mean Shift Clustering for tumor segmentation, Histogram Equalization for contrast enhancement, the Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) Algorithm for hyperparameter optimization, and Sparse Feature Encoding for dimensionality reduction. Hybrid approach greatly enhances the accuracy of classification by 98.1% accuracy, 97.5% precision, 98.3% recall, and 97.9% F1-score. Comparative evaluation determines that the suggested model outperforms other approaches when compared. Conclusions validate stability, effectiveness, and applicability of the suggested model for usage in real-world medical situations for enhanced tumor detection, diagnostic rate, and enhanced patient outcomes.

title: Beyond Forecasting: Discovering Hidden Weather Regimes using Multivariate Clustering
authors: Nirmal Kumar M, Subramanian P, Surendran R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Knowledge of urban weather regimes is critical for environmental planning, disaster preparedness, and climatic monitoring in metropolitan areas. This study presents an evidence-based framework for detecting and characterizing such regimes utilising daily meteorological data from 43 cities across the United States, Canada, and Israel, spanning February 2012 to October 2017. Key variables include air pressure, wind speed, temperature, and relative humidity. The data were preprocessed through aggregation, missing value imputation, outlier treatment, and standardization to ensure quality and consistency. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was applied for dimensionality reduction to extract dominant patterns, followed by clustering using an enhanced Canopy-KMeans algorithm with minimum variance initialization, optimal k selection via the Elbow Method, and computational efficiency achieved through the triangle inequality. Temporal persistence filtering ensured that identified regimes represent physically meaningful and stable atmospheric states. Five distinct regimes were classified: Hot–Humid Calm, Mild–Dry Transitional, Mild–Windy Transitional, Cold–Humid Unstable, and Hot–Dry Windy. Cluster centroids and intra-cluster variability provide quantitative descriptions of each regime’s environmental characteristics. Validation using the Davies-Bouldin Index, Silhouette coefficient, Calinski-Harabasz Index, and Adjusted Rand Index confirms that k = 5 yields the most stable and interpretable solution. The proposed framework offers a robust foundation for urban weather characterization, with potential applications in climate assessment and risk mitigation.

title: Early Prediction and Diagnosis of Tomato Leaf Diseases using Meerkat Clan Algorithm
authors: Santhosh Kumar Medishetti, Tattikota Madhu, Ponnala Bhaskar, Vanga Divya, Pullagurla Akshaya, Chukka Ganesh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Early and accurate detection of tomato leaf diseases is critical for ensuring crop yield, reducing pesticide usage, and supporting sustainable agriculture. This study proposes a novel Meerkat Clan Algorithm (MCA)-based classification framework for the early prediction and diagnosis of tomato leaf diseases from digital images. The MCA is designed to efficiently optimize feature selection by mimicking the cooperative foraging and vigilance behaviors of meerkats, thereby enhancing classification accuracy while minimizing computational complexity. Image preprocessing techniques, including contrast enhancement and noise reduction, are applied to improve visual quality, followed by feature extraction using color, texture, and shape descriptors. The selected features are then classified using the optimized MCA model. Experimental evaluation is conducted on a benchmark tomato leaf disease dataset and results are compared against Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models. The proposed MCA-based approach achieves a classification accuracy of 98.8%, significantly outperforming SVM (92.5%) and CNN (96.1%). The findings demonstrate that the MCA not only accelerates convergence but also maintains robustness across varying disease categories, making it a promising tool for precision agriculture and automated plant health monitoring.

title: Smart Trip Planner for Personalized Tourism Itineraries
authors: Jeevan Pradish S, Prathish S, Sanjutha M, Tharunika R. C, S.Bharaninayagi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Travel is exciting, but planning often feels stressful and time-consuming. This work introduces a Smart Trip Planner that simplifies the process by generating personalized itineraries based on traveler preferences, schedule, budget, and destination. Powered by Generative AI, the system lets users describe goals in natural language e.g., A three-day budget trip to Kerala with waterfalls and trekking and instantly receive a tailored plan. It explains route and POI choices, ensuring transparency, while advanced models and location-aware features keep suggestions realistic and engaging. Unlike conventional apps, it offers an interactive, stress-free approach to trip planning.

title: A Comprehensive Study of Machine Learning and Deep Learning Techniques for Thyroid Cancer Classification
authors: Kayathri S, Mahendran N
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Thyroid cancer presents a growing health concern where timely and accurate diagnosis is crucial for effective treatment and improved patient outcomes. Due to its potential for growth and spread, leading to complications like difficulty swallowing, breathing, and voice changes. While many types have a good prognosis, some can be aggressive and require extensive treatment. The problem is to develop a novel diagnostic approach that improves the accuracy and reliability of thyroid cancer detection, reducing the rate of indeterminate results and minimizing unnecessary aggressive procedures. Current diagnostic pathways, relying on physical examinations, imaging techniques like ultrasound, face limitations in early-stage detection, accuracy in differentiating benign from malignant nodules. These challenges can lead to delayed diagnoses, unnecessary surgical interventions, and increased patient anxiety

title: Machine Learning-based Early Diagnosis and EMG-Assisted Monitoring of Parkinson’s Disorder
authors: Tejas S, Thanisha Kumar, Venkat Bharadwaj J, Ketan Desai, Vinu R, Jisy N.K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Parkinson’s disorder is one of the most commonly found neurodegenerative diseases that primarily affects the central nervous system. Non-motor symptoms can be observed, such as depression, anxiety, sleep disorders, and cognitive impairments, which also occur, further exacerbating this disease. Since there is no definitive test for Parkinson’s disease, it is difficult to diagnose. Doctors rely on a mental health evaluation, medical history, and physical exam, but these processes can be slow or inaccurate, especially in the early stages. Machine learning is gaining popularity in the healthcare field due to its ability to analyze complex data, identify patterns, and make predictions to improve medical decisions. This study examined methods such as K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and XGBoost (Extreme Gradient Boosting) to achieve better and improved outcomes for patients by utilizing treatment plans, ultimately enhancing the lives of individuals with Parkinson's disorder. The results indicate that early detection using EMG-based ML analysis achieves an accuracy of up to 99%, supporting timely medical intervention

title: TriFusion: A Client-Side Multi-Modal Encryption System with Double-Layer Security
authors: Chimakurthy Mounika Begum, Kamalapuram Vigneswara Reddy, Adhi Neeraja, Kavitha C. R.
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: With the increased fear of data breaches and unauthorized access with provision of confidentiality and integrity in information has become paramount. The paper introduces the TriFusion System a complete client-side, browser-based encryption and decryption platform with multi-layered security approach. It contains a proprietary double-layer encryption process dependent on Armstrong number transformations, and RGB color mappings that introduce complexity and randomness to make it immune to cryptographic attacks. It provides multi-key generation with password based approach, biometric image based approach and a hybrid approach for security and personalization. In order to maintain data integrity, The system employs a SHA-256 hash and saves it into the encrypted file in order to detect tampering during decryption. The TriFusion System executes only within the user’s web browser, independent of any server interaction, therefore completely avoiding the hazards related to transmission of data or centralized storage. Exploratory tests prove its robustness, scalability, and usability for secure file management for local and portable environments.

title: VoteBank: An Intelligent, Safe, and Open Online Voting Platform
authors: Rahul Kumar, Raunak Raj, Rana Ayush, Abhay Agarwal, Sundeep Raj
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The intelligent, safe VoteBank is presented in this paper and a transparent electronic voting system created to update elections. The system integrates biometric and OTP-based methods, confirming, storing the vote securely, and counting over time. Audit recording can be helpful in fostering trust and guaranteeing efficiency and secrecy. Through regarding customary voting procedures that developed from the ballot. VoteBank makes limited accessibility, logistical delays, and little interference possible offers a platform that is future-proof, scalable, and user-friendly. It is suitable for authority, corporate and institutional elections. The design emphasises accessibility, security and openness to increase democratic engagement.
