title: Electromagnetic Formation Flying Using Alternating Magnetic Field Forces and Control Barrier Functions for State and Input Constraints
authors: Sumit S. Kamat, T. Michael Seigler, Jesse B. Hoagg
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This article presents a feedback control algorithm for electromagnetic formation flying with constraints on the satellites' states and control inputs. The algorithm combines several key techniques. First, we use alternating magnetic field forces to decouple the electromagnetic forces between each pair of satellites in the formation. Each satellite's electromagnetic actuation system is driven by a sum of amplitude-modulated sinusoids, where amplitudes are controlled in order to prescribe the time-averaged force between each pair of satellites. Next, the desired time-averaged force is computed from a optimal control that satisfies state constraints (i.e., no collisions and an upper limit on intersatellite speeds) and input constraints (i.e., not exceeding satellite's apparent power capability). The optimal time-averaged force is computed using a single relaxed control barrier function that is obtained by composing multiple control barrier functions that are designed to enforce each state and input constraint. Finally, we demonstrate the satellite formation control method in numerical simulations.

title: GPR-GSLAM: Gaussian Process Regression–Enhanced Real-Time RGB-D SLAM Using Gaussian Splatting
authors: Xinlong Qi, Yan Zhang, Hongyong Fu, Lu Zhang, Xiaoxiao Guo, Xinyuan Jiang
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) has recently revolutionized novel view synthesis and provided a new paradigm for photorealistic Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM). However, current 3DGS-based RGB-D SLAM systems still face three key challenges: incomplete depth observations due to sensor noise and occlusions, unreliable pose initialization in challenging environments, and the difficulty of balancing reconstruction accuracy with computational efficiency. To address these challenges, we propose Gaussian Process Regression–enhanced Gaussian Splatting SLAM (GPR-GSLAM), a real-time RGB-D SLAM system built around two key components. First, we employ Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) to complete missing depths and introduce an adaptive learning-rate mask to accelerate the optimization of Gaussians initialized from GPR-completed depth while preserving convergence stability. Second, we develop a robust tracking-and-mapping pipeline that combines a Fractional-Weighted Generalized Iterative Closest Point (FW-GICP) with dual-mode tracking for reliable pose initialization, and leverages differentiable 3D Gaussian Splatting for a two-stage pose optimization: a joint SE(3) corrective update of the camera pose and keyframe-initialized Gaussians that rapidly absorbs the residual error from the tracking process, followed by decoupled refinement of camera pose and Gaussian parameters, enabling adaptive map correction and fine-grained accuracy recovery. Quantitative evaluations on TUM RGB-D, Bonn, and Replica show that GPR-GSLAM maintains real-time operation (30 FPS) while achieving strong photorealistic mapping quality and pose accuracy, offering a favorable accuracy-efficiency trade-off.

title: CODI: Contextual Object Detection via Image Inpainting
authors: Sinan Çavdar, Selim Aksoy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Object detection is a fundamental task in many applications of remote sensing image analysis. Problems such as inter-class similarity, intra-class variability, and existence of heterogeneous backgrounds can benefit from leveraging contextual information to improve the detection performance. Most context modeling architectures introduce additional modules that aim to extract contextual information from the main backbone that is also used for learning the object representations. We propose a new approach for contextual object detection via image inpainting named CODI where a custom module fuses object-specific features from an object detector and contextual representations from an inpainting-based generative model. The resulting multi-scale representation named the contextual pyramid network is injected into the feature extraction backbone so that both the oriented region proposal network and the classification and regression branches of the detector can benefit from the richer representations resulting from this fusion. In contrast to others, our architecture obtains semantic context independently from and without relying on the backbone of the object detection model to guide both localization and labeling. Extensive experiments with quantitative and qualitative evaluation are performed on the DOTA, HRSC2016, and DIOR-R datasets. With mean average precision scores of 76.61%, 90.57%, and 67.63% on these datasets respectively, the proposed model achieves higher performance compared to other models from the literature. Ablation experiments also show that CODI enables improvements in precision and recall with effective control of the score probability threshold during detection.

title: BACON: A Body-Aware Framework for Parameterized Collision Detection Acceleration
authors: Yicheng Xing, Dahu Feng, Hongyi Li, Xinglong Ji, Rong Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: The escalating intricacy of robotic systems has created an urgent need for customizable hardware platforms tailored to diverse robotic applications. Concurrently, the rapid iteration of robotic deployment scenarios demands an agile and scalable hardware development methodology. A critical but often overlooked module in agile hardware design is collision detection, a fundamental module in robot accelerators that is essential for safety and control. In this work, we present BACON, a hardware collision detection framework that generates high-precision, high-efficiency accelerators for rigid-body robots with arbitrary degrees of freedom and structures. BACON streamlines the design process with a parameterized template that can be rapidly tuned for new scenarios. Our framework introduces three key innovations: a dynamic-static decoupled design for efficient detection in highly dynamic environments; a Monte Carlo tree search-based optimization strategy that automatically tailors parameters for diverse robotic morphologies and scenarios; and a body-aware scheduler that balances workloads and eliminates redundant computations via early exit mechanisms. When validated on six robotic systems and implemented on Xilinx VCU118 and ZU15EG FPGA, BACON demonstrates an average speedup of 17.85× over CPUs and 2.62× over GPUs in collision detection tasks, highlighting its capability to enable scalable, high-performance robotic accelerators for a new generation of agile robotic systems.

title: Thrust Generation Mechanism of a Hybrid Excitation Field Modulated Transverse Flux Linear Generator by Magnetic Field Modulation Theory
authors: Minshuo Chen, Lei Huang, Hui Yang, Jianlong Yang, Zhengyuan Zhu, Yuan Li, Fengyu Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The magnetic field modulated transverse flux linear machine (TFLM) effectively combines the advantages of magnetic field modulated machine and TFLM, exhibiting high power density at low speed, effectively blocking eddy currents, and improving machine efficiency. However, its thrust generation mechanism is hard to analyze due to its complex three-dimensional (3-D) magnetic circuit structure. In this article, the thrust generation mechanism of hybrid excitation field modulated transverse flux linear generator (HE-FM-TFLG) is analyzed from the perspective of 3-D magnetic field modulation. First, the machine configuration of HE-FM-TFLG is introduced. Then, considering 3-D magnetic field modulation and hybrid excitation structure, the main harmonic and thrust characteristics of HE-FM-TFLG are derived based on magnetomotive force (MMF)-permeance model. A HE-FM-TFLG prototype is manufactured, and a prototype experiment platform is built to test the electromagnetic characteristics of the prototype. Both finite element method (FEM) and experimental results demonstrate that increasing the excitation current not only enhances thrust but also reduces no-load back electromotive force (EMF) total harmonic distortion (THD), thereby improving power quality. The prototype employs cross-connected windings simultaneously in both the circumferential and axial directions to reduce thrust ripple. Moreover, the hybrid excitation structure endows it with flux regulation capability. This enables it to better capture wave energy for power generation when there is a certain degree of variation in wave speed. The effectiveness of the analytical results is verified by FEM results and experimental results.

title: Toward Automated Validation of Language Model Synthesized Test Cases using Semantic Entropy
authors: Hamed Taherkhani, Jiho Shin, Muhammad Ammar Tahir, Md Rakib Hossain Misu, Vineet Sunil Gattani, Hadi Hemmati
publish: IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering
abstract: Modern Large Language Model (LLM)-based programming agents often rely on test execution feedback to refine their generated code. These tests are synthetically generated by LLMs. However, LLMs may produce invalid or hallucinated test cases, which can mislead feedback loops and degrade the performance of agents in refining and improving code. This paper introduces <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">VALTEST</monospace>, a novel framework that leverages semantic entropy to automatically validate test cases generated by LLMs. By analyzing the semantic structure of test cases and computing entropy-based uncertainty measures, <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">VALTEST</monospace> trains a machine learning model to classify test cases as valid or invalid and filters out invalid test cases. Experiments on multiple benchmark datasets and various LLMs show that <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">VALTEST</monospace> not only boosts test validity by up to 29% but also improves code generation performance, as evidenced by significant increases in pass@1 scores. Our extensive experiments also reveal that semantic entropy is a reliable indicator to distinguish between valid and invalid test cases and provides a robust solution for improving the correctness of LLM-generated test cases used in software testing and code generation.

title: Pre-Estimation System of Falling Asleep Process Using Distribution-Based Deep Learning Model With Polysomnography
authors: Seungwon Oh, Young-Seok Kweon, Gi-Hwan Shin, Seong-Whan Lee
publish: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics: Systems
abstract: Sleep is associated with mental and physical health; therefore, it is important to pre-assess sleep quality for daily life. However, previous sleep studies, such as self-reporting and sleep stage (SS) classification, have limitations in their ability to assess sleep quality at an early stage. Therefore, a new approach based on the pre-estimation system for sleep quality using a sensor-based model is required. In this study, we propose a distribution-based deep learning model to pre-assess sleep quality using the estimation of the falling asleep process (FAP) at the early SS. Sleep onset latency (SOL) is considered to pre-estimate the FAP because SOL is associated with insomnia and could be observable at the beginning of sleep. Moreover, multimodal polysomnography (PSG) signals, including two-channel electroencephalogram (EEG), electrocardiogram (ECG), and electromyogram (EMG), are used to consider the complexity of sleep dynamics. The advantage of the proposed method is combining each distribution from PSG with the importance score to compare influence and show the probability of wake over time. To evaluate the model performance, the feature extraction and temporal encoder with the previous SS module are compared, respectively, and the proposed model achieved the best mean absolute error (MAE) (8.65) and concordance index (C-index) (0.708) among baseline models, including AttnSleep, TinySleepNet, and MEDI-SOL, while maintaining a competitive Brier score (BS) (0.041) and negative binomial log-likelihood (NBLL) (0.145). As a result, the main contribution of this study is that it can pre-assess sleep quality by estimating a probability over time of when a subject will fall asleep.

title: AC Loss of Double-Pancake Coils Wound with Striated Copper-Coated REBCO Tape Using the Laser-Scribed Method
authors: Yuuki Himeno, Takaemi Suenaga, Ryoma Oishi, Yuji Nishida, Shun Miura, Hiromasa Sasa, Koichi Yoshida, Hiroshi Miyazaki, Masataka Iwakuma, Teruo Izumi, Takato Machi, Hishiro T. Hirose, Miyuki Nakamura
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: Reducing AC losses in superconducting AC devices is crucial as it significantly contributes to decreasing the cryogenic load. One effective approach to mitigate the hysteresis loss of REBa₂Cu₃O₇−δ (REBCO) superconducting tapes is to subdivide the superconducting layer into multiple filaments and minimize the filament width. Our research group has successfully reduced the AC loss in short-length segmented tapes using laser scribing. In previous studies, striated conductors with only a silver stabilization layer were used, but there were concerns about current bypassing during quenching. In this study, we developed striated copper-coated REBCO tape using laser scribing. To suppress localized heating during quenching, copper-coated tapes were striated using laser ablation. However, exposure of the edge during laser ablation poses the risk of moisture corrosion. To avoid this, the entire tape was coated with electrodeposited polyimide to protect the exposed areas. Subsequently, the AC losses of the striated and non-striated tapes were evaluated. First, the AC losses of short samples were assessed using the saddle-shaped pickup coil method. Subsequently, a double-pancake coil was fabricated using these tapes, and its AC losses were evaluated in liquid nitrogen. These coils had an inner diameter of 40 mm, outer diameter of 59.04 mm, and consisted of a double-pancake structure with 80 turns per pancake.

title: RAISA: A Vision-based Intelligent Safety Guidance Agent for Railway Operations via Modular Prompt-Orchestrated Reasoning
authors: Kyung Ho Kang, Kyoung Ok Yang, Jun Won Choi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Railway safety remains a critical challenge due to the difficulty of detecting and responding to front-view hazards. We present the RAIlway Safety Agent (RAISA), an AI-powered system for front-view situational interpretation and role-specific safety guidance in railway operations. RAISA integrates a vision–language model (BLIP-2) and a large language model (Mistral-7B) within a Modular Prompt-Orchestrated Reasoning framework, structured into three stages: scene analysis, situation abstraction, and role-specific instruction generation. Unlike vision-only or rule-based systems, RAISA delivers semantically precise and context-adapted safety messages for both train drivers and traffic controllers. Through multi-turn prompting, the system enables zero-shot generalization across varied conditions, such as snow, fog, tunnels, and night scenes, without task-specific fine-tuning. Evaluated on 12,760 railway front-view images, RAISA demonstrated strong semantic fidelity and operational validity under zero-shot conditions, achieving over 93% average BERTScore F1 alongside high scores on reference-free checklist-based metrics, including PCR and CAC. The curated large-scale dataset and source code are made publicly accessible. Its interpretable architecture is designed for centralized server-based inference rather than edge deployment, ensuring scalable integration with existing railway communication networks and control infrastructures. By improving situational awareness and enabling network-level coordination, RAISA contributes to enhanced operational safety and efficiency, aligning with the goals of sustainable and intelligent railway transportation.

title: Super LiDAR Intensity for Robotic Perception
authors: Wei Gao, Jie Zhang, Mingle Zhao, Zhiyuan Zhang, Shu Kong, Maani Ghaffari, Dezhen Song, Chengzhong Xu, Hui Kong
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Conventionally, human intuition defines vision as a modality of passive optical sensing, relying on ambient light to perceive the environment. However, active optical sensing, which involves emitting and receiving signals, offers unique advantages by capturing both radiometric and geometric properties of the environment, independent of external illumination conditions. This work focuses on advancing active optical sensing using Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), which captures intensity data, enabling the estimation of surface reflectance that remains invariant under varying illumination. Such properties are crucial for robotic perception tasks, including detection, recognition, segmentation, and Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM). A key challenge with low-cost LiDARs lies in the sparsity of scan data, which limits their broader application. To address this limitation, this work introduces an innovative framework for generating dense LiDAR intensity images from sparse data, leveraging the unique attributes of non-repeating scanning LiDAR (NRS-LiDAR). We tackle critical challenges, including intensity calibration and the transition from static to dynamic scene domains, facilitating the reconstruction of dense intensity images in real-world settings. The key contributions of this work include a comprehensive dataset for LiDAR intensity image densification, a densification network tailored for NRS-LiDAR, and diverse applications such as loop closure and traffic lane detection using the generated dense intensity images. Experimental results validate the efficacy of the proposed approach, which successfully integrates computer vision techniques with LiDAR data processing, enhancing the applicability of low-cost LiDAR systems and establishing a novel paradigm for robotic vision via active optical sensing–LiDAR as a Camera.

title: Enhanced Threat Monitoring in IoT-Enabled Smart Traffic Environments via Random Forest Classifiers
authors: Manoj Kumar N, Srabana Pramanik
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The system will definitely be able to hunt down unexpected patterns that are like those seen in security breaches when it is hunting data that is coming from the stream of IoT sensors, car communication modules, and edge devices by analyzing in real-time the huge amount of diversified traffic data. The main contribution of this research is that it combines High-precision anomaly detection Random Forest classifiers with low false alarm rates. The method uses input vectors with several features that are obtained from different sources, for example, the temporal trends of traffic, the network latency, the data integrity, and the device activity logs. These features or parameters are iteratively trained and ranked according to their importance. As a result, the system decided to take only those parameters that belong to the threat situations, and, therefore, it can do the classification correctly. Furthermore, a module is given to the situational intimation, which not only facilitates the quick informing of the central controllers but also the vehicles that are there at the place, in case of the occurrence of a threat, thus, it enables better response efficiency. The model is very precise and attests this accuracy from the correct recognition of it significantly more than other machine learning methods. Besides, the system provides real-time traffic security, and this framework is also good for safe, resilient smart urban mobility systems.

title: A Multimodal Explainability Framework for Retinal Clinical Decision Support Systems
authors: Vedaant Agarwal, Yelena Yesha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The prevalence of retinal diseases demonstrates the need for more efficient diagnostic methods. Conditions such as choroidal neovascularization, diabetic macular edema, and drusen remain leading causes of vision loss. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is the clinical gold standard for retinal imaging, yet manual interpretation is time consuming and subject to variability across physicians. Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSS) address these limitations by aiding disease detection; however, current CDSSs often lack transparency, limiting clinical adoption. Interpretability must encompass graphical, visual, and textual modalities that mirror physician reasoning. This study introduces a unified interpretable framework integrating all three. t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embeddings generates projections of learned embeddings, revealing class separation and progression trends, that provide graphical interpretability. Swin-UNet generates a retinal layer segmentation image that provides visual interpretability by supporting anatomical verification. GPT-5 generates a structured, evidence-grounded patient report that provides textual interpretability. Evaluations on benchmark OCT datasets confirm consistent cluster geometry aligned with severity, accurate layer delineation, and verifiable narrative outputs, advancing explainable and workflow-ready CDSS for retinal disease management.

title: Stress Analysis Through PPG and GSR Integration using an IoT-Enabled Wearable Device
authors: C.Sivamani, Nancy Amalarani J, Shanmuga Sundar N, Enba Tamil E
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Stress influences mental and physical health and impacts more than half of the world population every year. In the long term, stress can affect respiratory and cardiovascular systems, highlighting the need for effective and consistent monitoring techniques. The objective of this research is to develop a wearable device that can detect the stress level in real time by utilizing physiological signals. The recommended system merges a galvanic skin response (GSR) sensor with a MAX30102 pulse and heart rate sensors for variation with stress. Human motion can produce noise in PPG and GSR signals, so an MPU6050 motion sensor is included in the device to assist in detecting and subtracting motion artifacts from the signals. The device addresses the shortcomings of traditional stress measurement techniques through its accuracy, portability, and comfortable design. Experimental testing shows that the system is sensitive and reliable for stress detection and provides a translation from contemporary wearable monitoring to established health care assessment. This innovation enhances remote health management and early stress identification.

title: Morlet Empowering Wavelet Decision Neural Network with Lotus Effect Optimization Algorithm based Classification of Skin Cancer
authors: K. Thenmozhi, Bhagyashree Kulkarni, S.P. Velmurugan, Sanjay Agal, Ramya Maranan, Dr.M.SivaramKrishnan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Skin carcinoma constitutes the most frequently diagnosed malignant neoplasm globally, rendering timely recognition indispensable for reducing morbidity and mortality and for improving treatment efficacy. Conventional diagnostic modalities, involving visual inspection followed by histopathological biopsy, suffer from inherent invasiveness, potentially lengthy turnaround times, and substantial susceptibility to inter-observer variability. This article presents an advanced hierarchical framework combining a Morlet Empowering Wavelet Decision Neural Network (MEWDNN) with a Lotus Effect Optimization Algorithm (LEOA) to enable fully automated and accurate differentiation of cutaneous tumours. Efficacy is achieved by initially exposing dermoscopic imaging to a Morlet wavelet transformation specifically adapted to emphasise integrated spatial and spectral attributes, thus producing feature vectors with superior class-separability over standard extraction pipelines. Hyper-parameter tuning of the resultant decision network occurs through the LEOA, producing accelerated convergence and demonstrable robustness across disparate dermoscopic cohorts. Extensive validation against benchmark public repositories indicates that the combined MEWDNN-LEOA architecture consistently registers statistical superiority over prevailing algorithms, evincing superior diagnostic accuracy, significantly lower misclassification rates, and negligible alterations in performance across repeated cross-validatory partitions. Collectively, these findings furnish robust evidence in support of the architecture as an independent and non-invasive instrument for the automated primary evaluation of malignant cutaneous lesions in clinical settings..

title: Generative Analytics Pipelines for Multi-Modal Business Intelligence Automation
authors: Naveen Kolli, Abanish Mishra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Generative Analytics Pipelines (GAPs) are proposed as an end-to-end framework that transforms multi-modal business data into actionable insights with minimal human intervention. Structured transactional records (such as sales and inventory) are integrated with unstructured sources including customer reviews, social media posts, and product images, and processed through state-of-the-art generative and contrastive models that automatically cleanse, fuse, and enrich heterogeneous data streams. The methodology is validated on the publicly available Retailrocket Recommender System Dataset, which combines clickstream logs, product metadata, and user sessions, demonstrating how GAPs learn joint embeddings that capture patterns across text, time series, and visual inputs. In a retail environment, the framework uncovers latent demand trends, reveals emerging product affinities, and generates human-readable insights (for example, increased demand for eco-friendly backpacks following a social campaign) within a fully automated workflow. Experiments show that GAP-derived embeddings improve forecasting accuracy by up to 15 percent and recommendation hit-rate by 12 percent, while user studies report a 60 percent reduction in analyst review time. By unifying ingestion, representation learning, orchestration, and narrative generation, GAPs provide a scalable pathway toward reliable and autonomous business intelligence.

title: Intelligent Exercise Guidance System for Beginners using AI
authors: Burra Rahul Goud, K.Ashwini, Shaik Sumera, Gurijala Anita, Sunkaraboina Sreenu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Intelligent Exercise Guidance System has been developed to provide users with an interactive and personalized workout experience. The system enables individuals to register by entering their personal details, including name, age, height and weight. Based on these inputs, the system generates a personalized fitness analysis. Also there have a Specific diet plan. Once logged in, users can select exercises by interacting with a visual body posture diagram, which categorizes workouts based on specific muscle groups. After selecting an exercise, the system activates the live camera to track movements in real-time, ensuring correct posture and counting repetitions accurately. The proposed method utilizes pose estimation methodologies utilizing OpenCV and MediaPipe, ensuring accurate motion detection. To improve user encouragement, the platform provides instantaneous audio feedback following the accurate execution of movements. The proposed system ensures precise workout monitoring, minimizes exercise errors, and enhances fitness results through the integration of advanced recognition models, motion analysis, and automatic repetition counting. The integration of computer vision, AI-based posture assessment, and interactive feedback enhances user engagement, fostering consistency and commitment to workout regimens.

title: Automated Environmental Sensing for Roof-Top Plantation
authors: M. Brindha, S. Prabakar, Shreya Bhagwat, E. Sathya Prakash, S. Harini
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Precision agriculture cannot be developed and successful without environmental monitoring, which is essential to sustainable farming, especially in the space-limited urban setting. In this paper, the following is the design of an automated low-cost environmental sensor system to be used in rooftop plantations. The system keeps track of the important environmental parameters such as ambient temperature, relative humidity, and soil moisture through energy saving sensors. These sensors are connected to a wireless microcontroller which sends the data to a centralized dashboard that can be visualized in real time and be monitored remotely. The system is designed and optimized as a field-deployable and power-efficient system by employing off-the-shelf parts to make it affordable and scalable. The platform enables the urban farmers to have the foundation of environmental data to make informed decisions on irrigation and crop management. The first deployment is characterized by stable sensor operation, a stable data collection process, and avenues of user interaction through the dashboard. The research is useful in further development of IoT-based smart farming, which will help to use the resources more efficiently and achieve sustainable crop growing in urban areas.

title: Generative AI for ETL Automation: Revolutionizing Data Flow Management
authors: Naveen Kolli, Milan Parikh, Veeravenkata Maruthi Lakshmi Ganesh Nerella, Kathiresan Jayabalan, Shivaranjani Sankara Krishnan, R.Maruthi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The diversity of heterogeneous data sources in pervasive modern enterprises requires scalable and adaptable Extract-Transform-Load (ETL) pipelines. Established rule-based ETL approaches and template-driven ETL frameworks suffer from rigid structures and are not suited to deal with schema drift resulting in increased maintenance and higher development costs compared to auto-generated ETL pipelines. This paper describes GenETL based on leveraging generative-AI large language models and semantic embeddings for automated schema inference, automated transformation rule generation, and dynamic pipeline orchestration. The generative methodology is supported by a feedback reinforcement loop and generative test cases to improve performance with every run. Benchmark tests, against four existing ETL methods demonstrate an overall 97% transformation accuracy, 85% automation rate, and 6-hour adaptation to the changes in the source schema for provided data flows. This positive result demonstrates a significant reduction in the time to create an ETL pipeline and overall improvement in data quality. Future work plans extend GenETL to support near real-time streaming generation requirements, further domain-specific tuning, and data privacy-preserving automation of the pipeline generation process.

title: Longitudinal Temporal NLP Models of Kidney Disease Progression Retrieved using Clinical Notes
authors: Khaleelullah Syed, Nikhat Fatima, Aamir Raza, Aashesh Kumar, Bickey Kumar Shah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a progressive disease which needs early monitoring and regular monitoring to avoid complications and cure the patient. Conventional methods of CKD modeling might be premised on the most systematic data and overlook the plentiful time and text signals that can be found in patient narratives. In this paper, we introduce a time-dependent Natural Language Processing (NLP) framework, which is designed to capture progression of CKD with the use of unstructured clinical notes. Using temporal encoding strategies (Time2Vec, Bi-LSTM and time-aware Transformers) and incorporating domain-specific pretrained language models (Clinical BERT), we translate raw text into temporally-aligned representations of disease state at multiple points in time. The training and testing of the models occurred on an annotated set of MIMIC-III dataset that included the explicit and implicit CKD stages (temporal expressions). The models, which scored highest among those evaluated, is the Time-aware Transformer that had an F1-score of 0.915 and an AUC of 0.94, significantly better than baseline and interpretable models. The presented strategy shows how temporal reasoning plays a pivotal role in modelling disease dynamics and makes an effective and explainable framework available to monitor CKD using freetext clinical data. The present work establishes a framework that would be used in future multi-modal/real-time predictive systems of chronic disease management.

title: Performance Analysis of a BLDC Motor as Part of a Load Sided Resonant Inverter Under Fundamental Frequency Switching Operation
authors: Jan Loos, Kerstin Siebert, Holger Hirsch
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The proceeding electrification of motor drives is an important part of decarbonization. Brushless DC Motors are widely spread for different applications due to their simplicity of control, relatively high-power density and low cost. Voltage source inverters operated under fundamental frequency switching are an established power electronic topology to feed brushless DC motors. In this contribution, the performance of a brushless DC motor fed by a load sided resonant inverter is discussed. First, the topology and the concept of the stator sided resonant circuit is introduced. Next, a model of the topology is presented and the characteristics of the resonant tank are discussed. The control strategy is derived and the simulation results of the system model are compared to measurement results in terms of the speed-torque curve and the efficiency.

title: Early Detection and Personalized Care for Varicose Veins
authors: Summia Parveen H, Ilakkiya S, Jaya Ghayathiri B S, Kamali V M, Madhu Sri P S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Varicose veins are a common venous disorder affecting the lower limbs, often leading to pain, ulcers, and severe complications such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) if left untreated [1] [6]. Early detection remains challenging due to limited awareness and accessibility to affordable diagnostic tools. To address this gap, we propose an AI-enhanced mobile health (mHealth) application that leverages a VGGNet-based deep learning model to analyze leg images for detecting varicose veins and classifying their severity as mild, moderate, or severe [4] [8] [11]. The system integrates personalized treatment recommendations, medication reminders, progress tracking, and teleconsultation with vascular specialists [2] [3] [7]. It also provides multilingual educational resources to improve patient understanding and engagement. Experimental results demonstrate reliable detection accuracy and efficient classification performance. By promoting a modular and patient-centered model, this approach transitions varicose vein management from a hospital-centric framework to a more accessible, proactive, and self-managed system, thereby enhancing early diagnosis, treatment adherence, and overall vascular health outcomes [6] [14].

title: A Novel Enhanced H-Bridge Converter with Short-Circuit Fault-Tolerant Capability for Four-Phase 16×12 SRM Drives
authors: Raúl Intriago, João P. Carvalho Silveira, Gabriel Intriago, Rolando R. Caicedo Castro, Tárcio André dos S. Barros, Marcelo Vinícius de Paula
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Given the limited access to specialized maintenance services in geographically isolated areas, such as farms, small rural communities, or remote routes, electric vehicles demand motor drives that combine energy efficiency with high reliability and fault tolerance. In this context, this article proposes a novel enhanced H-bridge converter based on half-bridge modules and implements a short-circuit fault-diagnosis strategy for a 30 kW four-phase SRM. The proposed converter and strategy restore the normal phase operation after their first short-circuit fault. In this sense, the drive system lifespan is improved, and the drive control system can alert the vehicle driver before a second fault could occur in the same drive phase. Results show that the SRM drive is capable of mitigating short-circuit faults while maintaining speed regulation performance at rated torque.

title: Automatic Melody Improvisation using Genetic Algorithms
authors: G Keerthi, N. Neelima, T. V. Smitha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Automatic melody creation is an emerging field of research that blends creativity and computation. This work presents an automated melody improviser that employs a Genetic Algorithm (GA) to generate note sequences in various musical styles while following a user-provided target melody. The system accepts flexible note input using commas or spaces and supports both major and minor scales in MIDI format. Each melody evolves over several generations through fitness testing, crossover, and mutation. The styles Soft, Rap, and Classical each apply their own fitness rules to influence melodic behaviour, including smooth movement, rhythmic contrast, and contour matching. The software generates both MIDI outputs and PDF reports with fitness graphs, pitch-contour plots, and summary tables for analysis. Experimental outcomes show that the generated melodies remain close to the target while maintaining distinct style features. These results confirm that evolutionary algorithms can balance structure and creativity, providing a valuable tool for AI-based music composition.

title: Fractional Spectral Adaptive Filtering for Robust Compressive Sensing: Rational Discrete Fractional Transform-LMS Recovery and Air-Comp Application
authors: Pendyala V Muralidhar, B.Rama Rao, A. S. Srinivasa Rao, D.Nataraj, K S Chakradhar, M.Sivasankara Rao
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Recent developments in over-the-air computation (Air-Comp) and wireless sensor networks (WSNs) have highlighted the increasing need for compressive sensing (CS) recovery algorithms that can operate dependably in real-world wireless settings. In contrast to ideal circumstances, noise and multipath affect real-world channels. The precision and stability of conventional recovery techniques are weakened by propagation, fading, and other factors. Under low-noise or noise-free conditions, classical algorithms like Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (OMP) and time-domain Least Mean Squares (LMS) show good recovery; however, when realistic impairments are introduced, their performance drastically deteriorates, resulting in slow, unstable, or suboptimal convergence. To address these limitations, the propose a robust, spectrum-adaptive CS recovery approach using the Least Mean Squares (LMS) algorithm in the Rational Discrete Fractional Transform (REDT) domain. The REDT provides a sparsity-enhancing transform framework that regularizes adaptive filtering, thereby suppressing additive noise and reducing spectral spreading caused by wireless channels. By transforming the CS recovery problem into the REDT domain, signals achieve sparser representations, which facilitate faster convergence, improved denoising, and greater robustness against channel fading. Comprehensive results, validated through error convergence and recovery plots, reveal that REDT-LMS consistently surpasses conventional LMS, achieving lower steady-state error and higher reconstruction accuracy. This demonstrates not only the theoretical suitability of REDT-domain adaptive filtering for compressive sensing recovery but also its practical efficiency for emerging applications in Air-Comp and distributed edge-based sensor networks. The proposed method offers a reproducible, open-source-supported framework, making it a viable solution for next-generation wireless sensing and communication systems.

title: GCA: Metaheuristic Driven Cost and Energy Aware Scheduling in Edge Computing Environment
authors: Rameshwaraiah Kurupati, P Ashwini, Babina Elangbam, S Sreeduth, R Pavan, S K Varshat Pasha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This study introduces the Gaussian Combined Arms (GCA) algorithm, a novel metaheuristic designed to optimize task scheduling in edge computing by minimizing makespan, energy consumption, and cost. Leveraging adaptive Gaussian-guided exploration with exploitation balance GCA dynamically adjusts scheduling decisions to improve resource utilization and operational efficiency. The algorithm was implemented in the EdgeSimPy simulator and evaluated using the Alibaba workload, with results benchmarked against traditional algorithms such as Genetic Algorithm (GA), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). Experimental findings demonstrate that GCA outperforms all baselines achieving up to 18.8% reduction in makespan, 16.2% lower energy consumption, and 15.8% cost savings, while maintaining high scalability and robustness across varying workload intensities. These improvements highlight the potential of GCA as an effective and scalable scheduling framework for modern edge computing environments, paving the way for integration into heterogeneous and large-scale multi edge-cloud architectures.

title: AI Powered Pneumonia Detection for Chest X-rays using Deep learning
authors: Prasanna Kumar K. R, Harini M, Harshini G, Balajagadeesh M, Gopal S. B, Ponselvakumar A. P
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Pneumonia is one of the most life-threatening respiratory diseases and as such, it should be diagnosed very quickly and effectively in order to start an appropriate treatment. Diagnosis via chest X-ray has traditionally been the burden of radiologists, which can be inefficient as well as very subjective, and potentially inaccurate. This research aims at creating an AI-based deep learning solution using Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for diagnosing pneumonia through chest X-ray images. The suggested model uses the steps of preprocessing, augmentation, and CNN-based classification to differentiate between normal and pneumonia-affected lungs. The model's capabilities are measured using such metrics as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, confusion matrix, and ROC-AUC. Results from our trials demonstrate that the model obtains a test accuracy of 95% and exhibits good ROC performance, AUC ≈ 0.98, suggesting that the model may serve as a radiologists diagnostic support system.

title: Ontology-Driven Modeling and Analysis of Ubiquitous Information Systems for Smart Automation and Human–Computer Interaction
authors: Nidhi Mishra, Moti Ranjan Tandi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Intelligent automation and human–computer interaction (HCI) are essential for enhancing logistics and user communication systems in ubiquitous information environments. This work presents an ontology-based framework for modeling user data, system behavior, and environmental data, facilitating knowledge-driven decision-making and improved device interconnectivity. The suggested system analyzes raw sensor data in real-time, analyzes user interaction patterns, and facilitates task automation based on user needs. Machine learning and hybrid ontology-driven systems are used for evaluation, and performance is assessed using F1 score, accuracy, precision, recall, and AUC. The results show that ontology-based machine learning greatly improves HCI multitasking performance and system automation, allowing for quick response to changing user demands. The framework facilitates better decision-making, responsiveness, and user happiness by offering an organized method for describing intricate behaviors and interactions in ubiquitous contexts. These results highlight how ontology-driven models can be used to advance hybrid information systems and intelligent automation, providing a scalable solution for user-centric, intelligent applications in next-generation ubiquitous computing settings.

title: Comparative Analysis of Time Series Forecasting Models for Energy Consumption Prediction: A Case Study on PJME Grid Data
authors: A. Akilandeswari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Predicting electrical energy demand accurately remains essential for optimal power system management and strategic infrastructure planning in today's interconnected grids. The evaluated techniques encompass classical statistical models including ARIMA, Exponential Smoothing, and ETS, alongside advanced machine learning approaches such as Prophet, LSTM, Random Forest, and ensemble combinations. Performance evaluation demonstrated Prophet's superiority, achieving Root Mean Square Error of 4152.65 MW and Mean Absolute Percentage Error of 10.74%, with ensemble methods providing secondary optimal results. These findings deliver critical insights for grid operators and energy forecasting researchers, supporting enhanced demand prediction capabilities and improved operational efficiency in modern power systems management.

title: Malware Detection and Classification using Hybrid Models
authors: R Vijayalakshmi, Iswarya G, Tamanna S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Cybersecurity systems continually encounter the escalating threat of complex and evolving malware. Conventional detection schemes primarily rely on binary classification, limiting their capability to distinguish among diverse malware families. A hybrid layered framework for malware detection and classification is presented, integrating Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for dimensionality reduction, a Random Forest (RF) model for binary detection, and a CNN–Transformer deep learning model for family/type-level classification. The Random Forest model efficiently differentiates benign and malicious samples, while the CNN–Transformer hybrid captures both local and global feature dependencies to enhance classification accuracy. Experiments conducted on benchmark malware datasets achieved a classification accuracy of 99.93%, surpassing classical machine learning techniques such as K-Nearest Neighbor and Naïve Bayes. The proposed framework demonstrates high scalability, precision, and efficiency in malware detection and categorization. Future extensions will incorporate explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) modules and automated response mapping to improve interpretability and actionable decision support in cybersecurity defense.

title: Deep Learning-based Damage Detection for Structural Health Monitoring of Civil Infrastructure
authors: Fulvio Bergantin, Alberto Falcone, Agostino Forestiero
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Ever-increasing concerns about the structural security of modern urban environments underscore the need for intelligent systems capable of autonomously and quickly detecting damage in civil infrastructure. Manual or non-automatic inspections are time-consuming, onerous, and inclined to subjectivity, while traditional AI-based approaches meet challenges in generality, comprehensibility, and consistent performance in diverse conditions. This paper presents an Artificial Intelligence pipeline integrating the Segment Anything Model and a classic ResNet model classification for smart surface damage identification in civil infrastructure. The designed framework exhibits flexibility, interpretability and computational efficiency, which makes it particularly suited for resource-limited systems and structural health monitoring tasks. Preliminary experiment results on both synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of robust segmentation before classification in enhancing damage detection accuracy, particularly when dealing with complex textures and challenging defect boundaries. The proposed framework also opens new perspectives for integrating deep learning-based visual inspection within digital twin environments, supporting predictive maintenance strategies and continuous monitoring of structural health conditions.

title: Proactive and Data-Driven Non-Invasive Student Productivity Analysis via Sleep Variability using Machine Learning
authors: L. Rahunathan, G. Arun, Suhana Nafais A, Bhuvaneshwari G, Harikrishnan N, Harini N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This research studied the modeling of students' daily cognitive performance by assessing sleep and daily stressors. Participation data was collected from a realistic longitudinal dataset that simulated a university student cohort to study total hours of sleep, sleep timing, daily stress, and reaction times for cognitive tasks. Five machine learning regression models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, SVR, and Ridge) were fit to predict cognitive function for the next day, and performance was assessed using Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The tuned XGBoost Regressor was the best performing model with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 90%. In other words, the regression model explains 90% of the variance for cognitive performance. The results found that variability of sleep timing and daily stressors (the amount of time following stressful cognitive tasks) were the most important predictors of cognitive performance. Overall, this research suggests that there is great potential for predicting cognitive function using machine learning and real-world multi-modal data, which can inform the personalized development of academic and wellness-focused interventions in promoting student success and well-being.

title: Design and Implementation of Frequency Reconfigurable Microstrip Patch Antenna for Wireless Power Transfer Applications
authors: Kasigari Prasad, N V Udayeswara Reddy, L Venkata Lakshumma, P Swapna Sree, B Umesh Chandra, G.Thirumalaiah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: With the increasing need for battery-free and power-efficient IoT devices, RF-based Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) is emerging as a practical solution. This work features a compact frequency-reconfigurable microstrip patch antenna coupled with a tri-turn square-shaped complementary spiral resonator (3-SCSR), specifically developed for robust WPT applications. Constructed on a 50 mm × 50 mm × 1.6 mm FR-4 substrate, the design achieves notable size reduction by embedding the 3-SCSR in the ground plane. Three PIN diodes facilitate versatile operating modes—single, dual, and tri-band configurations—over a broad span from 0.205 GHz to 1.7 GHz, enabling use in VHF, ISM, GSM, UHF, and L-band settings. The prototype exhibits a peak gain of 2.84 dBi and omnidirectional radiation suitable for extensive coverage. For efficient energy conversion, a voltage-doubler rectifier using low-barrier Schottky diodes is optimized at 1.5 GHz, delivering 50% RF-to-DC conversion efficiency at –10 dBm input. Simulation studies in CST and MATLAB confirm antenna performance and energy harvesting capability. This low-cost, miniaturized design offers a promising solution for long-life IoT nodes in remote or hard-to-maintain locations.

title: DC-Link Capacitor Design for High-Speed Integrated Motor Drives: Reliability and System-Level Constraints
authors: Soroush Ahooye Atashin, Saeed Peyghami, Pooya Davari, Amol Ramesh Chopade, Norbert Hanigovszki, Frede Blaabjerg
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The DC link capacitor is one of the important components in Integrated Motor Drives (IMDs) in terms of reliability, and power density. This paper proposes a reliabilityoriented algorithm to select the DC link capacitor used in highspeed IMDs, considering both thermal stress and system-level performance constraints. The proposed algorithm relies on an excessive thermal load caused by the motor's high-frequency operation that contributes to heating the self-temperature of the DC link capacitor. Additionally, torque ripple-induced vibration is treated as a key system-level constraint due to its impact on mechanical integrity in high-speed applications. The thermal analysis is based on the applied mission profile, analyzing the hot-spot temperature over a mission profile, which cover a wide speed range operation. To handle the simulation time for a long mission profile, precomputed lookup tables are employed for capacitor current, copper loss, and core loss of the electrical motor. The simulation results confirm the effectiveness of the optimized capacitor selection in meeting lifetime by doing stressstrength analysis and system specifications requirements.

title: Early Stroke Prediction using Lifestyle and Health Metrics with SHGE Algorithm
authors: Deepa A, Aruthra D, Jaswanth S, Megavarshan G, Lokesh Kumar M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Stroke remains one of the leading causes of death and permanent disability worldwide, which is why the detection should take place early enough to avoid and treat it. Traditional diagnostic testing such as CT and MRI scans is expensive, time-consuming, and not always accessible in rural health facilities. To overcome these weaknesses, this study puts forward an innovative machine learning system using a Stacked Hybrid Gradient Ensemble (SHGE) model for predicting stroke. The model includes demographic, lifestyle, and clinical factors like age, BMI, glucose level, hypertension, smoking status, and history of heart disease. The data, gathered from hospital records, showed extreme class imbalance, which was addressed using the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE). Three robust gradient boosting models XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost were stacked as the base learners, and Logistic Regression as the meta- learner to build the SHGE model. Comparative testing with Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and single boosting models proved that SHGE always reported the maximum accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity. Model explainability was improved through SHAP, which identified the most critical risk factors affecting stroke prediction. The framework also incorporates a Streamlit-based chatbot with ChatGPT for real-time, interactive, and user-friendly stroke risk assessment to facilitate prediction as well as conversational guidance. Experimental findings highlight that the SHGE framework provides better predictive accuracy, interpretability, and accessibility, which places it as a likely candidate for solving clinical decision-making in stroke prevention.

title: RecSys-DQKit: A Python Library for Comprehensive Data Quality Assessment of Recommender Systems
authors: Karun Thankachan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The performance and fairness of recommender systems depend critically on the quality of the underlying interaction data. Yet, training datasets often contain duplicates, temporal leakage, skewed exposure patterns, and implicit popularity bias, while also suffering from imbalance, missingness, and poor subgroup representativeness. Such issues distort evaluation, entrench bias, and undermine user trust. Existing toolkits either target general-purpose machine learning validation [1]–[3] or focus on post-training evaluation [4], leaving recommendation-specific data quality largely unaddressed. We present recsys-dqkit, which to our knowledge, is the most comprehensive open-source Python library for systematic data quality assessment in recommender systems. The toolkit implements duplicate and leakage detection, negative-sampling validation, popularity and exposure bias quantification, representativeness and imbalance checks, cold-start risk estimation, catalog and session health analysis, and temporal drift monitoring. Results are surfaced through standardized interfaces and automated reports that highlight potential risks before model training. By integrating recommendation-specific diagnostics with reproducible reporting, recsys-dqkit provides a holistic framework for data quality in recommender systems, bridging a key gap between general validation libraries and domain-specific recommendation frameworks [5], [6].

title: Channel-Sequence Attention and Multi-Scale Features based Speech Enhancement
authors: Sunnydayal V, Sanjana Das, Eduru Sree Nikitha, Kante Shalini Sandhya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Two-stage speech enhancement models are the evident winners compared to single-stage methods, however, they usually work under the STFT completely which results in not only long but also costly computational processes and additionally difficult phase refinement. To resolve these issues, Channel Attention Multi Scale Feature based STFT-STDCT Spectrum Fusion Network (CSMS-FDFNet) is introduced as a novel framework that performs the first enhancement phase in the STFT domain and effectively executes the second phase in the STDCT domain.The approach takes advantage of the superior denoising ability and the simpler phase structure of the STDCT to suppress the residual noise and misalignment very efficiently. The model also includes a multi-scale feature extractor (MSFE) for better representation and a ch/annel-sequence attention (CSAtt) mechanism for drawing attention to the essential information. Extensive evaluations have shown that CSMS-FDFNet is the highest performing model that not only beats the other two-stage models on the key metrics considered but also places itself at the top of the list. The proposed method is a framework that is powerful yet economically friendly and thus highly competitive with the currently available top-notch techniques, presenting a remarkable improvement in the area of speech enhancement.

title: Advanced Smart Energy Meter Monitoring and Anti-Theft Solution based on Internet of Things (IoT) enabled Technology
authors: G. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of urbanization and energy demand has intensified the need for efficient monitoring and theft detection in power distribution systems. The classical electromechanical and non-mechanical meters are inaccurate and prone to manipulation, which has caused utility providers to lose a lot of revenue. The given research provides an IoT-based smart energy meter monitoring and anti-theft device that incorporates embedded voltage/current sensors, tampering detection units, LoRaWAN-based communication, edge analytics, cloud integration, and hybrid detection algorithms. This suggested system uses Raspberry Pi as an edge processor, Azure IoT Hub as a cloud-processing unit, and distributed databases in order to scale data storage. The hybrid CNN-SVM approach is used to identify the abnormal consumption patterns and it is supplemented with the rule-based logic to detect the tampering events that includes reverse current flow and bypass connections. Experimental analysis illustrates that the suggested solution attains an average monitoring accuracy of 98.3% to energy consumption and a theft detection accuracy of 96.8% compared to the baseline models such as SVM, Random Forest and CNN-only models. Security analysis indicates that AES and ECC-based encryption have less than 3.5% overhead which guarantees confidentiality as well as efficiency. The findings confirm the effectiveness, scalability, and feasibility of the suggested system to be used in reality. In the future, this framework will be expanded by introducing federated learning to detect theft privately and verify the use of blockchains to validate energy transactions, which will enhance trust and transparency in smart grids. This is a major contribution that is aimed at developing sustainable, smart, and inaccessible energy distribution ecosystem.

title: Generative AI for Credit Risk Assessment: A Machine Learning Framework for Data Augmentation and Scoring
authors: Sowjanya Karri
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Credit risk assessment is an important aspect of identifying borrowers' trustworthiness and maintaining financial stability; however, typical credit scoring models for lending decisions suffer from data sparsity, class imbalance, and bias to some extent that leads to inaccurate or unfair predictions. This work develops a prejudice-aware framework for credit scoring systems that employs generative AI to improve the fairness and accuracy of predictions. More specifically, we use Conditional Tabular Generative Adversarial Networks (CTGAN) to classify, balance, and create (synthetic) credit data to supplement the actual credit data with actual borrower profiles. This solved sparsity and allows borrow population to be more accurately prioritized. We evaluate two standard credit scoring classifiers (XGBoost, Random Forest, Neural Networks) on the augmented dataset along with SHAP-based decision explainability to facilitate interpretability for loan officers. In an experimental evaluation using the German Credit Dataset, we showed strong performance improvements, with recall = 0.83 and AUC = 0.91 for XGBoost, and we showed improved fairness across demographic groups. This study demonstrates the potential contributions of data augmentation, through generative AI in particular, to create credit risk models that are more descriptive, accountable and ultimately high performing and contributes to a more equitable next generation of financial decision systems.
