authors: Filippo A. Spinelli
publish: N/A
abstract: Bulk material handling involves the efficient and precise moving of large quantities of materials, a core operation in many industries, including cargo ship unloading, waste sorting, construction, and demolition. These repetitive, labor-intensive, and safety-critical operations are typically performed using large hydraulic material handlers equipped with underactuated grippers. In this work, we present a comprehensive framework for the autonomous execution of large-scale material handling tasks. The system integrates specialized modules for environment perception, pile attack point selection, path planning, and motion control. The main contributions of this work are two reinforcement learning-based modules: an attack point planner that selects optimal grasping locations on the material pile to maximize removal efficiency and minimize the number of scoops, and a robust trajectory following controller that addresses the precision and safety challenges associated with underactuated grippers in movement, while utilizing their free-swinging nature to release material through dynamic throwing. We validate our framework through real-world experiments on a 40 t material handler in a representative worksite, focusing on two key tasks: high-throughput bulk pile management and high-precision truck loading. Comparative evaluations against human operators demonstrate the system’s effectiveness in terms of precision, repeatability, and operational safety. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first complete automation of material handling tasks on a full scale.

title: Evaluation of a Compton Camera System for Whole-body Imaging of Ac-225: A Simulation Study
authors: Yuemeng Feng, Arkadiusz Sitek, Shadi Abdar Esfahani, Hamid Sabet
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: In this study, we introduce a Compton camera system design for whole-body imaging of Actinium-225 (<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac), one of the trending radionuclides for targeted alpha therapy (TAT). The system enables multi-energy gamma photon detection with higher efficiency compared to mechanically collimated SPECT. This design consists of two detectors made of Cadmium zinc telluride (CZT), providing a field of view (FOV) adequate for whole-body imaging, while achieving high sensitivity and clinically usable imaging resolution within a reasonable scanning time. This work focuses on the system design and evaluation using the Monte Carlo simulation toolkit GATE. The imaging performance is evaluated at two energy peaks (218 keV, 440 keV) by applying the energy windows of 211-225 keV and 430-450 keV, representing the major detectable gamma energies generated from <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac. We explore the possibility of using the Compton camera system for treatment response monitoring in TAT. The full decay chain of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac is simulated. Results demonstrate an image resolution of 1.0 cm using a NEMA IQ phantom with 5.7 MBq of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac simulated in a cold background. An image resolution of 1.3 cm can be achieved with a hot-to-background ratio of 30:1, and a resolution of 3.7 cm can be achieved with an activity ratio of 12:1. The best achievable sensitivity at a 10 cm distance from the detector is 0.5% at 218 keV and 0.45% at 440 keV as calculated using a pure gamma source in the simulation. The proposed system may serve as an alternative imaging tool for TAT scanning in clinical settings.

title: Contour-Guided Feature Selection for Visual Relocalization
authors: Hsin-Chun Lin, Yu-Hsiu Lin, Ming-Xian Hong, Yung-Yao Chen
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Scene coordinate regression (SCR) offers an efficient alternative to computation-heavy feature-matching methods for visual relocalization but often suffers from incorrect geometric associations in complex environments. This paper proposes a novel contour-guided feature selection framework to enhance SCR robustness by integrating point and line features. We introduce two key mechanisms: a Feature Contribution Estimation (FCE) module that dynamically reweights features to suppress noise, and a Contour Guidance (CG) module that leverages edge maps to prioritize geometrically significant structures during training. Extensive experiments on the 7-Scenes and Cambridge Landmarks datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art learning-based baselines, achieving an average accuracy of 80.6% on the 7-Scenes dataset. This approach encourages the model to learn more stable and semantically meaningful features, ultimately enhancing localization performance.

title: Embedded Multi-view Clustering via Fusing Tensor Subspace Representation and Adaptive Graph Learning
authors: Jingyu Wang, Tingquan Deng, Yi Ran, Ming Yang, Xinwang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Multi-view clustering (MVC) aims to uncover the consistent structure and latent distribution of data by integrating information from diverse perspectives. A series of MVC models have been developed, but most of them are limited. They either naively fuse multi-view data into a single view or process each view in isolation, thereby neglecting the complex relationships between views. Among which, multi-stage approaches are heavily dependent on pre-learning and post-processing steps. To overcome these limitations, a one-stage MVC model, namely the embedded multi-view clustering approach with tensor self-representation and adaptive graph learning (EMCTGL), is proposed. In the proposed model, a step-structured data tensor is constructed and then decomposed to learn a cross-view self-representation tensor, effectively capturing the global topological relationships across all views. To achieve a clearer global subspace structure, a novel TLog-induced non-convex low-rank regularization is imposed on the rotated representation tensor. Under relaxed symmetry constraints, the self-representative tensor guides the learning of view-specific affinity graphs and a σ-norm penalty is applied to promote approximation of symmetry of affinity graphs. Subsequently, the normalized view-specific graphs are adaptively fused and factorized into the final clustering indicator matrix by embedding the semi-non-negative decomposition within a one-stage framework. To reduce the computational complexity, EMCTGL is extended to an anchor-driven MVC through determining anchors based on an adaptive density-peak strategy. Effective optimization schemes are devised to solve these non-convex models. Extensive experiments on various real-world datasets demonstrate that EMCTGL outperforms current state-of-the-art techniques.

title: SiVe: See Into the Vehicle's Hidden Persons Via Laser Doppler Vibrometer
authors: Zhu Xiao, Shirong Guan, Jingyang Hu, Siyu Chen, Hongbo Jiang, Keqin Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Detecting stowaways hidden in various transport vehicles, including cars, trucks, containers, and trailers, is crucial to border security inspection systems. Existing solutions mainly rely on contact-based sensors and manual inspection, which significantly compromise the efficiency of border control operations. Therefore, there is an urgent need for an automated, efficient and fast non-contact vehicle hidden person detection system. In this paper, we propose SiVe, a novel border inspection system that utilizes laser Doppler vibrometer (LDV) to detect hidden people in the vehicle. We extract signals associated with human activities (such as breathing, heartbeat, low-frequency body movements, etc.) from complex laser reflection data to detect the presence of hidden people. Specifically, we first employs the Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD) algorithm to extract and reconstruct signals associated with human activities in complex and noisy environments. Then based on the characteristics of EMD outputs, we design a Time-series Variation Feature extraction Identification network (TVFI-net) model that accurately captures complex time-varying patterns for efficient and reliable detection of hidden people presence. Extensive real-world experiments validate the effectiveness of SiVe in various environments. The system achieves an average presence detection accuracy of 99.93<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> for sedans and MPVs, 98.37<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> for light trucks, 98.07<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> for heavy trucks, and 95.23<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula> for trailers in non-contact detection of hidden people across twelve different vehicle types, under various indoor and outdoor environments.

title: The Solid-State Grounding: The Concept, Design, Structure, and Performance
authors: S. A. Saleh, A. Jee, J. Meng, E. Ozkop, R. Ahshan, A. Al-Durra
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: 1The grounding system of any power system equipment is designed to support the continuity of operation, provide a path for fault currents, improve personnel safety, and reduce/eliminate ground potentials. The growing number of grid-connected power electronic converters (PECs) poses challenges for conventional grounding systems. These challenges are mostly due to ground currents and potentials that are dominated by harmonic components produced by grid-connected PECs. Such ground currents and potentials are caused by the instantaneous unbalances, in voltages and/or currents, created by switching actions of a 3φ grid-connected PEC. This paper investigates new designs of grounding systems that are based on power electronic converters. Different possible designs and structures are examined in order to meet the requirements of a grounding system. A design procedure is developed for the proposed grounding systems that is introduced as the solid-state grounding. The performance of the solid-state grounding is evaluated in simulation and laboratory experimentation for different equipment. Performance results show encouraging abilities of the solid-state grounding to limit ground potentials and currents, while minimizing the harmonic distortion. Finally, observed operational features of the solid-state grounding are further demonstrated through comparisons with other grounding systems under similar operating conditions.

title: A Physics-Informed Data-Driven Friction Prediction Method for Crystal Growth Equipment
authors: Lingxia Mu, Xielong Zhang, Youmin Zhang, Shaobo Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The nonlinear friction has a critical influence on the quality of single-crystal silicon (SCS), because of the lifting speed jitter and creeping phenomenon induced by the friction during the Czochralski crystal growth process. In this article, a new friction prediction method is proposed by fusing the improved LuGre friction model, lifting servo dynamic model, and measured data. The friction prediction physical information neural network (FP-PINN) is constructed, where the loss function consists of both physical information loss and data loss. The physical information loss includes the improved LuGre (ILG) model and servo dynamics. Where, ILG is modified by considering the crystal growth characteristic, i.e., the influence of SCS weight variation and rotation. In addition, a partial differential equation is constructed to describe behavior of the crystal weight variation. A weight estimation (WE)-PINN is then designed to solve the crystal weight, since the SCS weight variation caused by crystal growth and speed jitter is hard to calculate in real operation process. Finally, the obtained SCS weight is integrated into the FP-PINN to achieve an accurate and robust friction torque. Experiments are conducted to verify the accuracy and generalization ability of the proposed method.

title: Visual Robot Aided Laser Standoff Methane Sensor for Pipeline Leak Detection
authors: Jinyi Li, Xuhan Ran, Weijia Gong, Xue Yang, Chang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: As gas pipelines continue to expand, efficient and intelligent leak detection has become increasingly critical for natural gas transportation and safe production in the oil and gas industry. Due to the inefficiency of traditional manual detection methods and their unsuitability for hazardous environments, this paper proposes a laser detection system for gas pipeline leak detection, enhanced by a vision-guided robotic arm. Additionally, the Cuckoo algorithm is introduced to optimize the classic Tsai-Lenz hand-eye calibration algorithm, addressing its sensitivity to noise and the coupling effects between rotation and translation matrices, thereby significantly improving the system’s robustness and accuracy. Experimental results show that the improved algorithm reduce translation and rotation errors by 43.75% and 61.53%, respectively, demonstrating its advantages in terms of reliability and precision. Finally, an indoor gas pipeline leakage experiment conducted at a 3 m standoff distance revealed that the detection system achieves a leak point positioning error of 1 cm and can effectively track methane concentration changes within a range of 10 ppm·m to 9200 ppm·m. Outdoor field tests validated the system’s reliable detection performance and robustness against environmental interference under real-world operational conditions.

title: Robust Pixel-by-Pixel Multimodal Remote Sensing Image Registration Using Geometry Preserving Dense Registration Network
authors: Liang Zhou, Tao Peng, Zhiqiang Han, Liangzhi Li, Qing Zhu, Yuanxin Ye
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The integration of multimodal remote sensing (RS) data is pivotal for advancing Earth observation capabilities, where high precision cross-modal image registration serves as the cornerstone for realizing its full potential. While sparse feature matching methods have achieved high registration accuracy by extracting corresponding points and solving the parameters of the assumed geometric transformation model, they still struggle to effectively address local nonrigid deformations between multimodal images. Additionally, image dense registration methods are prone to introducing significant mismatching noise, which frequently results in structural distortions of typical ground features (e.g., roads, buildings, etc.) within global deformation regions. To address that, we propose a novel geometry preserving dense registration network (GPDRNet) for multimodal RS image registration tasks. Our approach incorporates three key innovations: 1) a feature enhancement module that generates more discriminative cross-modal feature representations; 2) a geometry consistency loss that preserves critical structural and morphological characteristics of typical ground features within global deformation regions; and 3) a local deformation-aware post-processing module that first estimates global affine field, and then identifies local deformation regions through residual flow analysis. Experimental results validate the superior effectiveness and robustness of the proposed GPDRNet over existing state-of-the-art multimodal RS image registration methods. The code of the proposed method will be available at https://github.com/yeyuanxin110.

title: Client-Side Video Analysis for Content Moderation with MoQ
authors: Andrew Freeman, Jeremy Bellert, Abanisenioluwa Orojo, Greg Speegle
publish: Proceedings of the conference on Proceedings of the 5th Mile-High Video Conference
abstract: None

title: Adaptive Multimodal Federated Optimization with Privacy and Blockchain Trust
authors: K. Ramesh Babu, M. Ramesh, M Gnana Prasuna, G. Ganesh Kumar, R. Banu Priya, Anita Pradhan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This article presents the Adaptive Multi-Modal Federated Optimization (AMMFO) framework which was developed to tackle important challenges in data privacy, fairness, and accountability in learning in the context of federated learning. The AMMFO framework addresses the need to train models with data from multiple modalities available at the edge in a secure and efficient manner while building trust and respecting privacy in a decentralized system. AMMFO applies differential privacy to protect sensitive model updates from adversarial inference and it leverages a blockchain-based trust mechanism to allow for transparency, immutability and decentralized accountability. The framework optimally adapts learning across multiple data modalities enhancing communication efficiency and stability of model convergence. Results from experiments indicate that AMMFO achieves 8-10% higher accuracy compared to FedAvg and FedProx, and 7-12% greater privacy resistance compared to FedDP while exploring different privacy budgets. Additionally, AMMFO improves convergence time by 15–20 percent and achieves less than 8% blockchain overhead. Overall, these results demonstrate the AMMFO framework's balance of performance, privacy, and scalability which enables next generation AI systems that are situated within privacy and trust-worthy frameworks in domains such as healthcare, finance, autonomous systems, and smart cities.

title: Automated Hive Image Analysis: A Comparative study on Machine Learning Approach for Bee Detection and Classification
authors: Pratheeksha Hegde N, Jason Elroy Martis, Sannidhan M S, Dabis Camero
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Honeybee populations are essential for pollination and agricultural productivity but face increasing threats from parasites, pesticides, and climate change. To address the need for effective hive monitoring, this study introduces a deep learning-based system for automated bee detection and classification. Utilizing the YOLO (You Only Look Once) architecture, the proposed method performs real-time identification of various bee types, including worker bees, pollen carriers, hornets, and queen bees. The system consists of four stages: object detection, bee isolation, feature extraction, and classification. A dataset of 5,025 annotated hive images was used to train and compare multiple YOLO versions. Among them, YOLOv8 achieved the highest accuracy—98.87% at 100 training epochs. Evaluation metrics such as confusion matrices and performance curves confirm the system's effectiveness in distinguishing between bee categories. The proposed approach offers a scalable, accurate, and efficient solution for intelligent beekeeping. Future work will focus on real-time behavior analysis, handling environmental variability, and deployment on low-power edge devices.

title: Cybershield AI: Detecting & Preventing DNS Spoofing Attacks
authors: S. Nivedha, P. Ananthi, M. Boopathi, R. Jayakeerthick
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Cyber Shield AI is an artificial intelligence machine learning framework that is used to identify and mitigate the Domain Name System (DNS) spoofing attacks. DNS spoofing redirects normal traffic to rogue servers that can be used to steal data, perform phishing (attack) and install malware. The conventional rule-based or signature-based approaches find it difficult to detect newer and advanced forms of spoofing and this poses the necessity that adaptive detection mechanisms be employed. In this research paper, a hybrid between supervised and unsupervised learning will be proposed to extract features and detect anomalies in DNS traffic. The algorithms used to accurately infer the legitimate requests and spoofed requests additionally include the Random Forest and Neural Networks to identify legitimate requests and spoofed requests even when the network is dynamic. Multi-layer detection model can improve the accuracy and decrease false positives and symmetric-key cryptography is able to provide a secure transmission of data. Empirical testing of actual DNS traffic (as well as simulated attack data) shows that it is highly accurate with better precision, recall and F1 scores than traditional evaluation. The Cyber Shield AI therefore offers a good scalable and secure AI-driven means of mitigating the DNS spoofing threats in contemporary networks.

title: AI-Augmented Service Fabric for Adaptive Resource Management in Cloud Environments
authors: Srinivasu Yalamati
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Dynamic workloads, heterogeneous resources, and stringent Service Level Agreement (SLA) demands are making cloud environments increasingly vulnerable to performance instability and security threats. Nevertheless, traditional threshold-based auto-scaling techniques are reactive and simplistic, often failing to achieve an optimal energy-performance balance under dynamic workload conditions. For online resource provisioning in the cloud, we propose an AI-Augmented Service Fabric (AASF), a hybrid intelligent architecture that integrates reinforcement learning-based adaptive control with short-horizon workload prediction. The system employs a Q-learning-based agent to determine the most efficient scaling actions that minimize latency and energy consumption, while an Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) model predicts incoming request arrival rates. The M/M/m queueing model is employed to formally describe the service dynamics, thereby enabling analytical evaluation of response times and stability conditions. Experimental results on real-world Google Cluster Workload Traces (v2/v3) demonstrate that AASF achieves 100% SLA compliance, reduces average latency by approximately 44%, and lowers energy consumption by around 51% compared with fixed and reactive scaling baselines. Moreover, the hybrid predictive-adaptive mechanism ensures less oscillatory behavior, improved robustness, and smoother scaling decisions. This work contributes a data-driven, mathematically grounded, energy-aware orchestration layer that transforms reactive cloud-centric architectures into self-optimizing autonomous systems. By linking cloud efficiency with sustainability goals and operational resiliency, the proposed AASF framework provides a scalable roadmap for next-generation intelligent resource management.

title: Customer Churn Prediction
authors: P.Thiru Moorthy, J.Vijay Franklin, Manju Bashini. S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Customer churn is a significant issue for financial institutions because it is cheaper to retain existing customers than to acquire brand new customers. This study presents a machine learning approach for customer churn prediction by leveraging structured and unstructured datasets. The dataset comprises data from 500 customers with 19 demographic, behavioral, and feedback-related features. A full pre-processing pipeline was implemented to handle missing values, encode categorical variables, scale numerical variables, and produce a TF-IDF and sentiment analysis of customer feedback. A variety of classifying algorithms were trained to assess predictive power including Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost, and Support Vector Machine and measured through accuracy, AUC, and confusion matrix metrics. Of all the classifying models, the XGBoost model produced the highest predictive performance. The trained model will be leveraged as an interactive Streamlit application, where users will acquire both single and bulk predictions of customer churn probability as visualization of feature importance and action guidance to mitigate churn. The proposed system has validated that sentiments from free texts can be iterated into structured models to improve overall accuracy of churn classification mechanism, but also enhance mitigating retention strategies for banking institutions proactively.

title: Hybrid FT-Transformer and BiLSTM Framework for Accurate Air Quality Prediction using Adaptive LiON Optimization
authors: Periasamy Sannasi, Subramanian P, Surendran R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Air pollution is a serious health hazard and hence a threat to urban sustainability, making air quality forecasting an essential task. This paper presents a Hybrid Feature Tokenizer Transformer–BiLSTM framework optimized through Adaptive LiON, capable of grasping both global temporal dependencies and local sequential patterns of multivariate air quality data. The model brings together pollutant concentrations, meteorological variables, and urban factors, while the feature tokenizer and attention mechanisms improve representation learning. BiLSTM adds another layer of refinement to temporal dependencies by fully modeling past and future sequences, with Adaptive LiON fastening hyperparameter tuning for strong convergence. The framework was tested with a dataset about air quality in Delhi and has provided better predictive performance with MAE-2.515, MAPE-1.850%, MSE-3.810, RMSE-1.952, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>-0.992. Therefore, the results show that the model can minimize prediction errors and generalize well to short- and long-term forecasting horizons. Hence, the approach proves to be a scalable and reliable solution for systematized air quality prediction with real-time implementation and has pragmatic implications for urban planning, health advisories, and environmental policy formulation.

title: An Intelligent College Enquiry Chatbot for Automated Information Retrieval using NLP
authors: Akshaya DK, Anitha P, Dharsana SK, K. Narasima Mallikarjunan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The College Enquiry Chatbot is an advanced automated system designed to improve the efficiency and accessibility of information dissemination related to college services and activities. It aims to provide immediate, accurate, and user-friendly responses to common queries such as admissions, courses, faculty, hostels, fees, and extracurricular activities. Users can interact with the chatbot through this interface, which simplifies query input and retrieval. This paper presents a novel hybrid intelligent chatbot architecture to provide immediate, accurate, and conversational responses to queries. The system integrates a rule-based fuzzy matching engine for high-confidence, frequent queries with a powerful generative AI fallback model. Overall, the College Enquiry Chatbot provides a dynamic, intelligent platform that bridges the communication gap between students and the administration, improving engagement and the quality of information delivery.

title: Prediction and Analysis of Water Quality Index using Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Deepa S, Arun G, Kanimozhi T, Suguna R, Chandru M, Aravinth S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Clean and reliable water is a vital factor for sustainability and public health. Traditional testing of water quality relies on manually selected tests, which take a lot of time and money. This study uses machine learning (ML) techniques to help automate and improve the prediction of the Water Quality Index (WQI). Factors are preliminary examination of the water and include physicochemical factors such as pH, chloramines, sulfate, conductivity, trihalomethanes, and turbidity. The data was collected from Kaggle and preprocessed using forward fill/backward fill, inject Gaussian noise (to augment the data), and removed outliers using the Interquartile Range method. For feature selection, a combination of Recursive Feature Elimination, and Random Forest algorithm were used, filling the role of a feature selection method. Three algorithms, KNN, LightGBM, and CatBoost were evaluated with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> scores of 0.8835, 0.9295, and 0.9669, respectively. The CatBoost model showed better predictive performance with lower error metrics compared to both KNN and LightBG, and also provided accuracy in mapping both mean and median WQI scores. The proposed machine learning framework added value to water quality assessments for immediate decisions about water being tested, and about sustainability and time-saving methods.

title: Review of Phasor Estimation Algorithms and Applications of Phasor Measurement Units
authors: Samah A. Mohamed, Hala M. Abdel Mageed, Osama M. Arafa, Mohamed H. Merzban, Magdy B. Eteiba, Amr A. Saleh
publish: IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Magazine
abstract: Modern electrical networks are becoming more complicated, and power system dynamics are being greatly impacted by incorporating renewable energy sources widely. This change emphasizes the necessity for creating new monitoring systems to guarantee the electricity network's continued operation and effectiveness. The measurement infrastructure is vital in this situation. To address diverse applications for monitoring and controlling, such as load shedding and fault detection, it becomes imperative to strike an optimal balance between precision in measurements and minimal reporting latency [1]. Power network detection is accomplished by the use of monitoring systems, which include supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) and contemporary metering devices with Phasor measuring units (PMUs). SCADA is essential to electrical networks because of its dependability and ease of use. Nevertheless, problems with the SCADA system have surfaced, such as slow error detection, low sample rate, and inability to produce time synchronization signals. As a result, switching to new operating systems is required to enhance the SCADA system's acquisition efficiency. Emerging communication technologies, the necessity for quick data processing in power systems, and the more complex difficulties deriving from data transport make this modification important [2]. A synchronized monitoring system, like PMUs, can be a useful tool in difficult circumstances and offers a strong foundation for the complex power system [3]. Synchrophasor measurement, which facilitates the characterization of distribution grids (DGs), served as the main driving force behind the invention of PMUs. When DGs are in operation, the system experiences a reverse power flow, which impairs the distribution power supply's efficiency, reduces the equipment's ability to work, and results in voltage instability [4].

title: A Compact Robotic System for Passive Ankle Therapy and Venous Health Monitoring
authors: Athul Krishna U, Manikanda Prabu N, Syed Numaan S, Vinay Kumaar HP, Vimal Raj K, Thillai Rani M
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Prolonged sitting disrupts venous blood circulation in the lower limbs, leading to chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), varicose veins, and deep vein thrombosis. Existing solutions such as compression stockings, pneumatic pumps, and bulky rehabilitation robots provide only partial relief, lacking portability and adaptability for daily use. To address this gap, we present VENOUS+, a compact robotic healthcare device designed to passively train the ankle and stimulate the calf muscle pump. Unlike traditional systems, VENOUS+ integrates an adaptive foot-mapping mechanism that adjusts ankle motion according to user posture, ensuring comfort and safety. Additional features include accelerometer– gyroscope–based fall detection, emergency stop control, and a thermal management system for extended operation. Beyond therapy, the device enables AI/ML-assisted health monitoring with real-time data logging. Experimental results show that VENOUS+ improves venous blood flow velocity and ankle range of motion by more than 70% compared with sedentary conditions, achieving nearly three-fourths of active exercise effectiveness. These outcomes highlight VENOUS+ as a practical bridge between costly rehabilitation machines and simple wellness tools, promoting sustainable venous care in sedentary lifestyles.

title: A Connected Ambulance System Leveraging IoT for Real Time Navigation and Automated Emergency Procedures
authors: M. Manochitra, Madhumitha. V, Rithika. K, Shalini. N, Tharani. M
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Emergency Medical Services (EMS) often experience critical delays due to manual coordination, traffic jams, and poor patient identification. This paper presents a Smart Ambulance System that uses IoT technology to reduce response times and improve hospital readiness through automation and real-time data sharing. The system combines biometric patient authentication, GPS-based routing, and automatic hospital notifications, using an ESP8266-12E microcontroller, Arduino IDE, PHP, and MySQL. It analyzes real-time traffic and hospital capacity data to find the best routes and reserve hospital beds in advance. Automated alerts keep family members and medical staff informed. Experimental results show a 20 to 30% decrease in response time, 92% accuracy in patient identification, and better coordination between ambulances and hospitals. This system offers a scalable and dependable framework for effective emergency management, useful in urban healthcare, rural outreach, and disaster relief.

title: Modeling of Memoryless Power Amplifiers and Implementation Scheme of Adaptive Predistortion in Wireless Communications
authors: Yi Han
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: This paper focuses on memoryless power amplifier (PA) modeling and adaptive predistortion (APD)—key technologies for enhancing linearity and efficiency in wireless communication systems, as PAs (critical components in transmission chains) exhibit inherent nonlinearity that distorts signals and degrades communication quality, making accurate modeling and effective predistortion essential. First, three memoryless PA models were constructed, with performance evaluated by balancing fitting accuracy (alignment with real PA nonlinearity) and structural complexity (computational cost); comparative analysis showed the polynomial model was optimal, as it achieved sufficient fitting precision without excessive complexity hindering real-time use. Subsequently, the study determined the ideal gain factor g—a pivotal parameter for the predistortion model—via iterative simulations to match the PA’s actual gain characteristics, and analysed predistortion models of varying orders to explore trade-offs between linearization effect and computational overhead, identifying an optimal order range of 15th to 20th where models effectively suppressed distortion without unnecessary complexity. Ultimately, considering practical engineering constraints like hardware computational limits, a 15th-order APD model was selected for implementation, balancing strong linearization performance with feasible deployment to provide a practical solution for improving PA linearity in wireless systems.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Customer Loyalty Prediction
authors: KalyanKumar P, Sherwyn Matthews S, MahaManikandan S, Nithish M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Customer loyalty prediction is crucial for keeping customers in competitive retail sectors such as the fashion industry and other businesses. Basic measurements such as Recency, Frequency, and Monetary (RFM), Net Promoter Score (NPS), and Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) do not capture emotional or behavioral factors, so they have limits in prediction. The Sentiment-Enhanced Loyalty Score (SELS) combines normalized sentiment from text reviews ([-1, 1], based on BERT) and purchase frequency ([0, 1]), giving both equal weight (0.5). Using a Random Forest classifier, SELS divides customers into Loyal, At-Risk, and One-Time Buyer groups. In a UK/US fashion retail data set, SELS achieves 87.5% accuracy, which is 25-30% better than RFM, NPS, and CSAT for predicting churn and customer lifetime value (CLV). Pie charts and an NPS-style score make it easier to improve retention planning. This flexible framework, built on natural language processing and machine learning, offers a solid and clear tool for data-driven customer relationship management that addresses emotional and behavioral gaps in current methods.

title: A Path Planning Method for UAV Transportation Based on PSO
authors: Bing Liu, Yinglang Zhu, Jingjing Qian, Jiaqi Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: This study first establishes a mathematical model for the research objective: maximizing the number of cities visited while ensuring the total path length does not exceed L. If the number of visited cities is identical, the model aims to minimize the total path length. Subsequently, an improved PSO algorithm is developed and applied to UAV logistics transportation scenarios. This approach addresses the research goal of optimizing multi-target point paths under endurance constraints, demonstrating that the PSO algorithm can effectively solve UAV transportation path planning problems.

title: AI-Powered Enhanced Medical QA Chatbot System with Sentiment Analysis Mood Tracking and Personalized Mental Health Recommendations
authors: Abeesh SV, Srinitya G
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Mental health challenges such as anxiety, depression, and stress-related disorders continue to rise globally, necessitating accessible and personalized digital support systems. This paper presents an AI-Powered Enhanced Medical QA Chatbot System that integrates transformer-based natural language processing with fine-grained sentiment and mood analysis to deliver contextual, emotionally adaptive, and clinically relevant responses. The system employs a fine-tuned T5 transformer model for medical question answering, supported by a Gemini AI verification layer to ensure factual accuracy, tone appropriateness, and response safety. Sentiment understanding is performed using an enhanced VADER-based multi-emotion classifier capable of detecting over twelve emotional states with intensity scaling, enabling dynamic personalization of therapeutic recommendations such as mindfulness tasks, cognitive behavioral therapy exercises, and guided relaxation resources. Temporal mood trends are maintained to adapt interventions over time. Experimental evaluation demonstrates improved semantic coherence, reduced factual error rate, and increased user engagement, with ROUGE-L reaching 0.87 and sentiment classification accuracy at 92%. The proposed system advances emotionally intelligent and safety-aware digital mental health support.

title: Integrated Deep Learning Models of Residual Attention Network with Recurrent Neural Network for Accurate Facial Recognition and Emotional Detection
authors: Srinivas B, S. Maruthuperumal, Dr. Ramesh G
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: One of the difficult tasks in the research field of social communication is detecting human emotions from images. These days, face recognition approaches are very useful for applications like home security, criminal identification, and phone unlocking systems. Face recognition technology is one of the popular tasks under the Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) field. In order to capture the nano and micro facial emotions, automatic facial emotion detection models are needed. Most of the traditional models do not focus on the subtle facial landmarks and miss the contextual elements needed for precise face as well as emotion recognition. Thus, this paper proposes an automated model of facial recognition and emotion detection using a deep learning approach. Initially, the required input images are collected from the benchmark datasets. Secondly, the person is identified by face recognition using the Residual Attention Network (RAN). Finally, the human emotions are detected through RAN with a Recurrent Neural Network (RAN-RNN) model. This integral model leverages the strength of both networks to ensure robustness, processing the sequence of features over time, and detecting the emotion significantly. Once the recognition and detection are done, the proposed model obtained an accuracy of 95.72%, which represents the supremacy of the proposed system.

title: High-Frequency Resonance Suppression of MMC-HVDC Based on the Coordination of Voltage Feedforward Filtering and Passive Damping
authors: Yunfeng Li, Tao Wen, Yijia Cao, Jiebei Zhu, Ming Kong, Yuhang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: The interaction between the negative damping inductive characteristics of MMC-based converter station in the high-frequency band and the capacitive characteristics of the AC system is the reason for the high-frequency resonances (HFRs). Existing damping controls and voltage feedforward filtering methods cannot suppress the HFRs completely because the negative damping of MMC in the high frequency range cannot be eliminated, resulting in the persistent HFR risk. To address this problem, the requirements of voltage feedforward loop for shifting the mentioned negative damping frequency range is revealed based on the simplified MMC impedance. A voltage feedforward filter composed of a notch filter and a first-order low-pass filter is presented accompanied by the parameters calculated and optimized. Furthermore, a coordinated suppression strategy integrating voltage feedforward filtering with a passive damping filter is proposed based on the principle of impedance reshaping. This strategy can eliminate the negative damping of the HVDC station completely in the high-frequency range while simultaneously reducing the parameters of passive damping filter. By doing so, the comprehensive performance of the coordinated suppression scheme is significantly improved. Time-domain simulations validate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method under various operating conditions.

title: On the Scalability of Access and Mobility Management Function: the Localization Management Function Use Case
authors: Domenico Scotece, Giuseppe Santaromita, Claudio Fiandrino, Luca Foschini, Domenico Giustiniano
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: The adoption of Service-Based Architecture (SBA) in 5G Core Networks (5GC) has significantly transformed the design and operation of the control plane, enabling greater flexibility and agility for cloud-native deployments. While the infrastructure has initially evolved by implementing key functions, there remains significant potential for additional services, such as localization, paving the way for the integration of the Location Management Function (LMF). However, the extensive functional decomposition within SBA leads to consequences, such as the increase of control plane operations. Specifically, we observe that the additional signaling traffic introduced by the presence of the LMF overwhelms the Access and Mobility Management Function (AMF) which is responsible for authentication and mobility. In fact, in mobile positioning, each connected mobile device requires a significant amount of control traffic to support location algorithms in the 5GC. To address this scalability challenge, we analyze the impact of three well-known optimization techniques on location procedures to reduce control message traffic in the specific context of the 5GC, namely a caching system, a request aggregation system, and a service scalability system. Our solutions are evaluated in an OpenAirInterface (OAI) emulated environment with real hardware. After the analysis in the emulated environment, we select the caching system – due to its feasibility – for being analyzed in a real 5G testbed. Our results demonstrate a significant reduction in the additional overhead introduced by the LMF, improving scalability by minimizing the impact on AMF processing time up to a 50% reduction.

title: SGA-Seq: Station-aware Graph Attention Sequence Network for Cellular Traffic Prediction
authors: Shiyu Yang, Qunyong Wu, Zhanchao Huang, Zihao Zhuo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Cellular traffic prediction is crucial for optimizing network resources and enhancing service quality. Despite progress in existing traffic prediction methods, challenges remain in capturing periodic features, spatial heterogeneity, and abnormal signals. To address these challenges, we propose a Station-aware Graph Attention Sequence Network (SGA-Seq). The core idea is to achieve accurate cellular traffic prediction by adaptively modeling station-specific spatiotemporal patterns and effectively handling complex traffic dynamics. First, we introduce a learnable temporal embedding mechanism to capture temporal features across multiple scales. Second, we design a station-aware graph attention network to model complex spatial relationships across stations. Additionally, by progressively separating regular and abnormal signals layer by layer, we enhance the model’s robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that SGA-Seq outperforms existing methods on five diverse mobile network datasets spanning different scales, including cellular traffic, mobility flow, and communication datasets. Notably, on the V-GCT dataset, our method achieves an 8.04% improvement in Root Mean Squared Error compared to the Spatiotemporal-aware Trend-Seasonality Decomposition Network. The code of SGA-Seq is available at https://github.com/OvOYu/SGA-Seq.

title: Development of a phase transient test bench to optimize a cold-atom microwave clock
authors: Luc Archambault, Mathieu Guéridon, Cédric Majek, Luca Lorini, Arnaud Landragin, Bruno Desruelle, Bruno Pelle
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Ultrasonics, Ferroelectrics, and Frequency Control
abstract: MuClock is a commercial transportable microwave clock developed at Exail Quantum Systems, using rubidium atoms cooled by isotropic laser light. MuClock is comparable with typical hydrogen masers in terms of volume and long-term frequency stability, as it nominally reaches a fractional frequency stability of 1 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−15</sup> in less than two days and maintains this level of performance over more than one month of integration time. The evaluation of several systematic frequency shifts is on-going. This article presents the impact of the frequency bias induced by microwave phase transients on the clock frequency stability and accuracy. Using an in-house designed test bench, the phase of the 6.8 GHz microwave clock signal is measured with a phase resolution close to 1 μrad and a temporal resolution below 100 ns. It enables a thorough optimization of the sequence and a better control of each phase transient event, making their contributions to the overall frequency shift negligible. The accuracy of the associated systematic effect is evaluated at 3 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−15</sup>.

title: A 3-D Analytical Modeling of High- k MOSFETs Using Conformal Mapping: A Cell Topology Perspective
authors: Zhigang Wang, Yihui Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: A 3-D analytical model from the cell topology perspective is developed to optimize the specific <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-resistance (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${R}_{\mathrm{ON,sp}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) for power vertical MOSFETs with a high-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math> </inline-formula> insulating dielectric (HKMOS). Based on the circular-cell solution solved by Green’s function considering interface charges (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${N}_{\text {it}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), this model enables the transformation of cell topology from circle to polygon via Schwarz–Christoffel (SC) conformal mapping. The intrinsic coupling between cell layout and device design is also revealed to co-optimize <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${R}_{\mathrm{ON, {sp}}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and breakdown voltage (BV).

title: Spatial Correlation of Routing and Platooning for Detecting Arbitrary BH Attacks in CAV Platoons
authors: Everaldo Andrade, Lucas Araujo, Aldri Santos
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: CAV platoons rely on routing and platooning services to ensure coordinated and safe mobility. However, their open and infrastructure-less communication environment exposes them to Black Hole (BH) attacks that disrupt routing and degrade platoon performance. This paper presents DeSCAV (Anomaly Detection based on Multi-Services State for CAV Platoon), a cooperative detection system that exploits the spatial correlation between routing and platooning services to detect anomalies caused by arbitrary BH attacks. Using a Convolutional Neural Network, DeSCAV models the relationship between these services to enable a distributed and adaptive detection. We implemented DeSCAV in NS-3 and integrated with SUMO and TensorFlow, and compared it with the KsBH-Detec approach under multiple traffic densities. Results show that DeSCAV outperformed KsBH-Detec, with $\approx$0.8% false alarms and 9–10% missed alerts against 50–64% and 43–57%, respectively. DeSCAV achieved accuracy above 0.93 and F1-score $\approx$0.95, while KsBH-Detec reached only 0.39 and $\approx$0.26. DeSCAV also detected attacks up to 5.7x faster, confirming its higher accuracy and robustness under all densities.

title: Joint Optimization of Federated Continual Learning and Inference in IoT Towards Intelligence: A Multi-Objective SAC with Hybrid Action Space
authors: Ruizhe Yang, Xuan Wang, Meng Li, Yinglei Teng, Enchang Sun
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: To support the intelligent evolution of Internet of Things (IoT) systems toward enhanced comprehensiveness and sophistication, this paper proposes a distributed training and inference oriented toward continual learning. By integrating federated continual learning with inference offloading, the system addresses key challenges in IoT scenarios, including large-scale data processing, catastrophic forgetting during incremental updates, and resource constraints. A joint optimization framework of training-inference is established to analyze model accuracy, latency, and energy consumption. The optimization objective and strategy are formulated as a Markov Decision Process (MDP) with a hybrid action space and customized reward mechanism. The Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm enables action grouping and the transformation between discrete and continuous actions, achieving unified optimization of training and inference. Simulation results show that compared to existing approaches, the proposed method improves node selection, resource allocation, and offloading strategy by jointly considering communication and computation costs.

title: Task-Oriented Integrated Sensing and Communication for Multidevice Cooperative Motion Recognition
authors: Zhuo Sun, Zhiwen Yu, Huimin Mao, Zhiqiang Wei, Zhu Wang, Bin Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Multidevice cooperative wireless sensing offers a promising solution for human motion recognition, owing to its superior privacy preservation and robustness. In the sensing process, devices continuously extract features from channel echoes and transmit them to a fusion center for motion recognition over successive time slots. The intertwined sub-processes of sensing and communication jointly determine recognition accuracy, yet simultaneously compete for limited radio resources. Moreover, the dynamic nature of practical environments further complicates this interplay due to the presence of moving interference sources and time-varying number of cellular users sharing the available bandwidth. Therefore, it is of paramount importance to jointly optimize sensing and communication resource allocation among devices and across time slots, while meticulously accounting for the impacts of dynamic environment to maximize recognition accuracy. In this paper, we propose a task-oriented integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system for multidevice cooperative wireless motion recognition in dynamic environments. Specifically, we formulate a joint sensing and communication resource allocation problem to maximize recognition accuracy, represented by a discriminant gain metric that explicitly accounts for both sensing quality and communication constraints. Since this problem is a fractional program, we transform the original sum-of-ratios objective function into an equivalently subtractive form that facilities the development of a two-step iterative offline optimization (TSIO) algorithm to achieve the benchmark performance. Furthermore, to effectively cope with dynamic environmental influences, we further design a multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL)-based online optimization (MRLO) scheme, which predicts environmental conditions at the subsequent time slot and adaptively optimizes resource allocation. Extensive numerical results illustrate that the proposed algorithm significantly enhances the recognition accuracy with dynamic environment influences, compared to existing benchmark algorithms. It is also observed from results that the sensing performance primarily drives recognition accuracy when energy is limited, whereas communication performance becomes the dominant factor under bandwidth constraints.

title: Miniaturized Si₃N₄ Resonator with a High Polarization Extinction Ratio and Quality Factor for Improving the Sensitivity of Resonant Integrated Optical Gyroscope
authors: Sheng Liao, Changkun Feng, Chen Wen, Muyuan Tian, Yixin Xu, Yueyang Li, Qiwei Wang, Ningfang Song, Hui Li
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Resonant integrated optical gyroscope (RIOG) has significant potential for miniaturization and high-resolution sensing. This work reports a 16-mm-diameter Si₃N₄ resonator that achieves simultaneous high polarization extinction ratio and quality factor (Q). Polarization selectivity is achieved by combining a bending-loss-induced cutoff with offset S-bend waveguide filters. The Q factor is enhanced by implementing an under-coupled operation regime in an ultrathin-core waveguide architecture. And thermal stability is ensured via interfacial stress engineering, which involves cycles of re-etching and dual annealing. The aforementioned approaches achieve dual breakthroughs—a polarization extinction ratio exceeding 1800 dB/m and a Q of 14 million, preserving <7% of the variation in the Q from –40 to 60 °C. These advancements collectively result in record-long bias stability of 0.19 deg∙h-1, achieving tactical-grade resolution in RIOG. The achieved performance marks a significant step toward the practical deployment of RIOGs.

title: Terahertz Waveguide Probe Loaded with Complementary Split-Ring Resonator for Crack Detection in Metallic Surface
authors: Fei Liu, Ming Ye
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: TThis paper proposes a terahertz open waveguide probe integrated with a complementary split-ring resonator (CSRR) for metallic crack detection. Simulation results show that the detection sensitivity decreases in a periodic oscillatory pattern with increasing lift-off distance. At an optimal lift-off distance of 4 mm, the probe can accurately detect metal microcracks with a width of 0.01 mm and a depth of 1 mm, identify cracks in common metals such as copper and aluminum, and operate effectively on rough surfaces with a root mean square (RMS) roughness of 10 μm and a peak-to-valley (PV) height of 50 μm. It also enables subsurface crack detection through a 2 mm-thick PET layer. Experimental verification further demonstrates that the probe can penetrate a 200 μm-thick release paper to stably detect strip-shaped cracks with a width of 0.4 mm and a depth of 0.1 mm. Optimizing the gap between the CSRR and the waveguide port to 1.92 mm increases the crack-induced S11 signal variation by 3 dB, significantly enhancing the detection sensitivity. In addition, the probe successfully identifies cylindrical metal defects with a diameter of 0.35 mm and a depth of 0.1 mm in experimental tests. This probe offers a reliable and efficient technical solution for detecting metal surface and subsurface cracks.
