title: A Comprehensive Review of Deep Learning Approaches for Proactive Pneumonia Detection using Chest Radiographs
authors: Bhushan Rathi, Dhananjay Deshpande
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Pneumonia is an important health challenge that is threatening the world especially vulnerable people. The correct and swift diagnosis is key to successful care and improved recovery process. Deep learning (DL) has rapidly evolved over recent years, particularly in its applications to data analysis of medical images like chest X-rays (CXRs) with the view of letting the technology automatically detect pneumonia. This review aims to recognition pneumonia at early stage from chest X-ray images. It also describes important methods of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), transfer learning models, ensemble modeling, and attention mechanisms. The review also exhibits an overview of the major datasets, evaluation metrics mostly used and the level of performance reported in recent studies. Moreover, it highlights present-day challenges such as the limited availability of data, the imbalanced classes, and the lack of interpretability of the models, the problems of adapting the models to different clinical settings. Lastly, the article identifies new research directions in the better incorporation of DL systems in healthcare practice. All in all, it is a convenient study aid to a researcher and a medical professional interested in the application of DL in more accurate pneumonia diagnostics.

title: Using Machine Learning to Detect Deepfake Videos on Social Sites
authors: T. Kavitha, S. Hemalatha, K. Ajaykanna, S. Dinesh, A.Jabastin
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The use of machine-learning-based method to detect deepfake videos on social media platforms stems from the problem of increasing deepfake videos being posted on social media while concerns over misinformation, reputational damage, privacy violations, and online scams are proliferating. This work proposes new method for using machine learning to find deepfake videos, leveraging key-frame extraction in video analysis and using a recent deep learning approach, CNN and LSTM hybrid. Our approach begins with the extraction of salient frames from video for analysis, thus minimizing computational burden while retaining visual information that is salient to the identification task. The CNN discovers spatial features within frames, finding features that represent artifacts of manipulation. The LSTM analyzes video by accounting for the temporal dimension across frames examining commonalities and inconsistencies in sequences of frames and video, building specificity of the detection approach. In experimental assessment, our hybrid CNN-LSTM model outperformed the conventional approach in distinguishing between authentic and deepfaked videos using benchmark datasets. The results of the experiment suggest that spatial and temporal analysis can effectively identify deepfakes resulting in detection platform that will scale to applications on social media.

title: Privacy-Aware Federated Learning Framework for Secure and Efficient Smart City Services
authors: Chancalviben N B, Oviya S, S. Ananthi, R. Subha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The recent development of smart city systems, which are enabled by the Internet of Things (IoT) and Artificial Intelligence (AI), has escalated the issue of data privacy and regulatory compliance. Classical centralized learning systems put sensitive citizen information at risk of privacy violations and cannot satisfy such rigorous standards as GDPR. This paper suggests a Privacy-Aware Federated Learning (PAFL) system which can be used to address these restrictions and allow access to decentralized, secure and efficient training of AI models without transmitting raw data. The framework combines both Data Protection Differential Privacy (DP) where the updates to the local model are encrypted, and Homomorphic Encryption (HE) where the aggregation at the server side is secure. Examples of experiments carried out on the City of Chicago Traffic Volume Dataset prove that at a privacy budget, ϵ =1.0, the proposed PAFL model can achieve accuracy of 95.2 priority and at the same time achieves a high level of privacy protection with minimal degradation when compared to centralized learning. More so, the system ensures a high level of communication overhead reduction, as well as model utility maintenance in the face of heterogeneous IoT environments. The findings confirm that PAFL is a scalable and privacy-sensitive solution, which enables reliable and regulation-friendly smart city services.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Ear Disease Detection and Classification: Current Trends and Future Prospects
authors: Sumi Sudhakar, J. Jenkin Winston
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Ear disease detection and classification are important for early diagnosis and appropriate treatment that reduces the risk of negative effects such as hearing impairment and other complications. Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) play an important role in the medical image interpretation for early detection of diseases, classification, and accurate diagnosis. The integration of deep learning (DL) models, which are a subclass of ML, has significantly improved the ear diagnosis outcomes. These systems are capable of analysing otoscopic images and patient histories and predicting diseases such as otitis media, abnormalities of the tympanic membrane, hearing loss etc., with high accuracy. The proposed study focused on different AI techniques such as ML, DL, hybrid models and transfer learning (TL). Hybrid models combine different learning approaches such as ML, DL and TL. The objective of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness of these approaches and identify their strengths and limitations. The findings indicate that CNN- and hybrid-based frameworks achieve high diagnostic accuracy, often exceeding 95%, but challenges persist due to limited dataset size, demographic imbalance, and the inability to capture rare or early-stage conditions. The study concludes that larger standardized datasets, and multimodal integration are required to enhance reliability, generalizability, and clinical applicability in real-world settings.

title: State Transition Graph-Based Pipelined Sequential Multiplier
authors: Basavaraj, M. Vinodhini, C. Paramasivam
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper presents a State Transition Graph (STG)-based Pipelined Sequential Multiplier designed for high-throughput and efficient multiplication operations in VLSI systems. The proposed architecture extends a conventional STG-based multiplier by introducing a five-stage pipeline, where each stage performs progressive partial product accumulation based on the bits of the multiplier input. This pipelining significantly reduces latency and enhances throughput by enabling stage-wise computation overlap, while preserving the area and control simplicity of traditional sequential designs. The design is implemented in Verilog HDL, functionally verified using Xilinx Vivado, and synthesized for ASIC deployment using Cadence Genus in 45 nm technology node. Additionally, Static Timing Analysis (STA), including setup and hold checks, was performed using Cadence Tempus, confirming improved timing closure and enabling higher clock frequencies. Compared with the previous STG design, the proposed multiplier achieves significantly higher throughput, along with reduced critical path delay and improved operating speed. These improvements make it highly suitable for high-speed VLSI applications.

title: Integrating Baudot Encoding and Chaotic Maps with Symmetric Cryptography
authors: Yelipe Gowtham, Geda Tejesh Chowdary, Paramkusam Sriharsha, M Navaneeth, Kavitha C. R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This project introduces a hybrid encryption framework that improves the security of data through the formulation of Baudot encoding, chaotic maps and symmetric cryptographic algorithms. Baudot code offers simple binary representation of plaintext diffused further through three chaotic maps – Logistic, Tent, and 1-D Cosine Polynomial (1-DCP). The resulting pseudo random chaotic sequences are XORED with the encoded data prior to the application of symmetric encryption (AES, 3DES or Twofish). This dual-layer efforts guarantees elevated confusion, entropy and diffusion. The performance evaluation was performed for input sizes of (10KB, 50KB, 100KB, 150KB, 200KB) to calculate encryption and decryption time and memory consumption. Results indicate the proposed system offers efficient and scalable security where the Tent map and AES attain the best speed. Such an architecture is not only highly resistant to everyday cryptographic attacks, but also computationally light, appropriate for secure data exchange in lightweight and real-time settings.

title: Quantum Tensor Network Neural Architecture: Exploiting Partially Symmetric Tensors in Quantum-Limited Neural Networks
authors: M.Ponkanagavalli M. Ponkanagavalli, P. Jeba Santhiya, Christo Ananth, S. Dyana, M. Sucharitha, Joshua Bapu J
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper proposes a Quantum Tensor Network Neural Architecture that synergistically integrates quantum and classic frameworks in order to advance quantum machine-learning. The architecture increases efficiency by constraining model weights structurally. It does this using partial symmetric decompositions of tensors that are integrated into variational quanta circuits. The symmetry constraint increases tensor reconstruction accuracy, and reduces errors compared to non-constrained approaches. A hybrid quantum-classical method of training accelerates convergence, stabilizes parameter updates and establishes robust and noise-resistant performance on simulated quanta devices. Stability and scaling of the model are supported by its theoretical underpinnings including algebraic and spectrum analyses. QTNNA is a promising framework that can process high-dimensional information effectively. This approach tackles the curse of dimensionality in quantum computing, by utilizing tensor network to manage exponential complexity.

title: Comparative Study of Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithms for Constrained Financial Portfolio Optimization
authors: Priyanka A, Anisha Radhakrishnan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Financial portfolio optimization under real-world constraints: limited asset count, budget caps, and market volatility poses a complex multiobjective challenge. Classical models such as Markowitz’s mean variance optimization (MVO) and the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) often underperform during turbulent periods, notably the 2020 market crash. This paper presents a comparative study of five Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithms (MOEAs) NSGA-II, NSGA-III, SPEA-2, MOEA/D, and DEMPO applied to a constrained $1,000,000 portfolio comprising 48 S&P 500 stocks (2020–2022), with cardinality limits of 5–10 assets. Each algorithm is evaluated in six metrics: annualized return, volatility, Sharpe ratio, Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR), hypervolume, and Inverted Generational Distance (IGD). The results show that MOEA / D achieves the highest return (62.59%) but with elevated volatility (46.94%), while DEMPO minimizes tail risk (CVaR: −0.24%) and excels in precision. Compared to classical models, MOEAs demonstrate superior adaptability and compliance with constraint. To address dynamic market shifts, we propose an adaptive MOEA framework integrating reinforcement learning for scalable, real-time portfolio management. The findings affirm the potential of MOEAs for robust and risk-aware financial decision making in volatile environments.

title: Optimizing Cloud Resource Allocation using Reinforcement Learning
authors: S.Kalpana, T.Kiruthiga, Krithika V, Jackson J, Gomathi N.
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Efficient resource allocation is a core challenge in cloud computing environments, where workloads and demands vary dynamically. Traditional heuristic or static allocation methods often fail to maintain optimal utilization and cost efficiency under changing conditions. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning (RL)-based framework for adaptive resource allocation in cloud infrastructures. The proposed system dynamically learns to balance workload distribution, minimize service latency, and reduce operational costs by continuously observing system states and making informed allocation decisions. Using a Q-learning-based approach, the model achieves near-optimal performance without prior system knowledge. Simulation results demonstrate improved resource utilization (up to 18%), reduced energy consumption (by 12%), and decreased response time compared to baseline static and heuristic techniques. The proposed method highlights the potential of intelligent automation in cloud management systems.

title: Near-Resonant Frequency Detection of LLC Converters Based on Quality Factor Design
authors: Arvin Escultero, Marvin Ralph Bautista, Carl Michael Odulio
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The LLC resonant converter is widely used for its high efficiency and low electromagnetic interference when operated near its resonant frequency. However, in applications with wide output voltage variation, conventional control methods often force operation away from resonance, increasing losses and noise. This paper presents a method for detecting the resonant frequency that allows stable, near-resonant operation without using secondary-side sensing or high-precision components. The proposed approach is based on quality-factor design, allowing accurate resonance detection using only primary-side measurements while minimizing the influence of magnetizing current. The algorithm was analyzed and validated through MATLAB and PLECS simulations under various component tolerance conditions. Results show that the method effectively detects the resonant frequency, maintains unity gain, and achieves both zero-voltage and zero-current switching. The findings demonstrate that the proposed approach enables efficient and lownoise operation with low-cost components, making it a practical solution for power supply and battery-charging applications requiring reliable and simplified hardware implementation.

title: A Comprehensive Study on Plant Disease Detection using Deep Learning Models
authors: Mythili M, Mahendran N
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Agriculture plays a crucial role in supplying food materials and supporting growing economies and populations. Plant disease leads to the wastage of food materials and destroys the diversity of species. Early detection of plant disease using an automated technique can improve the quality of food products and reduce economic loss. At present, deep learning (DL) techniques provide promising results in image recognition, and they are more accurate in detecting and classifying objects. Numerous studies using DL models in plant disease have obtained promising results. This study reviews various studies using DL for the early diagnosis of plant disease. Furthermore, it provides a comprehensive review of ongoing research in this field, dataset availability, the operation of well-known DL architectures, and evaluation indices. Also, it discusses the steps involved in plant disease detection and compares the performance of several other models that are in use. This study addresses the limitations and challenges in leaf disease detection.

title: A Smart IoT based Home Automation System for Controlling and Monitoring Home Appliances and Security
authors: Vaishali Bangera, Sumana C, Sindu M Gouda, Anusha H A, Shivani N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Making it easier to monitor and control home appliances and security systems is the aim of the smart home management system. The system's mobile applications allow users to remotely control household appliances by utilising cutting-edge technologies like wireless connectivity and the Internet of Things (IoT). To automate functions like home security, temperature control, and lighting, the system combines a number of sensors and controllers. Convenience, safety, and energy efficiency are increased by security alerts and real-time energy usage tracking. Because of this solution's scalable and adaptable architecture, users can increase the capabilities of their smart homes to suit their needs..

title: Synthetic Data for Health Risk Prediction: An Evaluation using Machine Learning
authors: Prabina Subedi, Sri Ramya Divakarla, Manaswini Emani, Sreeja Kochuvila, Sunitha R.
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: One of the major issues in health research is that the patient data necessary to develop good predictive models is often not available because of the privacy laws and regulations. In this research, Conditional Tabular Generative Adversarial Networks (CTGAN) are looked at for the production of synthetic health data that is privacy-preserving and their use in diabetes risk prediction is assessed. The Pima Indians Diabetes dataset was used to train Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine classifiers on both the original and CTGAN-generated synthetic datasets. The model performance was evaluated through accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC metrics. The outcome showed that the Random Forest was the best with an accuracy of 82% on original and 63% on synthetic datasets, proving that synthetic data had a large share of the predictive power while being privacy-safe. The decrease in performance was not too much but still allowed the data to keep the main statistical relationships, thus confirming CTGAN as a suitable tool for privacy-conscious healthcare analytics. The research presents synthetic data as a solution to the problem of medical AI being limited to non-confidential areas by the need to be secure, ethical, and reproducible.

title: Post-Graduation Admission Prediction using Deep Belief Networks and Active Voting Method
authors: Madupalli Radhika, K V Panduranga Rao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Predicting post-graduation admission outcomes has become an important task for students and institutions in today’s competitive education system. Admission decisions depend on various factors such as academic performance, test scores, research experience, and recommendation strength. In this study, a new method is proposed for predicting the admission chances of Indian students applying to foreign universities by using Deep Belief Networks (DBN) combined with an Active Voting Method (AVM). The model uses the Graduate Admissions Dataset from Kaggle, which includes key features such as GRE score, TOEFL score, CGPA, Statement of Purpose (SOP), Letter of Recommendation (LOR), and research experience. The data is divided into three parts: academic records, experience and recommendations, and demographic information. Each part is trained separately using a DBN to extract meaningful features. These refined features are then merged and passed to the AVM, which combines the predictions from multiple classifiers to produce a final decision. The proposed system classifies applicants into two categories. Accepted or Rejected. Experimental results show that the model achieves an overall accuracy of 98%, which is higher than existing Machine Learning (ML) models such as Random Forest (RF), eXtreme Gradient Boost (XGB), and Logistic Regression (LR). The results prove that the combination of DBN and AVM provides more reliable and consistent predictions.

title: Drone Quidditch: Aerial Manipulation and Human–Robot Collaboration in a Novel Drone
authors: Rajasekar L, Snehil Yash, Pongiannan R K, M. Indirani, S. Govindaraju, Brindha R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The emerging field of drone sports, popularized by drone soccer, has primarily focused on maneuvering and collision-based interactions. This paper introduces "Drone Quidditch," a novel aerial sport that elevates the challenge by requiring drones to perform complex, dynamic mechanical manipulation tasks: intercepting, catching, and throwing an evasive micro-drone ("Golden Snitch") through a designated goal hoop. We present a comprehensive system design encompassing a lightweight aerial manipulator, a hybrid perception stack (YOLO + EKF + LSTM), and a hierarchical control system comparing PID, Model Predictive Control (MPC), and a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO)Reinforcement Learning (RL) agent. The system is rigorously evaluated in high-fidelity Gazebo and PyBullet simulations featuring accurate aerodynamic modeling (blade element theory, quadratic drag, and downwash effects). We provide extensive experimental results from 2,400 simulated throws and a user study (n=20) that directly compares the performance of human pilots with autonomous agents. Our results indicate that RL policies significantly outperform both traditional controllers and human pilots in scoring consistency, speed, and efficiency, while illuminating key safety and design trade-offs for successful real-world deployment.

title: PromptFixer: An AI-based System for Improving and Structuring User Prompts for Language Model
authors: Medamanoori Dhanush, Briso Becky Bell
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The rise in the use of large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini has highlighted the need for well-designed prompts to achieve meaningful and effective responses. Nonetheless, the users frequently fail to devise effective prompts, which results in ambiguous, insufficient, or grammatically incorrect instructions. The current paper presents PromptFixer, an AI-powered interface that will be deployable to analyze, improve, and streamline a user input so that it can be used and interacted with by an LLM in the best way possible. PromptFixer understands intent and grammatical structure in prompts by figuring out how to implement natural language processing techniques--part-of-speech tagging, dependency parsing, and named entity recognition--in the context of prompts. The system sorts through prompts, which are categorized as informational requests, commands, or programmatic calls, and optimizes them through the state of the art transformer models like FLAN-T5 and GPT-2. A safety module also identifies poisonous or unethical inputs by means of zero-shot classifiers and toxicity APIs. Sentence-Bert used during similarity testing is to retain semantic completeness whereas the quality of the output is measured against metrics such as BERTScore and readability indices. The given system improves timely comprehensibility, security, and adequacy, and will lead to better interaction possibilities between humans and AI in various sectors, including content creation, programming, and online learning.

title: Hybrid Metaheuristic Feature Selection for Microring Resonator Gas Sensing in Consumer IoT
authors: Thompson Stephan, Malathi Sathish, Nehal Nandini, Ashina Rawat
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Photonic microring resonator arrays are attractive for hazardous gas detection due to their high sensitivity, compact form factor, and real-time operation. As spectral complexity increases, the resulting feature space can become large and redundant. We present a multi-objective feature selection framework that balances classification accuracy and subset size using a weighted fitness. We evaluate six baselines, particle swarm optimization (PSO), grey wolf optimizer (GWO), artificial bee colony (ABC), whale optimization algorithm (WOA), firefly algorithm (FA), and genetic algorithm (GA), and three proposed hybrids (Whale–PSO Enhanced (WPE), Firefly–Genetic Blend (FGB), Bee–Whale Evaluator (BWE)) on a simulated microring dataset for ammonia, methane, and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. The proposed BWE, which combines ABC’s local foraging with WOA’s spiral exploration, in our experiments, yields compact subsets while maintaining high accuracy. In Internet of Consumer Electronics (ICE) deployments, selecting features at the edge reduces payload and on-device compute, supporting Quality of Service (QoS)-aware communication across cloud, fog, and edge tiers.

title: Design and Performance Analysis of a Single Inductor Continuous Input Current Buck-Boost Converter for Photovoltaic Applications
authors: Simisi Mosamane, Paul Barendse
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Discontinuous input current in traditional buckboost converters poses challenges for photovoltaic (PV) systems, particularly in achieving accurate Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) and conducting electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) diagnostics. While alternatives such as SingleEnded Primary Inductor Converter (SEPIC) and Ćuk converters offer continuous input current, they often incur higher component costs and complexity. This paper investigates a single-inductor continuous input current (SI-CIC) buck-boost converter as a simplified and cost-effective alternative. Simulation results demonstrate that the SI-CIC maintains continuous input current and stable dynamic behavior across operating conditions, making it well-suited for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P V}$</tex> integration. A comparative analysis with the conventional buck-boost converter confirms the SI-CIC's superior current continuity and application-specific advantages.

title: Recent Trends in Alzheimer’s Disease Detection using Deep Learning Models
authors: D. Stephen, R. Samuel Rajesh Babu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease is a progressive neurological disease regarded as a late-stage dementia. Typically this disease cause reduction in brain volume and affect daily activities. Early detection and diagnosis of Alzheimer’s disease is crucial, particularly in the early stage, because risk awareness allows patient to adopt preventive measures before the occurrence of irreversible brain damage. This paper exclusively analyse the disease across four major topics. Initially, it reviews the role of deep leaning in detecting Alzheimer’s disease and highlights its significance in medical imaging. Subsequently, it investigates popular Alzheimer’ disease datasets are in use. Moreover, it discusses the steps involved in pre-processing including normalization, resizing, and augmentation. Furthermore, it describes the operation of well-known deep learning models used in Alzheimer’s disease detection. Finally, it describes the evaluation metrics used to assess the performance of the classifiers. It also reviews the challenges in Alzheimer’s disease detection. The objective of this paper is to offers detailed review of several literatures on Alzheimer’s disease and analyse the importance of deep learning model in early detection.

title: Improving EV Charger Resiliency for MW Charging Systems
authors: Aswad Adib, Michael Starke, Joao Onofre Pereira Pinto, Renata Kimpara, Madhu Chinthavali
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: In this paper, the resiliency of a megawatt-scale EV charging station is investigated. Fault detection and tolerance methodologies are presented, based on monitoring the voltage offsets in DABs and switch-level currents in three-phase inverters, with the goal of maintaining operation at rated power during single faults and at reduced power under multiple fault conditions. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy, simulation results at the rated 1 MW power of the charging station are carried out, followed by controller hardware-in-the-loop (CHIL) experiments on a 250 kW section of the station. The results highlight the feasibility of the integrated fault-tolerant methods for resilient, high-power EV charging infrastructure.

title: Cityscape AI: Smart Resilient City Platform
authors: Pallavi Nayak, Tanisha Swami, Tuhin Ghosh, Naman Upreti, Mir Kirdar Abbas
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This study proposes Cityscape AI, an AI-driven platform integrating real time environmental monitoring, green space optimization, predictive disaster management. The system provides real-time environmental monitoring of pollution, temperature, humidity, and disaster notifications, offering timely information on urban conditions. Through AI-based green space optimization, the project focuses on the mitigation of urban heat islands and air quality improvement. Predictive analytics models are integrated for proactive disaster management and risk assessment to enable quick response and mitigation responses. The platform’s smart dashboard enables decision making for both citizen and authorities enhancing urban sustainability. This integrated system improves quality of life, energy efficiency, and ecological balance as it improves urban resilience. Smart resilience assists in creating habitable, adaptable urban environments that are able to manage the environmental issues of today by collaborating in tandem with the greater vision of smart cities. Results show improved environmental awareness and faster reaponse time compared to existing systems.

title: AI-based Predictive Model for Binary and Multiclass Heart Disease Classification in IoMT
authors: Cheruvugattu Ushasri, Gayatri Ketepalli
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Cardiovascular disease continues to be a predominant cause of death globally, highlighting the necessity for effective and proactive diagnostic measures. This research presents an AI-driven predictive model connected with the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) for binary and multiclass classification of cardiac disorders. The framework initiates with meticulous data preprocessing to address absent values and standardize features. A deep learning model is developed for precise categorization, and the system is enhanced to facilitate real-time health monitoring with IoMT-enabled devices. The efficacy of the proposed model is assessed utilizing critical metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, and latency. Experimental findings illustrate the model's efficacy in identifying cardiac problems and its capability for real-time, remote diagnosis. Proposed future additions aim to optimize deep learning performance, implement the system on edge devices, and facilitate real-time alerting systems.

title: Content based Image Retrieval and Disease Prediction using Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: D.Prasanna, A. Kalaiyarasan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Recent medical research indicates that most people worldwide are affected by various lung diseases. This paper proposes a novel Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture, termed XLG Cancer Net, for accurate identification of lung diseases. The Lung image MRI dataset and the initial Gaussian filter preprocessing eliminate noise and improve the quality of the input dataset's pixels. The Swin-Net segmentation specifically separated the number of clusters to identify the affected region and its shape, including thickness and external area, as well as the inner and outer layers. From that, Content-Based Image Retrieval (CBIR) feature extraction specifically analyses the same features and eliminates irrelevant ones, and each feature is validated based on performance metrics. The technical output from the XLG Cancer Net classifies lung diseases, including large cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and Adenocarcinoma. The results show an Accuracy of 96%, a precision of 95%, a recall of 95%, and an error rate analysis, while simultaneously minimizing the false ratio, and it applies to a real-time medical application.

title: A Scalable DC Coupled MW-Class Power Electronics-Based Energy System for Off-Grid Hydrogen Production From Hybrid AC/DC Sources
authors: Aswad Adib, Renata Kimpara, Joao Onofre Pereira Pinto, Marcio Magri Kimpara, Michael Starke, Prasad Kandula, Madhu Chintavali
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a scalable, megawatt-class power electronics (PE) topology designed for off-grid hydrogen production plants based on Proton Exchange Membrane (PEM) electrolyzers. The 10 MW system integrates hybrid nondispatchable energy sources connected to a modular multilevel converter (MMC) interfacing with a 10 kV medium-voltage DC link. On the load side, multiple 1 MW subsystems consisting of three dual active bridge (DAB) converters arranged in a series-primary, parallel-secondary configuration interface the electrolyzers. Additionally, the system includes an energy storage unit that provides power during standby mode and enables grid formation and system startup. Given its modular design, the system can be further scaled by connecting additional 10 MW units in parallel to achieve gigawatt-scale power. Since the proposed architecture combines several PE-based interfaces, each equipped with its own independent control scheme, a power management system coordinates the overall operation by receiving feedback and measurements and dispatching commands and setpoints to individual controllers. The proposed solution is evaluated through simulations of realistic operating scenarios, including system startup, variations in energy source availability, and system shutdown and standby modes.
