title: Multi-UAV Path Planning for Mobile Edge Computing With High-Density Mobile Devices
authors: Lihan Liu, Hongrui Miao, Chunhui Qu, Zhuwei Wang, Haijun Zhang, Zhidu Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) assisted mobile edge computing (MEC) in high-density user mobility scenarios, a field that has not been extensively explored in current research. We introduce a novel deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, named “j-PPO+EN-ConvNTM”, specifically designed to optimize MEC performance in urban environments with user mobility. The framework integrates spatiotemporal data modeling and spatial transformer network (STN) through an enhance Convolution Neural Turing Machine (EN-ConvNTM) module, which includes a three-dimensional external memory. It also features a joint continuous and discrete action decision-making module, termed joint proximal policy optimization (j-PPO). This design enables effective handling of the dynamic and complex nature of urban mobility patterns. The proposed approach extends the PPO technique to accommodate joint continuous and discrete action decisions, thereby enhancing UAV adaptability and efficiency in providing MEC services. Extensive simulations demonstrate significant improvements over all baseline models, particularly in terms of equilibrium efficiency and service continuity in high-density scenarios. Our research addresses a critical gap in existing UAV-assisted MEC studies, which primarily focus on static or low-mobility user scenarios, and supports the development of more robust and efficient smart city applications, meeting the real-world demands of modern urban infrastructures.

title: Towards Practical Headphones Eavesdropping Leveraging COTS Mmwave Radar
authors: Xiangyu Xu, Haotian Zheng, Yu Chen, Hao Kong, Zhen Ling, Jiadi Yu, Junzhou Luo, Xinwen Fu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Headphones have become ubiquitous in daily work and communication, leading users to assume a sense of privacy and security during confidential conversations while overlooking the potential risk of eavesdropping. In this paper, we present mmEar, an end-to-end eavesdropping system that demonstrates the feasibility of compromising headphones using a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) mmWave radar. Unlike previous approaches that rely on relatively strong vibrations, mmEar targets extremely faint, low-SNR speech-induced vibrations on headphone surfaces. To address this challenge, we introduce a Faint Vibration Emphasis (FVE) technique that amplifies phase variations on the IQ plane, followed by a deep denoising network for enhanced signal quality. Furthermore, we design a diffusion-based generative model within a pretrain–finetune framework, leveraging large-scale synthetic data to significantly improve generalization and robustness across diverse scenarios. Extensive experiments on multiple headphone and earphone models validate the practicality and effectiveness of the proposed attack, revealing that most tested devices can be compromised to recover intelligible speech.

title: A Rotational Motion Parameter Estimation Method for Slow-Spinning Space Targets Utilizing Similarity Analysis of Sequential ISAR Images
authors: Rongzhen Du, Qingxu Qiao, Lei Liu, Huiping Zhu, Yan Lu, Feng Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Uncontrolled satellites and other space targets usually exhibit slow-spinning motion. Accurately estimating their rotational motion parameters (RMP) is of great significance for uncontrolled state analysis. To address this challenge, a method is proposed herein to estimate the RMP of slow-spinning space targets, based on similarity analysis of sequential inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) images. Firstly, an ISAR imaging model for slow-spinning space targets is constructed. It is then derived that two adjacent ISAR images exhibit an approximate planar rotational geometric relationship, and the planar rotation matrix in this relationship is directly associated with the RMP. Then, RMP, namely the rotation axis and angular velocity, are taken as optimization variables, while the similarity between successive ISAR images serves as the objective function. In this manner, the estimation of RMP is constructed as an unconstrained optimization problem. Ultimately, the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is utilized to estimate the RMP. Without depending on any prior knowledge about the target's structure, the proposed method can realize RMP estimation. Experimental results obtained from electromagnetic simulation data demonstrate its effectiveness and robustness.

title: An Adaptive Multiparameter Penalty Selection Method for Multiconstraint and Multiblock ADMM
authors: Luke Lozenski, Michael T. McCann, Brendt Wohlberg
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: This work presents a new method for online selection of multiple penalty parameters for the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm applied to optimization problems with multiple constraints or functions with block matrix components. ADMM is widely used for solving constrained optimization problems in a variety of fields, including signal and image processing. Implementations of ADMM often utilize a single hyperparameter, referred to as the penalty parameter, which needs to be tuned to control the rate of convergence. However, in problems with multiple constraints, ADMM may demonstrate slow convergence regardless of penalty parameter selection due to scale differences between constraints. Accounting for scale differences between constraints to improve convergence in these cases requires introducing a penalty parameter for each constraint. The proposed method is able to adaptively account for differences in scale between constraints, providing robustness with respect to

title: Robust 2.5D Feature Matching in Light Fields via A Learnable Parameterized Depth-Degraded Projection
authors: Meng Zhang, Haiyan Jin, Zhaolin Xiao, Jinglei Shi, Xiaoran Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Due to the loss of 3D information, accurate and robust 2D image feature matching remains challenging for many computer vision applications. This paper introduces a 2.5D feature that uses the disparity value from the light field Fourier disparity layer (FDL) as a rough proxy of scene depth. Without explicit depth estimation, a parameterized depth-degraded projection is proposed to construct the geometric transformation of paired features between two light fields. Then, we propose a parameterized learning solution to calculate the depth-degraded projection. This solution estimates a global constant fundamental matrix, a variable disparity-guided translation vector, and a depth compensation term using a very simple network. Although the 0.5D relative disparity provided by the FDL does not represent precise depth, it can also significantly reduce the depth ambiguity in feature matching. Therefore, the proposed solution achieves accurate feature-matching results by minimizing the sum of reprojection errors across all matching candidates. On the public light field feature-matching dataset, the proposed solution outperforms existing 2D image feature-matching solutions and light field feature-matching algorithms in terms of matching accuracy and robustness. The code is available online <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.

title: A 0.3-V Compact VCO With Tail Filtering Using Double-8-Shaped Inductors in 65-nm CMOS
authors: Ruixi Yu, Yunbo Huang, Li Wang, Hongyu Ren, Xiaoyu Shan, Kai Cheng, Zunsong Yang, Bo Li
publish: IEEE Microwave and Wireless Technology Letters
abstract: This letter presents a 0.3-V double-8-shaped inductors-based voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO). It features a compact area, low power, and low magnetic coupling. The nested double-8-shaped inductors are proposed to achieve full magnetic-flux cancellation and the second harmonic tail filtering without area overhead. Fabricated in a 65-nm CMOS process, the prototyped VCO operates from 5.36 to 5.99 GHz while consuming less than 0.35 mW power under a 0.3-V supply. It achieves phase noise of −131.1 dBc/Hz at 10 MHz offsets, corresponding to a peak FoM of 190.2 dB. The proposed VCO with a compact core area of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$240\times 125~\mu $</tex-math> </inline-formula>m demonstrates high integration density and power efficiency, which is promising for compact and energy-efficient phase-locked loops (PLLs) in Internet-of-Things (IoT) radio applications.

title: Cooperative Control of Mobile Autonomous Agents via Communication Routing
authors: Chaofan Wang, Rongrong Qian, Yuan Qi, Hao Su, Weican Kong, Wenxing Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Cooperative control of mobile autonomous agents relies on interagent communication, while most existing studies are concerned with local information exchange between neighbors. In addition to local information exchange, global information exchange, e.g., via communication routing, is also an important approach, that might have the advantage of accelerating the convergence of cooperative control. However, there are few works on the joint design and analysis of cooperative control and communication routing for mobile autonomous agents. In this paper, we propose a technique which realizes the cooperative control of mobile autonomous agents by incorporating communication routing. To be specific, we first design a control law combining local and global information exchange. Then, considering the delay caused by routing, we analyze the convergence performance of above control law by using a frequency-domain method for time-delay systems, which shows that the convergence rate of the control law we designed is faster than that only with distributed control or routing. Finally, simulations are provided to validate the theoretical results.

title: Security Region of DC-GIL Insulator Considering Electro-Mechanical Breakdown
authors: Jianan Dong, Boxue Du, Yifang Wang, Hucheng Liang, Daomin Min
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: DC-GIL insulators are key components that provide both electrical insulation and mechanical support. However, their insulation and mechanical designs have traditionally been developed separately, without accounting for the influence of mechanical stress on insulation breakdown. This study investigates how mechanical stress affects the breakdown strength of epoxy/Al2O3 composite samples at various temperatures. Results show that breakdown strength decreases significantly with increasing mechanical stress, and this effect becomes even more pronounced at elevated temperatures. The security region of DC-GIL insulators can be defined as the region bounded by the breakdown-strength (EB) and tensile-strength (σB) intercepts on the coordinate axes. Accordingly, the criterion E/EB + σ/σB < 1 can be used to assess the safety margin of DC-GIL insulators.

title: Requirements Driven Explainable Artificial Intelligence Framework for Secure and Transparent Clinical Decision Support Systems
authors: Mobeen Nazar, Salahuddin Unar, Anil Ahmed, Mazliham Mohd Su’ud, Muhammad Mansoor Alam, Azizah Rahmat
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In the medical field, where clinical decision support system have a significant impact on vital medical decisions, there is an urgent need for transparent and secure artificial intelligence solutions. This research offers a thorough framework that combines explainable artificial intelligence methods with requirement engineering concepts to improve clinical decision support system security and transparency. The framework uses concern separation goal modeling (Knowledge Acquisition in automated specification), stakeholder analysis (Use Case Modeling), and concern separation (Aspect-Oriented Requirement Engineering) to ensure that system explanations are aligned with stakeholder needs while addressing privacy, compliance, and safety requirements. The proposed approach is evaluated using a real-world medical dataset demonstrating improvements in explanation consistency, requirement alignment, and robustness under security constraints. These results highlight the potential of integrating Requirements Engineering with XAI to support secure, interpretable, and accountable AI-driven clinical decision-making.

title: HR-HEC: Heuristic-to-Refined Hand-Eye Calibration via Congruent Matching Sets
authors: Li Liu, Hao Wu, Lin Hua, Dahu Zhu
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Accurate and efficient hand-eye calibration (HEC) is crucial for vision-guided robotic machining system, particularly in precision grinding blades. However, existing closed-form solutions are highly susceptible to noise and outliers, while iterative solutions depend on good initial estimates. To overcome these limitations, we construct a heuristic-to-refined HEC (HR HEC) algorithm that eliminates dependence on initial estimates and calibration rigs. Leveraging an improved 4-Points Congruent Sets (4PCS) algorithm for heuristic search, HR-HEC robustly establishes accurate point correspondences between initial point clouds, and then constructs congruent matching sets (CMS). These sets, together with global point clouds, are transformed into a unified robot coordinate frame for refined search. The globally optimal hand-eye matrix and stitching results are obtained by minimizing the point-to-plane distance. Calibration experiments demonstrate that the blade absolute stitching error (disN) by HR-HEC can reach 0.06 mm, representing 65.9% improvement over state-of-the-art methods, and meeting the accuracy requirements for blade grinding.

title: Blendshape-Based Facial Animation Using OPF and Random Forest
authors: Carlos E. R. C Silva, Silvio R. R. Sanches, Claiton Oliveira, Henrique Y. Shishido, Danilo S. Sanches, Antonio C. Sementille
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: In recent decades, interest in capturing human facial movements and identifying facial expressions for the purpose of generating realistic facial animations has increased, both in the scientific community and the entertainment industry. High accuracy in this process is necessary because humans naturally develop the ability to identify facial expressions. Then, slight imperfections in the animation of a virtual face become noticeable, especially in the eyes and mouth region. To reduce these artifacts, some solutions use facial motion retargeting, which helps to transfer the actor’s expressions more faithfully and, consequently, produce more realistic animations. This paper presents a facial animation method that utilizes a supervised classifier model to identify the most common human facial expressions and automatically redirect them to a face model generated from a combination of a small number of blendshapes. The results showed that, even when using conventional RGB cameras to capture faces, our approach generates expressions that closely resemble reality.

title: A Comparative Study of Bio Inspired Optimization Algorithms for Enhanced PID Control of BLDC Motor Speed
authors: Le Thi Minh Tam, Nguyen Viet Ngu, Pham Duc Hung
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents a systematic comparative study of bio-inspired optimization algorithms for tuning Proportional–Integral–Derivative (PID) controllers in brushless DC (BLDC) motor speed regulation. Four representative metaheuristics are considered, namely the Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO), and Butterfly Optimization Algorithm (BOA). Unlike many previous works that focus on a single algorithm or on limited pairwise comparisons, this study develops a unified optimization and simulation framework in which all methods are applied to the same BLDC motor model, under identical operating conditions and performance criteria. The PID gains are obtained by minimizing the Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE), while controller performance is independently assessed using the Integral of Absolute Error (IAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and key transient response metrics to rigorously quantify tracking accuracy, dynamic behavior, and disturbance rejection. Numerical results clearly show that all bio-inspired approaches outperform conventional fixed-gain PID control. More importantly, the comparative analysis highlights the specific strengths of each algorithm: PSO provides the most balanced and robust performance over all indices, GWO achieves very fast response with low overshoot, and BOA yields an almost overshoot-free response at the expense of slower convergence. These findings not only confirm the effectiveness of bio-inspired tuning, but also offer practical guidelines for selecting appropriate optimization strategies in high-performance BLDC motor drive applications.

title: Parameterized Grinding Planning of Robotic Arms based on Optimization Experiences Generalization for Tubular Workpieces
authors: Ningyuan Wang, Yuemeng Ma, Qiang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In order to make industrial robotic arms adaptively accomplish the uniform grinding tasks for tubular workpieces of different sizes, spatial orientations and surface characteristics, a parameterized planning framework is proposed in this paper. In this framework, Moving-Circle-Determination(MCD)-based geometric parameter calculation is designed for two types of tubular workpieces (both elbow and tee tube). Then the Adaptive Uniform Grouping (AUG) mechanism is designed and applied in path cost calculation module to make all points evenly grouped, and results in a minimal computational complexity of optimization algorithm in the framework. And then Two-stage Progressive Optimization (TPO) algorithm, containing both Experience Generalization Ant Colony System (EGACS) and Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN), is designed to calculate the optimal grinding order in the maximal convergence rate, where optimization capabilities of both EGACS and DDQN are enhanced with accumulation of uniform grinding task based on optimization experiences generalization mechanism applied in TPO algorithm. Finally Parameterized Velocity Vector Summation (PVVS) is designed and applied in the path planning and tracking control module to drive robotic arms to accomplish uniform grinding tasks. Compared to the state-of-the-art methods and algorithms, performance advantages of the planning framework proposed are at least 16.94%, 21.60%, 28.78%, 4.59% and 48.68% in terms of size estimation, spatial orientation estimation, convergence rate, solution quality and computational complexity respectively.

title: Biomimetic Compliant Manipulator for Vascular Guidewire and Catheter Operations
authors: Chuyang Leng, Xijing Zhuang, Changsheng Wang, Yang Gao, Haiyang Li
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: This article presents a novel vascular interventional guidewire and catheter manipulator based on purely compliant mechanisms, adopting a technical approach different from that of existing surgical robots. Inspired by human manual manipulation of guidewires and catheters, the proposed manipulator adopts a biomimetic operation paradigm, enabling axial and rotational actuation while simultaneously measuring the interaction force and torque in real time. By employing purely compliant mechanisms, the design is highly simplified, with integrally manufactured core components and no rigid kinematic pairs. A symmetric architecture is adopted to enable a modular design, facilitating assembly and maintenance. Experimental results validate the performance of the proposed biomimetic compliant manipulator, and operational safety is demonstrated through a force-limiting control strategy based on the integrated force-sensing capability. The proposed design concept provides guidance for the development of vascular interventional surgical robots and is potentially applicable to mechanical systems requiring multiaxis manipulation and sensing.

title: Efficient GaSb/GaInAsSb/InAsSb triple-junction thermophotovoltaic cells
authors: Lifen Su, Yiyi Lou, Xin Li, Yu Wang
publish: IEEE Electron Device Letters
abstract: We simulate lattice-matched GaSb/GaInAsSb/InAsSb triple-junction thermophotovoltaic cells. The simulations with the experimentally-suggested optoelectronic properties indicate that near 20% efficiency and over-1 V open-circuit voltage are predicted for this cell, being superior to its dual-junction counterparts and confirming a new type of cell for thermophotovoltaic applications.

title: A Robotic Emulator for User-Driven Design of Multi-DOF Transradial Prostheses
authors: Souvik Poddar, Eleonora M. Botta, Deanna H. Gates, Jiyeon Kang
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Highly functional upper-limb prostheses have been developed to restore dexterous end-effector motion, but increased mechanical functionality often leads to greater weight, more complex control schemes, and higher cost. In the absence of modular, reconfigurable robotic platforms, prosthesis selection is still driven by subjective preference or brand familiarity rather than systematic evaluation. Such platforms are needed to isolate and quantify the influence of design parameters, such as wrist mobility, device weight, and control strategy, on functional performance. To address this gap, we present a novel robotic transradial prosthesis emulator, Intelligent Prosthesis Emulator for Daily Living Enhancement (I-PEDLE), that will serve as a configurable testbed for evaluating upper-limb prosthetic designs. I-PEDLE features a lightweight three-degree-of-freedom (3-DOF) transradial prosthesis leveraging a cable-driven system with off-board motors to decouple motor weight from the prosthesis. We characterize the device through dynamic trajectory tracking and multi-step response tests, then demonstrate its functional relevance in two daily living tasks (Table-Pour and Shelf-Place), comparing fixed and actuated wrists. Finally, we establish feasibility for systematic evaluation through a parameter sweep across multiple wrist configurations in a complex Shelf-Pour task. Ten healthy participants using a bypass socket emulated transradial prosthesis users. The results show that increasing active wrist DOF does not necessarily reduce excessive residual joint motion. This study establishes the feasibility of using I-PEDLE as a versatile robot-based evaluation platform to investigate how specific prosthetic wrist features may influence upper-limb coordination during functional tasks.

title: Low-Frequency Amplitude-Modulated Ultrasound Stimulation Drives Hippocampal Oscillations and Enhances Memory in Mice
authors: Ruru Wang, Xu Liu, Xin Wang, Xiaoqing Zhou, Jingna Jin, He Wang, Zhipeng Liu, Ren Ma, Tao Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Although transcranial ultrasound stimulation (TUS) can noninvasively target the hippocampal oscillatory network, which serves as a critical interface between cellular functions and cognition, its modulatory efficiency is constrained by the low-pass filtering properties of neuronal membranes. To overcome this limitation, we developed a low-frequency amplitude-modulated (AM) TUS paradigm to enhance neuromodulatory efficiency by improving resonance within the hippocampal oscillatory network. We applied 5, 40, and 80 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS and 5 Hz pulsed AM-TUS to the mouse hippocampus, and analyzed local field potentials before and after stimulation. Results showed that 5 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS significantly enhanced the phase locked value (PLV) (increment: 0.054±0.017) and coherence (increment: 0.040±0.016) in the theta band, and the phase-amplitude coupling (PAC) in theta-low gamma (increment, 1.521±0.249) and theta-high gamma (increment, 0.821±0.299) bands. In contrast, the 5 Hz pulsed AM-TUS showed negligible effects. While the 40 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS enhanced PLV and coherence in the theta band and PAC in theta-low gamma bands, the 80 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS only enhanced PLV in the theta band. Thus, the 5 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS demonstrated superior neuromodulatory efficiency over all other paradigms. The outstanding modulatory efficiency of 5 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS on the oscillatory network was further confirmed in the 14-day TUS, demonstrating enhancements in spatial learning and memory. The 5 Hz sinusoidal AM-TUS presents a novel and efficient approach to precisely modulating hippocampal oscillatory network through entrainment.

title: From Raw to Synthetic: Evaluating LLM-Based Data Augmentation for Sentiment Analysis
authors: Busra Tekinay, Mansur Alp Tocoglu
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This study examines the impact of large language model-based data augmentation on Turkish sentiment analysis, focusing on how synthetic data influences model performance across different dataset configurations. A balanced corpus of hotel and movie reviews labeled with positive and negative sentiments was used to construct six dataset variants: Raw, Raw+GPT, Raw+Claude, Raw+GPT+Claude, GPT-only, and Claude-only. Synthetic samples were generated through zero-shot prompting using GPT-4o and Claude-models and incorporated exclusively into the training portion. Multiple classifiers—including Naive Bayes, SVM, Logistic Regression, CNN, LSTM, and BERT—were trained and evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics. Experimental results reveal that while synthetic-only datasets considerably reduce performance, hybrid datasets (Raw + Synthetic) achieve results statistically comparable to the Raw dataset, demonstrating that synthetic reviews can effectively complement real data. These findings highlight that Large Language Model-generated synthetic data, when combined with authentic samples, preserves model robustness while expanding training diversity, offering a practical solution for low-resource language datasets.

title: High-Voltage Square-Wave Pulse Generator Based on LC-Marx Topology with a Common-Source Common-Gate JFET Solid-State Switch and Asynchronous Timing Synthesis Strategy
authors: Liang Yu, Sicong Wang, Wenbo Xu, Lvheng Ren, Shixin Wang, Shoulong Dong, Chenguo Yao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: While the LC-Marx generator represents an effective topology for compact high-voltage pulse generation, its inherent oscillatory decaying waveform severely constrains its deployment in critical systems mandating flat-topped square waves, such as dielectric barrier discharges (DBDs) and flash X-ray systems. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a novel high-voltage square-wave generator based on an asynchronous timing synthesis strategy. This is achieved through three synergistic innovations. First, the adoption of the LC-Marx topology halves the required number of switches through alternating capacitor polarity charging and enhances energy efficiency by allowing the main discharge current to bypass the switches. Second, a high-voltage solid-state switch, based on a series-stacked common-source common-gate JFET structure, is designed. This design eliminates the necessity for complex isolated drivers and floating power supplies, thereby resolving the scalability challenges inherent in conventional Marx generators. Third, an innovative asynchronous timing synthesis strategy is employed to transform the oscillatory pulses into a high-quality flat-top square wave by precisely time-delaying and superimposing the outputs of multiple LC-Marx modules. This paper elucidates the design principles of the switch and the methodology for square-wave synthesis. A prototype was developed and successfully generated 10 kV, 1 μs pulses with a top flatness of under 3%, thus corroborating the viability and demonstrating the distinct advantages of the proposed architecture for developing next-generation high-performance solid-state pulsed power sources.

title: Micro-Transfer Printing of SiGe BiCMOS Electronic Chiplets on Silicon
authors: He Li, Tinus Pannier, Ye Gu, Prasanna Ramaswamy, Ruggero Loi, Patrick Heise, Mesut Inac, Alex Farrell, Antonio Jose Trindade, Alin Fecioru, Kristof Dhaenens, Toon De Baere, Nishant Singh, Laurens Bogaert, Senbiao Qin, Biwei Pan, Jing Zhang, Geert Van Steenberge, Peter Ossieur, Günther Roelkens
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: We demonstrate micro-transfer printing (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>TP) and post-printing metallization of thin electronic chiplets on silicon, with a view to heterogeneously integrate electronic integrated circuits (EICs) with photonic integrated circuits (PICs). <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>TP decouples the fabrication of EICs and PICs, and simultaneously enables their tight integration with high-throughput, small form-factor and on wafer-scale. In this study, we successfully established the process flow for releasing and printing 300 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m × 200 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m SiGe BiCMOS electronic driver chiplets and electrically connecting these chiplets using a polymer ramp to overcome the 20-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m chiplet thickness, providing a gain of 14 dB and bandwidth of over 35 GHz with low-parasitic interconnections. The proposed methodology provides a practical and mass-producible solution to realize the stacking of EICs on silicon photonic wafers for emerging applications such as co-packaged optics (CPO).

title: An Adaptive Non-Probabilistic Convex Modeling Method Based on Cluster Analysis
authors: Mingdong Wang, Gang Zhao, Liqing Chen, Jie Liu, Qi Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: Non-probabilistic convex models have significant advantages in dealing with limited sample data with unimodal distributions but often struggle to capture complex features when facing multimodal distribution data effectively. To address this limitation, this paper proposes an adaptive non-probabilistic convex modeling method based on cluster analysis, constructing a new convex polyhedron clustering (CPC) model. The proposed method begins by partitioning sample data into multiple sub-class clusters using a combination of posterior evaluation and K-means clustering techniques. A preprocessing step is incorporated to adaptively adjust the number of sub-class clusters according to the variability within the sample data. Sub-convex polyhedrons are then constructed within each sub-class cluster to quantify localized uncertainty domains. These sub-convex polyhedrons are integrated to form the CPC model, with mathematical expressions derived from the characteristics of convex polyhedrons to model the uncertainty domain of the entire dataset. Additionally, the model introduces safety index and distance index as reliability indices and establishes corresponding criteria to evaluate the performance of the proposed convex modeling method. The effectiveness of the method is further validated through three numerical examples, demonstrating its advantages over existing advanced convex modeling approaches.

title: A Hierarchical Time-Scaled Framework for Resilient Fusion of PC/INS Navigation Systems
authors: Bo Wang, Kuaikuai Yu, Jinguang Yue, Donghua Zhao, Tongyu Liu, Chong Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Autonomous systems like unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) need a resilient solution for navigation. This solution must provide accurate heading information when Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) signals are unreliable. The combination of a Polarization Compass (PC) and an Inertial Navigation System (INS) is a promising approach. However, PC observations suffer from unpredictable reliability issues. These issues include quality fluctuations, unstable sampling rates, and long-term outages. Existing methods often do not handle these dynamic reliability changes in a fine-grained way. Other methods rely on black-box models that lack interpretability.This paper proposes a new Hierarchical Time-Scaled Fusion (HTSF) framework to solve this fundamental problem. The framework’s core idea is to intelligently schedule and fuse information from three different reliability tiers. This process happens within a unified Cubature Kalman Filter (CKF) structure. A time-scaling principle guides the entire process. The main contributions of this paper are threefold. First, for high-quality real PC observations, we designed a dual-testing robust adaptive update mechanism. It combines a physical a priori assessment with a statistical a posteriori test. Second, for short-term PC data gaps, we propose a theoretically sound Time-Scaled Virtual Measurement (TSVM) method. This method effectively suppresses short-term INS drift. Third, we integrate an interpretable Transformer model as a resilient safeguard for long-term PC outages. We treat its predictions as stochastic observations with quantified uncertainty. This ensures a seamless integration into the filter. Comprehensive flight experiments were conducted. The results show that our proposed HTSF framework achieves higher orientation accuracy, robustness, and resilience compared to existing advanced methods in various complex scenarios.

title: Controllable Pulse Conversion and Buildup Dynamics in a 2-$\mu$m Fiber Laser
authors: Bo Fu, Congyu Zhang, Zanzhu Pan, Jiahang Zhang, Tingyi Liu, Gang Wang
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Pulsed fiber laser at 2-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m band has important applications in fields including material processing, environmental monitoring, and surgery. Mode-locking and Q-switching are two common working mechanisms of pulsed lasers, while the control of their existence and conversion in the same laser proves difficult. In this work, the theoretical model used in ultrafast laser optics is adapted for the conversion between mode-locked and Q-switched pulses. We proposed a method which introduces a feedback loop to control the conversion between the two regimes at 2-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m, revealed the laser dynamics during the transition process, and verified the feasibility of the method by simulation and experiment. This research provides a stable method to control the working regime of 2-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula>m pulsed lasers as well as a model for future research concerning gain variation in ultrafast laser dynamics.

title: Learned Image and Video Compression: Foundations, Algorithms, and Open Challenges
authors: Dror Porat, Dotan Levi
publish: Proceedings of the conference on Proceedings of the 5th Mile-High Video Conference
abstract: None

title: An Advanced Drug Mechanism of Action (MoA) Prediction Approach from Gene Expression using Transformers and XAI
authors: Hariharan S, J. Praveenchandar, D. Linett Sophia
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence into phar-pharmaceutical research is often hindered by a lack of trust in its opaque ’black-box’ decision-making processes. This paper directly addresses this challenge by introducing a transparent computational framework for predicting a drug’s Mechanism of Action (MoA). We present X-MoA-Former, a novel multi-modal framework centered on a Transformer architecture that concurrently learns from chemical, genomic, and bioassay data. A key innovation is our unified tokenization strategy, which allows the model to process these disparate inputs as a single, cohesive sequence, enabling it to capture subtle cross-modal relationships. Beyond classification, our framework incorporates SHAP (Shapley Additive exPlanations) to provide transparent, feature-level justifications for each prediction. Our results demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, significantly outperforming baseline models, particularly on rare MoA classes. This work shows that high predictive accuracy and clear biological interpretability can be achieved simultaneously, establishing AI as a more reliable and indispensable partner in accelerating drug discovery.

title: Protein Structure and Mutation Analysis for Predicting Pathogenic Variants
authors: Hency Mariam, S. Christina Magneta, R. Golden Nancy
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Accurately predicting dangerous protein changes is essential for precision medicine and understanding genetic disorders. This paper lays the foundation for the eventual integration of structural features obtained from AlphaFold by presenting a machine learning framework for predicting mutant pathogenicity by fusing positional data with physicochemical descriptors. Using stratified test data from the ClinVar database, the Random Forest classifier demonstrated good performance, achieving an accuracy of 77.9%, an F1-score of 70.4%, and an AUC of 0.854. The proposed system enables batch and single-variant evaluation with feature engineering, comprehensive data preprocessing, and an easy-to-use deployment interface. By focusing on characteristics that are interpretable and biologically meaningful, the method ensures transparency and reproducibility, which are crucial in clinical and research applications. This approach allows for efficient variant triage in clinical genomics pipelines while maintaining generalisability and computational economy. Lastly, the approach enhances reliable computational methods for evaluating protein variants and opens the door to more informed and reliable clinical decision-making by bridging the gap between sequence-based prediction and structure-aware pathogenicity evaluation.

title: Edge AI Driven Real Time Voice Controlled System for Sustainable Water Management
authors: Bhaskar M K, Rakhi S, Likhitha Swamy, E A Gowri, Manoj B
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Water is one of the most essential resources for life and its conservation is always a challenge. This project aims to develop a voice-controlled water dispenser to promote water conservation using advanced AI technologies. Current water dispensers predominantly rely on manual controls or basic sensor mechanisms, which lack flexibility, personalization, and advanced monitoring features. The proposed model introduces an AI-driven system that leverages a neural network classifier. The model is trained on Edge Impulse to recognize 11 specific voice commands, enabling hands-free, hygienic, and precise control of water flow. A manually curated dataset of one-second audio samples was used to train the model, achieving an optimized accuracy of 87%. The model is deployed on an advanced microcontroller, integrated with a flow sensor to ensure accurate monitoring and regulation of water usage. Additionally, a visual display offers real-time feedback by showcasing the device status and recognized commands, improving usability. Compared to existing systems, this approach provides greater adaptability, enhanced water-saving capabilities, and a more user-friendly experience. By integrating AI with IoT, the proposed system demonstrates the potential for creating sustainable and innovative solutions to everyday challenges, offering a significant advancement in smart home technology.

title: Unipolar/Bipolar 0-1 MHz Arbitrary Pulse Generator Using an Ultrafast Series-Stacked 20 kV MOSFET Module
authors: S. M. Mortazavi, T. Huiskamp
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: High-voltage nanosecond pulse generators are increasingly employed in industrial applications and for research and development, where fast, repetitive high-voltage pulses are required. Depending on the application, variations in frequency, pulse polarity, and waveform shape are often necessary. This paper presents a simple ultrafast pulse generator based on a series-stacked 20 kV MOSFET module capable of producing unipolar/bipolar pulses with arbitrary waveforms. The proposed topology, including a high-voltage AC-DC converter and seriesstacked MOSFETs, is described in detail. Experimental results demonstrate the capability to generate positive, negative, and bipolar rectangular nanosecond pulses. The generator reliably produces pulses with peak-to-peak voltages up to 20 kV under a 30 A load, at operating frequencies from 0 to 1 MHz, either periodically or in burst mode, while respecting the topology's average power limit. Output parameters are fully adjustable according to user-defined waveform patterns.

title: A Novel 22 kW Bidirectional All-GaN Integrated Onboard Charger Using a 3L-NPC and Interleaved Dual-Buck With Low Common Mode Voltage
authors: Ebraam Fakhuri, Christian Klumpner, Md Rishad Ahmed, Ying Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a simulation study on a 22 kW bidirectional all-GaN integrated onboard charger (iOBC) that combines a three-level neutral-point-clamped (3L-NPC) AC-DC front end with a two-phase interleaved dual-buck DC-DC back end. Referencing both stages to a split DC link limits device stress to half the bus voltage, enabling the use of 650 V GaN devices and supporting high switching frequency with improved power density and efficiency. The topology inherently lowers common-mode voltage; simulation results show near-complete cancellation at the DC/DC output. The control implemented is a grid-synchronised cascaded dq scheme for the 3L-NPC and phase-shifted interleaving with per-leg current control for the DC-DC stage. PLECS results in G2V and V2G operation confirm near-unity power factor with THD at 2.5 % at 22 kW, drain-source voltage peaks around half of the DC link voltage. By keeping each switch within half-bus voltage while shifting ripple to twice the switching frequency, the proposed architecture enables a compact, efficient, and scalable charger platform.

title: A 2kW, 100V Gan-Based Half-Bridge Power Module Using an Optimized PCB-Ceramic Stack-Up for High Efficiency and Power Density
authors: Manuel Rueß, Peter Mack, Jonas Pannasch, Jeremy Nuzzo, Mathias C. J. Weiser, Dominik Koch, André Zimmermann, Ingmar Kallfass
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents a 2kW, 100V GaN-based halfbridge power module optimized for high efficiency and power density. The proposed module features a PCB-ceramic stackup combining the advantages of printed circuit board and ceramic substrate technologies. A multilayer flex-PCB design is employed to minimize parasitic inductances, while a highly thermally conductive AIN ceramic interface ensures efficient heat dissipation. These design measures enable high-speed switching operation with output currents up to 70A. Two 100V, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \mathrm{m} \Omega$</tex> GaN bare dies are connected in parallel and used as highand low-side switches. The flex-PCB power-loop design with a 25 μm thin isolation layer enables the realization of a power-loop inductance of 98.6 pH, supporting voltage transitions reaching 48V/ns with maximal voltage overshoots of 17% of the input voltage. The 250μm thick AlN ceramic baseplate provides a low thermal resistance path to the heat sink, resulting in a simulated thermal resistance of 0.49K/W between the GaN die to the heat sink. Evaluated in a 48 V and 75 V buck converter topology, the power module reaches dc-to-dc efficiencies above 98% and output powers of 1.6 kW at 48 V and 2.2 kW at 75 V with maximum operating temperatures of 65° C. With a power density exceeding 800W/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> and the capability to operate at MHz frequencies, this GaN half-bridge module based on the proposed PCB-ceramic stack-up offers significant advantages in terms of efficiency, power density, and thermal performance for high-current switched-mode power supplies.

title: Miller Charge Control for Voltage-Balancing of Series-Parallel Connected Gan HEMT Switch Cells
authors: Reece Cateley, Andrew Lapthorn, Bill Heffernan, Vedang Gaikwad
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The research presented in this paper concerns the development of systems to enable series-parallel arrays of fieldeffect based transistors to be operated as a single switch cell. In addition to exploiting the improved figure of merit of lower voltage transistors in high voltage applications, these switch cells could also allow for promising transistor technologies which are immature or otherwise incapable of high power ratings to be implemented and tested in high-power converters. A conceptual architecture for these series-parallel switch cells is presented. Furthermore, the design and validation of a gate drive system to enable the precise injection of charge onto a HEMT gate is presented, which is capable of affecting the distribution of the cell's blocking voltage across its constituent transistors to prevent overvoltage. Further research will include development of the FPGA-based voltage-balance control system, optimisation of the performance and efficiency of the voltage-balancing system, and the development of any necessary current-balancing systems to expand the current capability of these switch cells.

title: Evolution of a Bidirectional Low Frequency Trapezoidal Electromagnet Current Source
authors: Bill Heffernan, Michael Hayes, Ke Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper describes the evolution, through three stages, of a driver circuit designed to produce a flat-topped, circa 50 A bidirectional trapezoidal current, at a frequency in the region of 10 Hz, through an air-cored electromagnet coil to produce the constant, but periodically flipped, magnetic field necessary for an open channel groundwater electromagnetic flowmeter. The final circuit was built to be transportable for field use. This employs two separate commercial AC-DC power sources for regenerative magnetization and steady-state operation, respectively. These are connected to the coil by an eight MOSFET switching circuit, and is powered from lithium ion batteries via a sine-wave inverter.

title: ReasonLite: A Unified Framework for Distilling Reasoning into Small Language Models
authors: Karun Thankachan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Small language models (SLMs) offer advantages in cost, latency, and deployment control but often underperform on multi-step reasoning tasks without large-model guidance or costly supervision. While techniques like chain-of-thought prompting, self-consistent decoding, and rationale distillation improve reasoning, fragmented tooling, unclear evaluation practices, and high token costs hinder progress. ReasonLite addresses these gaps with a modular Python library for reasoning-centric distillation in SLMs. It unifies answer and rationale supervision, multi-sample agreement, and program-aided distillation for verified intermediate reasoning. The library also provides discrete and continuous compression to reduce token budgets while retaining reasoning quality. To promote reproducibility, ReasonLite includes standardized diagnostics, curriculum scheduling, tracebudget control, and configurable policies for safe reasoning trace storage and emission. This paper offers a functional overview of ReasonLite, presenting it as a cohesive and reproducible framework for advancing reasoning efficiency in small models.

title: Critique Connect: Augmenting Human Creativity through AI-Driven Semantic Analysis and Adaptive Feedback Synthesis-A Review
authors: Mohd Anas, Shelly Gupta, Nikhil Raikwar, Gaurav Verma, Hritik Roushan, Mukesh Kumar Tripathi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Feedback is essential to creative growth, even if it’s haphazard, inconsistent and hardly ever easy to act on. Critique Connect solves this opportunity gap with an AI-based model that decodes raw peer feedback and structures it into usable insights. The system has two levels. first, where the system pre-processes feedback using a BERT based model and cluster it to avoid redundancy as well as measure sentiment and tone, whilst extracting the underlying semantics. And then if author use a generation model like GPT, the author can generate clear and concise advice that the creators are able to follow. To encourage activity, Critique Connect "gamifies" the site and promises badges, experience points and a leader’s board to those leaving considered critiques. In our preliminary analysis, auhtro found that Critique Connect improves feedback on three aspects, i.e. clarity, depth, and useful-ness improvement. This results in higher user satisfaction and higher creativity novelty. It’s perfect for schools, arts organizations and events like hackathons. Their vision is Visions Critique Connect show how AI can revolutionize feedback culture by taking a set of vague loose-comments and aggregating them into a coherent, constructive comment about author work that will inspire human creativity and innovation, things which machines are not very good at.

title: IoT-Enabled Battlefield Surveillance Robot with Metal Detection and Real-Time Alerts
authors: Thendral R, Sanjay S, Naveen S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: In contemporary defense and security, the requirement for intelligent and autonomous surveillance has been far beyond what is needed. Suggested project is IoT-based battlefield surveillance robot with real time monitoring, metal detection, and instant alert generation. The system can reduce risks to human operators with remote navigation and detection of threats in the battlefield. The robot comprises an ESP8266 NodeMCU microcontroller, ESP32-CAM for live streaming, and a selection of sensors such as ultrasonic, flame, sound, and metal detection modules. Remote observation and control is enabled by the Blynk smart phone app with global access using the Internet of Things. Instant alerts are generated to the operator device whenever a possible threat such as metallic objects, unfamiliar sound, or fire is identified. The suggested approach decreases the drawbacks of RF, Zigbee, and Bluetooth-based surveillance systems extensively applied now, which are full of range problems and pairing problems. Experimental testing demonstrates the system effective in threat detection, real-time alert generation, and continuous surveillance and thus suitable for defense, border surveillance, and rescue operations.

title: Comprehensive Heuristic Resource Scheduling Method Based on Virtualized Clusters
authors: Jing Li, Mingjie Ma, Jia Hao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: The quality of the scheduling method for virtualization clusters directly affects the performance of the entire cluster. Improper scheduling can even eliminate the advantages of virtualization clusters and reduce the performance of the entire system. Aiming at the problems of low resource utilization and poor performance caused by improper resource scheduling in cluster mode, a comprehensive heuristic resource scheduling method based on virtualization cluster - Resource Type Priority List Scheduling (RTPLS) algorithm is proposed. The entire algorithm includes two stages: resource monitoring and virtual machine scheduling. On the basis of considering multiple threshold triggering conditions such as CPU, memory, and network in the host load judgment during virtual machine scheduling, the host’s resource oscillation granularity and resource weight are introduced to comprehensively evaluate the resource load situation of the entire host, avoiding frequent migration of virtual machines caused by the oscillation of host resource load. In the selection of target virtual machine migration, in order to minimize the number of virtual machine migrations as much as possible, the compatibility coefficient λ of virtual machines is introduced, and the migration is sorted according to the priority list of λ to reduce the server load and energy consumption caused by virtual machine migration with the minimum number of virtual machine migrations. When selecting the target server, in order to minimize the load on the target virtual machine, target server relevance is introduced. Finally, by testing the algorithm in practical environments, it was found that the RTPLS algorithm can significantly improve the efficiency of host load balancing adjustments and enhance resource utilization.

title: Synthetic Aperture Radar Image Segmentation using a Convolutional Neural Network-based U Net
authors: Jeyasimma R, Mukesh K, Vijayaraj J, J. Priya, Amsavalli K, B.M.Arun Esai
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) is a vital remote sensing technology that captures detailed surface information independent of weather and lighting, enabling wide applications in environmental and geospatial analysis. However, the intrinsic noise and complex signal patterns in SAR data make image interpretation and segmentation highly challenging. This paper presents a deep learning-based SAR image enhancement and segmentation framework that integrates a U-Net Convolutional Neural Network with a spectral-normalized PatchGAN discriminator. The model leverages Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 datasets, where images are preprocessed into uniform 512×512 tiles to ensure efficient training and consistency. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior segmentation accuracy, effectively preserving texture details and large-scale structural boundaries across multiple land types, including urban, agricultural, grassland, and barren regions. The approach shows strong potential for real-world applications in precision agriculture, disaster management, and urban planning, offering an efficient solution for improving SAR image interpretability and advancing automated geospatial analytics.

title: Synthetic Data Augmentation with General Adversarial Networks for Improving Rare Cancer Detection in Histopathology Images
authors: Saraswathi P, Srihari R M, Vijayakarthick K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: In order to increase the survival rate of the patient, an early detection of cancer histopathological images are analysed. Finding unusual cancer types is still quite challenging due to the unavailability of large volume annotated images. There’s also class-imbalance in the medical datasets. Researchers present a novel way of generating synthetic histopathology images for rare cancer classes using Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Networks. Synthetic images, which are added to data collection, help to upgrade a classifier based on ResNet18 to detect cancer. According to the experimental results, the inclusion of synthetic data produced by GAN helps in increasing the classification accuracy of the model, the F1 score. Also, the model becomes robust as it gets trained on real plus synthetic data compared to the model trained on real data. According to the study, synthetic data can help to tackle data shortage and improve detection accuracy for rare cancer. Synthetic data is all about machines creating intelligent data by learning from the real data.

title: Parameter Identification and Adaptive Control of a High Power Medium Voltage Dual Active Bridge
authors: Tobias Merz, Nikolas Menger, Georg Zieglmaier, Fabian Sommer, Rüdiger Schwendemann, Marc Hiller
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: A unified control software is typically designed and tuned for structurally identical Dual Active Bridges (DABs) based on worst-case hardware parameters. However, improving dynamic behavior, efficiency and resource utilization requires precise knowledge of each individual unit, since even identically built systems may exhibit different characteristics due to component tolerances and varying operating conditions. This necessitates either additional sensors or individual testing and adaptation of each DAB's control algorithm. To address this limitation, this work presents an online parameter identification method that estimates the leakage inductance with less than 2 % deviation without requiring extra sensors. Additionally, the identified inductance is used to adjust the control algorithm in real time, thereby improving efficiency and enabling higher maximum output power by relaxing conservative software constraints, while ensuring operation within the safe operating area.

title: Hybrid Wrapper-based Feature Selection Framework for Sentiment Analysis using Machine Learning and Ensemble Models
authors: B.Bhasker Murali Krishna, Kethireddy Mallikharjuna Rao, Balvindersingh Bondili, Y Sherly Priscilla, Manoj Kumar Vemula, G Satyanarayana
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Sentiment analysis is an area of study that is extensively researched. It is concerned with the process of recognizing and classifying opinions that are conveyed in text into one of three categories: positive, negative, or neutral polarities. One of the most important steps in improving the accuracy of sentiment classification is feature selection, which is a process that helps reduce dimensionality, eliminate features that are irrelevant, and improve the efficiency of the model. This study explores the performance of a variety of feature selection methods for sentiment analysis, with a special emphasis on hybrid wrapper-based approaches. In order to create a feature vocabulary that is as efficient as possible, SVM- Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) is followed by Sequential Feature Selection (SFS/SBS) in this particular case. The efficacy of these selected characteristics is evaluated with the use of a number of machine learning classifiers, such as Support Vector Machines (SVM), Naive Bayes (NB), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Logistic Regression (LR), and Decision Tree (DT). In addition, in order to further improve the classification performance, ensemble learning approaches, including as Random Forests, Extra-Trees, XGBoost, AdaBoost, and stacking, are used. The findings of the experiment show that the hybrid feature selection strategy, when used in conjunction with ensemble methods, leads to a considerable improvement in sentiment classification accuracy. As a result, a solid foundation for opinion mining in text-based data is provided.

title: MATLAB Simulation of Echo and Delay in Audio Signals using Z-Transform
authors: Kottaimalai Ramaraj, Nalavadi Lokesh, Omkaram Kalyan Raju, M Sasi Varun, J Dinesh, Shaik Sameer Ahmad
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The article provides a case study on the application of Z-Transform techniques, which are implemented using MATLAB, to simulate delay and echo effects in discrete-time audio signal processing. This work's goal is to show how theoretical ideas in digital signal processing (DSP) can be used to create useful audio effects, which are frequently employed in virtual sound modeling, communication systems, and music production. Standard audio samples were used to test and construct the system in MATLAB and confirm its functionality. To replicate various acoustic settings, variable parameters including echo strength and delay period were employed. The technology effectively generates echo effects with adjustable features, according to simulation results. The success of Z-Transform-based modeling for these kinds of applications is confirmed by the processed audio outputs, which clearly show the presence of delayed signal components. To sum up, this study confirms that Z-Transform and MATLAB simulation can be used to create and implement simple audio effects. The method offers a fundamental comprehension of the direct application of DSP concepts to actual sound processing systems.

title: Automated Blood Group Identification using Biometrics
authors: Prabhakar Marry, J. Rethna Virgil Jeny, Sathvika. V, Rohith.K, Jagannath Preetham. J, Tejeshwar Reddy. K
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Determining blood groups is a fundamental step in clinical diagnostics and is traditionally carried out through invasive laboratory techniques. This project presents an innovative, non-invasive method that leverages machine learning to predict blood groups using fingerprint images. A Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model is developed to categorize fingerprint patterns into the four primary blood groups: A, B, AB, and O. The fingerprint dataset, annotated with respective blood group labels, undergoes preprocessing procedures such as normalization, augmentation, and resizing to enhance model performance. The CNN is trained to extract and learn intricate features that may have potential associations with specific blood types. Although conventional diagnostic procedures remain the most reliable, this study explores the viability of using biometric inputs for blood group classification. The outcomes highlight the possibility of integrating AI-based fingerprint analysis into healthcare systems, potentially contributing to advancements in biometric diagnostics.

title: Visual-based Sentiment Analysis Chatbot
authors: Harshita Bhardwaj, Hrijuth Rajesh, Javakala Reddy Dharanesh Reddy, Gaurang Kishore, N.Neelima, Glace Varghese T.
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: In today’s world, mental health has become a pressing global issue, affecting people across all age groups and walks of life. 15% of India’s adult population experiences mental health issues. According to Indian journal of Psychiatry India has 0.75 psychiatrists per 100,000 people whereas WHO recommends at least 3 per 100,000. Despite of increasing awareness, access to effective mental health care remains limited due to factors such as high costs, lack of availability and persistent social stigma. The social stigma generally leads people to push themselves to not express their thoughts and feelings and prevent individuals from seeking timely support, leading to prolonged emotional distress and reduced quality of life. In today’s fast-paced and digitally connected world, there is a need for solutions that are not effective but also accessible, affordable and stigma-free. Advancements in Artificial Intelligence, especially in the fields of Natural Language Processing (NLP) have opened up new possibilities for mental health support. This paper proposes the development and application of a sentiment-aware chatbot- an AI-powered virtual assistant designed to understand to users’ emotional support, especially during moments when professional help is not immediately available. Ultimately, this technology aims to bridge the gap between traditional mental health services and the daily emotional needs of individuals fostering a culture where mental well-being is prioritized, supported and destigmatized.

title: Exploring the Diagnostic Potential of Histopathological Images in AI-based Breast Cancer Detection
authors: Nagendra Nath Dubey, Gaurav Mishra, Laxman Singh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Diagnosis of breast cancer has already seen significant impact from the emergence of artificial intelligence. In this work, we focus on analysis of various literatures on AI based breast cancer categorization using histological image with their performance, gap analysed and future improvements. We have also shown the various histological dataset available for research and development. Despite the advances that have been made, challenges still exist including unbalanced data while outperforming even the largest image datasets requires plenty of computing power. In addition, it is often unclear how these models achieve their result, and thus they cannot be used in real practice. Future work should explore a better understanding of feature extraction and datasets that are both larger and informative. Future work should also design models that are interpretable in hospitals or clinic systems, therefore trusting the decisions they make will facilitate their use and trust in practice. With these improvements, technology can better help doctors to identify and manage breast cancer sooner and with better accuracy.

title: Unified Data Management: A Comparative Study of Multi-Model vs Single-Model Database Architectures
authors: Milan Parikh, Nithya Subramaniam, Karthik Chakravarthy Cheekuri, Venkata Sai Chandra Veerlapally, Srikanth Reddy Keshireddy
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The organized handling of data is of growing importance in contemporary applications owing to the abundance of mixed data sources, ranging from structured, semi-structured, unstructured and graph-based sources. In addition, the existing single-model database is not friendly to multi-modal data and multiple storage and access schemes. This has the disadvantage of: poor performance, poor flexibility and large operational overhead. This study addresses this problem by building a comparative structure for multi-model and single-model database architectures in order to test their efficiency, adaptability and resource consumption for scenarios of unified data management. We are using new methodology based on synthetic data set generation from cross-domain, schema equivalence mapping, hybrid workload design, Workload Translation Layer and Dynamic Resource Allocation Controller. The quantitative assessment in terms of various performance, resource, consistency and adaptability criteria proves that the proposed multi model system has highest Composite Performance Index (CPI=86) with superiority in terms of cross model query latency, schema evolution, holistic performance balance while various traditional RDBMS and polyglot approaches exhibit trade-offs. These results suggest the use of multi-model architectures for heterogeneous data management is a robust, flexible and scalable solution with significant advantages for modern enterprise and cloud natively-based applications.
