title: Time-Stretched Optical Frequency Comb Dispersive Fourier Transformation for Rapid Measurement of 3D Morphology of Solar Cells
authors: Li Chen, Zhehai Zhou, Guangwei Chen, Tengfei Wu, Zhendong Zhu, Ying Qin, Yue Zhao, Jibo Han, Yu Bai, Zhiyong Zhang, Xiang Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Accurate measurement and quality inspection of solar cell morphology are essential for ensuring high fabrication yield and device performance. Conventional techniques for online inspection are restricted by slow acquisition speed, limited resolution, or complex implementation, and thus cannot fully satisfy the demands of high-throughput manufacturing. To overcome these limitations, we propose a spectral interference measurement method based on an optical frequency comb (OFC) combined with time-stretched dispersive Fourier transform (TS-DFT), enabling real-time, continuous, and high-speed analysis. Theoretical analysis indicates that the minimum detection time per frame can reach 4 ns owing to the repetition rate of the OFC, whereas the practical acquisition speed in the current implementation is limited to the millisecond scale due to hardware constraints. Experimental results demonstrate a spectral resolution of 0.39 nm and high accuracy with root-mean-square errors of 0.543 μm (locked OFC) and 0.732 μm (unlocked OFC). These results confirm the capability of the proposed system for precise online inspection and its potential in 3D precision manufacturing.

title: Cracking Analysis and Optimized Design of Integrated Planar Transformer for High-Power Density LLC Converter
authors: Xinqi Li, Chunguang Ren, Xiaoqing Han, Ming Xu, Julu Sun, Juanjuan Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Magnetic integration technology, which is generally accomplished through flux cancelation to achieve a tradeoff between transformer losses and footprint, has been widely adopted to minimize core volume and significantly enhance converter efficiency in high-frequency applications. However, some existing conventional magnetic integration design methods may lead to reliability issues such as core cracking in high-frequency and high-power density applications. Core cracking always results in an additional core loss and winding loss. In this article, a core cracking phenomenon is investigated in integrated planar transformers in high-frequency and high-power density LLC converters. The mechanism behind the phenomenon is analyzed in detail, and an optimized design method of the integrated planar transformer without changing the footprint and profile is proposed, which relocates the air gaps to the plate to solve the issue of core cracking. The proposed approach effectively addresses the core cracking issue while reducing the losses, thereby enhancing efficiency, power density, and reliability. Besides, some comparative analysis between the traditional method and the proposed optimized method has been done to demonstrate the advantages of the proposed method. Finally, a 2kW LLC converter prototype with 400 V-to-48 V conversion is implemented to verify the proposed theoretical method. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed solution achieves a power density of 19670 W/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> with a peak efficiency of 98.1%.

title: Adversarial Attacks Resilient Machine Learning-Enabled Access Control Scheme for Consumer Electronics in IoT-Based Applications_supp1-3662480.pdf
authors: Ashok Kumar Das
publish: N/A
abstract: Consumer Electronics (CE) have become integral to the evolving Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem, providing enhanced security, interoperability, and intelligence through machine learning (ML) to improve IoT functionality and user experiences. However, as CE devices manage sensitive data, security vulnerabilities emerge, particularly due to the use of wireless communication channels, which are often insecure. The lack of security in ML training and testing on CE-related datasets heightens risks such as data poisoning and adversarial attacks. In this article, a resilient machine learning-based access control scheme (RMACE-IoT) is designed to address these critical security challenges in IoT applications. RMACE-IoT not only strengthens the security of data exchanges but also defends against adversarial attacks that could undermine ML model predictions. The proposed RMACE-IoT is validated through a real-time testbed experiment, showcasing its effectiveness in enhancing resilience and mitigating adversarial threats. The proposed scheme (Case 1) achieves communication cost reductions of up to 40.00%, 60.42%, 61.49%, 65.87%, and 81.73% when compared with the schemes of Luo et al., Ali and Pal, Wang et al., Ever, and Zhang et al., respectively. In terms of computational cost, the proposed scheme demonstrates improvements of 99.90%, 52.76%, 52.29%, 99.95%, and 45.70% over the corresponding schemes. These results demonstrate the practical applicability and advantages of RMACE-IoT in real-time IoT scenarios. This work significantly advances the field by addressing pressing security concerns in CE systems, paving the way for safer, more reliable, and intelligent consumer devices.

title: Soft Label Pruning and Quantization for Large-Scale Dataset Distillation
authors: Lingao Xiao, Yang He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Large-scale dataset distillation requires storing auxiliary soft labels that can be 30-40× (ImageNet-1K) or 200× (ImageNet-21K) larger than the condensed images, undermining the goal of dataset compression. We identify two fundamental issues necessitating such extensive labels: (1) insufficient image diversity, where high within-class similarity in synthetic images requires extensive augmentation, and (2) insufficient supervision diversity, where limited variety in supervisory signals during training leads to performance degradation at high compression rates. To address these challenges, we propose Label Pruning and Quantization for Large-scale Distillation (LPQLD). We enhance image diversity via class-wise batching and BN supervision during synthesis. For supervision diversity, we introduce Label Pruning with Dynamic Knowledge Reuse to enhance label-per-augmentation diversity, and Label Quantization with Calibrated Student-Teacher Alignment to enhance augmentation-per-image diversity. Our approach reduces soft label storage by 78× on ImageNet-1K and 500× on ImageNet-21K while improving accuracy by up to 7.2% and 2.8%, respectively. Extensive experiments validate the superiority of LPQLD across different network architectures and other dataset distillation methods.

title: Effect of Ice-Bridging Degree on AC Flashover of 110 kV Composite Insulators under Natural Icing
authors: Yanpeng Hao, Zijian Wu, Shipei Xiang, Lei Huang, Huan Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The growth of ice ridges narrows the air gaps between insulator sheds, degrading electrical performance under icing conditions. To quantify how the ice-bridging degree affects flashover, this study conducted natural icecovered alternating-current (AC) flashover tests on 110 kV composite insulators with various ice-bridging degrees (35.5 %–83.5 %), using both even-rising and stepwise voltage methods. An image-processing method tracked arc development. Results show that a higher ice-bridging degree lowers the 50 % flashover voltage by 10.1 %–39.8 % and shortens the intermittent-arc stage. At comparable ice-bridging levels, stepwise tests yielded voltages about 4.2 %–24.6% lower than even-rising tests because liquid water films formed during the voltage withstand period raised surface conductivity. After the last arc extinction–reignition event, flashover occurred within one-quarter of an AC cycle. The critical arc length (Lₐ)—defined as the arc length at the voltage peak before final extinction—was 16.2 %–35.1 % of the dry-arc distance, far below the 62.6 %–64.6 % reported in earlier studies. Lₐ varied little with the ice-bridging degree or icing/melting state. Based on the observed AC arc development, a camera frame rate of ≥ 200 fps is therefore required to capture pre-flashover discharges for field monitoring. These findings clarify the influence of ice-bridging degree on insulator flashover and provide support for image-based early-warning systems on iced transmission lines.

title: Robust FMCW Radar Clutter Suppression for UAV detection via learning Physics-Informed Priors
authors: Hao Zhang, Shunjun Wei, Rui Min, Shuangqiao Li, Yinghao Cheng, Jin Li, Mou Wang, Jun Shi, Guolong Cui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The rapid development of the low-altitude economy has made reliable UAV surveillance in urban and field areas a critical task. For FMCW radar, detecting these low, slow, and small targets is severely compromised by strong clutter, particularly the pervasive sidelobe clutter from static infrastructures that masks faint target echoes. To address this challenge, this paper proposes the Physics-Informed Guided Decomposition Network (PIGD-Net) for robust and adaptive radar clutter suppression. Firstly, we reformulate the clutter suppression task as a guided component decomposition problem. Subsequently, a multi-objective optimization framework is introduced. The framework employs a convolutional sparse-enhancement module to accurately capture the target component, while concurrently suppressing the low rank clutter via a guided nuclear norm minimization, which is dynamically steered by a data-driven mask. This entire optimization process is then unfolded into the PIGD-Net architecture, enabling efficient training by accommodating the distinct characteristics of its internal module. Crucially, PIGD-Net operates under a composite unsupervised loss, enforces the inherent physical properties of each component by fusing a reconstruction term, a Hoyer-based sparsity prior, and an orthogonality penalty, thereby obviating the need for ground-truth labels. Extensive experiments on simulated and real world data validate the performance of the method. Compared to existing methods, PIGD-Net achieves efficient suppression with a fast processing time, while significantly improving the Signal-to Clutter Ratio and target fidelity.

title: Data-Driven Optimal Bidding Strategy in Day-Ahead Electricity Markets Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xiangyu Chen, Chaoxu Mu, Hui Wang, Changyin Sun, Jinshan Bian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: With growing renewable integration, optimizing bidding strategies is critical for efficient capacity allocation and generator revenue. However, using real operational data poses significant privacy risks. Thus, this article proposes a novel electricity market bidding strategy optimization framework based on reward learning and enhanced by conditional tabular generative adversarial networks (CTGAN). Initially, a CTGAN is employed to synthesize market data, effectively implementing data augmentation and mitigating privacy leakage risks. Subsequently, a reward learning algorithm grounded in the maximum entropy principle is developed to infer the implicit reward functions. Finally, leveraging the identified reward functions, a deep <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Q$</tex-math></inline-formula>-network algorithm generates enhanced bidding strategies. Experimental results indicate that the CTGAN method more accurately replicates real-data distributions than conventional methods. In bidding simulations, the strategy derived from the identified reward function demonstrates enhanced flexibility and strategic behavior compared to predefined reward approaches, ultimately increasing generator profits and improving market efficiency.

title: Two-Stage Inversion Based on PDFNO and FDFD for Logging-While-Drilling Electromagnetic Ultra-Deep Detection
authors: Yang Liu, Jian Wang, Delong Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: The inversion of Logging-While-Drilling (LWD) electromagnetic ultra-deep detection plays a critical role in geological guidance and reservoir evaluation. However, the computational speed of forward modeling for complex formations hinders the realization of real-time inversion. The application of deep learning (DL) has demonstrated potential to significantly enhance inversion efficiency. In this paper, we develop a two-stage method based on physics-driven Fourier neural operator (PDFNO) and frequency domain finite difference (FDFD) to achieve efficient two-dimensional formation inversion. In the first stage inversion, the PDFNO method significantly accelerates both forward modeling and Jacobian matrix computation, reducing computational time. During the second stage inversion, the FDFD method precisely inverts formation details, thereby ensuring inversion accuracy. The two crucial practical switching criteria are proposed for transitioning from PDFNO stage inversion to FDFD stage inversion. Both switching criteria can identify the appropriate switching iteration, thereby ensuring the accuracy and efficiency of the inversion. Three typical geological structure numerical examples are designed to evaluate the proposed method and the inversion results are compared against conventional FDFD based inversion. In numerical examples, the two-stage inversion method achieves comparable accuracy to FDFD based inversion while reducing computational time by approximately 50%, demonstrating the effectiveness of the two-stage inversion method.

title: An Ultra-Compact and Fully Integrated Tunable IR-UWB Transmitter in 28-nm CMOS for High-Density Neural Implants
authors: Esmaeil Ranjbar Koleibi, Reza Bostani, Konin Koua, William Lemaire, Benoit Gosselin, Sébastien Roy, Frédéric Nabki, Réjean Fontaine
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper presents a fully-CMOS, tunable impulse radio ultra-wideband (IR-UWB) transmitter for high-density implantable neural recording systems. Fabricated in 28 nm CMOS technology, the transmitter features an ultra-compact edge-combining architecture based on a digitally tunable impulse response filter (IRF) occupying only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.0027~ {\mathrm {\text {m}\text {m} ^{2}}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. The measured output exhibits a central frequency of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4.5~ {\mathrm {\text {G}\text {Hz} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> with a 10-dB bandwidth of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3.6~ {\mathrm {\text {G}\text {Hz} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, providing robust spectral performance. It achieves <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1~ {\mathrm {\text {G}\text {Hz} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> frequency tunability by adjusting pulse widths from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$650~ {\mathrm {\text {p}\text {s} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$800~ {\mathrm {\text {p}\text {s} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, ensuring compliance with FCC spectral masks. A current-starved ring VCO (CSRVCO), with a compact <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$150~ {\mathrm {\mu \text {m} ^{2}}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> layout, serves as the clock source, offering wide frequency tuning, low power consumption, and enhanced output power. The transmitter employs On-Off Keying (OOK) modulation and delivers a peak output amplitude of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$660~ {\mathrm {\text {m}\text {V} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> with up to 5.1% energy efficiency. At a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$20~ {\mathrm {\text {M}\text {Hz} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> pulse repetition rate, the transmitter consumes only <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$78~ {\mathrm {\mu \text {W} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> while producing -24.5dBm of output power. Measurement results confirm compliance with FCC regulations and suitability for deep implantation in biomedical applications. The design achieves a competitive Figure-of-Merit (FoM) of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.017~({\mathrm {\text {m}\text {m} ^{2}}} \cdot {\mathrm {\text {p}\text {J} }}) / (\text {b} \cdot {\mathrm {\text {V}}})$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, demonstrating its scalability and efficiency compared to prior state-of-the-art solutions.

title: Cost-Optimal Satellite-Assisted Video Delivery
authors: Yuriy Reznik
publish: Proceedings of the conference on Proceedings of the 5th Mile-High Video Conference
abstract: None

title: Ultra-low latency software (HEVC and VVC) encoding: capabilities and applications
authors: Mauricio Alvarez-Mesa, Chi Ching Chi, Benjamin Bross
publish: Proceedings of the conference on Proceedings of the 5th Mile-High Video Conference
abstract: None

title: Guest Editorial: Special Issue on Intelligence of Social Things-Enabled Cooperative Learning for Behavioral-Cultural Modeling
authors: Chinmay Chakraborty, Bhuvan Unhelkar, Saïd Mahmoudi, Martin Margala, Sayonara Barbosa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems

title: Visual Proprioception and Contact Prediction for Soft Robotic Arms Using Onboard Sensing and Generative Models
authors: Yunqi Huang, Guanran Pei, Josie Hughes, Thomas George Thuruthel
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Soft continuum robots possess inherent compliance and ensure safe interactions. Whilst advantageous, their high degrees of freedom pose significant challenges for estimating the robot's configuration and sensing external contacts. Existing analytical methods rely on finite state-representations that do not accurately capture the complex deformations in these systems. Learning-based approaches have shown promise, as they do not require any prior assumptions about the state representation; however, there are still challenges in extending them to handle external contacts. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel perception framework for soft robotic arms by using onboard sensor data and generative models to develop image-based perception systems capable of reconstructing the arm's state, even under external contact. Our approach features an automated data preprocessing pipeline that isolates the robot from the environmental background, enabling the training of robust perception models. It then utilizes onboard IMU data and actuation commands to generate a high-dimensional visual representation of the robot's state, while also detecting contact locations with high accuracy.

title: Generative AI Sensor Fusion for Secure Digital Twin Ecosystems: A Standardization-Aligned Framework for Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Mahmood Afzal Hussain, Vishal Bhardwaj Meruga, Arun Kumar Rajamandrapu, Sai Raghavendra Varanasi, Sesha Sai Sravanthi Valiveti, Ambarish G. Mohapatra
publish: IEEE Communications Standards Magazine
abstract: Active fault management of the integration of Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs), Digital Twins (DTs), and AI-driven sensors needs a secure and uniform framework. In relevance, the paper presents a hybrid Variational Autoencoder-Generative Adversarial Network (VAE-GAN)-based model with a redesigned Generative AI-Driven Sensor Fusion (GAI-SF) architecture. The proposed architecture combines the streams of multivariate sensor data and preempts anomalies before performance levels may be detected as degraded. Experimental validation based on Tennessee Eastman Process (TEP) and NASA turbofan engine data shows that it is up to 80 times better than classic fusion techniques in F1-score, and lowers the detection latency by some 40%. In addition to predictive performance, GAI-SF is fully compatible with ISO/IEC JTC 1/ SC 42, 3GPP SA6, and ETSI MEC standards, meaning it can be used in secure, interoperable, and AI-controlled deployment in next-generation 5G/6G CPS ecosystems.

title: Resource Optimization for Semantic Communication in 6G Networks: A Survey
authors: Sana Sharif, Faria Khandaker, Muhammad Naeem, Waleed Ejaz
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Semantic communication (SemCom) is an emerging technology for sixth-generation (6G) networks that focuses on the transmission of meaning and task-relevant information, rather than raw data. In contrast, traditional communication (TradCom) transmits complete data streams without considering contextual or semantic importance, which often leads to redundancy and inefficient resource utilization. In this survey, we provide a comprehensive analysis of resource optimization for SemCom networks, focusing on mathematical models, optimization techniques, and performance metrics such as data rate, energy efficiency, and delay. We investigate intelligent frameworks and emerging solutions that align with the quality of service (QoS) demands of 6G networks, offering a unified perspective on using SemCom for scalable, efficient, and robust communication systems. We also highlight major challenges, outline future research directions, and present potential solutions for SemCom-powered wireless networks. We provide a discussion on fundamental concepts to provide readers with the essential background needed to understand the technical advancements in the field. We provide a thorough analysis of existing literature to identify key research gaps and highlighted valuable lessons to guide future directions. Overall, this survey serves as a foundational reference for resource optimization in SemCom networks, laying the groundwork for intelligent and context-aware communication systems capable of meeting the stringent performance demands of 6G networks.

title: MSVM-UNet: Multi-Scale Spatial Attention Enhanced Vision Mamba U-Net for Agricultural Disease Segmentation
authors: Lin Shi, Xinyu Liu, Li Zhao, Haiyang Zhang, Zhanlin Ji
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Agricultural diseased leaf image segmentation is a critical technology for precision agriculture and intelligent crop protection. To overcome the limitations of current segmentation methods-such as imprecise leaf edge extraction, difficulty in detecting small disease lesions, and insufficient robustness in complex backgrounds-this paper proposes an agricultural diseased leaf image segmentation method based on an enhanced visual state space model, named MSVM-UNet (Multi-Scale Spatial Attention Vision Mamba U-Net). This method employs an encoder-decoder framework and integrates improved Visual State Space (VSS) modules in both the encoder and decoder, enhancing long-range dependency modeling and local-global feature fusion. Simultaneously, a Multi-Scale Spatial Attention (MSSA) module is introduced in the skip connections to enhance cross-scale feature representation and capture fine boundary details of disease spots. To simulate real field imaging conditions, we perform random horizontal or vertical flips on the images and randomly adjust hue, saturation, and brightness before training. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared with mainstream methods, MSVM-UNet achieves significant performance improvement in agricultural diseased leaf segmentation tasks, reaching 80.44% mIoU and 92.56% Dice on the validation set, providing our solution for intelligent agricultural disease monitoring.

title: Adaptive Iterative Learning Reliable Control of Nonrepetitive Systems With Multiple Iteration-Varying Parametric Uncertainties
authors: Yong Chen, Deqing Huang, Xuefang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: The repetitiveness prerequisite of iterative learning control has always been the main obstacle to promoting its practical applications. In this article, a novel adaptive iterative learning reliable control scheme is proposed for the nonrepetitive systems with multiple iteration-varying parametric uncertainties, where actuator faults and state delays are considered simultaneously. During the design of the controller, the class-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k_{\infty } $</tex-math> </inline-formula> function is leveraged to dispose of the unmodeled lumps of systems through neural networks, and the transformation of control signals is established to compensate for the negative impact of the inefficient actuator. The technical features of our approach lie in an innovative parametric estimation mechanism that integrates the hyperbolic tangent function and an auxiliary sequence is presented to accommodate the nonrepetitive uncertainties, thus achieving the zero-error convergence of output. As the main merits, the proposed control scheme is promising to manifest better performance and practicality than the existing methods, owing to the weak assumptions on the system dynamics, the little prior knowledge of parametric uncertainties, and the strong learning ability of the controller.

title: AttnMPNet: An Attention-Based Message Passing Network for MIMO Detection
authors: Jian Zheng, Yi Sun, Tiancan Xia, Wenyue Zhou, Xiaosi Tan, Yongming Huang, Chuan Zhang
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: In this letter, we propose AttnMPNet, an attention-based message passing neural network for massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) detection. AttnMPNet integrates Gaussian approximated message passing with self-attention to iteratively refine soft posterior estimates for each transmitted symbol. Within each iteration, approximate likelihood messages are first constructed and then processed through attention blocks to capture inter-symbol dependencies, followed by symbol-wise posterior probability estimation. To support this inference pipeline, we further design a compact and expressive feature representation that enables both efficient computation and high detection accuracy in massive MIMO scenarios. Simulation results show that AttnMPNet achieves near-maximum-likelihood performance across diverse MIMO configurations while significantly reducing inference latency compared to neural baselines.

title: X-IoMT: A Cross-Layer IoMT Dataset for Anomaly Detection with FGSM and PGD-Based Adversarial Augmentation
authors: Rui P. O. Pinto, Bruno M. C. Silva, Pedro R. M. Inácio
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: With the growing adoption of the Internet of Medical Things (IoMT), concerns around security, reliability, and anomaly detection across heterogeneous system layers are increasing. The essence of contemporary anomaly detection lies in Machine Learning (ML), training models on datasets for the desired functionality. Nonetheless, currently available datasets are mostly insufficiently supported with multi-layer analysis, as they usually target a single architectural layer or a narrow attack type. To close this gap, we offer X-IoMT, a publicly available dataset designed to enable the research of anomaly detection in IoMT environments. In the Internet of Things (IoT) architecture, the X-IoMT data embodies anomalies from the perception, network, and application layers. Besides, it incorporates adversarial perturbations by Fast Gradient Sign Method (FGSM) and Projected Gradient Descent (PGD) under both L2 and L∞ norms with extra adversarial augmentation: both on detection performance under common attacks and on resilience against adversarially manipulated samples. Thus, X-IoMT could be an important tool for evaluating and benchmarking reliable anomaly detection models in IoMT scenarios with cross-layer attack coverage and extra adversarial augmentation. This paper contributes with the presentation of the dataset, inherently aiming to support the advancement of more reliable and secure IoMT systems.

title: A Hardware-Efficient Approximate Booth Multiplier for Error-Tolerant Applications
authors: Bavisetty Sai Swaroop, Paramasivam C
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Multiplication is a low-level operation in digital circuits, especially in signal processing, machine learning, and embedded computing. High-performance, low-power, area, and delay multiplier design is important to the low-power VLSI systems of today. For most applications, high-precision computation is not required, and thus there is space for approximate computing as an acceptable design option. In this paper, an approximate Booth multiplier architecture is proposed for applications where a minimal computation error is acceptable. The design starts with a traditional radix-4 Booth encoder and Wallace tree reduction for the base case multiplier. Three directed approximation methods are used to make it more efficient. 1. Wire-based partial product generation, which reduces the logic routing overhead and complexity. 2. Truncation of the least significant bit (LSB) to reduce the operations during the last summation stage. 3. Utilization of a custom approximate 4:2 compressor, which optimizes the usage of gates in the reduction tree. The architecture is synthesized in Verilog HDL and functionally verified. Synthesis is performed using a 90nm standard cell library to estimate the important parameters such as area, timing, power, and error rate. The results show that the approximate multiplier saves considerable area and power with a minor loss in timing and output accuracy. The characteristics make it suitable for use in image processing and machine learning inference, where energy efficiency is of greater concern than exact computation. The solution suggested highlights the merits of approximating at the structural level to obtain a good tradeoff between performance and efficiency.

title: Enhancing IoT Healthcare Security with Optimized Edge Computing and Micro-Segmentation using KSEPA and T3FENN
authors: Winner Pulakhandam, Yashwant Kumar Kolli, Venkataramesh Induru, Karthik Kushala, Vijai Anand Ramar, R.Pushpakumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: To strengthen the security of IoT health networks, it will be a requirement to combine edge computing, micro-segmentation, and federated learning frameworks. The approach proposed by the authors in this research work relies on the combination of Triple Tiers Federated Edge Neural Network (T3FENN) and Knowledge-based Secure Edge Processing Architecture (KSEPA). With edge computing, the application enables processing medical data closer to its source, thus reducing latency and bandwidth usage. The network is segmented with micro-segmentation that ensures network isolation and reduces the attack surface with limited damage in case of breach. T3FENN supports local model training on edge devices, thus guaranteeing privacy-preserving machine learning. KSEPA ensures the secure transport of data. Compared to independent approaches, the methodology has several key advantages, including latency: 35.7 ms, efficiency: 92.1%, security efficacy: 88.4%, privacy preservation: 92.5%, and scalability: 350 devices. This study identifies an effective framework for the safety and scalability of a healthcare IoT system with decreased cyber threats and improved patient privacy. The outcomes further highlighted the importance of using pioneering technologies such as KSEPA and T3FENN for IoT-based health infrastructures.

title: Criminal Identification using Residual Densenet with Particle Swarm Optimization for Facial Attribute Prediction
authors: A. Jency, K. S. Thirunavukkarasu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Criminal identification using machine learning has gained a lot of attention for how it can be used to enhance security and individualization. Facial analysis in particular is offering meaningful information about age, gender and emotional condition, important information for effective identification systems. Traditional deep learning models are difficult to be applied in real-time applications due to their high computational complexity and low flexibility to dynamic datasets. There is a need for models which are not only accurate, but also efficient and generalizable to diverse conditions. This paper proposes a new method combining Residual DenseNet and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) in order to improve the accuracy and the compute speed of facial attribute prediction. Residual DenseNet is used as the backbone for the deep feature extraction whereas Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is used for the optimization of hyperparameters and model architecture for capturing fine granular facial details. The model is evaluated on three datasets including FaceForensics++, DrawSomething and Flickr-Faces-HQ which represents a wide range of expressions, poses and lighting conditions. The proposed system exhibits great improvements in the way that the system can predict the age, gender and emotional states as opposed to normal based models. It also shows better generalization between data sets ensuring robustness under a real-world situation. Visual examination in form of feature map and quantitative evaluation in form of accuracy, F1, precision and recall values validate the model.

title: Temporal Fusion Transformer Forecasting and MILP Prescriptive Optimization for Hospital Pharmacy Supply Chain Orchestration
authors: Manish Raj Anand, Abhilash K S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Healthcare supply management requires timely, data-driven decisions to prevent stockouts, control costs, and safeguard patient outcomes. This study presents an AI-orchestrated framework that integrates probabilistic forecasting with prescriptive optimization to plan pharmacy replenishment within a globalized manufacturing–warehouse–logistics network. Using six years of point-of-sale transactions for 57 drugs, the framework integrates two architectures. A Temporal Fusion Transformer (TFT) produces multi-horizon, quantile-calibrated demand forecasts that capture uncertainty, seasonality, and covariate effects. A Mixed-Integer Linear Program (MILP) then transformed these forecasts, subject to operational and logistical constraints, into executable decisions on what to order, when, from which origin, and via which transport lane. The operation follows a rolling structure in which the TFT generated an eight-week forecast each week, the MILP was solved over the same horizon, the plan for the first week was executed, system states were updated, and the cycle was then repeated. The forecasting component achieved MAE 5.46 units, RMSE 7.81 units<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and sMAPE 4.37%, yielding a stable, low-variance demand signal. The prescriptive stage attained an overall fill rate of 97.8% while respecting operational constraints, indicating near-target service with disciplined spend. The framework delivers reliable demand forecasts and translates them into replenishment plans that balance service levels with efficient resource use. Its orchestrator integrates uncertainty-aware quantile planning, interpretable regulation of the cost–service–lead-time trade-off, and operational realism to keep outputs actionable. These capabilities enable deployment in hospital pharmacies for replenishment, preparedness, and vendor selection, while offering a scalable template for AI-assisted global healthcare supply networks.

title: Enhancing Big Data Forecasting with Gradient Boosting Machine Learning Framework
authors: Sankara Rao, Seema M, VijayaDurga D, Nagarjuna Nallametti, Manasa S, Keerthana N V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Nowadays, rapid digital transformation and the capacity to precisely predict the future from enormous and intricate data sets are essential for many industries. The paper outlines a powerful method of improvement in big data prognosis by deploying Gradient Boosting Machine (GBM) learning algorithms, which are capable of outperforming and achieving the scalability required. The outlined system is a multi-stage data processing pipeline that integrates a distributed data ingestion framework initially to ensure efficient handling of both real-time and batch data streams. Data preprocessing techniques such as outlier filtering, normalization, and dimensionality reduction are utilized in order to increase the quality of data, and thus, the system can work with less computational load. Feature engineering is also enhanced through mutual information scores and recursive feature elimination to get rid of unnecessary variables from the dataset. The system's nucleus utilizes a Gradient Boosting Machine that consecutively constructs a set of weak learners— mostly decision trees—by successively reducing the error via iterations. Due to the size and complexity of the data, the system is set up in a distributed computing environment for parallel training and faster convergence of the model. The process of hyper-parameter tuning is done through Bayesian optimization, which intends to effectively manage the bias-variance trade-offs. Experimental results reveal that the suggested GBM-based architecture decisively trumps classical machine learning algorithms such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machines, and Logistic Regression in several basic metrics. The main points of this paper are in its employment of efficient preprocessing techniques, intelligent feature selection, distributed learning architecture, and sophisticated GBM optimization, which all combine to provide a scalable, high-accuracy prediction solution for big data scenarios.

title: Satellite Imagery based Deep Learning for Environmental Monitoring in India’s Ecologically Sensitive Regions
authors: Aashika A, Aashika Sukhinesh Gopalan, P. Kavitha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Deforestation is a pressing global issue with serious and far-reaching consequences. It significantly contributes to climate change, accelerates soil erosion, and threatens biodiversity. Coastal erosion is a silent yet severe threat that leads to the loss of valuable land and infrastructure, economic setbacks, and heightened vulnerability to natural disasters. This research and software tool addresses these challenges by utilizing Deep Learning and Remote Sensing techniques for detection of the above two environmental threats. By harnessing Google Earth Engine (GEE) to access Sentinel-2 satellite data, we focused on ecologically sensitive regions of India, obtaining approximately 2,000 preprocessed datasets to train a robust U- Net model. Our U-Net model achieved an impressive 94.56% and 96.83% validation accuracy for deforestation and coastal erosion respectively. This software tool applies deep learning- driven semantic segmentation for bitemporal change detection, precisely identifying deforestation through post-classification comparison and quantifying coastal erosion via coastline displacement analysis using geospatial distance metrics. Once a change is detected, the system immediately sends live alerts via email. A function constructs a MIMEMultipart message, attaches the alert details along with a map snippet, and then securely dispatches it through an SMTP server after TLS encryption and authentication, ensuring prompt notification to relevant officers.

title: Dew-Enabled Edge Intelligence: A Hybrid Framework for Offline Crowd Computing
authors: Krishna Dheeravath, Samudrala Venugopal, Ch Vijaya Kumar, N Raja Kumar, Premkumar Chithaluru, Pallati Narsimhulu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Crowd computing systems often depend on cloud-based infrastructure, which creates challenges in areas with limited internet access. Many remote environments or unstable networks cannot support real-time data sharing, leaving such systems unreliable in critical situations. This paper introduces a dew-enhanced edge computing model that supports offline crowd coordination and local data processing. The proposed architecture uses a two-layer setup combining ESP32 microcontrollers and Raspberry Pi 4 boards. The ESP32 units are responsible for collecting basic inputs or sensor data from the environment. These devices are lightweight and consume very little power, making them suitable for large deployments. On the other hand, Raspberry Pi 4 units act as coordinators that handle processing and decision-making closer to where the data is generated. A cloud backend, developed using NodeJS on Glitch and MongoDB, supports data synchronization whenever internet access becomes available. This means the system can continue to function even when disconnected from the cloud, syncing stored data once connectivity is restored. The architecture supports local interactions between users and devices, allowing data to be processed and shared among nearby units without waiting for cloud approval. This is important for real-time operations in environments like disaster zones, rural monitoring, or community-based learning setups. Experiments measured system performance based on latency, task completion rate, and system responsiveness under both connected and offline conditions. The setup achieved strong results in local coordination speed and reduced communication delays. By focusing on local interaction and device collaboration, this method provides a reliable and scalable path for crowd computing in unstable network conditions. The architecture improves system dependability and opens new possibilities for low-cost, distributed intelligence.

title: Proactive Financial Stream Mining with Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Concept Drift Adaptation
authors: S. Ganeshmoorthy, Jeynaendhra. K, Hemnaath. L, Naveen Kumar. N, Dhinesh. K, Balaji. V
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Stock market forecasting is inherently challenging due to the non-stationary nature of financial data, where price and volume patterns continuously evolve under the influence of economic policies, global events, and investor sentiment. Such variations, known as concept drift, diminish the reliability of traditional predictive models that assume static data distributions. Existing approaches, including sliding windows and ensemble retraining, either adapt too slowly to abrupt drifts or incur high computational costs, limiting their real-time applicability. To address these limitations, this paper introduces "Reinforcement Learning–Driven Adaptive Mining (RL-DAM)", a novel framework that integrates "Dynamic Drift Detection (DDD)" with "Policy-based Reinforcement Learning (PRL)" for real-time financial prediction. The DDD module monitors distributional shifts and model error to identify drift occurrences, while the PRL agent dynamically determines the optimal adaptation strategy such as model update, window adjustment, or retention based on reinforcement signals. Experiments on real-world financial datasets, including NSE/BSE indices and S&P 500 stock streams, demonstrate that RL-DAM consistently improves forecast accuracy, drift adaptation latency, and computational efficiency. These results confirm RL-DAM’s robustness and scalability for volatile market environments requiring adaptive, data-driven decision-making.

title: Next-Gen Service Robotics: The Rise of SYNTELIX
authors: Vijay M, P.Kavya, S.Pavani, P.Surendranath, K.Aneefa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Amidst the fast-emerging age of artificial intelligence and automation, the demand for role-adaptive, intelligent, and interactive robots is increasingly vital in various industries like education, healthcare, and hospitality. Narrow-functionality-based service robots mostly have limited interaction features and are not context-aware, hence less effective in complex real-life, multi-user environments. SYNTELIX is a futuristic multimodal humanoid robot that combines Artificial Intelligence (AI), Machine Learning (ML), Natural Language Processing (NLP), Speech and Vision recognition, and multilingual communication into one cost-effective robotic platform. SynTelix is designed to perform as a universal personal assistant that learns various functions—like an education tutor for students, a restaurant service agent, a care guide in hospitals, and a smart environment digital assistant. The robot can both recognize and answer user questions via voice and text, sense human presence and activity via camera vision, and undertake context-based actions given the surroundings it's embedded in the system features a touchscreen interface, allowing easy human interfacing and selection-based services, such as ordering food, accessing study resources, or calling for medical assistance. SYNTELIX facilitates multilingual communication, becoming available to users of varying linguistic backgrounds.

title: Hardware Design and Experimental Validation of a 30 kW, 800 V Three-Phase Three-Level ANPC Converter with 99% Efficiency
authors: Michael Glashauser, Jonas Wühr, Otto Kreutzer
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This article presents the hardware design and experimental validation of a highly efficient 30 kW three-phase three-level Active Neutral Point Clamped converter for power factor correction in electric vehicle charging applications. With high switching frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{kHz}, 800 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex> DC-link voltage and passive cooling, the converter reaches an efficiency of 99.2 %. The three-level topology increases power density while it reduces voltage stress and harmonic distortion. This work includes the design of power stage, input filter and PCB layout, optimized for automated production. Experimental tests validate the functionality of the hardware design up to its nominal voltage and power of 800 V and 30 kW. The efficiency was measured electrically and verified calorimetrically. This work aims to support the practical development of performance optimized three-level topologies in cost effective EV charging applications.

title: MRI Image-based Artificial Intelligence Deep Learning Method for Brain Tumour Identification
authors: Narenthirakumar Appavu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Adults with brain tumors, which are defined by the aberrant and fast proliferation of brain cells, run a serious risk of experiencing neurological deficits and, in the worst situations, passing away. Accurate diagnosis is still a substantial clinical problem since these tumors differ greatly in size, texture, or anatomical location. Manual analysis of MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) data is laborious and prone to human mistake, despite the fact that MRI is still a vital diagnostic tool. This study suggests a unique brain tumor detection strategy based on an amended You Only Look Once version 7 (YOLOv7) architectural to increase diagnosis accuracy in line with SDGs 3 (Good Health and Well-Being) and 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure). The approach is intended to efficiently categorize meningioma, glioma, and pituitary tumors. To improve the visibility of important characteristics in MRI images, our system uses sophisticated image enhancement techniques in conjunction with adaptive filtering. To improve model robustness and generalization, a publically accessible brain tumor dataset of 1200 non-tumor pictures, 1050 glioma cases, 1025 adrenal tumors, and 1047 meningioma cases is subjected to significant data augmentation. The model achieves more accurate learning across several tumor classifications by employing decoupled detection heads. According to experimental data, the suggested system performs better in terms of detection accuracy than cutting-edge methods. By encouraging research-driven learning in health imaging and SDG 17 (Collaboration for the Goals) by means of the use of open datasets and cooperative innovation in healthcare AI, this project advances SDG 4 (Quality Education). As a result, the suggested framework offers a clever and long-lasting way to accurately diagnose brain tumors, promoting the development of global healthcare.

title: Assessment of Artificial Intelligence in Hybrid Cloud Security Service and Future Industry
authors: G. Narsimlu, A. Padma, B R Sreedhar, Swatmaram, G. Deepa, P. Suresh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The cloud security an extensive analysis of deep learning techniques cloud computing has so many benefits, including cost effectiveness and remote access that can be used from any location in the world with a reliable internet connection, its use has grown daily over the past few decades as a result of the constantly rising needs. Cloud-based solutions were being used by the enterprises, which simplified infrastructure and IT management. Cloud computing explosive rise has raised serious security issues as well. The internet and open systems have always had security concerns, and cloud computing is no different. Similar to open systems and the internet, where security has been a major problem, cloud computing.. In order to solve these issues, deep learning approaches have demonstrated a great deal of potential in improving cloud security solutions. Numerous deep learning and machine learning techniques are analyzed in this review study, along with security concerns and their effects on cloud computing. Furthermore, security threats and categorized various algorithms in relation to cloud security. Finally, outlined potential avenues for future study to improve the security cloud-based computing. Traditional risk assessment methods focused on manual inspection and static rules are no longer useful with the rise of cloud computing. In order to facilitate adaptive risk assessment, real-time threat detection, anomaly identification, and proactive risk mitigation, this study investigates cloud security architecture. AI-driven security methods that predict vulnerabilities and dynamically modify defenses by continuously analyzing system logs, network traffic, and threat intelligence.

title: Comparative Analysis of Modular Hybrid Adders in Radix-4 Booth Multiplier Architectures
authors: Telluri Vani Sai Bhavani, Sonali Agrawal, C. Paramasivam
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper introduces an enhanced modular hybrid adder architecture aimed at improving delay performance in arithmetic units for digital signal processing (DSP) applications. By replacing the conventional Ripple Carry Adder (RCA) block with a Carry Increment Adder (CIA), the proposed design achieves faster computation while maintaining low area and power overhead. The improved adder is integrated into a Radix-4 Booth multiplier, resulting in significant reductions in critical path delay and power-delay product (PDP). All the architectures were designed using Verilog HDL, simulated using Xilinx Vivado and synthesized using Cadence Genus tool with 45nm technology. Synthesis results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach in achieving high-speed and energy-efficient operation suitable for real-time embedded systems, like Digital Signal Processing, Image and Video processing, and approximate computing.

title: Edge Computing based Cubic Gradient Deep Multilayer Perceptron for Global Warming Prediction on Crop Yield
authors: Varghese S Chooralil, Vinodh P Vijayan, Biju Paul, Rohaya Latip
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Edge computing can notably improve the crop yield prediction accuracy and promptness in the face of global warming by processing data locally and swift feedbacks to changing environmental conditions. By incorporating edge computing with deep learning (DL), farmers can adjust to climate change influences and optimize resource use accordingly resulting in productive agricultural systems and mitigating potential losses. Nevertheless, the existing DL-based approaches for intensifying agricultural productivity, explicitly in crop yield prediction in the wake of global warming, have not persistently provided satisfactory results. In response to this challenge, a novel Cubic Cosine Stochastic Gradient Deep Multilayer Perceptron (CC-SGDMP) method that strengthens agricultural productivity by predicting crop yield accurately is proposed. The CC-SGDMP method performs feature engineering and classification via edge computing layer and cloud computing layer respectively. Initially, using agriculture device layer the information is obtained. Following which via the edge computing layer, Cubic Interpolated Stochastic Statistical Cosine-based Feature Engineering task is performed. Here, pre-processing is done using Cubic Interpolation function to ensure class balance and relevant feature extraction is obtained utilizing Neighbor Embedding Statistical Cosine function.

title: A Bidirectional Sign Language Interaction System using Multimodal Deep Learning
authors: M K Nagarajan, Sadda Krishna Teja, NoorBasha Moushid, Chavala Sarath Kumar, Nakka Venkata Bhanu Prakash
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing (DHH) individuals often encounter communication challenges when interacting with people who don’t know sign language. Traditional solutions like interpreters or one-way recognition tools do not offer scalable and real-time access. This work introduces BiSignAI, a two-way sign language interaction system built with computer vision, natural language processing, and speech technologies. The system uses FlaskSocketIO for real-time communication, OpenCV for capturing gestures, and several pre- trained deep learning models (Keras/TensorFlow) for sign recognition. For processing text and speech, sentence-transformers (all- MiniLML6-v2) and LLM-based modules manage embeddings and contextual interpretation, while pgvector combined with PostgreSQL allows for effective semantic search and storage. In the other direction, BiSignAI translates text into animated A-Z fingerspelling sequences using pre-stored alphabet frames. The prototype shows high responsiveness, a scalable setup, and practical usability, enhancing accessibility in education, healthcare, and workplace communication.

title: A Reading Automaticity Assessment Algorithm and a Personalized Homework Framework for ESL Education
authors: Jing Xiong
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Reading automaticity stands as a significant barrier for learners acquiring English as a second language (ESL). Unlike grammar and pronunciation, which can be enhanced with existing tools, reading automaticity improvement remains challenging due to the lack of computer-assisted tools, a gap rooted in the inherent difficulty of measuring this skill. This paper proposes a reading automaticity assessment algorithm based on the forced alignment approach. This algorithm converts students’ speech audio into sentences/ phrases’ time series. Subsequently, the principal component analysis is applied to identify students’ common reading automaticity weaknesses from the extracted speech time series. Additionally, a personalized homework framework is proposed to improve students’ reading automaticity efficiently without imposing much additionalworkload on teachers and students. The proposed reading automaticity assessment algorithm is validated through case studies by comparing the algorithm-rated reading automaticity scores with teachers’ grading. Furthermore, the personalized homework framework is tested via an 8-week triple-blind experiment at a Chinese university, and the results demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach.

title: Energy Management Strategy with Partial Photovoltaic Curve Scanning for Reduced Energy Storage Utilization in DC Microgridsgobble
authors: Hein Wai Yan, Gaowen Liang, Ezequiel Rodriguez Ramos, Enrique Nunes, Glen G. Farivar, Josep Pou
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Partial shading conditions are common in photovoltaic (PV) systems, yet conventional energy management strategies for dc microgrids often assume uniform irradiance, leading them to rely heavily on batteries when PV systems operate under partial shading. To address this limitation, this article proposes an energy management strategy with an event-triggered partial-PV-curve scanning mechanism, offering a practical and model-free solution to mitigate the partial shading effects in microgrids. The scanning mechanism, triggered by dc-link voltage deviations, is embedded in a flexible power point tracking scheme. It bypasses local maxima and terminates once the PV power matches the demand, thereby limiting the scanning range. When the load demand exceeds the available PV maximum power, the proposed scheme senselessly completes a full-curve scan and settles at the global maximum power point, which is the best possible operating point for the given demand. By enabling the PV system to act as the primary dc-link voltage regulator even under partial shading and reducing the scanning duration, the proposed strategy aims to improve the battery usage. The effectiveness of the proposed strategy is validated by both simulation and experimental results, demonstrating a reduction in battery operating time by over 34 % compared to the conventional scanning-based strategy.

title: Generating Rainy Scenarios with LiDAR for Autonomous Driving
authors: Ye Liu, Yafei Wang, Zhisong Zhou, Kunpeng Dai, Xiaoke Yang
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Rainy datasets play a critical role to train the neural networks for autonomous driving, and yet they are scarce when compared with datasets captured in the clean weather. Simulation works consisting of generating the rainy scenarios completely on engine and inserting raindrops into the real sunny scenarios have been proposed. However, those works cannot construct realistic scenarios in any rainy day owing to their limitations of relying on the empirical ingredients and not comprehensively modelling the random process. We therefore reconsider the whole procedure of the scenario generation by re-reducing the rainfall rate equation from the perspective of raindrops while taking the effect of wind into consideration, and utilizing a joint probability to model the raindrop generation in terms of eventual points in the cloud. The experimental results represented by Kullback-Leibler divergence and Bhattacharyya distance between generated and real scenarios from the viewpoints of raindrop ranges, point angles, and point intensities respectively show that those rainy scenarios are close enough, and thus generated scenarios can replace real captured counterparts.

title: SSDC-Grasp: A Joint Semantic Segmentation and Depth Completion Approach for Robotic Grasping of Transparent Objects
authors: Ling Tong, Kechen Song, Hongkun Tian, Yunhui Yan, Fei Shen, Xian Tao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The optical characteristics of transparent objects, specifically reflection and refraction, induce texture distortion and geometric information loss in RGB-D imagery, presenting critical challenges for existing RGB-D-based grasping approaches. To address this, we propose SSDC-Grasp, a synergistic perception framework integrating semantic segmentation with depth completion, whose core innovation lies in dualmodality feature fusion for transparent object reconstruction. Firstly, semantic features including color and texture in central regions are reconstructed via a semantic segmentation network (SSNet). Secondly, we develop DCNet, a novel lightweight depth completion network employing an encoder-decoder decoupling architecture to repair 3D geometric information from local to global scales. SSDC-Grasp synergizes SSNet and DCNet to generate complete transparent object point clouds with enriched semantics. This comprehensive feature reconstruction strategy collectively enhances representation capabilities in transparent regions, thereby enabling more reliable grasp pose detection. Real-world robotic experiments demonstrate an average grasping success rate of 81.81%. The project is available at: https://github.com/meiguiz/SSDC-Grasp.

title: Resilient Control of Fixed-Wing UAVs under DoS Attacks and Actuator Faults via Intelligent Prediction Compensation
authors: Minrui Fu, Ziquan Yu, Youmin Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper proposes a resilient control framework for fixed-wing unmanned aerial vehicles (FUAVs) subject to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks and actuator faults. An extended Kalman filter with a temporal convolutional network (EKF–TCN) predictor is developed to forecast missing trajectory commands during DoS intervals. A tube-based model predictive control (Tube-MPC) scheme is then employed to generate guidance commands under explicit input constraints, while a quaternion-based velocity controller ensures full-attitude flight without Euler singularities. To enhance fault tolerance, a fixed-time observer and online quadratic programming-based allocation are integrated to handle actuator efficiency loss and bias. Hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves accurate trajectory tracking with bounded errors under DoS attacks and actuator faults, while keeping control inputs within limits, thus enabling safe and resilient flight.

title: DeepGSR: Deep group-based sparse representation network for solving image inverse problems
authors: Ke Jiang, Xinya Ji, Baoshun Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: In the past few years, group-based sparse representation (GSR) has emerged as a powerful paradigm for image inverse problems by synergizing model-driven interpretability with nonlocal self-similarity priors. Nevertheless, its practical utility is hindered by computationally expensive iterative processes. Deep learning (DL) methods can avoid this deficiency, but they often lack of model interpretability. To bridge this gap, we propose a novel deep group-based sparse representation framework, termed DeepGSR, which brings the GSR method and the DL approach together. DeepGSR not only circumvents the iterative bottlenecks of conventional GSR but also preserves its model interpretability through a learnable parameterization. Specifically, the network is built upon a GSR model that leverages nonlocal self-similarity, and it integrates adaptive patch matching and aggregation mechanisms to model complex intra-group relationships in the latent space. To reduce the computational complexity associated with traditional SVD-based rank shrinkage, we introduce a learnable low-rank shrinkage module that incorporates low-rank constraints while enhancing the interpretability and adaptability of the model. To better exploit frequency-specific structures, the network incorporates a shifting wavelet-domain patch partitioning strategy, which separately models high- and low-frequency components to further enhance the representation ability of the network. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DeepGSR, when applied as a drop-in replacement module to various image inverse problems such as image denoising, single-image deraining, metal artifact reduction, sparse-view computed tomography reconstruction, phase retrieval, and all-in-one image restoration consistently delivers effective performance, validating the effectiveness of the proposed framework. The source code and datasets have been made publicly available at https://github.com/shibaoshun/DeepGSR.

title: Anomaly Detection for Generic Failure Monitoring in Robotic Assembly, Screwing and Manipulation
authors: Niklas Grambow, Lisa-Marie Fenner, Felipe Kempkes, Philip Hotz, Dingyuan Wan, Jörg Krüger, Kevin Haninger
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Out-of-distribution states in robot manipulation often lead to unpredictable robot behavior or task failure, limiting success rates and increasing risk of damage. Anomaly detection (AD) can identify deviations from expected patterns in data, which can be used to trigger failsafe behaviors and recovery strategies. Prior work has applied data-driven AD on time series data for specific robotic tasks, however the transferability of an AD approach between different robot control strategies and task types has not been shown. Leveraging time series data, such as force/torque signals, allows to directly capture robot-environment interactions, crucial for manipulation and online failure detection. As robotic tasks can have widely signal characteristics and requirements, AD methods which can be applied in the same way to a wide range of tasks is needed, ideally with good data efficiency. We examine three industrial robotic tasks, robotic cabling, screwing, and sanding, each with multi-modal time series data and several anomalies. Several autoencoderbased methods are compared, and we evaluate the generalization across different robotic tasks and control methods (diffusion policy-, position-, and impedance-controlled). This allows us to validate the integration of AD in complex tasks involving tighter tolerances and variation from both the robot and its environment. Additionally, we evaluate data efficiency, detection latency, and task characteristics which support robust detection. The results indicate reliable detection with AUROC exceeding 0.96 in failures in the cabling and screwing task, such as incorrect or misaligned parts and obstructed targets. In the polishing task, only severe failures were reliably detected, while more subtle failure types remained undetected.

title: Time-division multiplexing switching transients and bandwidth effects on the X-ray Integral Field Unit readout performance
authors: E. Cucchetti, H. Geoffray, S. Beaumont, W. B. Doriese, M. Durkin, C. Kirsch, R. Denis-Jung, O. Maisonnave, A. Panglosse, P. Peille, K. Sakai, S. J. Smith, N. A. Wakeham
publish: IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity
abstract: The X-IFU (X-ray Integral Field Unit), on the future European X-ray observatory NewAthena, will perform high-resolution imaging spectroscopy over an array of 1,504 transition-edge sensors operated at 55 mK. Its readout is performed via time-division multiplexing (TDM) at a few MHz, which relies on fast (but not instantaneous) switching between pixels of the same column. Differences in the currents of consecutive rows lead to signal-dependent transients in the readout. These transients, and how they settle before sampling of the final row signal, are in turn governed by the open-loop bandwidths in the system. Limitations of the bandwidths smear the transients and contaminate the settling of photon pulses, resulting in a frequency- and amplitude-dependent error on the output signal. Switching transients have thus ultimately a direct impact on the instrument's energy scale. Although the origin of these perturbations is well-understood, quantifying their end-to-end impact on performance remains challenging. We compare here experimental data with simulations to assess the accuracy of numerical predictions. We also present an end-to-end analysis of nonlinearity in the X-IFU energy scale due to switching transients, and compare it against current performance budget allocations. These simulations show that the X-IFU can meet its energy scale requirements.

title: Smart Multi-Scenario Task Deployment for AUV Cluster Network: a Large Language Model-Driven Exploration-Enhanced MARL Approach
authors: Shengchao Zhu, Guangjie Han, Chuan Lin, Chuanliang Chen, Zhenyu Wang, Fan Yang, Tongwei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Recent advances in network technologies and Multi Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL) have accelerated the development of Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) cluster networks, enabling intelligent applications such as target tracking and cooperative target encirclement. However, existing MARL models are typically designed for single-task scenarios, limiting their scalability in real-world multi-task environments. To ad dress this, we propose a lightweight MARL framework capable of handling multiple AUV tasks with reduced reliance on underwater sampling. Specifically, a unified state space representation is constructed to support task generalization, while a hybrid online offline MARL training paradigm is introduced by leveraging the logical reasoning and sample generation capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs). This reduces the demand for real-time data collection. Furthermore, a supervised pretraining strategy is incorporated to improve convergence and learning stability. Based on these components, we develop the Large Language Model-driven Hybrid online-offline MARL algorithm towards Multi-Task scenarios (LLM-HMT), which supports intelligent deployment of multi-task AUV cluster systems with minimal state representation, reduced sample requirements, and limited training iterations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that LLM HMT outperforms mainstream MARL baselines in convergence speed, task success rate, and resource efficiency, highlighting its potential for practical underwater applications.

title: Automated Quantification of Trophectoderm Morphology in Human Blastocysts via Instance Segmentation
authors: Hang Liu, Chen Sun, Shanshan Wang, Lei Chen, Guanqiao Shan, Wenyuan Chen, Haocong Song, Zhuoran Zhang, Changsheng Dai, Xingjian Liu, Haixiang Sun, Yu Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Segmenting individual trophectoderm (TE) cells is essential for developing quantitative metrics to assess the developmental potential of human blastocysts. The elongated shape and circular arrangement of TE cells lead to continuously varying orientations across the image, posing challenges for existing cell instance segmentation methods that assume uniformly oriented cells. As a result, most methods segment the TE as a single region, and the development of quantitative, cell-level metrics predictive of live birth potential remains unexplored. In this work, we propose an instance segmentation model that represents elongate, circularly arranged TE cells using elliptical distance maps, with which superior performance in both segmentation accuracy and metric extraction was achieved, compared with state-of-the-art methods. The extracted metrics, including TE cell number, the mean and standard deviation of cell length, width, area, and mean inter-cell distance, serve as effective predictors of a blastocyst’s live birth potential. When used to predict live birth, these metrics achieved a significantly higher area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC = 0.693) than traditional TE morphological grades (AUC = 0.585). The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/robotVisionHang/TESeg.

title: Hydrophobicity Classification of Composite Insulators Using Multi-scale Water Droplet Detection and Feature Fusion
authors: Haitao Wang, Yu Wang, Qiang Wu, Jian Sun, Yeqiang Deng, Zhongxiang Fu, Lei Lan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Hydrophobicity degradation is a critical factor leading to pollution flashovers in composite insulator systems. The International Electrotechnical Commission (IEC) 62073 visual inspection method suffers from ±1 level measurement uncertainty, while existing deep learning methods lack physical interpretability for maintenance decision-making. This paper presents a hierarchical framework employing a physically grounded intermediate representation. A five-level droplet taxonomy (C1-C5) based on contact angle physics decouples droplet morphology from surface assessment. An enhanced Faster Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Faster R-CNN) with Squeeze-and-Excitation Residual Network-50 (SE-ResNet-50) backbone achieves 75.8% mean Average Precision on 16,535 labeled droplets. The fusion of 21 detection-derived and five image-processing features yields a 4.08% improvement over the naive combination. Evaluated on 1,160 independent images spanning four climate zones and 2-13 years of service life, the method achieves 77.09% Full Hit Accuracy (FHA, exact HC level match) and 99.13% Tolerant Accuracy (TA, predictions within ±1 level), compliant with IEC 62073 uncertainty tolerance. The hierarchical design enables verification of classification reasoning through inspectable C1-C5 intermediate outputs.

title: Prescribed Performance Control of Deformable Object Manipulation in Spatial Latent Space
authors: Ning Han, Gu Gong, Bin Zhang, Yuexuan Xu, Bohan Yang, Yunhui Liu, David Navarro-Alarcon
publish: IEEE/ASME Transactions on Mechatronics
abstract: Manipulating 3-D deformable objects presents significant challenges for robotic systems due to their infinite-dimensional state space and complex deformable dynamics. This article proposes a novel model-free approach for shape control with constraints imposed on key points. Unlike existing methods that rely on feature dimensionality reduction, the proposed controller leverages the coordinates of key points as the feature vector, which are extracted from the deformable object's point cloud using deep learning methods. This approach not only reduces the dimensionality of the feature space but also retains the spatial information of the object. By extracting key points, the manipulation of deformable objects is simplified into a visual servoing problem, where the shape dynamics are described using a deformation Jacobian matrix. To enhance control accuracy, a prescribed performance control method is developed by integrating barrier Lyapunov functions to enforce constraints on the key points. The stability of the closed-loop system is rigorously analyzed and verified using the Lyapunov method. Experimental results further demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Cyber-Physical Systems using Security and Encryption Schemes for Student Credential Management
authors: S. Jaya Prakash, Priyadharshini S, Jayasundar S, R. Nandhini, S. Kamalaveni, G. Ulaganathan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The rising penetration of institutional networks to steal or alter personal data has created a security flaw that has to be fixed. A blockchain based credential verification system named Secure Edu give a different mechanism of safeguarding credentials from unauthorized access. However, blockchain-based credential verification systems have scalability issues and are susceptible to authenticating attacks. In order to improve blockchain-based attestation systems, the current study suggested a novel design that integrated Hierarchical Merkle Trees (HMTs) with Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). HMT method is reduced the computing overhead besides securing the data. On the opposite hand, MFA employed many levels of security to preserve the integrity of private academic records against hacking. With a smallest CPU, memory, and latency at 120 ms and 28 percent accordingly, the suggested system demonstrated performance and scalability, laying the groundwork for a robust and efficient credentials validation system. These findings demonstrate how major operational inefficiencies and security flaws are removed when MFA and HMTs are used to improve blockchain-based credential verification systems. All things considered, the suggested architecture creates a safe, scalable, and high-performing platform for confirming current academic qualifications.

title: VLSI Design based Smart Traffic Signal Control
authors: Naveenkumar R, Karuppasamy Karthikshun A, Oliver Rexton A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This study introduces the design and implementation of a VLSI-based Smart Traffic Signal Controller with Pedestrian Crossing for transportation systems. To improve hardware efficiency, Verilog synthesized on FPGA is used in the development of this study. In traditional controllers which is static, but this system adapts signal timing dynamically based on real-time vehicle density and pedestrian demand, ensuring smooth traffic flow while maintaining road safety. Operating modes such as normal mode and pedestrian-priority mode are embedded to handle different traffic scenarios. Sensor-based detection enables accurate green cycle allocation and safe pedestrian intervals, reducing traffic, and fuel consumption. Experimental evaluation indicates accuracy between 81% and 91% in improving traffic control and pedestrian crossing management. Experimental simulation using ModelSim validate the system’s low power consumption. This study ensures low power consumption, and minimal delay, making it a cost-effective and adaptable framework for urban traffic management. With its adaptability, the controller offers significant advantages in terms of safety, efficiency, and reliability over traditional systems.

title: Design of Electronic Circuits for Electrical Ground Support Equipment of Spacecraft Propulsion System
authors: Muthuselvi K, Saurabh Agrawal, V Abarna, Krishna Mohan Shanbhogue K, Shambayya K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The Assembly, Integration and Testing (AIT) phase is critical in spacecraft development, particularly for the Spacecraft Propulsion System (SPS). Electrical Ground Support Equipment (EGSE) plays a pivotal role during this phase by facilitating comprehensive verification and validation of the SPS. EGSE encompasses specialized electronic circuits and systems designed to interface with spacecraft components during ground testing.
