title: Enhancing GDLSTM-based Building Energy Demand Prediction with Multi-Objective Optimization in IoT-based Big Data Centers
authors: Revathi.S, S. Silvia Priscila, Praveen B M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The fast development of intelligent buildings and IoT-based infrastructures needs extremely precise energy demand forecasting to increase the efficiency and sustainability of their operations. Traditional models typically have a hard time in modeling the non-linear relationships that exist in the construction of energy usage as dictated by the dynamic environmental and occupancy conditions. This study presents a Gated Deep Long-Term Memory (GDLSTM) model that has been improved by applying multi-objective optimization with both NSGA-II and MOPSO to make real time predictions of building energy demand through IoT sensor data. The suggested method incorporates the continuous data collection, excellent feature selection and dynamic hyperparameter optimization to guarantee robustness and generalization. In benchmark datasets, experimental evaluation demonstrates that GDLSTM has an RMSE of 0.151 kWh, MAE of 0.184 kWh and MAPE of 12.3% and R2 of 0.694, which is 8.6 times better than LSTM, BiLSTM, and CNN-LSTM models. These findings assert the role of the optimized GDLSTM as a good predictor of time-dependent variations and increase the reliability of prediction. The framework has a high likelihood of being incorporated into smart grids that employ IoT and adaptive energy management systems to offer a scalable solution to sustainable data-driven building operations.

title: Cognitive and Fuzzy-based Optimization Models for High-Performance Computing in Distributed IoT and Sensing Applications
authors: Ashu Nayak, Anjali Krushna Kadao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The growing use of distributed Internet of Things (IoT) devices and sensing systems requires High-Performance Computing (HPC) that efficiently manages uncertainty, diverse resources, and temporal constraints. This work presents the first primarily hybrid cognitive and fuzzy-backed optimizations, aimed at improving the adaptive decision-making process, uncertainty management, and resource-sensitive intelligence within the distributed IoT, neglecting adaptive decision systems. The cognitive model self-learning and self-adaptive features optimize the fusion of computation and communication resources, while the fuzzy approach efficiently manages soft (imprecise) and variable (dynamic) environments. Simulation results validate all the proposed components of the optimization model, demonstrating the impact of hybrid neural and fuzzy systems on improving task scheduling and energy efficiency, load balancing, throughput and latency reduction, fault tolerance, and fault tolerance compared to traditional optimization methods. The cognitive and fuzzy hybrid model is scalable to complex systems while meeting the performance requirements. Focusing on the hybrid intelligent optimizations reinforces the work within distributed IoT sensing systems while meeting the HPC requirements of future-driven IoT systems to enhance precision, energy efficiency, and resiliency.

title: Augmented Reality-Enhanced Digital Twin and Image Processing Framework for Automated Quality Inspection in Industry 4.0
authors: Rokesh Maran B, Abiya MJ, Prasath Narayanan, A Sanath Kumara Sarma, Mugendiran V
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The rise of Industry 4.0 has increased the demand for automated, reliable, and real-time quality inspection systems in manufacturing. This paper presents an Augmented Reality (AR)-driven inspection framework that integrates computer vision, virtual simulation, and immersive visualization to overcome the limitations of conventional manual inspection. The proposed system employs a camera-based hardware station to capture high-resolution images of industrial components, specifically the LMK12UU linear bearing. Dimensional and geometric features are extracted using Python-based OpenCV and imutils libraries, while Unity Engine provides a virtual 3D environment for real-time analysis and visualization. An AR-enabled Android application overlays defects and measures data directly onto the physical workpiece, offering intuitive and immersive feedback. Additionally, the system is integrated with IoT (Blynk) to enable remote monitoring and data-driven decision-making. Experimental validation demonstrates an inspection accuracy of 98.73%, with error rates not exceeding 2.63%, and a total process and control time of approximately 160 ms per workpiece. These results highlight the potential of the AR-based framework as a scalable, cost-effective solution for automated quality control in smart manufacturing and Industry 4.0 environments.

title: Performance Improvements in Electromechanical Actuator based Control Systems used for Launch Vehicle Applications
authors: Kiran V, Venkataraman K R, Vaishnavi S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Control Systems using electromechanical actuators in closed loop configuration based on Direct Current (DC) motor and position sensor are extensively used in launch vehicles for trajectory control. These control system elements are qualified and acceptance tested to required quality levels to ensure reliable performance during the mission profile. In view of this, rigorous functional testing was carried out at every stage of assembly and integration of actuator assembly with the respective subsystem. Such screened actuators have proved their reliability over several launches also. Despite successful heritage of usage and completion of component level evaluation, an anomaly observed during a final stage control system checks due to the non-responsiveness of actuator for the command issued. This deviation led to a detailed root cause analysis which tailored down to workmanship issues in motor assembly during realization and assembly into the actuator. As part of preventive measures, modified procedures in motor fabrication phase and additional measurements that provide information on motor brush contact integrity were introduced. These improvements turned out to increase reliability of motor performance and hence the actuator, which was also demonstrated in subsequent missions. This paper discusses the anomaly observed in the actuator during final system level testing and failure analysis in terms of electrical, chemical and mechanical aspects. The failure in the feedback of the actuator during step response was studied using analytical tool like Scanning Electron Microscopy, Raman Spectroscopy and NDT tools like CT and X-ray which revealed issues in the assembly processes during DC Motor realization. The presence of inadvertent contaminants and insufficient brush pressure led to inadequate contact with commutator. In view of this implementation of new measurement systems such as brush pressure calculations and modified assembly procedures are put in place to meet the actuator performance for mission.

title: Automated Multi-Category Classification of Customer Support Tickets using XGBoost
authors: M.Ishwarya Niranjana, R.Naresh, G.Ragul, S.Pranesh, R.Revanth, V.Parthipan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: In recent years, customer support automation has become popular because of accelerated growth in service requests and the need to resolve them at a faster rate. Support ticket classification manually is time-consuming, prone to errors, and slows down the response management process. In this paper, an automated multi-category customer support ticket classification system based on Natural Language Processing techniques and the XGBoost algorithm is proposed. Ticket text is preprocessed and converted to semantic embeddings via the SentenceTransformer model (all-MiniLM-L6-v2) and are subsequently input into an XGBoost multi-output classifier to jointly predict ticket category, priority, and sentiment. In contrast to other machine learning methods that depend on manually crafted features and are averse to noisy, unstructured text, our method capitalizes on transformer-based embeddings for better accuracy and generalizability. The system is incorporated into a MERN stack web application that includes role-based access, real-time chat, and dashboards to facilitate end-to-end support automation. As a result, there is increased operational efficiency, minimized ticket triaging time, and improved customer satisfaction.

title: Noise Adaptive Simulation of Steane Code Fidelity for Enhanced Quantum Communication Networks
authors: N. Nagasoudhamani, Krishna Nukala, Bharthavarapu Nirosha, Shilpa Adla, Sivva Yalamarthi, Dadinaboina A.K. Rao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Quantum communication protocols such as superdense coding enable high-capacity information transfer using quantum entanglement. However, their performance is significantly affected by environmental noise and decoherence. This study presents an enhanced simulation framework for evaluating the Steane 7-qubit error correction code applied to superdense coding under realistic noise conditions. Building upon earlier models, the proposed work introduces robust circuit depth control mechanism and noise-aware simulation using Qiskit Aer to analyze depolarizing, amplitude damping, and phase damping errors. The system automatically encodes, decodes, and measures fidelity across varying noise probabilities, classifying results into performance tiers based on resilience. Comprehensive visualization through trend plots, heatmaps, and tier distributions offers clear insights into the impact of noise on quantum communication fidelity. The findings demonstrate that Steane encoding stabilizes fidelity within moderate noise levels, thereby improving the robustness of dense coding. This enhanced model provides a reproducible and scalable approach for studying quantum error correction, contributing to the design of noise-tolerant quantum communication networks.

title: Life Cycle Assessment Comparison of Multi-Phase IPM, IM, and EESM for EV Applications
authors: Farshid Mahmouditabar, Volker Pickert, Saleh. A. Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: The transition to electric vehicles (EVs) has intensified the need for sustainable traction motor technologies. This paper presents a comprehensive Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) comparing three widely used traction motors for EV applications: an Interior Permanent Magnet (IPM) motor, an Induction Motor (IM), and an Electrically Excited Synchronous Motor (EESM). While the IPM motor includes rare-earth materials, the IM and EESM represent rare-earth-free alternatives. All three motors are designed to deliver equivalent performance, allowing for a fair comparison of their environmental impacts. The assessment focuses on three critical life cycle stages: raw material extraction, the use phase over a realistic driving cycle and vehicle lifetime, and End of Life (EoL) recycling. Results highlight the trade-offs between embedded emissions and operational efficiency, providing insights into the sustainability potential of each motor type. This study addresses a gap in existing literature by offering a complete, performancematched LCA of multi-phase traction motors, supporting informed decisions in the design of next-generation EV drivetrains.

title: Optimizing Microstrip Antennas for Green Communication and 6G Using Information-Theoretic Random Forest
authors: Muhammad Kamran Shereen, Xiaoguang Liu, Xiaohu Wu, Ayesha Naseem, Muhammad Uzair
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: This study introduces an Information-Theoretic Random Forest (ITRF) framework for optimizing microstrip patch antenna performance in green communication and 6G networks. Leveraging Shannon entropy and mutual information, the research enhances feature selection and predictive modeling for a Y-shaped microstrip antenna designed for the 3.25 GHz-4.25 GHz band. The developed Random Forest Regression (RFR) model, incorporating information-theoretic principles, achieved Mean Absolute Errors (MAE) of approximately 0.0054 for Gain and 0.0049 for S11, demonstrating robust generalization and improved computational efficiency. This work contributes to 6G by supporting technologies like massive MIMO, RIS, and URLLC, and explores quantum-inspired learning for enhanced optimization. By integrating information theory and machine learning, this research offers a scalable, interpretable, and efficient alternative to traditional simulations for green and adaptive wireless systems.

title: Next-Gen Healthcare Claims Optimization: DL-Based ResAttBiL Integrated with CDC, Modular Design, and Data Observability
authors: Murugan Ambalakannu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Legacy healthcare claims systems modernization to an intelligent Medical Claims Engine (MCE) responds to increasing complexity of healthcare data and operational needs. This modular architecture contains six primary domains: claim acquisition, data preprocessing, feature engineering, Residual Attention-Bidirectional Long Short Term Memory (ResAtt-BiL) modelling, storage in Amazon Web Services (AWS) S3 cloud, and analytics reporting. Each module is designed to improve workflows, increase data integrity, and improve predictive accuracy. The ResAtt-BiL model combines the deep feature extraction strengths of ResNet, the bidirectional sequence learning of BiLSTM and attention to focus on relevant data, and provides strong classification and fraud detection. Amazon Web Services (AWS) S3 cloud storage allows for scalable, encrypted, highly available cloud storage, while integrating seamlessly and ensuring data compliance. Analytics reporting converts data into consumable insights, by converting transaction data into real-time dashboards and forecasting models. Real-time telemetry and Change Data Capture (CDC) improving observability of the data and will help maintain its freshness. Continuous Integration/ Continuous Development (CI/CD) pipelines and the Agile Development methodology are used to drive iterative advancement and cross-development collaboration. This overall architecture serves as a new frontier in healthcare claims automation, and improves the speed, transparency, and affordability of health systems.

title: Intelligent Sign Language Interpretation using Hand Gesture Prediction
authors: Mrs.R.Krishnaveni, Ms.M.C.Kaviya, Ms.M.Kaviyasri, Mr.M.Dhayanithi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The accessibility challenges faced by the deaf and hard-of-hearing community's gap in communication with the rest of the public continues to be a concern. This paper proposes an effective vision-based Indian Sign Language (ISL) alphabet recognition system based on deep learning. The new system utilizes the CNN model underwent training with a preprocessed 35 ISL alphabet class dataset. Techniques for Data augmentation including image rotation, shifting, and horizontal flipping were utilized to improve generalizability. The framework demonstrated a validation performance of 100% and training accuracy of 98.75% in 20 epochs with remarkable learning capacity without overfitting. The system successfully interfaced with OpenCV and MediaPipe libraries for the detection of hands substantiating the suitability of the system for real-time purposes. The strong accuracy and effective architecture stipulate the potential of the system serving as the center of future assistive technologies with the prospect of having better translator systems to facilitate effective communication.

title: Enhanced Heart Disease Classification using Jensen-Shannon Divergence Feature Selection: A Comparative Machine Learning Approach
authors: A.Akilandeswari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Heart disease represents a significant global health burden, requiring accurate diagnostic solutions for effective patient management. This study presents a novel classification framework employing Jensen-Shannon divergence for feature selection combined with machine learning algorithms to address high-dimensional clinical data complexity. The JS divergence approach extracts discriminative features while overcoming traditional statistical method limitations in identifying nonlinear patterns. Three classifiers—Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Logistic Regression—were evaluated on a benchmark heart disease dataset containing 303 records with 13 clinical attributes. Experimental results show that JS divergence significantly enhances classification accuracy across all tested algorithms. Random Forest achieved optimal performance with 94.3% accuracy, outperforming SVM (91.8%) and Logistic Regression (88.5%). The methodology improves diagnostic efficiency and model interpretability through symmetric divergence measures providing unbiased feature evaluation and superior outlier robustness.

title: Rapid Rescue: Integrated Emergency Ambulance Service Platform
authors: Lincy A, Mutheswaran P, Iynesh Karthick M, Gautham R, Vasanth Rahul R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Ambulance services are crucial for saving lives during emergency situations. Unfortunately, in many parts of India, existing ambulance systems, like the government operated "108" service, are struggling to meet the demand. Problems like traffic congestion, limited availability, and other operational issues often lead to delayed response times, putting patients at risk. In order to tackle this, an Integrated Emergency Ambulance Service Platform has been developed in this work to bring together both public and private ambulance providers into a single, real-time system. Using GPS technology, the platform will instantly connect users to the nearest available ambulance, cutting down response times and improving outcomes for patients. In addition, the system deploys predictive analytics using K-nearest Neighbor, which helps to optimize ambulance dispatch based on both historical data and live conditions. By combining multiple service providers and leveraging real-time data, Rapid Rescue is streamlining the entire ambulance booking process with an accuracy of 92%. This system improves the efficiency of emergency services by identifying hotspots and it is scalable for implementation in diverse environments.

title: A Survey of Modular OCR Approaches for Tamil-Brahmi Inscriptions: Segmentation and Reconstruction Focus
authors: K Saranya, S R Nitthin Kumar, R Praveen Kumar, S Arun Nivesh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The digitization of Tamil–Brahmi inscriptions is essential for preserving South India’s early written heritage, yet presents significant technical challenges stemming from surface erosion, broken or missing strokes, variable carving depths, and irregular character spacing—factors that severely undermine conventional OCR engines designed for printed or modern handwritten text. This survey provides a comprehensive review of both classical and contemporary techniques adapted for epigraphic data, focusing specifically on segmentation and reconstruction modules within modular OCR pipelines. We examine traditional image processing approaches including projection profile analysis, connected component labeling, morphological filtering, and contour tracing, discussing their limitations on degraded inscriptions. We then analyze advances in deep learning, encompassing convolutional neural networks for pixel-wise segmentation and classification, recurrent and attention-based sequence models for context-aware recognition, and vision transformers for capturing long-range dependencies. The primary contribution of this survey is demonstrating how modular OCR architectures that decouple preprocessing, segmentation, classification, and reconstruction stages enable targeted improvements, flexible integration of new methods, and resilience to low-resource conditions. We identify critical open challenges including data scarcity, annotation costs, eroded glyph reconstruction, and scalability, and propose future research directions such as semi-supervised learning, synthetic data generation, cross-script transfer learning, and epigraphically informed language models to advance automated ancient script digitization.

title: Emerging Semi-Supervised Skin Lesion Segmentation using Unlabelled Samples with GAN and Transformer Representations
authors: M. Megala, T.R. Nisha Dayana
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Early cancer detection and diagnosis depend on accurate and automated skin lesion segmentation helping dermatologists in their work. On the other hand, deep learning models find great challenge in the absence of large, annotated datasets in the medical field. These problems consist in overfitting and limited generalisation. Manual labelling calls for knowledge, time, and money; hence, depending on very large, annotated datasets is generally not practical for medical applications. We introduce a new semi-supervised method using unlabelled samples including generative adversarial networks (GANs). This approach is proposed to transcend the already mentioned limitations. The method makes advantage of a two-stage training structure. First phase of the supervised learning process uses annotated data to learn semantic segmentation maps. After that, the unsupervised phase uses Structured Prediction-based Deep Reinforcement Learning (SP-DRL) to improve generalisation, which lowering the dependence on annotations. Strong data-driven features have been proposed to be derived from a surrogate task using convolutional and Transformer-based representations, which reducing the demand for annotations. The proposed method was evaluated using three benchmark datasets: PH2, ISIC 2017, and ISIC 2018. The segmentation performance shows to be better with increasing Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) scores of 89.2% (ISIC 2018), 87.4% (ISIC 2017), and 91.1% (PH2) respectively. Further, the model shows better generalisation and resistance against domain changes, which surpassing conventional approaches under total supervision. This semi-supervised method closes the difference between the availability of annotated medical datasets and those without labels, which enabling the useful adoption of automated lesion segmentation systems.

title: Optimizing Digital Filters for Noise Reduction in Medical Image Processing
authors: Mandeep Kaur
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper discusses the optimization of digital filters for improving noise reduction for medical image processing. Clear and accurate imaging is of prime importance in medical diagnostics, noise in which can drastically impair the quality of an image, potentially causing misdiagnosis or postponing treatment. Various traditional filtering methods such as Gaussian, median and Wiener filters are tested for their ability to maintain image details while reducing noise. Additionally, the study discusses hybrid filtering techniques that combine several filtering techniques for better performance. Machine learning based approaches are also studied, focusing on adaptive filters which can be dynamically adapted to the type and level of noise. The results reveal the optimized digital filters, in particular when paired with machine learning, can dramatically improve the denoising performance, ensuring more clear medical images without compromising the diagnostic power.

title: Sentiment Analysis for Transformer-based approach using Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Ch. Bhavani, M. Viju Prakash, Odilbek Matsapayev, Temur Eshchanov, P.Sasikumar, B.Venkataramanaiah
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Machine learning classifiers are now widely used across the world, transforming a variety of large and small scale industries. The number of algorithms—each allocated for specific tasks—can make it not simple for both beginners and experts to find the most appropriate model. Sentiment to be analyzed for human safety. This research tackles that challenge by experimenting with an in-depth analysis using Machine learning techniques and the efficient Transformers library. By conducting researchers' comments from existing studies, we proposed a novel method that maps classifiers performance based on descriptive adjectives. Machine learning algorithms producing effective highly accurate results in prediction. Accuracy is one of the performance metric to analyze performance of any machine learning classifiers Our proposed model shows sentence into positive, negative and neutral using Decision Tree(DT), Logistic regression, Naive bayes, Random forest (RF), Support Vector Machine(SVM) achieved 97% and K nearest neighbour(KNN).The proposed research is showing innovative in prediction of sentiment analysis compared to existing methods.

title: AI- Enhanced Biosensors for Real Time Detection of Infectious Disease Biomarkers
authors: Anuradha Kambalapelly, M.Anitha, P.Krishna Meena, Srinivas.D, V Sumalatha, P.Y.N.S.MANOJ
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Infectious disease diagnosis is one of the global health concerns since the traditional methods are not always fast and able to detect the disease early. Recent developments on biosensors that use AI make it possible to detect biomarkers of infectious diseases in real-time. The work is a presentation of the creation of AI-based biosensor systems with the ability to detect biomarkers which signify the disease onset. Data analysis used CNN with support with machine learning (SVM) to increase diagnostic accuracy. AI models were integrated with optical and electrochemical biosensors to provide sensitive analytical results in a short period. Sample processing Clinical sample Detection time, sensitivity, and specificity were measured. The AI-based biosensor system was found to have a 95% sensitivity and a 98% specificity which was higher than the normal diagnostic tests. The time of detection was not more than 15 minutes, which allowed effective real-time monitoring. The system was seen to be stable in relation to viral and bacterial pathogen biomarkers. By incorporating AI into the biosensing technologies, the speed and accuracy of detection are enhanced greatly, providing a solid foundation to early diagnosis of diseases and real-world clinical application due to continuous optimization and validation.

title: Low Power Reconfigurable PRBS Checker
authors: Pragna Vedi, Paramasivam C, Ganapathi Hegde
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The fully reconfigurable pipelined architecture for FPGA based parallel pseudorandom binary sequence (PRBS) test pattern creation is demonstrated and simulated in this work. PRBS parameters such as order, polynomial, seed, and output width are dynamically reconfigurable at runtime without resynthesis. The architecture enables great timing performance and scalability through the use of pipelined data paths with scalable XOR networks. Implemented and verified in Verilog HDL, the architecture includes a self synchronizing PRBS checker, a clock gating controller, and an error estimator for efficient performance evaluation. Reversible logic gates Toffoli and Feynman were introduced, resulting in approximately 41.58 power reductions and 40.54 area reductions. Timing performance was also enhanced with reduced delays. The architecture is suitable for low power, area efficient, and high speed VLSI communication system testing.

title: Accurate Characterization of Transceiver Devices Using 3-Port Balun De-Embedding Techniques
authors: Shirong Lv, Yong Wang, Liang Xie, Yuxuan Jiang, Huailin Liao, Wu Wen, Chong Duan
publish: IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Magazine
abstract: This paper presents a baseband data compensation method that utilizes a 3-port balun de-embedding technique to accurately measure the RF parameters of transceiver chips, including noise figure and nonlinear characteristics. This study explores the theoretical derivation of the 3-port balun de-embedding algorithm, the design of calibration components, and the baseband data compensation algorithm. The S-parameters of the balun are derived using an optimized TRL de-embedding algorithm, and then the baseband data compensation algorithm is applied to correct the amplitude. Experimental results conducted on a PCB demonstrate that this method significantly improves the accuracy of RF parameter measurements, providing technical support for enhancing the performance of programmable RF transceivers. The proposed method not only enhances the accuracy of RF chip testing but also provides new insights and technical approaches for future research in related fields.

title: Stacked Ensemble with Hybrid Feature Selection for Intrusion Detection
authors: Raavi Hari Krishna, T. Thanigasalam, V Ganesan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: In this study, a detailed guideline is provided for the development of an Intrusion Detection System (IDS) in response to the growing need for robust network security. It is based on the precise identification and categorization of abnormal network traffic to prevent a broad spectrum of cyber-attacks. Experimentation is based on a benchmark dataset of Kaggle, which consists of a wide range of types of network activity. Preprocessing of data entails filling in gaps, eliminating the noisy data, and handling the outliers by using the Interquartile Range (IQR) technique. To address the class imbalance, Adaptive Synthetic Sampling (ADASYN) is utilized to generate representative synthetic samples of minority classes, thereby improving the classification balance. Selection of features is performed using a hybrid method of Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE), which helps to minimize the dimensionality and preserve the important features. To construct the model, a heterogeneous ensemble, which is named Stacked Ensemble Classifier (SEC), is suggested to combine Decision Trees, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) using a stacking approach to obtain a greater predictive reliability. Experimental findings demonstrate that the given SEC model achieves 95.74% of classification accuracy, 94.28% of precision, 92.63% of recall, F1score of 93.45, and a low Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.057. These results indicate that the suggested IDS is reliable and efficient to process dynamic and high-dimensional network traffic, which is a convenient solution to emerging cybersecurity issues.

title: The Mediating Role of Entrepreneurial Orientation in Big Data Analytics Capability-Value Creation_supp1-3664256.docx
authors: Ajax Persaud
publish: N/A
abstract: Many studies on big data analytics provide empirical evidence showing that Big Data Analytics Capabilities (BDAC) do not always result in value creation or competitive advantage. This study sheds light on how entrepreneurial orientation (EO) mediates the relationship between big data analytics capabilities (BDAC) and value creation in SMEs. The study employed a mixed-method design, integrating desk research, executive interviews, and a survey of 447 Canadian SME leaders. Partial least squares structural equation modelling(PLS-SEM) analysis, supported by reliability and validity diagnostics, common-method-bias tests, and model-fit assessments, ensured the robustness of results and enabled triangulation across methods. Findings reveal that EO mediates the BDAC–value creation relationship, suggesting that SMEs with stronger EO leverage BDAC more effectively. Thus, developing EO is essential for unlocking BDAC's value-creation potential. A practical implication for senior executives is that employing EO – proactiveness, risk-taking, and innovativeness – can lead to better leverage of BDAC insights for value creation. A theoretical implication is that EO can complement other organizational capabilities such as analytics culture to extract greater value from BDAC. The empirical evidence provided in this study complements previous studies that have examined other mediators such as analytics culture and absorptive capacity. It provides additional insights into how SMEs can leverage their BDAC for value creation by being more innovative, proactive and encouraging risk-taking across the organization.

title: Trend-tracking chirplet transform
authors: Long Ge, Dezun Zhao, Tianyang Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Vibration signals from rotating machinery often contain dense and non-proportional instantaneous frequencies (IFs), which bring challenging for existing time-frequency analysis (TFA) methods in high-resolution time frequency characterization. Therefore, the trend-tracking chirplet transform (TTCT) is proposed in this paper. First, unlike symmetric windows used in traditional TFA methods, an asymmetric window (AW) optimization criterion is established to enhance the matching ability of local structures; second, the component-matching CT (CMCT) is optimized based on the AW, and its results are mapped into the high-dimensional space of time-frequency-dynamic chirprate-amplitude to separate non-stationary components; finally, the peak-tracking operator (PTO) is designed based on local extremum detection and trajectory-search mechanism to extract high-energy paths. Simulation results indicate that the TTCT can effectively characterize the non-stationary signal with dense and non-proportional components. Vibration experiments on planetary gearboxes verify the effectiveness of the TTCT for status monitoring and fault identification. Furthermore, analysis results of whale sound signal demonstrate the robust anti-interference capability of the TTCT.

title: Three-dimensional Kinetics Experiments with Negative Reactivity Insertions in CROCUS for the Validation of TRIPOLI-4
authors: Cecilia Montecchio, Thomas Ligonnet, Davide Mancusi, Wilfried Monange, Oskari Pakari, Andrea Zoia, Vincent Lamirand
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: We investigate localized neutron flux perturbations in the CROCUS zero-power reactor, using both experiments and simulation. Reactivity is varied by means of a dedicated oscillation system that precisely inserts cylindrical samples of absorbing materials, namely tantalum (Ta), tungsten (W), and gold (Au), into a core channel. The resulting flux response is recorded by the high-resolution SAFFRON detection array, which provides insights both on the localized evolution within millimeters of the perturbation point. These measurements are then used to validate two features of the Monte Carlo code TRIPOLI-4®: the kinetic simulation mode, which is capable of solving the time-dependent Boltzmann equation coupled to the delayed neutron precursor equations, and the asymptotic reactor period calculations.

title: Intelligent Live Origin and Resilient Streaming
authors: Xiaomei Liu, Rajasekhar Ummadisetty, Joseph Lynch, Chris Newton
publish: Proceedings of the conference on Proceedings of the 5th Mile-High Video Conference
abstract: None

title: Enhanced Electromagnetic Vortex Imaging Method Based on Multi-aperture Array
authors: Da Liu, Hongyin Shi, Ting Yang, Jianwen Guo, Zhijun Qiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Vortex electromagnetic waves possess intrinsic orbital angular momentum (OAM), providing an orthogonal degree of freedom that enhances information capacity. However, generating high-mode OAM beams requires stringent conditions, and their information-carrying efficiency is often limited, leading to constrained resolution. To overcome these limitations and achieve enhanced target azimuth information, improved degrees of freedom, and higher azimuth resolution, this paper proposes an OAM-position multiplexing Fourier ptychography (OPMFP) method. OPMFP synergistically integrates Fourier Ptychography (FP) with conventional electromagnetic vortex imaging. Firstly, an electromagnetic vortex propagation and imaging model incorporating OAM-position multiplexing is established. Secondly, the impact of phase error terms within the high-frequency echo model on imaging reconstruction fidelity is analyzed. Finally, leveraging the sampling framework of OPMFP in electromagnetic vortex radar, a high-frequency information recovery algorithm is proposed. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to conventional electromagnetic vortex imaging, the proposed OPMFP method successfully reconstructs high-purity, high-mode information and delivers superior azimuth resolution performance even when employing vortex beams within a lower mode range.

title: RadioRS: A Sampling-Free Low-Altitude Wireless Networks Leveraging Radio Maps and Rate-Splitting
authors: Shengyu Zhang, Shiyao Zhang, Weijie Yuan, Zan Li, Tony Q.S. Quek
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: The Low-Altitude Wireless Networks (LAWNs) has emerged as a cornerstone of next-generation mobile due to their flexibility and adaptability in providing on-demand connectivity. However, ensuring reliable and high-throughput aerial drone communication remains a major challenge, mainly due to the dynamic mobility of aerial drones and the complexity of the wireless propagation environment. Traditional LAWNs rely heavily on channel sampling and real-time feedback, which introduce latency and communication overhead. In this work, we propose RadioRS, a novel sampling-free aerial drone communication framework that combines Radio Map (RM) prediction with Rate-Splitting Multiple Access (RSMA) to enable robust and efficient communication without requiring explicit channel estimation during flight. RadioRS leverages a RM that provides location-aware predictions of channel state. To enhance the accuracy and generalization of these predictions under complex propagation conditions, we develop a generative model based on the Mamba architecture, which efficiently captures fine-grained correlations in the radio environment. Building on the RM, RSMA is employed to flexibly manage interference and improve spectral efficiency. In addition, we design a Mamba-powered controller that adapts beamforming strategies from the RM directly, further improving link reliability and throughput. Comprehensive simulation results demonstrate that the proposed RadioRS framework significantly outperforms conventional channel-sampling-based approaches in terms of both communication reliability and throughput.

title: DBSCAN-Leak, Novel Real-Time Water Leak Detection: A Case Study of SunRise Demonstrator
authors: Rauf Yasin, Seçkin Ari, Ammar Aljer
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Losses of non-revenue water (NRW) due to undetected leaks threaten the sustainability and operational efficiency of water distribution systems. This study presents an adaptive real-time DBSCAN-Leak algorithm. This algorithm enhances the conventional Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) method for anomaly detection in water distribution systems. Unlike traditional approaches that require static thresholds or complex hydraulic models, DBSCAN-Leak relies solely on flow measurements and dynamically adapts to day-of-week and hour-of-day consumption patterns. The framework utilizes a dynamic neighborhood radius and statistical confidence intervals to estimate the leak probability in real-time. The algorithm was validated using the flow data from the Lille University Scientific Campus. Compared to the original DBSCAN, DBSCAN-Leak achieved significant improvements, detecting 16 confirmed leaks versus one, with 100% precision, 98% accuracy, 80% recall, and an F1-score of 89%. These results demonstrate a low-cost, scalable solution that requires no additional hardware. This approach offers encouraging potential for utility-scale implementation and is extensible to other infrastructure networks, such as gas or electricity distribution networks.

title: Progressive Tactile Perception and Peripheral Hemodynamic Responses Induced by LIFUS on Fingertip
authors: Liuni Qin, Yinshen Huang, Jin Xie, Lili Niu, Laixin Huang, Fei Li, Shichun Bao, Guanglin Li, Yanjuan Geng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Peripherally applied low-intensity focused ultrasound stimulation (LIFUS) has emerged as a new modality of tactile restoration recently. If repetitive LIFUS would cause perceptual adaptation, like transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) does, has been rarely investigated. To address this issue, 14 healthy volunteers received LIFUS-based fine tactile stimulation on their right index fingertip in this work. To evaluate their perceptual stability, both subjective perceptual ratings and peripheral local hemodynamic responses were deployed. The sensory-level TENS was also included for comparison. Our results showed that the LIFUS brought better perceptual acuity and perceptual stability than TENS in terms of subjective perception and judgement. Moreover, the LIFUS induced an increase of local blood perfusion volume (BPV) since stimulation onset, while the TENS caused a decrease of BPV, both followed by a slow rebound to the baseline. Notably, repetitive LIFUS didn’t cause obvious progressive decrease of BPV responses with increasing dose, i.e., temporal accumulation, whereas TENS did. These findings would facilitate the development of non-invasive sensory feedback technique in multiple human-machine interaction scenarios, and shed valuable insights on neuromodulation mechanisms of peripherally applied LIFUS.

title: Gait-Adaptive Perceptive Humanoid Locomotion With Real-Time Under-Base Terrain Reconstruction_supp1-3664167.mp4
authors: Wengang Zhou
publish: N/A
abstract: For full-size humanoid robots, reliable locomotion on complex terrains—such as long staircases—remains challenging, even with recent advances in reinforcement-learning-based control. In such settings, limited perception, ambiguous terrain cues, and insufficient adaptation of gait timing can cause even a single misplaced or mistimed step to result in rapid loss of balance. We introduce a perceptive locomotion framework that merges terrain sensing, gait regulation, and whole-body control into a single reinforcement learning policy. A downward-facing depth camera mounted under the base observes the support region around the feet, and a compact U-Net reconstructs a dense egocentric height map from each frame in real time, operating at the same frequency as the control loop. The perceptual height map, together with proprioceptive observations, is processed by a unified policy that produces joint commands and a global stepping-phase signal, allowing gait timing and whole-body posture to be adapted jointly to the commanded motion and local terrain geometry. We further adopt a single-stage successive teacher–student training scheme for efficient policy learning and knowledge transfer. Experiments conducted on a 31-DoF, 1.65 m humanoid robot demonstrate robust locomotion in both simulation and real-world settings, including forward and backward stair ascent and descent, as well as crossing a 46 cm gap. Project page: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://ga-phl.github.io/</uri>.

title: Gradient-Guided Density Redistribution Network for Light Field Full-View Depth Estimation
authors: Tun Wang, Zhenglong Cui, Ruixuan Cong, Da Yang, Mingyuan Zhao, Yi Zhang, Hao Sheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Light field (LF) full-view depth estimation aims to recover dense and coherent depth maps for all sub-aperture views, which is crucial for applications such as 3D reconstruction, LF editing and virtual reality. However, directly extending center-view volume-based methods to the full-view is computationally infeasible, as it requires constructing a separate cost volume for each view. Besides, existing full-view propagation-based approaches, while more efficient, frequently suffer from edge fattening and cross-view inconsistencies in the presence of occlusions. In this paper, we propose a gradient-guided density redistribution network (GDRNet), a novel end-to-end framework that efficiently generates full-view depth maps by constructing a single plane-density volume and a multi-plane depth image, which are then propagated to all angular views. To resolve ambiguous estimates at occlusion edges, we perform a direction-aware gradient-guided density redistribution only inside a dilated edge narrow band. For each center pixel in edge regions, a guidance gradient is derived from the initial depth map to determine the normal and tangent directions. Then, density in edge fattening regions can be redistributed via sampling along the normal direction, while similarity along the tangent direction can fill bad pixels with inconsistencies. Furthermore, an adaptive edge extraction module with four directional learnable Sobel kernels is designed to jointly exploit spatial and angular gradients, enabling robust detection and localizing the refinement band. Extensive experiments on synthetic and real-world LF datasets demonstrate that GDRNet achieves state-of-the-art accuracy and edge sharpness in both quantitative and qualitative evaluations, while maintaining computational efficiency compared to full-view methods.

title: CTC-MVPT: A Cross-Temperature Continuous Tracking System for Minimum Voltage Point Based on a Universal Delay Chain With Multiple Monitoring Points
authors: Gaoteng Zhang, Kangning Wang, Jiliang Liu, Linnan Li, Huidong Zhao, Shushan Qiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: This brief presents a cross-temperature continuous tracking system for minimum voltage point (CTC-MVPT) based on a universal delay chain (UDC) with multiple monitoring points. By leveraging the timing information provided by the timing margin indicator and timing error indicator, the CTC-MVPT system enables continuous cross-temperature tracking of the minimum voltage point (MVP), significantly reducing power. Meanwhile, the two-step adjustment technique greatly shortens the time required for voltage regulation. In addition, this work further optimizes the 0-to-1 and 1-to-0 transition deviations of the UDC. Measurement results in a 22-nm technology show that the proposed CTC-MVPT system achieves up to 17.7% power reduction over the traditional adaptive voltage scaling (AVS) system as the temperature increases from <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$80~^{\circ }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>C. Therefore, it takes only 1.17ms to adjust the voltage from 0.55 to 0.41 V, representing a 47.8% reduction compared to the traditional scheme. Under the TT corner, the maximum deviation rate of the UDC is only 1.5%, and the maximum deviation between 0-to-1 and 1-to-0 transitions is merely 1.2%. Meanwhile, the system achieves a power gain of up to 55.3% with only a 0.26% area overhead for timing monitoring.

title: Learning Time-Varying Joint-Motor Mapping for Precise Control of Cable-Driven Humanoid Robots Under Transmission Uncertainties
authors: Chenyue Shao, Qingdu Li, Fengen Dai, Yudi Zhu, Yunfeng Hou, Jianwei Zhang
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Cable-driven robots face significant challenges in achieving precise motion control due to the inherent nonlinearity, strong coupling, and time-varying transmission dynamics. Traditional model-based methods require precise parameter identification and offline calibration, while existing data-driven approaches often fail to adapt to the evolving physical couplings in real time. To bridge this gap, this paper proposes a novel Dynamic Transmission Learning (DTL) framework. Its core innovation is an Evolving Graph Structure (EGS) that explicitly models the robot's motor-joint transmission as a dynamic graph. The EGS continuously learns and adapts the time-varying coupling coefficients (represented by the mapping matrix <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {A}_{t}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) directly from sensor data, enabling a calibration-free representation of the transmission dynamics. The framework thereby captures complex deviations such as cable elasticity variations, backlash, and nonlinear damping effects. Through extensive experiments on bipedal robots, we demonstrate that our framework significantly outperforms a range of sequential and graph-based baseline models in prediction accuracy. Furthermore, integrated into a real-time Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) control loop, the DTL framework effectively compensates for transmission errors, reduces joint tracking error by over 50%, and demonstrates robust performance across diverse locomotion scenarios.

title: A Multi-Scale Residual Attention Network for Drainage Pump Fault Diagnosis
authors: Yuning Song
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Fault diagnosis of drainage pumps is essential for ensuring the safe and stable operation of drainage systems. However, vibration signals acquired from drainage pumps under practical operating conditions are often characterized by strong non-stationarity, unavoidable environmental interference, and fault features distributed across multiple temporal scales, which poses significant challenges to accurate multi-class fault identification. To tackle these challenges, this paper proposes a multi-scale residual attention convolutional neural network (MRANet) for drainage pump fault diagnosis. A multi-scale residual attention feature extraction (MRAFE) module is designed to jointly model fault-related information at different temporal scales by means of parallel convolutions and residual connections, while attention mechanisms are incorporated within each scale branch to enhance discriminative fault features. Furthermore, a complementary multi-level feature integration (CMFI) strategy is developed to effectively integrate features extracted at different network depths, enabling end-to-end fault identification directly from raw one-dimensional vibration signals. Extensive experiments are conducted on a drainage pump vibration dataset containing eight operating conditions. Experimental results show that MRANet achieves an accuracy of 95.43%, outperforming several benchmark models. These results verify the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method for multi-class fault diagnosis of drainage pumps.

title: WCNIoT 2025 Copyright Page
