title: Quantum-Resilient Communication Protocol for Secure IoT Networks using Post-Quantum Cryptography and HMAC Integration
authors: Naga Divya Katragadda, Anees Fatima, Jyothi Yadla, T ReshmaReddy, Chhatre Shital, B Parvathi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: This massive rate of expansion of the Internet of Things (IoT) has brought about an immediate demand of safer and efficient communication methods with the capacity to endure upcoming cyber threats of the quantum age. Conventional cryptographic keys like RSA and ECC are getting more susceptible to quantum attacks and thus quantum-proof modules should be developed. This study introduces a Quantum-Resilient Communication Protocol, a lightweight cryptography-authentication post-quantum cryptography protocol, an integration of lattice and AES-GCM encryption with HMAC-based authentication to enable more resource-constrained IoT devices to be amely secured. MATLAB and NS-3 were used to simulate the proposed protocol and the performance of the proposed protocol was compared to a traditional ECC-based IoT protocol. The findings indicated that QRCP had improvement in the latency, throughput and energy savings over 40 percent and it was found that QRCP resisted quantum attack of Shor and Grover. The results justify the practicality of integrating the post-quantum cryptographic exceptors in the IoT network and provide a scalable, energy-saving, and future-enabling paradigm of the secure communication in the quantum era of computational computing.

title: Comparative Ensemble Techniques for Chronic Kidney Disease Leveraging Clinical Intelligence
authors: Sri Vanna Mathi S, Vasudevan V, Dhanasekaran S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a critical worldwide health disorder for which early detection is necessary for timely treatment. Traditional diagnosis techniques mainly depend upon clinical experience and this could lead to uncertainty and decision delay. Using explainable models trained on a publically accessible clinical dataset, this study suggests a Machine Learning (ML) based methodology to improve CKD prediction. Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), Naive Bayes (NB), Support Vector Machine (SVM) and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) a Stacking Ensemble were the six ML classifiers that were trained on a CKD clinical dataset. Each models F1 score, accuracy, precision, ROC-AUC, recall and MCC were evaluated. Generalizability was evaluated using cross-validation. SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) was used to make the model interpretable and ROC/PR curves and feature importance were produced as comparative visualizations. The ensemble model with stacking performed the best in all performance metrics with a ROC-AUC of 99.66%, 100% recall, 98.11% F1 Score and 97.50% accuracy. The NB and RF models demonstrated remarkable performance as well, with ROC-AUC values surpassing 98%. The suggested interpretable ML architecture offers great potential for inclusion into clinical decision-support systems to help medical professionals with early, data-driven detection while guaranteeing transparency and reliability in CKD diagnosis.

title: Cyber Threat Detection based on Artificial Neural Networks using Event Profiles
authors: Varimadugu Lokeshwar Reddy, Briso Becky Bell
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: In the new age of increasingly growing cyber threats, the rule-based security measures can no longer help identify complex attacks. The given project introduces a smart cyber threat detection system using the Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) and structural profiling of events by identifying anomalous activities in network settings. The proposed system is capable of reading security event logs and converting them to small event profiles and subsequent analysis of large-scale data by a deep learning model in order to identify patterns. Implementing the Bayesian inference into the system, it models interdependencies of variables with the help of the directed acyclic graph, which enhance the probabilistic threat classification. This hybrid solution overcomes the drawbacks of other available solutions since it improves the accuracy of detection, false positives, and provides the opportunity to analyze in real time. It uses Python, Django, and MySQL as the implementation of such a system and a number of machine learning algorithms such as ANN, CNN, Random Forest, and SVM to validate it. The experimental findings also prove the strength of the detection process of neural networks in spotting complex cyber threats providing an extensible and anticipatory approach to the current cybersecurity issues.

title: Federated Learning for Privacy - Preserving Image Classification
authors: Sogy K Idicula, Mamatha K R, S.Teitsana Devi, Justilin J R, Gomathi N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This study proposes a privacy-preserving federated learning framework for image classification that integrates decentralized deep learning, secure aggregation, differential privacy, and communication-efficient optimization. Multiple clients collaboratively train a convolutional neural network without sharing raw data, ensuring confidentiality and scalability. The framework employs secure aggregation to protect model updates, differential privacy to prevent data inference, and gradient compression to minimize communication overhead. Experimental evaluation on the CIFAR-10 dataset demonstrates that the federated model achieves up to 97 percent of centralized accuracy while providing strong privacy guarantees and over 90 percent communication reduction. Results further show that the proposed method maintains high performance under non-IID data distributions and improves convergence stability using the FedProx extension. Overall, the system achieves an optimal balance between accuracy, privacy, and efficiency, making it suitable for privacy-sensitive domains such as healthcare, IoT, and smart edge environments.

title: An Intelligent Lung Cancer Diagnosistic System based Latent Equivariant Quantum Convolutional Neural Network with Improved Orca Predation Algorithm using Histopathological Imaging
authors: Jyoti Sheoran, M. K. Pushpa, Kishore H N, Vijay Jagdish Upadhye, Ramya Maranan, S.SriRagavi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related mortality in the world and thus outlines the need to discover diagnostic methods beneficial to improve patient survival. Accurate classification of pathological images is essential for sub-typing and as a means for guiding therapy. The current research work presents latent equivariant quantum convolutional neural network (LEQCNN) with improved orca predation algorithm (IOPA) (Latent Equivariant Quantum Convolutional Neural Network augmented with Improved Orca Predation Algorithm or LEqCNN-IoPa) for automating the diagnostic process of lung cancer. Initially, initial stage preprocessing for the LC25000 dataset of histopathological images has been conducted using the Window-Aware Guided Image Filtering (WAGIF) technique to improve structural integrity, and also to reduce artefacts from noise. The improvement is further obtained via segmentation using a Return-(a)-ligned Decision Transformer (RADT) that captures the contextual relationship on pixel level further. The architecture is further enhanced to include Feedback DenseNet201 (FDNet201) which integrates feedback attention with dense connectivity to further improve the saliency of clinically meaningful features in the network. Finally, hyper-parameter optimisation is done by the IOPA meta-hyperparameter algorithm, which is based on biologically inspired exploration-exploitation mechanisms. Experimental results show that the LEQCNN-IOPA can achieve the overall precision of 99.85%, accuracy of 99.62%, and sensitivity of 99.59%.

title: Secure and Tamper-Proof Exam Center Attendance System using NFC and Encrypted QR Codes
authors: Aditya Elango, Nishanth Reddy Kuraku, Parikshith Sivakumar, Kavitha C. R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Fraud in regard to attendance and impersonation are important threats to the integrity of high stakes examinations. To overcome such issues as mentioned above, this paper proposes a secure and tamper-proof attendance system with Near Field Communication (NFC) technology, and AES-256 encrypted QR codes under a kerberos authentication framework. The system that has been proposed includes role-based interfaces. administrators create time and space bound QR codes to be linked to student NFC IDs; students authenticate through NFC cards and QR-codes are retrieved; invigilators check credentials through real-time decryption and hall assignment cross-check. Primary security mechanisms one-time-use QR codes, NFC chip authentication, and server-side validation, avoid such threats as replay attacks, cloned cards, and unauthorized access. Experimental validation within a simulated focus shows validation in under 5 seconds per student, and high resistance to tampering, validating for the system’s scalability into large-scale installations. This approach gives a holistic plan for secure digital presence in an academic setting as well as a high-security space.

title: AI - Powered Personalised Learning System
authors: Mr.D.BalaKrishnan, Y.TejaSri, A.Akhila, D.Rohith Kumar Reddy, D.Vaishnavi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This article introduces an innovative, interactive learning platform intended to enhance education personalization using artificial intelligence. The platform is developed in response to the increasingly diverse student learning needs that existing systems cannot accommodate. The platform facilitates initial secure registration of users and a diagnostic assessment to determine each learner's initial level. Using the results of the assessment, a personalized learning pathway is created for each learner, categorizing users as beginners, intermediate, or advanced levels and adapting lesson sequences for each learner level. The platform is designed to provide instantaneous feedback to learners, enabling real-time support for learner doubt and struggle via a chat assistant, and periodic topic-based assessments to encourage ongoing learner progress. Engagement of users is fostered by the inclusion of gamification features such as challenges and rewards. To provide real-world applicability, high-performing learners can link to internships. Data is gathered on the learner pathway of each user learning session and visually reported via a dashboard, highlighting user strengths, weaknesses, and milestones to encourage frequent self-improvement. Summative assessments and feedback loops will continually refine the content and platform features. Overall, the platform is intended to offer a more interactive, flexible, and motivating learning environment than traditional didactic models and promote learning for varied groups of learners with various goals.

title: Research on the Application of KNN and CART Algorithms in Network Security Intrusion Detection
authors: Jinqin Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: With the advancement of technology and society, we are progressively entering the era of the Internet of Everything, where the security of IoT network traffic holds increasingly critical importance in today’s world. Under the premise of ensuring network security, intrusion detection for IoT traffic serves as a vital component in safeguarding both IoT devices and network integrity. This paper primarily examines the performance of the KNN and CART machine learning algorithms across datasets of varying sizes. It aims to investigate the suitable dataset scales for each algorithm, analyze the relationship between dataset size and training set configuration, and explore potential improvement strategies.

title: Design of a Scalable IoT Edge Node Based on SPI Bus
authors: Zihan Ye, Wei Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: To address the limitations of existing IoT edge nodes—such as poor scalability, limited hardware interchangeability, and high customization costs—this paper proposes a modular edge node design based on the SPI (Serial Peripheral Interface) bus. The system employs a multi-processor architecture and uses the SPI bus as a backbone for modular expansion. By adopting a “standard access–terminal adaptation” strategy and a protocol-transparent transmission mechanism, the design achieves hardware unification, flexible device access, and general interchangeability. A unified transparent transmission frame format is used for data encapsulation and forwarding, effectively resolving compatibility issues caused by heterogeneous interfaces and protocols. Practical applications demonstrate that the proposed design significantly enhances the flexibility and scalability of edge nodes while reducing deployment and maintenance costs, demonstrating high practical value in engineering applications.

title: A Hybrid Intrusion Detection Framework using Rough Set-based Feature Selection and SVM Classification
authors: R M Ganesh, A.Sivanesan, Anirudh j, Aswin M S, Harikrishna K R, Mathews M Jaico, Roshan Roy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: In the fast-changing era of data communication, cyber-attacks and unauthorized access pose a significant threat to system and network security. Conventional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are plagued by low accuracy and high false positives, which erode their usefulness in real-time intrusion detection. To overcome this issue, a new hybrid approach is proposed where Rough Set Theory (RST) is used for feature selection and Support Vector Machine (SVM) for classification. The main aim is to improve the detection accuracy while, at the same time, minimizing the complexity and dimensionality of data and processing. RST successfully filters out the most important features from the network traffic data and eliminates redundant or irrelevant attributes before forwarding the pre-processed data to the SVM classifier. This, besides lowering the processing complexity, also enhances the classification performance. The novelty lies in the combined application of RST and SVM, hence offering a more efficient alternative to existing methods like Principal Component Analysis (PCA). The proposed IDS exhibits enhanced detection accuracy with an appreciable reduction in false positives, hence offering a more efficient and reliable intrusion detection mechanism.

title: CNN-Driven Retinal Images Segmentation
authors: J Sivakumar, V. Keerthana, P. Kaviya
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Retinal diseases such as papilledema, tortuosity, and glaucoma are major contributors to preventable blindness, yet they are often not diagnosed until they are in advanced stages due to reliance on human clinical evaluation. The problem lies in the need for precise, computerized, and interpretable diagnostic systems. In this contribution, we present a deep learning-driven pipeline wherein vessel enhancement through Frangi filtering is combined with pre-trained convolutional neural network, ResNet-18, to allow retinal fundus images to undergo autonomous classification and segmentation. Enhancement of the vascular structure facilitates increased visualizability, allowing ResNet-18 to identify delicate abnormalities corresponding to swelling, vessel tortuosity, and optic nerve cupping. Fine-tuning was performed on the model so as to enable the retinal images to be classified into four different classes: normal, papilledema, tortuosity, and glaucoma, with a resultant validation accuracy of 99.56% and rapid loss convergence. Innovation in the current contribution lies in the marriage of segmentation-guided feature enhancement and deep classification, providing a reliable framework for real-world ophthalmic screening.

title: Implementation of Artificial Intelligence based Skin Disease Detection using Computer vision Technique
authors: Himanshu Dixit, Kanagaraj R, Krishnaraj N, Chandru Vignesh. C, Sreethar. S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Modern self care has evolved to the point where skin health management is a critical part of the good life, and skin health management with personalized and accurate solutions. In this paper, we present Know Your Skins, an AI-based platform built on advanced computer vision methods especially YOLO (You Only Look Once) for detecting acne and assessing oiliness. The system combines collaborative filtering and rule based analysis to provide skincare recommendations targeted to the skincare needs of the individual. Additional it facilitates access to professional care through dermatologist appointment booking and assisting in tracking progress through image based monitoring. Unlike existing solutions, Know Your Skins addresses limitations of manual assessment, lack of personalization and high cost by presenting a comprehensive, scalable, and user-friendly platform. Results indicate high precision, recall rates on acne detection and user satisfaction with product recommendations. Future work includes expanding datasets, including more skin conditions, and building a cross platform mobile app for widespread accessibility.

title: Throughput Optimization of Digital Modulation Techniques Across Star and Ad-Hoc Network Configurations in BDsat-01 Maritime Systems
authors: A K M Mizanur Rahman, Md Hossam-E-Haider
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of maritime GEO satellite communication using Bangladesh Satellite-01 (BDsat-01), focusing on the integration of network topology optimization with physical layer modulation techniques. The study examines how varying sea states and weather conditions influence signal propagation and link reliability for vessels operating in the Bay of Bengal. Three network configurations—Mesh 3-hop, Star 1-hop, and Star 2-hop—are evaluated based on key performance indicators such as data rate, reliability, coverage, throughput, latency, and free-space path loss (FSPL). Adaptive Coding and Modulation (ACM) with QPSK and 8PSK schemes is applied to improve spectral efficiency and maintain stable connectivity under dynamic channel conditions. The simulation results reveal trade-offs between throughput, bit error rate (BER), and power requirements across different maritime environments. The integration of BDsat-01 with optimized GEO topologies demonstrates improved link robustness and broader coverage. Overall, the findings contribute to the design of resilient maritime communication systems capable of adapting to fluctuating propagation conditions while enhancing the operational efficiency of BDsat-01’s maritime services in the Bay of Bengal.

title: Smart Diagnosis of Plant Disease using AI and Imaging Technology
authors: Alfrin Getciyal S, Vignesh, Sujitha Juliet
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Plant diseases continue to be a major problem in agriculture worldwide, resulting in significant yield and quality losses. Maintaining agricultural yield and guaranteeing food security depend on early and accurate disease detection. Traditional diagnosis techniques, which rely on professional eye examination or laboratory analysis, are frequently laborious, arbitrary, and unsuitable for large-scale farming. This work integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Deep Belief Networks (DBNs) to present an intelligent framework for diagnosing plant diseases. While the DBN carries out hierarchical classification for increased precision and generalization, the CNN component collects spatial characteristics from leaf pictures. The model outperforms conventional CNN-MLP and CNN-SVM architectures with an accuracy of over 95%. Furthermore, it is portable and flexible for edge or mobile deployment, giving farmers access to real-time disease prediction. The suggested method serves as an example of how AI-powered image technology may revolutionize plant health monitoring, advance sustainable farming practices, and facilitate crop protection early intervention.

title: Control Strategy for a Boost-Derived LCC Converter with Low Input Ripple and Wide-Range Operation for Fuel Cell Systems
authors: Arvin Escultero, Carl Michael Odulio
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Fuel cells are increasingly being adopted as high-energy-density sources in renewable energy systems. However, their integration presents challenges such as wide voltage variations and performance degradation under dynamic load conditions. This paper presents a power converter design and control scheme tailored for fuel cell applications to address these issues. An LCC resonant converter topology is selected for its suitability in high-power operation and its inherent ability to function as a constant current source, thereby mitigating degradation caused by load variations. To further reduce input current ripple, a current-fed inverter is employed at the front end. A hybrid control strategy combining pulse-width modulation (PWM), phase-shift control, and variable-frequency control is proposed to achieve wide-range output current regulation while maintaining low input ripple. The system is modeled and simulated using PLECS and MATLAB. Simulation results verify that the proposed approach achieves wide-range constant-current operation with reduced input ripple, allowing the use of smaller filter components and enhancing fuel cell longevity.

title: High-Frequency Resonant Inverter for Resistive Heating in Electrified Industrial Furnaces
authors: Daniel Baggen, Nikita Huber, Julius Wilker, Rik W. De Doncker
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Heat treatment processes play a crucial role in the steel industry. Conventional industrial furnaces are heated by the combustion of natural gas, transferring heat to the steel either through convection or radiation. To electrify this process, gas burners can be replaced with resistive heating elements, which are currently supplied using thyristors connected to the low-voltage grid. This electrification method requires expensive 50 Hz ac transformers for electrifying furnaces in the MW range. To remove the necessity for those transformers, the move to the medium-voltage grid with an active front end, a local dc grid, and power electronic converters is necessary, which reduces costs and resource usage. In this work, we propose a resonant inverter for supplying heating elements with a 50 kHz ac current, which can be connected to a local dc grid. This approach utilizes the skin effect below the Curie temperature by increasing the resistance and thus reducing the current. The inverter is designed for an exemplary heating element of an electrical radiant tube. A prototype is built and experimentally validated, reaching a peak efficiency of 98.5%. Additionally, the load- and temperaturedependent behavior of the heating element is investigated.

title: Adaptive Educational Platform with Resume Integrated Career Assistance
authors: Shanmugapriya A, Mahalakshmi S, Mirnalini P, Nandhini S, Naveen Kumar S
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Absence of personal guidance, unavailable learning materials, time management and motivation are the significant issues that hinder students and job seekers to have academic and career success. The paper suggests the Adaptive Educational Platform featuring Resume-built Career Assistance to integrate several AI-based modules that personalize the learning and career support. The methodology consists of six fundamental development parts, such as Content Summarization based on hybrid TF-IDF and embedding algorithms and tools, such as Readability-lxml and GROBID; a Smart Resume Analyser that is based on SpaCy, PyMuPDF, and Plotly Dash as skill visualization and ATS scoring tools; a Personalised Quiz Generator with adaptive feedback and gamification testing; a Study Planner using Twilio notifications to facilitate proper scheduling; an AI-based Recommendation Engine, which matches learning resources and learning objectives; and a The experimental analysis showed that time management efficiency increased by 35% and that the knowledge retention of users improved by 28%. Proposed platform offers technically important, adaptive, and result-based solution, which improves the effectiveness of learning, fortifies career preparation, and supports the ongoing personal growth through intelligent automation.

title: 3D Mapping Navigation System using Lidar
authors: C Hilton Hilary, Chetan Raj M, Manideepa G, Lakshmi C R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Accurate mapping and dependable navigation are crucial for autonomous systems working in changing and unpredictable environments. This paper introduces a framework for 3D mapping and navigation that uses LiDAR and combines it with semantic Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) to create detailed environmental models. The system uses a drone with a 3D LiDAR and cameras to gather detailed spatial information. By combining geometric and semantic data from both LiDAR and images, the system can reliably detect obstacles and locate itself even in difficult or changing conditions. To address the lack of outdoor depth data sets, a new dataset was created to help improve the reconstruction of areas that are hidden or not seen by sensors. Testing shows that this method offers better depth accuracy and consistent mapping than current LiDAR and vision-based techniques. The system works quickly and can adjust to different situations, making it useful for tasks like autonomous driving, monitoring the environment, and inspecting buildings. This contributes to the progress of smart mapping technology.

title: Voice-Enabled Personalized Tutoring System for Rural English Learners
authors: Pitti Abhiram Reddy, Kasa Amareswar Reddy, Sruthy Anand
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Recent advances in natural language processing (NLP) and Generative AI (GenAI) have laid the foundation for personalized education systems that support learning. In this paper, we present a personalized tutoring system for English learners in rural parts of India. Acquiring new vocabulary and correct pronunciation is essential for learning a foreign language and using it confidently. To teach English effectively, the tutoring system should have the ability to identify learners’ pronunciation mistakes. Hence, pronunciation assessment is an important feature incorporated into the voice-enabled personalized tutoring system to ensure effective language learning. The pronunciation assessment module evaluates the user’s pronunciation. Most existing phonetic transcription methods face limitations due to variations in phoneme representation, which can result from factors such as accent differences and silent letters. This paper addresses these challenges by examining the effectiveness of an Automatic Phoneme Recognition Model. To provide more accurate pronunciation feedback for users with diverse Indian English accents, three speech models—Whisper, wav2vec2, and Kaldi—were fine-tuned on a region-specific dataset. Among them, Whisper achieved the best performance, with a word error rate (WER) of 7.8% and a phoneme error rate (PER) of 11.3%.

title: Modulation Adaptation Method to Reduce Switching Losses in Three-Level Converters Using Delta-Sigma Modulation
authors: Jannik Maier, Philipp Czerwenka, Eckhard Hennig, Ertugrul Sönmez, Gernot Schullerus
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel modulation adaptation method for a three-level converter using an asynchronous deltasigma modulator (ADSM) to reduce switching losses. Asynchronous delta-sigma modulators can reduce the average switching frequency compared to pulse width modulation (PWM) while offering superior total harmonic distortion (THD) performance due to their noise shaping capabilities. In contrast to fixed switching frequency PWM, the switching frequency of an asynchronous delta-sigma modulator depends on the instantaneous input signal. Therefore, the input signal waveform directly determines the switching frequency of the modulator. The proposed adaptation method uses two different input signal waveforms to reduce switching losses by decreasing the average switching frequency, considering the asynchronous delta-sigma properties. The input signal waveform is modified through linear interpolation by the proposed adaptation method compared to conventional input waveforms. The validation of the modulation adaptation method is confirmed by calculations, simulations, and measurements.

title: Bidirectional Multilevel Solid-State Transformer for Medium-Voltage EV Charging Stations with Vehicle-To-Grid Capability
authors: H.S.H De Zoysa, Sheldon S. Williamson
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Solid-state transformer (SST) technology enables direct connection to the medium-voltage grid and enhanced functionality for ultra-fast electric vehicle (EV) charging. This paper proposes a 1 MW bidirectional EV charging station using an SST-based architecture consisting of a cascaded H-bridge (CHB) multilevel AC-DC converter and a dual-active bridge (DAB) DC-DC stage. The system connects directly to an 10 kV medium-voltage AC grid and provides a 1000 V DC output to 4 level 3 EV chargers and Sola PV, adjustable via a buck-boost converter to accommodate various EV battery voltage levels. The high-frequency isolated DAB stage ensures galvanic isolation and flexible interfacing to the DC output bus. The bidirectional design supports vehicle-to-grid (V2G) and vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) power flow, and readily integrates local solar photovoltaic (PV) generation on the DC link for enhanced energy management.

title: Channel Estimation for mmWave mMIMO Systems with Mixed-ADC: Conditional Generative Adversarial Network and Deep Transfer Learning
authors: Lizheng Wang, Lijun Ge, Changcheng Qi, Gaojie Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: Millimeter wave (mmWave) massive multiple input multiple output (mMIMO) systems have the advantages of abundant spectrum resources, high transmission rate, and high multiplexing gain. However, the large number of antennas leads to high power consumption and difficult channel estimation. Although the problem of high power consumption can be addressed by reducing the analog-to-digital converter (ADC) resolution of radio frequency (RF) links, considering the accuracy of channel state information (CSI), high-resolution antennas are still needed to be deployed on a small number of RF terminals. Therefore, a mixed-resolution ADC should be used for signal transmission to consider channel estimation and power consumption tradeoff. To reduce the influence of quantization noise generated by the low- resolution ADC on channel estimation performance, we propose two deep learning-based channel estimation methods for mmWave mMIMO systems with mixed-resolution ADCs. Based on the conditional generative adversarial network, the first method has the advantage of generating more useful CSI with less available high-resolution CSI, which fits the characteristics of the mixed ADC system. Moreover, the second proposed method exploits deep transfer learning to train low-resolution antenna data using network parameters that have been trained at high-resolution antennas. Both methods can fully utilize the information from high-resolution antennas while mining the effective information from low-resolution antennas, thereby achieving high-resolution channel estimation while reducing mMIMO system overhead. Simulation results demonstrate that both methods can perform better than deep neural networks in mixed-resolution ADC scenarios.

title: Design of Multi-frequency Digital Lock-in Amplifier Based on Multi-sine Coherent Sampling
authors: Yuxiang Yang, Chengyue Gong, Haijun Lin, Hong Shi, Xin Tan, Fu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The lock-in amplifier (LIA) is a widely used instrument for weak signal detection, and the digital LIA (DLIA) has gradually replaced the analog LIA with the development of digital signal processing technology. However, multi-frequency DLIA, as the newest form of DLIA to meet the demand of simultaneous multi-frequency applications, has no ideal solution at present. This paper proposes a multi-frequency DLIA (MF-DLIA) based on multi-sine coherent sampling (MSCS), which innovatively adopts the multi-sine reference signal and the coherent sampling strategy, combined with the FPGA parallel architecture to achieve high-precision simultaneous multi-frequency demodulation. The experiment verification is conducted in sinusoidal test signals with the amplitudes ranging from 1 to 50 mV and at frequencies from 5 to 50 kHz in a -10 dB noise condition, which shows accurate demodulation results with the amplitude relative error below 1% and the phase absolute error less than 0.02°. Furthermore, it has been verified to dynamically detect multi-frequency impedance cardiography (ICG) simultaneously at six frequencies at [5, 10, 15, 25, 30, 50] kHz by adding an impedance analog front end, which exhibits high demodulation distinguishability at all the frequencies with the maximum amplitude variation of 1 mV and phase variation of 0.02°. This study offers an efficient approach to detecting multi-frequency weak signals, which will have broad applications in biological monitoring and industrial sensing.

title: An Efficient, Identifiable and Abortable Multi-Party Signature Scheme for VANETs
authors: Gang Shen, Zhenhua Han, Weizhi Meng, Mingwu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Vehicular ad-hoc networks (VANETs) are networks based on short-range wireless communication technology, mainly used for direct communication between vehicles and interaction with roadside infrastructures. The emergence of VANETs has improved the efficiency and safety of vehicle travel. However, malicious vehicles may intentionally send incorrect messages to mislead other vehicles for personal gain, and this behavior cannot be identified yet. To address this issue, we propose an efficient, identifiable, and abortable multi-party signature scheme for VANETs. Specifically, we utilize the property of zero-knowledge proofs to design a method that can efficiently identify malicious vehicles during the signature process, and define a strategy to quickly locate false proofs. Additionally, the message signing key in the proposed scheme is jointly generated by multiple entities, which avoids the security issues of key escrow and single point failure. Through rigorous security analysis, it is demonstrated that the proposed scheme satisfies essential security requirements for VANETs, including message unforgeability and authentication, vehicle anonymity, malicious traceability, collusion resistance, replay attack resistance, identifiable abort, and forward security of signing private key. Performance analysis shows that our scheme reduces the total aggregation verification time by up to 80% compared to existing schemes, and maintains a lower packet loss rate (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$< $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.6%) at higher vehicle densities. Therefore, our scheme is suitable for large-scale VANETs deployments.

title: Analytical Modeling of Multi-DOF Permanent Magnet Linear Braking via Equivalent Circuit Method
authors: Libin Cui, Guangtong Ma, Pedram Asef, Zhenhua Su, Piji Feng, Guanglai Huang, Shuai Xu, Jun Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: The permanent magnet linear braking (PMLB) has garnered significant attention for its contactless operation and high force density. However, conventional analytical models often exhibit limited accuracy due to oversimplified geometric assumptions and the inability to accommodate the multi degree-of-freedom (DOF) attitude variations of the mover. To address these limitations, this paper presents a novel three-dimensional analytical model based on an equivalent circuit method. Specifically, the permanent magnet (PM) is equivalently represented as a rectangular current carrying coil using the surface current method. The mutual inductance between this equivalent PM coil and the brake coil is calculated via the discrete Neumann formula. A dynamic equivalent circuit is then constructed to determine the induced currents in the brake coil, and the resulting braking force is evaluated using both the energy method and the method of images. The proposed model is thoroughly validated through finite element method (FEM) simulations. Additionally, the impact of various attitude conditions on braking performance is systematically analyzed. Finally, experimental results obtained from a full-scale prototype and measurement system show excellent agreement with the theoretical predictions, thereby confirming the model’s accuracy and practical applicability.

title: Cyber-Physical Security of Virtual Power Plants: A Survey
authors: Mohammad Raeispour, Shuo Yan, Lasantha Meegahapola, Xinghuo Yu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: Virtual power plants (VPPs) integrates distributed generation, storage systems, and load under a common control and market framework. Although the VPP concept brings improved flexibility and new services to the utility, it substantially endangers the grid due to the large cyber-physical attack surface. This paper investigates the cyber-physical security of VPPs in modern power systems. First, the structure of VPPs is outlined, including main components, control hierarchies, communication layers, and ancillary services. Further, the cyber and physical vulnerabilities are mapped across different layers of the VPP. This mapping further leads to a structured taxonomy of attacks common in VPP context. Following the vulnerability analysis, the paper looks into the different defense mechanisms relevant to VPP-coordinated distributed energy systems (DESs), in categorization of prevention, detection and isolation, and resilient control. The comprehensive investigation highlights the pressing need for the development of robust, co-designed security and resilience strategies across all layers of VPPs to safeguard their operations against evolving cyber-physical risk, which remains to be a significant gap in the VPP study.

title: Enhancing the Accuracy of Airborne Vehicle Detection Model using AI Technique
authors: R. Pavaiyarkarasi, Murali P, S. Irin Sherly, R. Shobana Lakshmi, D. Sungeetha, R. Jeena
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Automation heavily depends on automatic target detection systems as their main operational feature. Automated target detection achieves its goal through recognition of objects that appear in captured images. The Retinanet stands as a strong classification network for object recognition in images. The location invariance depends on the size of their training set and determines their performance characteristics. A solution focused on objects is possible using a relatively network architecture named Retinanaet. The article presents RetinaNet variant known as multi-level framework to identify objects when training data amounts are limited. This paper validates the introduced framework using internet-collected objects. The dataset includes three objects. The proposed framework achieves a substantial improvement of 99.27% accuracy in object detection. Experimental findings reveal that the proposed framework achieves superior recognition precision which surpasses conventional Support Vector Machines together with other transfer learning algorithms.

title: Scalable Task Scheduling in Cloud Environment using the One-to-One-based Optimizer Algorithm
authors: Rameshwaraiah Kurupati, Bokinala Lokesh, S Srikanth Reddy, Belli Pujitha, Sokam Bhavya Sree, Mannem Adi Shesha Reddy
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Cloud computing has become a fundamental paradigm for delivering scalable and on-demand computing resources, where efficient task scheduling plays a pivotal role in ensuring balanced resource utilization and system reliability. However, dynamic workloads and heterogeneous resources often lead to load imbalance, reduced VM success rates, and increased task failures, posing significant challenges to scheduling strategies. To address these issues, this study proposes a novel task scheduling framework based on the One-to-One-Based Optimizer (OOBO) algorithm, which leverages adaptive one-to-one task-to-VM mapping to achieve efficient and reliable scheduling. The framework was implemented and evaluated using the CloudSim simulator with real-world Alibaba workload traces, enabling a realistic assessment of performance under large-scale cloud environments. Comparative experiments against established metaheuristic algorithms, namely Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA), demonstrate the superior performance of OOBO. Specifically, OOBO reduced the degree of imbalance by up to 18.7%, increased the VM success rate by 12.4%, and decreased the task failure rate by 15.9% compared to the benchmarks. These results confirm that OOBO provides a balanced, reliable, and efficient scheduling mechanism, making it highly suitable for dynamic and heterogeneous cloud infrastructures. The findings highlight the potential of OOBO as a scalable optimization strategy for next-generation cloud computing systems.

title: Historical Review on the Performance of Monopole Circularly Polarized Antenna for Sub 6 GHz Applications
authors: Ch. Mahendra Kumar, E. Maneesh, N. Hemanth, Ch. Raghavendra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: A compact and efficient circularly polarized monopole antenna is analyzed for sub-6 GHz wireless communication applications. The study reviews and evaluates existing antenna structures to identify design trends, performance limitations, and feasibility for next-generation 5G systems. The proposed structure employs a multilayer configuration using an FR-4 substrate (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r</inf> = 4.4) and a metallic ground plane for effective radiation. A microstrip line feed mechanism ensures good impedance matching and stable performance across the 3.4 and 4.04 GHz band, achieving a return loss of -16dB and −19 dB. The paper further emphasizes comparative evaluation of related designs, highlighting Results in terms of gain, bandwidth, and axial ratio. This work aims to provide a historical and analytical foundation for developing advanced sub-6 GHz antennas with improved circular polarization and compactness.

title: CNN-based MRI Brain Tumor Classifier for Detecting Glioma, Meningioma, Pituitary Tumor, or Absence of Tumor
authors: Liziyo J, Savitha K. K
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is the clinical standard for assessing brain tumors, but has a long time to interpret and is prone to inter-observer variability. And one of the articles says this: "We propose a compact, deployment-ready Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for four-way classification glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumor, and no-tumor using contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI." Our method highlights patient-level trader splits, aggressive on-the-fly boosters, low Rank architecture and Grad-CAM (gradually-weighted class activation map) interpreter. The model has been trained, by making use of stratified train/validation/test splits and k-fold cross-validation on publicly available MRI benchmarks (see Section 3). On held-out data the classifier gives 98.4% overall accuracy and F1 scores at least 98% per class while having a substantially lower number of parameters and lower inference latency as compared to the common transfer learning baselines. An ablation study measures the impact of augmentation, dropping, and depth in the network. In addition to these features, the tool can provide predictions along with Grad-CAM overlay for quick screening which is a helpful characteristic for busy clinicians. These contributions support the approach that a resource efficient explainable CNN can provide near-state-of-theart performance in meningioma screening and is functional in the context of resource constrained clinical nephrology.

title: IoT-Enabled Smart Healthcare Monitoring: A Low-Cost Real-Time Solution for Vital Signs Tracking
authors: Rathiya R, Sreenivasa Perumal L, Anuja T, Srihari S, Sanjay K, Swetha M
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The rising need to keep a constant track of patients and identify the presence of health peculiarities early is the factor that has driven the creation of the automated and affordable healthcare systems. The paper will discuss the design and development of an IoT-based Smart Healthcare Monitoring System, where essential vital parameters, such as heart rate, body temperature, and blood oxygen saturation (SpO 2), are measured in real time. The system utilizes pulse sensor, DHT11, and MAX30100 coupled with an STM32 Nucleo microcontroller to capture accurate data and have consistent performance. The sensor results are sent through Wi-Fi and visualized with the help of the Blynk web dashboard which also sends automated notification about abnormal conditions. Experimental evidence showed that it had high measurement accuracy (heart rate 98.5%, temperature 98.2%, SpO 2 97.8%), quick response time (less than 2 seconds) and excellent uptime (99.1%), which is better than conventional low cost monitoring systems. The proposed solution minimized the workload of healthcare staff and also reduced the time spent on diagnosis compared to manual observation. This is due to its small size, low cost, and scalability, which may be adjusted to fit hospital wards, clinic environments, and home-based care, therefore, providing an effective and trustworthy solution to patient safety and healthcare provision.

title: AI-based Hybrid Approach for Real-Time Anomaly Detection and Fault Management in Digital Services
authors: Betul Karaoglan, Muhammet Tahir Guneser, Ufuk Akbulut, Sinem Cakmak Gursel, Yesim Kılınc Tiryakioglu, Gokhan Tepe
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Reliable access and high performance in digital services are essential for user satisfaction and business continuity. Failure to detect anomalies in service infrastructures in a timely manner can lead to performance degradation, customer dissatisfaction, and financial losses. This study presents an AI-based hybrid framework for real-time anomaly detection and fault management in digital services. The proposed system integrates statistical methods (Z-Score, linear regression), machine learning algorithms (Isolation Forest, One-Class SVM, LSTM Autoencoder), and an online learning model (River Half-Space Trees). Model hyperparameters were optimized using the Optuna library, and a majority voting mechanism was applied to reduce false positives. Contextual factors such as public holidays, pay days, and scheduled maintenance periods were incorporated to filter out expected deviations. Operating on real-time data streams, the system detects anomalies and classifies their direction as upward or downward. Experimental results indicate that the proposed approach improves anomaly detection accuracy and supports proactive fault management, enhancing service reliability and continuity.

title: Machine Learning-based Predictive Model for Ischemic Stroke Risk Assessment: A Data-Driven Approach using XGBoost
authors: S.Nithyaselvakumari
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Ischemic stroke is a leading cause of disability and mortality worldwide, requiring early and accurate prediction for timely intervention. This study proposes an XGBoost-based machine learning model for stroke prediction using structured patient data, including demographics, medical history, and hospital visit records. The dataset, consisting of 5,147 patient records, was preprocessed through missing value imputation, feature selection, normalization, and class balancing. To address class imbalance, random undersampling was applied, ensuring the model learned effectively from both stroke and non-stroke cases. The proposed model achieved 94.4% accuracy and 0.91 AUC-ROC, outperforming traditional models such as Random Forest and Logistic Regression. Feature importance analysis identified age, NIH Stroke Scale Score, hypertension, and cardiologist visits as key predictors. Comparative evaluation demonstrated that our model surpassed prior research in stroke classification. By integrating gradient boosting, feature engineering, and class balancing, this study provides a highly interpretable and clinically valuable model for ischemic stroke prediction, aiding healthcare professionals in early diagnosis and risk assessment.

title: Cost-Effective Voltage Stability Enhancement via HEES-based Interline DC Flexible Voltage Restorer
authors: Kuruva Raju, K. Kiran, K. Lokesh, V Mahesh Kumar Reddy, R. Senthil Kumar, K. M. D. Rajesh Babu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The stability of DC distribution systems is often compromised by voltage sag, swell, and imbalance caused by renewable intermittency and nonlinear loads. Traditional battery storage systems, though cost-effective, suffer from limited dynamic response, while high-conducting electromagnetic energy storage (HEES) offers millisecond-level compensation at high cost. To address this trade-off, a novel Interline DC Flexible Voltage Restorer (IFVR) is proposed, where a single HEES module is shared across multiple distribution feeders. The novelty lies in its priority-based switching strategy and multilevel inverter topology, which allow rapid injection/absorption of compensating current with reduced hardware. The proposed design integrates HEES with line-selector and mode-selector switches to dynamically restore interline voltages. Simulation studies were performed in MATLAB/Simulink with load resistance variations from 0.4 Ω to 10.1 Ω under sag (180 V), swell (260 V), and normal (230 V) operating conditions. Results demonstrate a transient recovery time below 1 s, voltage regulation within ±2%, and harmonic distortion below 3%. Compared with conventional DVR-based methods, the IFVR achieves a 25% reduction in storage capacity requirements and 18% improvement in response speed. This makes the configuration highly suitable for renewable microgrids, data centers, and EV charging systems, ensuring cost-efficient, scalable, and reliable DC voltage stabilization.

title: Transfer Learning with DenseNet for Accurate Breast Histopathology Images Classification
authors: Kottaimalai Ramaraj, S J Kavitha, S Preena Jacinth Shalom, S Prasath Alias Surendhar, R Indumathi, S Sakkaravarthi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Breast cancer is one of the most common diseases in women globally, and early detection is essential for effective treatment and improved patient outcomes. In this work, a transfer learning method using pretrained convolutional neural networks (CNNs) in MATLAB is presented for the automatic categorization of breast histopathology pictures. The DenseNet architecture is specifically utilized due to its enhanced feature propagation and efficient parameter utilization, both of these are being demonstrated to be beneficial in medical imaging applications. The suggested approach makes use of a labeled dataset of histopathological pictures that have been scaled and preprocessed to meet the network's input specifications. In order to achieve binary classification between benign and malignant tissue samples, the pretrained DenseNet model's final layers are fine-tuned using transfer learning. Accuracy, confusion matrix, and visual classification results are employed to measure the model's performance after it is trained using MATLAB's Deep Learning Toolbox. Experimental results indicate the transfer learning technique uses the rich and dense feature representations acquired from large-scale picture datasets to achieve excellent classification accuracy even with a very small dataset. To further improve accuracy and generalizability in practical diagnostic contexts, future research will investigate patch-based categorization, ensemble models, and bigger datasets.

title: End-to-End Deep Learning Model for Early Detection of Plant Diseases from Leaf Images
authors: Deepa Bhadana, Thanjaivadivel M, R. Lakshmana Kumar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Plant diseases are a significant hazard to cultivated output, and therefore early detection is crucial for proper crop management. Yet, most current plant disease detection systems suffer from issues such as overfitting, restricted dataset diversity, and poor generalization performance, which hinder their scalability in practical agricultural settings. This paper proposes a deep learning-based framework developed for the early detection of plant sicknesses using Plant images. The methodology begins with the acquisition of leaf images of plants, and then proceeds with careful steps in data preprocessing, such as image augmentation and resizing for increasing the robustness of the model. For extracting important texture features needed for disease identification, a Local Binary Pattern (LBP) is used. The InceptionV3 model is used as the classifier to separate healthy from diseased leaves. The system as put forward exhibited commendable performance and had an accuracy of 98.5%, a precision of 97%, a recall rate of 96%, and an F1-score of 96.5%. All the above are pointers to how well the framework identifies plant diseases correctly. To wrap up, the approach devised proves to be effective and sturdy plant disease detection as a solution in solving problems to date by prevailing methods, touting with substantial potentiality towards implementation within applicable agricultural scenarios.

title: Spyware Detection using Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning
authors: Ms. M. Raghavi, J.Bharath, S. Kabil Yugan, S. Karunakaran
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Spyware is considered one of the major immovable and secretive cybersecurity threats that are always present. The main purpose is to monitor users' activities in a covert way and to carry out the unauthorized transfer of sensitive data. Signature-based and heuristic detection, which are the traditional methods of detection, are not sufficient against these quickly developing, hidden, or even changing forms of spyware. AI and ML, on the other hand, are providing adaptive data-driven solutions, which can recognize the patterns and analyze behaviors of the threats to identify the unknown and emerging ones. The paper presents in-depth AI and ML detection methods for spyware and looks at the hybrid ones integrating both the static (PE headers, imported libraries) and the dynamic (registry modifications, process activity) aspects, focusing on the latter. It considers 15 recent IEEE and high-impact works in the same way, based on the methodology, characteristics of the dataset, feature extraction strategies, and performance results. Moreover, it suggests the creation of a web-based spyware scanning system that will allow not only individual file scanning but also whole system inspection, relying on a lightweight client agent and an AI-ML hybrid model. The survey closes with a discussion of the challenges that remain, like explainability, data privacy, and real-time deployment, and presents future directions for the development of autonomous, federated, and trustworthy AI-based spyware defense systems.

title: Smart Shopping Cart using RFID Technology for Automated Billing and Enhanced Retail Experience
authors: Rathiya R, Madhumitha S, Elakiya VL, Bharath Kumar P, Chithirika K S, Archana R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Automation technologies are creating a massive change in how people shop in the retail setting. Conventional retailing relationships tend to experience lengthy queues, handheld barcode scanning, billing mistakes and efficiency. To overcome the challenges, it is proposed, and assessed that a Smart Shopping Cart system based on Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology be developed. According to this system, RFID readers are installed on the cart and each goods is provided with an RFID tag to allow the detection of the products and generation of the money automatically and on the spot. Experimental findings prove that the Smart Cart will decrease the billing time (by approximately 110 seconds to 33 seconds in case of 20 items), decrease the error rates (8 percent to 3 percent in manual entry and barcode scanning to 1 percent, respectively), and increase the billing accuracy percent to 99 percent. Measures of customers satisfaction such as speed, convenience, accuracy, and ease of use also show that this better than the time-honored method of checkout. The system does not only reduce the human factor and enhances user experience, but also streamlines the operations of the store because it minimizes the dependency of cashiers as well as delays in transactions. These findings confirm the practicability of the application of RFID-based smart carts to supermarkets and retail chains as more efficient, accurate and customer-friendly solution to retail.

title: Carbon-Aware Large Language Models for Edge Inference: Towards Sustainable and Adaptive AI
authors: Mary Valentina Janet A, Pavithra S, Monika S, Nishanthini T, Preethi Jenitha S, Kavya A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The growing use of Large Language Models (LLMs) on edge devices presents serious challenges in balancing latency, computational performance, and ecological sustainability. Conventional methods focus mainly on energy efficiency in datacenters and neglect the specific constraints and real-time dynamics of distributed edge environments. The paper here introduces a Carbon-Aware LLM Inference Framework for Edge Devices, one that adjusts model behavior dynamically according to real-time carbon intensity signals from APIs like WattTime and ElectricityMap. The framework consists of four functional layers, Sensing & Signal Collection, Device & Model Profiling, Adaptive Inference Controller, and Execution & Accounting, that facilitate per-request inference decisions with the aid of approximation methods like quantization, early exits, and distillation. Experiments over benchmark tasks show that the system proposed attains between 80% CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emission savings and drastic latency reductions (from 250 ms to 160), while maintaining the proposed system accuracy 92.7%. Trade-offs between multiple objectives enable robust tuning between sustainability, accuracy, and responsiveness, enabling deployment on a wide range of real-world use cases. This paper fills the gap between green AI research and real-world edge intelligence, presenting a scalable, eco-friendly method for LLM inference.

title: AI-Driven System Design for Human-Animal Conflict Mitigation
authors: Sabesh Arunachalam K C, Kavin K, M.K.Elango
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The occurrence of human-animal conflicts within agricultural landscapes is a major threat to food security and livelihood as well as biodiversity conservation among farmers. Conventional crop protection strategies like fencing, patrolling, and scare techniques are labor-intensive, inconsistent and may not be viable in the long term. To eliminate these conflicts, this paper introduces an intelligent, AI-based system of real-time animal intrusion detection and automated deterrence. The proposed system uses the YOLO (You Only Look Once) deep learning model on robust and accurate detection of various animal species in different farm environments. A smart activation module will maximized energy consumption by keeping the vision system inactive when there is no movement occurring and activated when a possible motion is detected to cut down power usage and computational load. When this is successfully detected, the system records time-stamped photos, sends immediate messages to the farmers via a mobile app, and triggers non-invasive auditory signal to scare animals away safely. Moreover, environmental conditions like temperature and humidity are also constantly controlled to facilitate adaptive performance and to give farmers microclimate information to help him manage his crops better. Experimental analysis shows that the system has a low false-positive rate, high detection accuracy and latency of less than one second in reporting events, proving the appropriateness of the system in real-time application. The proposed system based on the combination of AI-based detection, automated alerting, and environmentally adjustable deterrence mechanisms provides a scalable and sustainable solution to improving the protection of crops and coexistence of humans and wildlife.

title: Discrete-Time State Feedback Control with Extended Observer for Interleaved Boost Converter
authors: Galina Mirzaeva, Yunxun Mo, Eduardo Espinosa
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Voltage-controlled DC-DC boost converters are used in the electric transport applications for integration of lowvoltage energy sources. Such applications require compact and reliable power converter designs coupled with high-quality steadystate and dynamic control performance. This paper proposes the use of a three-leg interleaved DC-DC boost converter and develops an advanced control scheme based on model linearisation, state feedback and extended observer. To support its design and implementation, the paper provides closed-form solutions for the discrete-time models and for all coefficients and gains used by the control. The proposed control is then tested by simulation in Matlab/Simulink and shows superior dynamic performance compared to PI control. Experimental validation in underway.

title: Data-Driven GRU Model for Reliable SoC Prediction in EV Battery Systems
authors: Alagar Karthick, Naveen Kilari, S. Kaliappan, P.Kavitha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: A key part of electric vehicle (EV) battery management systems (BMS) is accurate state of charge (SoC) assessment, which affects energy economy, battery lifespan, and drive safety. This research presents a method for reliable state-of-the-art (SoC) prediction in dynamic driving environments based on deep learning and using Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) networks. To efficiently capture temporal correlations in sequential batteries data, GRU, a form of RNNs, uses little computing power. Key factors like voltage, current, temperatures, and charge/discharge cycle are included in the suggested model, which is trained and verified using real-world datasets of EV batteries. Measures of performance such as R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) show that the GRU model outperforms both traditional approaches and other deep learning systems in terms of accuracy and generalizability. The results show that the model based on GRU can reliably anticipate the state of the circuit, which makes it perfect for use in electric vehicle real-time BMS systems.

title: AI Driven Multitask Transformer Framework for Predicting Learning Outcomes in ADHD Students
authors: J.S. Mary Fathima Anuja, S. Nagasundaram
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Children with ADHD often have a hard time paying attention, handling lots of info, and doing well in school consistently. Normal learning systems usually use simple rules or simple machine learning, but these can't really understand how ADHD students learn over time and how they act. So, this study suggests using a special Multitask Transformer Framework. It looks at how students behave over time. It uses things like how well they do on small quizzes, how interested they seem, and general behavior to create a hidden picture of each student. Then, it uses this picture to guess two things: whether they might drop out and how well they’ll do in the end. The system learns by trying to get both predictions right at the same time. Tests showed it did better than other methods, getting 88% accuracy and 0.86 F1 score for guessing who might drop out and 82% accuracy and 0.80 F1 score for guessing final grades. This is better than Logistic Regression (74%), Random Forest (79%), and LSTM (83%). This new system could to help kids early, supports everyone being included and it is shows is a pretty cool jump forward in using data to help students with ADHD learn better.

title: Solar-Powered Isolated Bidirectional DC–AC Converter for Microgrid and Distributed Energy Systems
authors: Y. Hari Krishna, K. Kiran, A. Venkata Ramana, D Arun Prasad, R. Senthil Kumar, K. M. D. Rajesh Babu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The reliable operation of microgrids and distributed energy systems requires efficient bidirectional conversion between DC and AC domains under varying voltage levels. Conventional converters suffer from limited efficiency and restricted voltage conversion capability when interfacing with solar photovoltaic sources. To address limitation, an isolated bidirectional DC–AC converter has been developed, incorporating a high-frequency transformer with a turns ratio of 5:25, resonance inductance of 46 µH, and mutual inductance of 190 µH. The proposed design enables wide voltage conversion with both step-up and step-down operation, governed by modulation indices formulated through resonant tank analysis. Hardware validation demonstrates stable operation with zero-voltage switching (ZVS) at full load, significantly reducing switching losses. Experimental results indicate that in AC–DC mode, the system achieves a peak efficiency of 95.2% at a rated power of 800 W, while in DC–AC mode, efficiency remains above 93% across the operating range. Harmonic analysis confirms that total harmonic distortion (THD) is maintained below 3.5% in AC–DC conversion and 4.2% in DC–AC conversion, ensuring compliance with grid standards. These results establish the proposed isolated bidirectional converter as a robust and cost-effective solution for renewable-powered systems, offering high efficiency, reliable voltage regulation, and suitability for future smart grid and electric vehicle charging applications.

title: Early and Reliable Non-Invasive Liver Disease Diagnosis using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: L. Rahunathan, G. Arun, Suhana Nafais A, Jaya Surya S, Bharanidharan B, Iniyan B
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Liver diseases are a major global public health problem, and early diagnosis enables improved outcomes of treatment. Existing methods to diagnose liver disease are mostly invasive, time-consuming, and expensive. The goal of our project was to develop a non-invasive and reliable method to detect liver diseases using machine learning methods from noninvasive clinical parameters. A real-time dataset was used with 122 patient records and 11 clinical and biochemical features. Five machine learning methods were tested, including Random Forest, Logistic Regression, Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), LightGBM and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). We further experimented with feature selection and optimization to improve the resulting models and predicted accuracy by minimizing the dimensionality of the data. Our finding has shown that machine learning methods, particularly LightGBM and MLP, can provide a reliable and non-invasive evidence-based approach liver diseases. Accuracy, F1-Score, and ROC-AUC were employed to evaluate these methods. Finally, LightGBM achieved the best performance, with an accuracy of 88.89%, F1-score of 0.8947, and a ROC-AUC of 0.9383. MLP also performed well with a ROC-AUC of 0.9506.

title: Insights and Emerging Trends in Artificial Intelligence for Early Detection and Monitoring of Parkinson’s Disease
authors: Sreekutty S.D, D. Pamela, Shajin Prince, Jayanthi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors, along with non-motor impairments including cognitive decline and sleep disturbances. Early detection is essential, as timely intervention improves quality of life, slows disease progression, and reduces healthcare burdens. Conventional diagnostic approaches relying on clinical assessments and neuroimaging face challenges such as subjectivity, delayed recognition, high cost, and limited scalability, often resulting in diagnosis after significant neuronal loss. This study reviews recent Artificial Intelligence (AI)-based approaches for automated PD detection across modalities including speech, handwriting, biomedical signals, and imaging data. Machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models demonstrate high accuracy, robustness, and interpretability, with several achieving classification performance above 90%. However, issues such as reliance on single-modality datasets, absence of clinical metadata, overfitting, and computational overhead persist. By integrating existing research, this study identifies current gaps and proposes directions toward multimodal, explainable, and computationally efficient AI frameworks for clinically relevant, scalable, and real-time PD diagnosis and monitoring in healthcare settings.

title: Explainable AI-based Tuberculosis Detection using DenseNet121 on Chest X-rays
authors: Yazhini D, Golden Nancy R
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: One of the most common infectious diseases in the world, tuberculosis (TB) kills a large number of people each year, especially in areas with limited resources. While timely intervention depends on early and accurate detection, manual interpretation of chest X-rays is frequently laborious, subjective, and subject to inter-observer variability. In order to tackle this issue, we suggest a DenseNet121 explainable deep learning framework for automated TB detection from chest radiographs. The model enhances interpretability by highlighting diagnostically relevant lung regions using a variety of Explainable AI (XAI) techniques, including LIME, Grad- CAM, Grad-CAM++, and Class Activation Mapping (CAM). Moreover, feature-space separability between TB-positive and normal cases is visualized using t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE). The suggested system demonstrated 100% recall for TB-positive cases, 99.3% accuracy, and a 99.8% F1-score after being trained and validated on a carefully selected chest X-ray dataset. The results show that the framework successfully combines clinical transparency and diagnostic precision, supporting reliable AI adoption in TB screening. These results outperform those of traditional CNN and ensemble-based models.

title: Secure, Predictive, and Transparent Cold-Chain Logistics using Deep Learning and Ethereum Blockchain
authors: Shiji Mol F R, J. Ayyana Prabu, R. Santhana Krishnan, S. Jeeva Paulin, J. Relin Francis Raj, S. Murali
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Ensuring vaccine integrity requires rigorous cold-chain management, as even minor temperature deviations can compromise safety, cause financial losses, and endanger public health. Conventional monitoring systems, dependent on centralized databases and manual oversight, remain prone to delays, inaccuracies, and tampering. To address these limitations, we propose an integrated framework that combines deep learning and blockchain for secure, predictive, and real-time cold-chain monitoring. A distributed network of IoT sensors captures temperature, humidity, vibration, and GPS data at one-minute intervals. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks forecast short-term temperature trends, Autoencoders (AE) detect anomalies, and one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Networks (1D CNN) classify shipment states as Safe, At Risk, or Spoiled. A decision engine fuses outputs from these models into a unified risk score, enabling timely and data-driven interventions. Critical events and metadata are immutably recorded on the Ethereum blockchain, while raw sensor data is stored off-chain using IPFS to ensure auditability and efficiency. The system also supports automated alerts, real-time monitoring through Grafana dashboards, and adaptive model retraining for continuous improvement. Evaluation covers forecasting accuracy, anomaly detection precision, classification performance, and blockchain efficiency. By uniting predictive analytics with tamper-proof logging, the proposed framework reduces vaccine spoilage, strengthens supply chain resilience, and offers a scalable solution for broader temperature-sensitive logistics applications.
