title: Energy-Risk Optimal Path Planning for Surface Vehicle via Parameterized Level Set in Dynamic Flows Marine Environment
authors: Huihui Chen, Yong Ma, Chengli Liu, Lingyu Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: A considerable proportion of ocean vehicles, particularly those with constrained operational capabilities, are vulnerable to external factors such as wind patterns and ocean currents. It is therefore imperative that a safe and viable route be identified for a ship to operate autonomously. The proposed methodology delineates a systematic approach for the mapping of environmental pathways on electronic charts, underpinned by parameter-level set equations. In order to address the shortcomings of the traditional level set method, namely its lack of smoothness and slow convergence, a new approach was devised. This approach is predicated on the premise that the impact of non-uniform dynamic wind and wave flows is accounted for by incorporating a matrix expansion processing method of wind field data slices into the boundary evolution part of the level set equation. Secondly, in order to optimise the real-time evolution of the reachable boundary, a curve parameter formula expressed by implicit function on Euclidean space is designed. In conclusion, the perturbation energy functional is constructed in order to solve the gradient descending flow and to ensure the robustness of the ship evolution curve in the presence of disturbance. The validity of the proposed methodology is substantiated by numerical exemplification.

title: Face Presentation Attack Detection by Exploiting Prior Knowledge of Region Relationships
authors: Lei Li, Shanshan Gao, Zhaoqiang Xia, Fabio Roli, Yuanfeng Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Face recognition systems have been widely deployed in mobile devices for user authentication and payment applications. However, these biometric systems remain vulnerable to face presentation attacks, posing significant security risks. In recent years, numerous countermeasures have been proposed, with analysis of differences between bona fide and attack presentations being a commonly adopted strategy. Nevertheless, the variations in image attributes and region movements have not been thoroughly explored. In attack images, the textures of the facial region and the background tend to be more similar, while local regions often exhibit more consistent directions of movement compared to bona fide presentations. Motivated by this observation, we propose a novel face presentation attack detection method that leverages prior knowledge of region relationships. Specifically, each input face image sequence is first divided into small patches, which are then processed by a pre-trained <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$TimeSformer$</tex-math></inline-formula> network utilizing divided time and space attention mechanisms to extract deep features. Two metrics—<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Cosine$</tex-math></inline-formula> similarity and mean squared error (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$MSE$</tex-math></inline-formula>)—are subsequently employed to measure the texture similarity and movement relationships of the regions of interest. During the inference phase, these measurements are fused to distinguish bona fide from attack presentations. Extensive ablation and comparison experiments, conducted on six face presentation attack detection (PAD) databases (i.e., Idiap Replay-Attack, CASIA-MFSD, OULU-NPU, MSU-MFSD, 3DMAD, and HKBU-MARs V1+), demonstrate that our method achieves superior detection performance, significantly improving precision over state-of-the-art approaches in most experimental settings.

title: A Deep Probabilistic Flow-Based Framework for Unsupervised Cross-Domain Soft Sensing
authors: Junn Yong Loo, Hwa Hui Tew, Fang Yu Leong, Ze Yang Ding, Vishnu Monn Baskaran, Chee-Ming Ting, Chee Pin Tan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Industrial soft sensing is crucial for accurate process monitoring through reliable inference of dominant sensor variables. However, developing effective data-driven soft sensor models presents challenges, such as achieving domain adaptability, addressing incomplete sensor labels, and learning stochastic data variability. To overcome these challenges, we propose a deep variational potential flow (DVPF) framework for cross-domain soft sensor modeling, taking into account the lack of sensor labels in the target domain. Our framework introduces sequential variational Bayes with recurrent neural network (RNN) parameterization to address the maximum likelihood estimation problem that characterizes cross-domain soft sensing. Central to the framework is a potential flow that performs unsupervised Bayesian inference on the RNN-extracted features to obtain an exact representation of the intractable posterior distribution. Together, these DVPF components learn domain-adaptable features that effectively capture complex cross-domain process dynamics and data variability. We validate the proposed DVPF on a real industrial multiphase flow process across varying operating modes. The results show that the DVPF demonstrates superior performance in cross-domain soft sensing compared to existing deep feature-based domain adaptation methods.

title: Combined Acoustic-Acupuncture Stimulation Demonstrates Efficacy in Primary Tinnitus Rehabilitation: Objective Evidence from EEG Brain Network Analysis
authors: Chanlin Yi, Haoyang Yu, Qingyang Li, Zhongliang Wang, Ruili Yang, Hongmei Song, Mi Yang, Dezhong Yao, Peng Xu, Yong David Zhao, Fali Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Tinnitus is a prevalent neurological disorder that significantly impacts patients’ quality of life and is difficult to treat. While acupuncture therapy and acoustic stimulation have individually shown therapeutic potential, their combined application remains largely unexplored. The aim of this study was to investigate the efficacy and neural mechanisms of combination therapy based on brain network technology. In this tinnitus intervention study, 240 patients were enrolled, randomly divided into three groups for three treatment schemes: acoustic stimulation therapy, acupuncture stimulation therapy, and combination therapy. Each group received four courses of treatment, three treatments a week for each course. Based on the resting-state electroencephalography (rsEEG) network analysis before and after intervention, we investigated the electrophysiological changes aroused by the therapies and the inter-protocols differences, as well as how it changes with therapy process progresses and its association with tinnitus rehabilitation. The combined treatment group’s post-intervention showed a more pronounced decrease in frontal-parietal-occipital connectivity in the delta, alpha, and beta frequency bands, indicating lower clustering coefficients (CC) and longer characteristic path lengths (CPL). In the combined group, the magnitude of these changes is highest and gradually decreases as therapy progresses, indicating a robust therapeutic effect. Moreover, the significant correlations of the CC and CPL changes separately with the changes of anxiety and auditory sensitivity further validate the efficacy of the combined acoustic-acupuncture stimulation therapy. Our pioneer study paves an innovative way for the treatment of primary tinnitus

title: GRAPPA : Generalizing and Adapting Robot Policies via Online Agentic Guidance
authors: Arthur Bucker, Pablo Ortega-Kral, Jonathan Francis, Jean Oh
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Robot learning approaches such as behavior cloning and reinforcement learning have shown great promise in synthesizing robot skills from human demonstrations in specific environments. However, these approaches often struggle to generalize to unseen real-world settings because they rely on task-specific demonstrations or complex simulators. While foundation models (e.g., LLMs, VLMs) offer rich semantic understanding from internet-scale data, using this knowledge to enable robotic systems to understand the underlying dynamics of the world, generalize policies across different tasks, and adapt policies to new environments remains an open challenge. To alleviate these limitations, we propose an agentic framework for robot self-guidance and self-improvement that comprises a set of role-specialized conversational agents, including a high-level advisor, a grounding agent, a monitoring agent, and a robotic agent. Our framework iteratively grounds a base robot policy on relevant objects in the environment and uses visuomotor cues to shift the policy's action distribution toward more desirable states online, while remaining agnostic to the subjective configuration of a given robot hardware platform. We demonstrate that our approach can effectively guide manipulation policies to achieve significantly higher success rates, both in simulation and in real-world experiments, without the need for additional human demonstrations or extensive exploration.

title: Towards Adversarial Robustness in MADRL-based EV Charging Scheduling: A Tailored Multi-Criteria Adversarial Attack and Defense Framework
authors: Zhuocen Dai, Mao Tan, Yin Yang, Xiao Liu, Yi Su, Kang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: With the growing adoption of reinforcement learning (RL) in Electric Vehicle (EV) charging scheduling, its vulnerability to adversarial attacks remains largely underexplored. These attacks, essentially a form of stealthy false data injection, introduce imperceptible perturbations to observation data, potentially leading to severe performance degradation. In this work, we propose a novel Multi-Criteria Adversarial Attack (MCAA), which goes beyond conventional adversarial methods that merely induce action shifts of agents. Instead, MCAA is designed to strategically deteriorate specific objectives in multi-objective optimization or to mislead the agent into violating physical constraints, according to the attacker’s intent. To counter such threats, we develop an Auto-Shielded Defense (ASD) framework that combines a preemptive Auto-shield module with adversarially robust agents trained via adversarial training. The Auto-shield extracts latent features to mitigate adversarial perturbations, while adversarially robust agents ensure reliable decision-making under attack. Extensive experiments show that ASD consistently outperforms standard RL in objective and system stability under attacks, effectively neutralizing various types and intensities of adversarial attacks.

title: AI Adoption and Innovation Strategy: An Empirical Analysis of Strategic Moderation by Innovation Stage Duration
authors: Ga Eun Choi, Jae-Seong Lee
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The adoption of artificial intelligence has emerged as a pivotal strategy for enhancing firms' innovation capabilities. However, the temporal framing of stage-specific lead times can substantially influence organizations’ intentions to adopt AI. This study estimates the effects of lead times at four stages of the innovation process—planning, development, commercialization, and distribution—on small and medium-sized enterprises’ (SMEs’) intentions to adopt AI, and examines whether these effects are moderated by firms’ innovation strategies. Using survey data from 3,900 Korean SMEs, we employ Firth-corrected logistic regression to address class imbalance and evaluate robustness through bootstrap procedures. Innovation strategy is operationalized as either exploitative or exploration-oriented, and the analysis includes controls for firm age, size, internal R&D investment, R&D intensity, patent counts, and industry competitive intensity. The results show that although an exploitative strategy is generally associated with weaker adoption intentions, its interactions with stage-specific lead times are consistently positive, with the strongest moderating effects observed in the planning and commercialization stages. These findings suggest that as lead times increase, exploitative organizations may expand their framing of AI—viewing it not only as an efficiency-enhancing tool but also as a mechanism for buffering risk and stabilizing execution—thereby reinforcing their intentions to adopt AI. This study extends the theoretical scope of AI adoption research by incorporating a temporal framing perspective and demonstrating the asymmetric effects of stage-specific lead times across innovation stages. From a policy standpoint, the findings suggest the need for targeting criteria that account for the dual conditions of strategic orientation and stage-specific bottlenecks, while from a managerial standpoint, this study highlights the value of reframing time-based constraints as strategic resources to guide more effective AI adoption decisions.

title: Snapshot Compressive Hyperspectral Image Reconstruction via Complementary Priors
authors: Yaning Zang, Min Huang, Lianru Gao, Lina Zhuang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Imaging
abstract: Coded aperture snapshot spectral imaging (CASSI) systems compressively project 3D hyperspectral data onto 2D measurements, offering high imaging speed and data efficiency. However, existing CASSI reconstruction algorithms still suffer from suboptimal reconstruction quality due to the ill-posed nature of hyperspectral compressive sensing reconstruction, which demands effective prior modeling. This paper proposes a novel reconstruction framework that integrates multiple complementary priors, jointly modeling spectral low-rankness, spatial nonlocal self-similarity, and deep image priors to comprehensively capture the intrinsic structure of hyperspectral images across spectral and spatial domains. By combining the strengths of model-based and data-driven priors, the proposed method achieves both strong generalization and expressive capacity. To tackle the optimization challenges posed by multiple regularization terms and parameters, an efficient ADMM-based solver is developed, which decomposes the problem into subproblems with closed-form solutions or those solvable via plug-and-play denoisers. In addition, an adaptive noise estimation mechanism is introduced to automatically tune the regularization parameters, eliminating the need for manual parameter adjustment. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms state-of-the-art approaches in terms of reconstruction accuracy and robustness across multiple datasets. Our code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/ETHAN-YA/PnP-Hybrid.git</uri>.

title: Design and Cold-Test Study of W-Band Suspended Array Ring-Rod Dual-Channel Integrated Microstrip Meander Line Slow Wave Structure
authors: Xing Liu, Zhanliang Wang, Yuan Zheng, Zhigang Lu, Shaomeng Wang, Yubin Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This article presents a suspended array ring-rod microstrip meander-line SWS (SARR-MML SWS), developed from the suspended ring-rod microstrip meander line SWS (SRR-MML SWS). The proposed configuration combines two SRR-MML traveling-wave tube (TWT) units through microstrip power dividers to enable efficient power combining. High-frequency simulations were performed in CST Microwave Studio to systematically analyze and characterize the high-frequency properties and electric field distributions of both the proposed SARR-MML SWS and the conventional single-channel SRR-MML SWS. Particle-in-cell (PIC) simulations systematically assessed the impact of interchannel spacing <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$d$</tex-math> </inline-formula> on output power, operational stability, saturation power, gain, and electronic efficiency. Under a 10-kV beam voltage, 263-A/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> current density, and 9.0-mm interaction length, the SARR-MML TWT achieves a saturation output power at 97 GHz that is 5251% higher than the single-channel design, confirming effective power combining under full coupling between channels. With a 10-W input power, the output reaches 166.66 W, corresponding to a gain of 12.21 dB and an electronic efficiency of 4.16%, along with a 3-dB saturation bandwidth of 92–100 GHz, indicating broad operating bandwidth. The SARR-MML SWS was fabricated via photolithography and validated through cold-test measurements, which showed a reflection coefficient S<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$11\lt -143$</tex-math> </inline-formula> dB and transmission coefficient S21 between −3.7 and −5.1 dB across 90–100 GHz, in good agreement with simulations, thereby affirming the reliability of the integrated design.

title: DFL-GC: A Decentralized Federated Framework for Planetary Gearbox Fault Diagnosis under Domain Shift and Class Imbalance
authors: Mingyu Shen, Lixiang Duan, Xiaoxuan Fan, Bin Feng, Shuang Cai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In planetary gearbox fault diagnosis, Federated Learning (FL) enables clients to train models while preserving data privacy collaboratively. However, achieving satisfactory performance typically assumes that data are independent and identically distributed across clients, and that class distributions within each client are balanced. In practice, these assumptions rarely hold: data collected at different clients under distinct working conditions induce domain shift, and within each client, predominantly normal operation leaves few fault samples, leading to class imbalance. Domain shift can destabilize model aggregation, and class imbalance biases learning toward the majority class. Therefore, addressing the coexisting domain shift and class imbalance is essential for the practical application of FL. To support serverless collaboration under parameter-only communication, a Decentralized Federated Learning (DFL) framework with a Gaussianized Feature Alignment Module (GFAM) and a Class-Balanced Kullback–Leibler loss (CBKL), named DFL-GC, is proposed and aggregated via a ring topology without a central server. During local training, each client applies GFAM to map local features to a standard Gaussian distribution and refines representations with a self-attention mechanism, reducing inter-client distribution discrepancy and improving diagnostic performance; CBKL applies client-specific class-frequency-aware weighting to Kullback–Leibler divergence terms to strengthen intra-class prediction consistency and interclass prediction separation for minority classes, improving minority-class diagnosis. Experiments on two planetary gearbox datasets show improved domain alignment and robustness to class imbalance, yielding superior diagnostic performance and outperforming seven comparative methods.

title: Distributed Temperature Sensing in the Spray-Cooled Shell of a 150-Ton DC Electric Arc Furnace Using Brillouin Optical Fiber Technology
authors: Farhan Mumtaz, Yeshwanth Reddy Mekala, Koustav Dey, Rony Kumer Saha, Ogbole Collins Inalegwu, Manoj Kumar Pullagura, Bohong Zhang, Muhammad Roman, Nicholas Dionise, Zane Voss, Jeffrey D. Smith, Ronald J. O’Malley, Rex E. Gerald II, Jie Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper presents the deployment and validation of a Brillouin - distributed temperature sensing (DTS) system for real-time thermal monitoring of the spray-cooled upper shell of a 150-ton direct current Electric Arc Furnace (DC EAF) at Big River Steel Plant, Osceola, AR, USA. A four-channel Brillouin DTS system from OZ Optics was employed, with one active channel instrumented using an in-house-fabricated Brillouin scattering-depressed single-mode optical fiber (SMF28e+). The 60 m optical fiber sensor was fabricated, with 20 m allocated for thermal measurement and 40 m used as lead-in fiber to isolate the interrogator from the furnace environment. The fiber was nested in stainless steel (SS) tubing and bonded to the hot-face surface of the shell using thermally conductive epoxy. The system captured transient thermal events including burner activation and process-induced heating over multiple furnace cycles. DTS-acquired data were validated against resistance temperature detector (RTD) measurements, confirming consistent thermal trends and system accuracy. Prior to the industrial deployment, several mock-up tests were conducted. Laboratory calibration demonstrated a linear Brillouin frequency shift with temperature, with a sensitivity of approximately 1.19 °C/MHz up to 515 °C and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.9988. Additional mock-up trials confirmed spatial resolution between 0.5 m and 1 m, with transmission and reflection spectra showing hotspot detection over sensing lengths up to 130 m. An averaging spatial step of 0.04 m was used, and acquisition sweep time was set to 1 min with a 10 MHz frequency step size and 10,000 averages. Monitoring the spray-cooled shell is critical in EAF operations due to its exposure to high thermal loads and susceptibility to localized overheating. Real-time hotspot detection and localization support proactive maintenance, reduce the risk of shell failure, and improve energy efficiency and operational safety. These findings underscore the potential of Brillouin - DTS systems to enable intelligent process control and predictive maintenance in next-generation steelmaking facilities.

title: Synesthesia of Machines Based Multi-Modal Intelligent V2V Channel Model
authors: Zengrui Han, Lu Bai, Ziwei Huang, Xiang Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: This paper proposes a novel sixth-generation (6G) multi-modal intelligent vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) channel model from light detection and ranging (LiDAR) point clouds based on Synesthesia of Machines (SoM). To explore the mapping relationship between physical environment and electromagnetic space, we construct a new V2V high-fidelity mixed sensing-communication integration simulation dataset with different vehicular traffic densities (VTDs). Based on the constructed dataset, we develop a novel scatterer recognition (ScaR) algorithm utilizing neural network SegNet to recognize scatterer spatial attributes from LiDAR point clouds via SoM. Subsequently, the developed ScaR algorithm is incorporated into channel modeling to recognize scatterers in a physically informed manner. We further distinguish recognized scatterers into dynamic and static scatterers based on LiDAR point cloud features. The aforementioned procedures determine parameters related to dynamic and static scatterers, e.g., distance, angle, and number, enabling the channel model to generate the corresponding channel impulse responses (CIRs). Through the ScaR algorithm, dynamic and static scatterers change with the variation of LiDAR point clouds over time, which precisely models channel non-stationarity and consistency under different VTDs. Some important channel statistical properties, such as time-frequency correlation function (TF-CF) and Doppler power spectral density (DPSD), are obtained and analyzed. Simulation results match well with ray-tracing (RT)-based results, thus demonstrating the necessity of exploring the mapping relationship and the utility of the proposed model.

title: DGM-RDW: Redirected Walking with Dynamic Geometric Mapping Between Environments_supp1-3660749.pdf
authors: Yi-Jun Li
publish: N/A
abstract: Redirected walking (RDW) subtly adjusts the user's visual perspective on head-mounted displays during natural walking to reduce forced resets, thus enlarging the size of the virtual environment that can be explored beyond that of the physical environment. Alignment-based RDW controllers aim to minimize spatial discrepancies by optimizing the alignment between the user's physical and virtual environments. We introduce a novel alignment-based method that dynamically calculates mapping functions between physical and virtual geometries to enhance the algorithm's awareness of the RDW environments. To achieve this, we first construct an abstract model defining a mapping function between physical and virtual geometries and establish feasibility constraints in differential form. We then concretize this mapping, optimize it, and develop a practical implementation for dynamic geometric mapping in RDW. Our approach distinguishes itself by determining dense spatial mappings around the user, rather than aligning environments according to limited metrics. Through extensive testing, our algorithm has proven to markedly decrease reset incidents in natural walking, surpassing existing RDW controllers. The introduction of dynamic geometric mapping provides a fresh perspective, contributing significant insights and advancing the field.

title: Compendia: Automated Visual Storytelling Generation from Online Article Collection_supp1-3663204.pdf
authors: Manusha Karunathilaka
publish: N/A
abstract: In the digital age, readers value quantitative journalism that is clear, concise, analytical, and human–centred. To understand complex topics, they often piece together scattered facts from multiple articles. Visual storytelling can transform fragmented information into clear, engaging narratives, yet its use with unstructured online articles remains largely unexplored. To fill this gap, we present Compendia, an automated system that analyzes online articles in response to a user's query and generates a coherent data story tailored to the user's informational needs. through two modules covering addresses key challenges of storytelling from unstructured text through two modules covering: Online Article Retrieval, which gathers relevant articles; Data Fact Extraction, which identifies, validates, and refines quantitative facts; Fact Organization, which clusters and merges related facts into coherent thematic groups; and Visual Storytelling, which transforms the organized facts into narratives with visualizations in an interactive scrollytelling interface. We evaluated Compendia through a quantitative analysis, confirming the accuracy in fact extraction and organization, and through two user studies with 16 participants, demonstrating its usability, effectiveness, and ability to produce engaging visual stories for open-ended queries.

title: Machine Learning & AI-based Analysis of EEG Signals for Neuropathic Pain Classification
authors: Om Sanjay Talekar, Sunit Sharad Sawant, Amay Patil, Kanchan S. Gorde
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Neuropathy, more precisely diabetic peripheral neuropathy, is one of the most progressive neurological disorders which can be seen in neuron activities and chronic pain. The old methods generally depend on self-report and medical checkup which limits early detection and monitoring of pain. This study done by us proposes that how artificial intelligence (AI) can help to identify the neurological pattern which are generated by electroencephalography (EEG) which is a non-invasive method. EEG signals are collected and processed in such way through a multilevel pipeline which includes noise removal, spectral decomposition and feature extraction of various signal frequency and connectivity measures. Also the machine learning models like Random Forest, Support Vector Machine and deep learning architectures are trained in such way that it can be able to classify the neuropathic versus non-neuropathic states of mind and even calculate the pain level. This finding shows that the flexibility of integrating EEG analytics and AI for having a personalized neuropathy evaluation showing a way toward automated neurodiagnostic systems and continuous disease-progression tracking.

title: A Carrier Frequency Estimation Method Based on Stochastic Resonance Combined with Cyclic Spectrum
authors: Yikun Tong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of carrier frequency estimation for commercial satellite handheld terminal signals in non-cooperative communication scenarios under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. Due to the limited antenna gain of handheld terminals and strong environmental noise, traditional methods struggle to accurately extract frequency features at low SNR. To overcome this, we propose a blind carrier frequency estimation method that combines stochastic resonance with cyclic spectrum analysis. The stochastic resonance module enhances weak signal characteristics, while the cyclic spectrum analysis extracts the discrete spectral lines corresponding to the carrier frequency. An estimation formula based on the spectral peak position is derived. By evaluating the resonance effect using singular value decomposition, the proposed method significantly improves estimation accuracy under complex modulation and low-SNR conditions. Experimental results show that, compared to conventional cyclic spectrum analysis alone, this method more effectively separates and accurately estimates carrier frequencies in noisy environments. It demonstrates greater robustness and general applicability to various modulated signals commonly used in commercial satellite communications.

title: Extension of Unified Predictive Flux Control Through Harmonic Compensation for EESM, IM, PMSM and SyRM
authors: Johannes Stoß, Marc Hiller, Andreas Liske
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper presents an extension of a unified predictive flux control algorithm for induction machines (IMs), externally excited synchronous motors (EESMs), permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs), and synchronous reluctance motors (SyRMs), enabling online compensation of steady-state model errors and spatial harmonics through an integrated repetitive control scheme. Building on the generalized machine model and continuous-control-set model predictive control (MPC) framework established in previous work, a twodimensional, angle-dependent error compensation algorithm is introduced. This allows robust mitigation of harmonics originating from stator winding imperfections, rotor slotting, and inverter nonlinearities while preserving the high dynamic performance and uniformity of the baseline controller. Due to its structure, the proposed approach supports a computationally efficient implementation that remains highly robust without requiring additional data or model knowledge compared to the baseline controller. Experimental validation on a 5.9 kW EESM, a 22 kW IM, and a 169 W PMSM demonstrates almost complete suppression of dominant current harmonics and a significant reduction in Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) under steady-state operation. The results confirm the effectiveness of the unified compensator in handling harmonics and model deviations across diverse machine types.

title: Aquanexus: AI & ML Driven Aquaponics System for Fish and Plant Health Monitoring
authors: R. Geetha, Bhoomika S, Charan Tej B G, Grishma Vadlamudi, Liswin Maria Pereira
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The surge in demand for sustainably food production requires advanced systems that enhance yield while minimizing resource consumption. Aquaponics, which integrates aquaculture and hydroponics in a closed-loop ecosystem, offers an eco-friendly alternative but still relies heavily on manual monitoring. This paper presents an AI-and IOT-driven smart Aquaponics system designed for small-scale deployment, integrating real-time sensing, computer vision, predictive analytics and adaptive control. The system continuously monitors critical water quality parameters, nutrient composition, environmental factors, and visual indicators of plant and fish health. The system combines IoT sensors for tracking water quality and nutrient parameters with computer vision models trained on datasets of fish and plant leaves. A dashboard enables real-time visualization, historical trend analysis, and alerts for abnormal conditions, supporting timely interventions and remote control of system components. By using machine learning to identify diseases in their early stages and predictive analysis, Aquanexus minimizes manual monitoring, enhances system efficiency, and ensures healthier growth of both fish and plants in a sustainable aquaponic environment.

title: Design of a Pulsed Charger Employing Active Ripple Energy Compensation for Electric Vehicle Batteries
authors: Reyyan Ahmad Khan, Sadik Cinik, Asim Ibrahim, Petar J. Grbović, Giuseppe De Falco, Roberto Petrella
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: Pulsed Charging (PC) has recently gained attention as a promising alternative to conventional charging methods due to its potential benefits for battery lifetime extension. The DC/DC converter must be in fact designed to manage the required current pulses, where the instantaneous output power might be much higher than the average power. Correspondingly, its input power should be constant to avoid any pulsation being fed back to the power source, i.e., the grid. Conventionally, bulky storage capacitor at the input side of the DC/DC converter adopted to manage the instantaneous power imbalance, resulting an increase in size, volume and cost. In this work, an Active Ripple Energy Compensator (AREC) is proposed, which connected directly at the DC/DC converter output, i.e., across the battery. Since the storage capacitor is not directly connected to the output, the required storage capacitance can be drastically reduced by intentionally increasing its voltage ripple. Moreover, the proposed PC system is capable of managing a wide output voltage range <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0 0} V \sim \mathbf{9 2 0} V$</tex> to support various battery technologies. Concept, design, and simulation are provided to validate the proposed method and highlight its advantages over conventional solutions.

title: Enhancing Scene Text Images in the Tamil Language using a Two-Stage Text Prior Super Resolution Framework
authors: Jayanthi P, Anusri A, Barath N, Kaviyavikashini M
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: There has been added emphasis on improving scene text images in recent years because of their ubiquitous application in recognition and digitization. This study tackles the issue of improving low-quality Tamil scene text images, which current super-resolution (SR) methods for Latin scripts are unable to address due to the script's complicated morphology. This work introduces a Two-Stage Text Prior Super-Resolution (TTPSR) framework that first implements CNN based unguided SR, and then, the transformed semantic text priors extracted using Tamil OCR are fused through a multi-head cross-attention mechanism. The model is trained on a dataset consisting of 17,500 Tamil text images. Experimental evaluation shows the model outperforms other conventional SR baselines with an average PSNR of 43.04 and SSIM of 0.9918. By the results presented, TTPSR is shown to be an effective and language-aware framework for morphologically rich scripts, and this work paves the way for multilingual super-resolution research.

title: Intelligent Robot for Human Following using Global Positioning System and Arduino
authors: Kanagamalliga S, Vinayagam P, Sabarivasan V, Vignesh R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: An autonomous human-following robot was developed to demonstrate the application of the Global Positioning System (GPS) in mobile robotics. The project was implemented using an Arduino Uno microcontroller, a Neo-6M GPS module, a motor driver, DC motors and a lithium-ion battery to ensure portability and efficiency. The GPS module was used to provide continuous latitude and longitude data, which was processed by Arduino through a navigation algorithm to calculate the relative position of the human target. Based on the processed data, control signals were generated and transmitted to the motor driver for proper movement control of the DC motors, allowing the robot to move towards the human. The system was structured to work in real time, with accurate navigation guaranteed by continuous comparison of current and target coordinates. The developed prototype was successfully tested in outdoor conditions, and it was observed that the robot was capable of following a human being by accurately processing GPS data and executing the necessary movements. Potential applications were identified in smart shopping carts, assistive robots for the elderly, automated transporters in industries and rescue operations. Future improvements have been suggested through the integration of sensors for obstacle avoidance and artificial intelligence.

title: Explainable Dual-Model Framework for Rainfall Anomaly Detection using SHAP-Enhanced Machine Learning
authors: Ridwan Noor Tasin, Md Readus Shalehin, A S M Wasif, Abdullah Bin Murad, Md Raian Ansari, Sudoy Kumer Ghosh
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Extremes in rainfall caused by climate present increasingly serious threats to agricultural economies and water resource systems, but traditional techniques of identifying anomalies remain black and opaque and do not offer an interpretative basis on which policy changes can be made in response to climate. The study introduces a novel two-model design that combines Isolation Forest and Autoencoder models, utilising Shapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) to provide transparency at the feature level and identify hydro-climatic anomalies in 40 years of rainfall data at Rajshahi. In comparison to current methods that focus on predictive accuracy without regard to interpretability, our hybrid consensus model achieves 92% precision, 95% recall, and 94% F1-score, while also demonstrating the effect of a seasonal relationship and time lag, which leads to the development of outliers. The interpretability perspective by SHAP indicates that 78 per cent of the identified anomalies occur during monsoon months, which has a direct correlation with documented floods and sensitive agricultural seasons. This framework addresses the black-box limitations of deep learning climatic models by integrating the strengths of unsupervised learning with clear mechanistic insights, offering actionable intelligence on early warning systems and adaptive hydrological planning in monsoonal basins with limited data.

title: Improving Natural Disaster Surveillance: A Grey Wolf Optimizer-based Approach for Drone Swarms
authors: Anurag Rege, Rounak Paul, Vanusha D, Vathana D, Delsi Robinsha S
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Natural disasters like earthquakes and tsunamis need immediate and effective surveillance methods to assess damage and coordinate rescue operations. The paper proposes a Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO)-based approach for controlling drone swarms to improve disaster surveillance over large geographical areas. The method is based on the hierarchical hunting strategy of grey wolves. The system has an alpha drone to lead the swarm towards high-priority zones requiring detailed monitoring. The beta wolves aim to explore the next best sites for surveillance and the delta wolves follow their lead. The algorithm adjusts drone positions to focus on critical regions, maximizing knowledge and data inflow. A density threshold is kept by the control center to ensure that the drones perform surveillance individually once the major disaster site is located. Additionally, the system can deploy reinforcements based on situational needs ensuring system scalability. This approach aims to improve response efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and provide real-time to support disaster management, mitigation and recovery efforts. The proposed approach ensures better area coverage, consistent convergence and reduced response time compared to other existing bio-inspired approaches. The significance of this approach lies in an effective and optimized surveillance technique.

title: A Comprehensive Review of IoT-Driven Soil Diagnostics and Crop Recommendation Techniques
authors: Pramila S, Sasikala T, Mohammed Sufiyaan Shaikh, Shubhdeep Bali, Keerthi. T, Harsha Bochageri
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Modern agriculture faces the dual challenge of improving crop productivity while ensuring sustainable use of resources. Traditional farming methods often rely on guesswork, which can lead to overuse of water and fertilizers, harming both crops and the environment. This study presents AgroSense, a smart farming solution that combines Internet of Things (IoT) technology with machine learning to support better decision-making for farmers. The system uses a combination of sensors and NodeMCU (ESP8266) microcontrollers to gather real time data on soil temperature, moisture, pH levels, and essential nutrients like nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium (NPK). The collected data is transmitted to Firebase, a cloud platform, where machine learning models process the information to recommend the most suitable crops based on current soil conditions. A user friendly interface, developed using Streamlit, allows farmers to view their soil data and receive crop suggestions through both web and mobile devices. Field tests were conducted in different farming environments to evaluate the system’s effectiveness. Results showed that AgroSense helped reduce unnecessary water usage and minimized fertilizer application while increasing overall crop yields. The system proved to be low-cost and accessible, making it ideal for small and medium-scale farmers. By merging traditional farming knowledge with data-driven insights, AgroSense promotes sustainable agriculture and supports long term food security. This survey highlights the potential of smart farming tools in transforming agriculture into a more efficient and environmentally friendly practice.

title: Multi-Objective Task Mapping in Cloud Environments using Secretary Bird Optimized Quantum Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Jayant Tyagi, Ganga D Benal, Shivareddy Devarapalli, Swapnil M Parikh, Ramya Maranan, M.SivaramKrishnan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Cloud infrastructure is evolving toward increased dynamism, exhibiting volatile workloads and diverse virtual machines. Within this context, multicriteria task scheduling that maximizes efficacy in Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) remains a pervasive, unresolved challenge. Contemporary heuristic and deterministic algorithms struggle to optimally reconcile simultaneous objectives—namely, energy consumption, resource utilization, and makespan. Therefore, the introduction of intelligent, adaptive scheduling frameworks is vital for delivering sustained operational efficiency. We propose a novel multi-objective task mapping scheme, designated QCoNNet-SBirdO, in which a secretary-bird species-inspired optimizer directs a quantum convolutional neural network to schedule cloud workloads. The method commences with comprehensive environment profiling—collecting task dependency matrices, utilization metrics, and power consumption at the hypervisor layer. A priority ranking for both task and virtual-machine (VM) candidates is deduced, and this ranking feeds a Quantum Convolutional Neural Network (QCoNNet) that exploits multidimensional resource interactions. Delegated task-to-VM mapping is subsequently derived via Secretary Bird Optimization (SBirdO), which iteratively refines conductivity and depth measurements until scheduling objectives converge. Outcome allocations undergo a reinforcement-control loop to ingest real-time discrepancies and augment fidelity. Empirical evaluations across heterogeneously provisioned cloud environments indicate that QCoNNet-SBirdO achieves a task prioritization accuracy of 99.2%, a reduction of 38.6% in energy consumption, a decrease of 41.3% in allocated resource requirement, and a 99.7% improvement in mapping velocity when benchmarked against reference heuristics. The results thus corroborate that the QCoNNet-SBirdO framework is both scalable and, in multicriteria terms, decisively superior to contemporary deterministic and meta-heuristic benchmarks across pivotal operational metrics.

title: Addressing the Cold-Start Challenge in Recommendation Systems using SBERT and XGBoost
authors: Ravuri Lalitha, Kokkiligadda Sirisha, Ghanta Trivikram, Gollapalli Seshu, Avala Phanindra
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: In the e-commerce industry, recommendation systems serve an important purpose of enhancing the consumer experience by providing tailored product recommendations. It does pose a massive potential problem in these systems when there’s a cold-start issue, which also makes it hard to issue a recommendation for new users or items when there is no prior interaction-related data. Meanwhile, for improving accuracy, previous models were based on neural collaborative filtering (NCF) and collaborative filtering enhanced by deep learning. These approaches exist to capture the interaction between users and items; based mostly on historical data, they do not address the cold-start condition. Here we propose a novel hybrid model that combines XGBoost and SBERT embeddings in order to circumvent this limitation. By fusing gradient-boosted learning with semantic text representations, pertinent product recommendations can be made even in cold-start scenarios. The suggested model constituted an improvement over the traditional approaches and tested itself to be quite resilient for e-commerce personalization with 97.12% accuracy, 96.38% F1-score, and 99.69% ROC-AUC.

title: A Sustainable Hybrid Energy System for Adaptive Street Lighting in Smart Cities
authors: Thillai Rani M, Amirthapriyan J, Balakumaran S K, Gowtham N, Manikanda Prabu N
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Street lighting consumes a large part of energy in modern cities, but the kinetic energy from human footsteps usually goes to waste. In this work, we propose a smart hybrid harvesting system that combines piezoelectric plates with a rack-and-pinion-type electromagnetic dynamo. Unlike most existing works that depend on only a single method, our design uses two methods together to extract more energy from every single step. The produced power is then passed through a conditioning circuit so that it becomes stable and can be stored in a rechargeable battery. This stored energy is used for powering intelligent LED street lamps, which can automatically adjust their brightness whenever they detect movement nearby, thus saving more power. A microcontroller unit is also added for monitoring and recording the harvested energy data, which is very useful for smart city analysis and planning. From earlier studies, it is seen that piezoelectric floors are simple but generate less power, while electromagnetic approaches yield a higher output but can disturb walking comfort. Our hybrid model attempts to overcome these issues by combining the strengths of both techniques, providing a more sustainable and efficient solution for future urban lighting.

title: Handheld Device for Automatic Number Plate Recognition
authors: Mithilesh K, Shanthi K, Keerthivasan S, Mohamed Aadil M A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This paper introduces a cloud-assisted and inexpensive Automatic Number Plate Recognition (ANPR) solution based on edge computing on the ESP32-CAM microcontroller for real-time identification of vehicles. As the need for scalable and inexpensive surveillance continues to expand across urban and semi-urban regions, the solution eliminates the reliance on high-end computing facilities. The solution combines the use of ESP32-CAM for image capture, YOLOv8 for vehicle and number plate detection, and PaddleOCR for optical character detection, with successful recognition on resource-light hardware. Google Cloud Platform (GCP)-based cloud connectivity offers remote access to data, real-time surveillance, as well as centralized storage for smart city applications. Simulation testing proves to demonstrate an average accuracy of detection as 85% and recognition as 80%, with a mean latency of 580 ms processing, ensuring real-time compatibility. The overall cost of the entire system remains under ₹1500, promoting high deployability across parking systems, gated societies, as well as school campus surveillance. This study presents evidence of a costeffective, lightweight, as well as scalable IoT-based ANPR solution that facilitates intelligent roadways as well as environmentally friendly smart infrastructure development.

title: Automatic Snacks Weighing and Packaging Machine
authors: K.Prabhu, S.Vijayachitra, B.Pavithra, R.A.Sabareeshwaran, T.S.Subhash
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This research shows the construction of the automated weighing and packaging machine limited to small industries. The weighing system employs a load cell together with an HX711 amplifier and control logic is managed using an ESP32 microcontroller. An operation can be started using a push button and information can be relayed using 16x2 LCDs in real-time. Material dispensing is enabled using a servo motor controlled for hopper opening and closing. The target servo now closes the hopper, after which the packaging operation is performed pneumatically. Effective and reliable packaging automation with minimal human intervention is probable owing to the combination of the sensors, the servo motor, and the pneumatic system at the machine’s compositional level. The design provided has a minimal footprint which makes it cost effective while also maintaning compatibility for implementation automation in snack or powder - based product packaging systems.

title: Efficient Task Allocation in Heterogeneous Cloud–Edge Environments via Optimized Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Nagendar Yamsani, Chenna Reddy P
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) applications are growing so fast that they need reliable scheduling of tasks in different cloud-edge environments to reduce latency and energy consumption. On the other hand, the differences in resources and the changes in network conditions challenge the easy allocation of workloads to a great extent. To address this difficulty, a cloud-edge collaborative computing system based on an optimized deep reinforcement learning controller has been developed. After that, a system QoS paradigm was developed that takes into account the advantages of both service providers and users. A collaborative task allocation approach based on deep reinforcement learning has been suggested to dynamically optimize the goal system utility using a deep reinforcement approach. The parameters are optimized by the Side Botched Lizard Optimization algorithm (SBLOA). Lastly, results from experiments show that the suggested approach can learn the computational expenses of cloud and edge cloud and the communication cost between many edge clouds. Additionally, the suggested approach has improved system utility by 10% when compared to cloud computing, random computing, and Q-table learning. These results support that the optimized DRL-SBLOA framework gives a scalable and energy-efficient solution for real-time task scheduling in complex cloud– edge environments.

title: Fake News Detection Using Machine Learning
authors: Deshagowni Meghana, Bamandla Ajay Mahadev, Baki Vinay Kumar, A. Vijaya Lakshmi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: False news detection using text classification technology has many real-world uses in addition to significant research value. However, current methods frequently overlook inter-article influence and suffer from class imbalance in datasets that contain misleading information. A hybrid framework that uses Electra embeddings for contextual representation, a Multi-Scale Recurrent Convolutional Neural Network (MSRCNN) for hierarchical feature extraction, and a self-attention module to model inter-article dependencies is proposed in this paper to address these issues. While focal loss lessens class imbalance during training, adaptive gated residual connections (AGRC) are used to enhance gradient flow and lessen noise propagation. The suggested AGC-RCNN continuously beats recent transformer-based models and traditional baselines (such as SVM and CNN-LSTM) in terms of overall accuracy, recall, and robustness, according to experiments conducted on publicly accessible fake news datasets [2], [5]–[7]. The model provides a scalable and interpretable solution for real-world misinformation detection, and its design also fits with current trends towards multimodal and explainable fake news detection frameworks [10]–[15].

title: Explainable Artificial Intelligence Frameworks for User-Centered Product Design
authors: Behara Venkata Nandakishore, Desidi Narsimha Reddy
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) frameworks are increasingly recognized as an essential method for ensuring transparency and user trust in AI-based product design. Traditional machine learning models are often treated as "black boxes", which generates uncertainty regarding the reasoning behind their actions. This paper describes an XAI framework that focuses on user-centered design that included techniques for interpretable machine learning. The use of SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) values allows designers and stakeholders to see what factors are leading to the AI-driven recommendations. The study uses the Red Wine Quality dataset as an example of using explainability as part of the decision-making process that allows for transparency (in the form of an explanation) and usability. The results provide insights into the impact of variable importance on quality prediction for the wine, which will enhance ethical, unbiased, and user-focused innovations.
