title: Differentiable Obstacle Avoidance Framework for Robot Safety
authors: Louis Fernandez, Sheila Sutjipto, Victor Hernandez Moreno, Anh Minh Tu, Marc G. Carmichael
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Obstacle avoidance is a fundamental requirement for safe and reliable robot operation. Due to the lack of techniques capable of efficiently and accurately computing volumetric distances and their derivatives, many obstacle avoidance frameworks neglect the volumetric characteristics of objects by using points or spheres as the choice of object representation. To overcome this, an optimisation-based method is used in this paper to accurately compute the minimum distance between convex shapes. In order to enable integration with gradient-based obstacle avoidance algorithms, a method that calculates the gradient of the minimum distance is introduced. This information is incorporated into a Quadratic Program to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for online obstacle avoidance. In contrast to methods that rely on closed-form expressions, the proposed framework leverages optimisation to simultaneously compute pairwise distances between multiple convex shapes. Simulation results, averaged over 1000 runs, demonstrate that the proposed approach completes tasks more accurately and consistently, improving trajectory tracking accuracy by up to 35% compared to the state-of-the-art baseline. The proposed framework is further validated on a physical robot system, confirming its practical applicability and robustness on real hardware.

title: Maximizing Revenue for Reliability-Aware Edge Application Deployment_supp1-3659644.pdf
authors: Fu Xiao
publish: N/A
abstract: Multiaccess edge computing (MEC) enables low-latency service delivery by deploying application instances on edge servers. However, edge servers are prone to failures, making it challenging to meet diverse user reliability requirements. A common approach is to deploy redundant instances across multiple edge servers, which improves reliability but increases costs and limits the number of users that can be served within budget. Therefore, efficient deployment strategies are needed to balance cost-effectiveness and reliability guarantees, thereby maximizing the app vendor’s revenue. In this article, we investigate the problem of <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</u>evenue maximization for <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">R</u>eliability-aware <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">E</u>dge <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">A</u>pplication <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</u>eployment (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{R}^{2}\text{EAD}$</tex-math></inline-formula>). Our objective is to maximize the app vendor’s revenue by deploying its applications on heterogeneous edge servers, subject to budget and resource constraints and users’ diverse reliability requirements. We prove that the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{R}^{2}\text{EAD}$</tex-math></inline-formula> problem is <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathcal {\text{NP}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-hard and propose an efficient approximation algorithm named <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{R}^{2}\text{EAD}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-A. By reducing the problem to a nonmonotone submodular maximization problem with curvature <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\alpha$</tex-math></inline-formula> under multiple knapsack constraints, we prove that <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{R}^{2}\text{EAD}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-A achieves a constant approximation ratio of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\frac{1}{\alpha }(1 - e^{-\alpha })$</tex-math></inline-formula>. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\text{R}^{2}\text{EAD}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-A outperforms the representative approaches across all tested cases.

title: GPR-Net: Geometric-Positional Collaborative Point Cloud Registration Network for Repetitive Ge-ometric Structures
authors: Xiaohui Lu, Jianhu Nie
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Point cloud registration is a critical task for building complete 3D models. Existing registration methods primarily focus on correspondence relationships between points, often using local geometric features to determine matches. However, this approach generates numerous false matches in scenes with repetitive geometric features due to similar structures. To address this, we propose GPR-Net, a collaborative correspondence discrimination network combining geometric and positional features of points. This method constructs a geometry branch using Dynamic Graph CNN (DGCNN) to extract multi-scale local features, while introducing a position branch to encode global spatial distributions. It employs a collaborative discrimination mechanism to select point pairs exhibiting both geometric similarity and spatial consistency. The main contributions of this work are threefold: (1) we design a dual-branch framework that integrates geometric and positional features for robust correspondence discrimination; (2) we introduce contrastive constraints in both branches to enhance feature distinctiveness and reduce mismatches in repetitive structures; (3) we demonstrate superior registration results compared to state-of-the-art descriptors through extensive experiments on ModelNet40 and noisy datasets. Experiments show our method effectively counteracts interference from similar structures, outperforming mainstream feature descriptors in registration accuracy and robustness within repetitive geometric feature scenes.

title: A Constraint Relaxation Co-Evolutionary Algorithm for the Two-Echelon Vehicle Routing Problem With Load-Dependent Drones_supp1-3658745.pdf
authors: Qun Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: The growing adoption of drones in last-mile logistics has raised urgent demands for controlling energy consumption costs while ensuring delivery efficiency. To address this, we formulate the Two-Echelon Vehicle Routing Problem with Load-dependent Drones (2E-VRPLD) within a depot-satellite-customer framework, which reflects realistic logistics conditions where drones experience continuously changing payloads as they pick up and deliver parcels. These load fluctuations cause discrete shifts in power consumption, making their actual flight endurance highly uncertain under a fixed energy budget and thereby significantly increasing the complexity of planning feasible routes and minimizing overall transportation costs. To solve this complex VRP variant, we develop a novel Constraint Relaxation Co-evolutionary Algorithm (CRCEA) that integrates a customer-satellite matching mechanism to minimize drone endurance redundancy and a minimal impact assessment strategy for route segment merging. Experiments show that CRCEA attains nearly negligible optimality gaps relative to Gurobi on small-scale instances, significantly outperforms seven representative heuristics on large-scale instances, and consistently delivers superior solutions in real-world delivery scenarios from leading express carriers JD and SF Express in Changsha, China. Furthermore, ablation studies identify key factors affecting algorithmic performance, and sensitivity analyses illustrate how drone performance parameters influence the efficiency of solving the 2E-VRPLD. This work provides a robust theoretical and practical approach for solving the two-echelon pickup-and-delivery routing problem with load-dependent drones, offering important insights for advancing smart logistics and improving enterprise operational efficiency.

title: A Novel Lightweight Hybrid GAN-Transformer Architecture for Sand-Dust and Haze Image Enhancement
authors: Muhammad Khawaja Kashif Masood, Pablo Otero
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Images captured under severe environmental degradation, such as sand, dust, and haze, significantly reduce the performance of vision-based systems, including autonomous vehicles, surveillance platforms, remote sensing missions, UAVs, and other computer vision applications. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a GTD (Generator–Transformer–Discriminator) hybrid architecture for sand-dust and haze image enhancement, designed to handle multi-scale hierarchical distortions that affect both local textures and global color distributions. The proposed framework integrates lightweight generative modules for local feature extraction with Transformer-based global feature modelling. Specifically, the conventional encoder is replaced by three parallel generator–Transformer pathways operating on full-, half-, and quarter-resolution inputs, enabling effective representation of degradations across different receptive fields. Features at each scale are refined using attention fusion blocks that incorporate channel-wise and spatial attention mechanisms, followed by adaptive multi-scale feature combination and a unified discriminator for image restoration. The model is trained using a composite loss function consisting of adversarial, perceptual, L1, and SSIM losses. Experimental evaluations on sand-dust and haze datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves consistent improvements in terms of PSNR, SSIM, DSSIM, CIE94, visual quality, inference speed, and computational efficiency when compared with representative benchmark methods. In addition, an Energy Efficiency Index (EEI) is introduced to assess the trade-off between restoration quality and energy consumption. Owing to its lightweight design and efficient inference, the proposed framework is suitable for real-time and embedded vision applications operating under challenging environmental conditions.

title: EMPM: Embodied MPM for Modeling and Simulation of Deformable Objects
authors: Yunuo Chen, Yafei Hu, Lingfeng Sun, Tushar Kusnur, Laura Herlant, Chenfanfu Jiang
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Modeling deformable objects – especially continuum materials – in a way that is physically plausible, generalizable, and data-efficient remains challenging across 3D vision, graphics, and robotic manipulation. Many existing methods oversimplify the rich dynamics of deformable objects or require large training sets, which often limits generalization. We introduce embodied MPM (EMPM), a deformable object modeling and simulation framework built on a differentiable Material Point Method (MPM) simulator that captures the dynamics of challenging materials. From multi-view RGB-D videos, our approach reconstructs geometry and appearance, then uses an MPM physics engine to simulate object behavior by minimizing the mismatch between predicted and observed visual data. We further optimize MPM parameters online using sensory feedback, enabling adaptive, robust, and physics-aware object representations that open new possibilities for robotic manipulation of complex deformables. Experiments show that EMPM outperforms spring-mass and learning-based baseline models. Project website: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://embodied-mpm.github.io</uri>.

title: OnMAXFlow: Link-Aware Online Maximum Flow for Hybrid Ambient Backscatter Wireless Networks
authors: Lanhua Li, Xiaoxia Huang, Xiaoyang He, Shimin Gong, Wanquan Liu, Yuguang Fang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing
abstract: Sporadic ambient radio frequency signals can offer opportunistic spectrum and energy sources for backscatter communications, but they also induce unpredictable transmission interruptions in ambient backscatter wireless networks (AmBWNs). Integrating self-carrier-generative active transmissions with backscatter communications could significantly enhance transmission stability but require frequent mode switching to accommodate the ever-changing ambient radio frequency signals. However, this will result in frequent changes in network topology and link capacity, posing significant challenges in solving the network maximum flow problem in hybrid AmBWNs. To address this problem, we design a link-aware online maximum flow (OnMAXFlow) scheme to tackle agile and adaptive flow scheduling and communication mode selection. Specifically, we first employ an online learning framework to dynamically track changes in ambient signal strength and channel states, enabling real-time evaluation of link capacity. We then model the network maximum flow problem as a stochastic multi-armed bandit (MAB) problem and solve it with a Kullback-Leibler upper confidence bound (KL-UCB) algorithm. Our experimental evaluation results reveal that our OnMAXFlow scheme exhibits rapid convergence and superior adaptability against the varying network states, while maintaining spectrum efficiency and latency performance comparable to the Oracle scheme, which always selects the optimal transmission modes and paths.

title: WEMA-VINS: Visual-Inertial SLAM With ELSED-MIS Line Filtering
authors: Linhan Yuan, Guoliang Liu, Yingxiu Li, Guohui Tian, Mingkun Liu, Huang Dai
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are widely used in various fields due to their flexibility and maneuverability. However, for UAV systems that rely solely on point features, weak-texture environments cause a decline in pose estimation accuracy, creating a severe localization challenge. The fusion of line and point features introduces more geometric constraints, enhancing system robustness and localization accuracy. This letter presents a lightweight monocular visual-inertial SLAM framework, WEMA-VINS (Weak-grid ELSED MIS-filtered and Angular-constrained VINS), designed for robust point-line fusion. It integrates weak-texture region elimination, ELSED line detection, Maximum Independent Set (MIS)-based pruning of redundant segments, and an angular-constrained line optimization module. Our proposed framework collectively improves point feature quality, preserves structural line information, and enhances robustness against endpoint drift and partial occlusion, leading to reliable point-line fusion and efficient state estimation. Extensive experiments on the KAIST VIO and EuRoC datasets demonstrate that WEMA-VINS significantly improves both localization accuracy and robustness, consistently achieving leading performance over recent point-line SLAM baselines while maintaining real-time efficiency.

title: Energy-Aware Application Life-Cycle Management in Cloud Edge Computing Continuum Using Applications Profiles
authors: Mohamed Mekki, Adlen Ksentini, Miloud Bagaa
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Efficient management of an application's life-cycle on a Cloud Edge Computing Continuum (CECC) infrastructure requires knowledge about: (i) the application behavior as well as its requirements in terms of compute and network resources evolution over time; (ii) information about the state and characteristics of the infrastructure, including its produced carbon footprint. In this paper, we propose an architecture for the CECC Application Orchestrator to efficiently handle the application's life cycle by designing and relying on applications and infrastructure profiling, which is done using monitoring information, including energy metrics and carbon intensity of infrastructures. First, we define a modeling method for application profiles, which represent the application's current and future compute and network requirements. Second, we model the problem of selecting the best locations to deploy or migrate applications while minimizing the deployment's cost and the carbon footprint. The model decides the current and future placements of each application and its allocated resources based on the application profile, the availability constraints of the application, and the available infrastructure resources. Last, we propose a heuristic solution to solve the problem rapidly, and we compare the different trade-offs between carbon and cost efficiency.

title: Fast Electrical Impedance Tomography with Hybrid Priors
authors: Shuaikai Shi, Ruiyuan Kang, Panos Liatsis
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Imaging
abstract: Electrical impedance tomography (EIT) is a non-ionizing and non-invasive imaging technique that reconstructs the electrical conductivity patterns within an object. Due to its low cost, real-time nature and portability, it is popular in a variety of applications ranging from medical imaging to industrial monitoring and geoscience. When electrical currents are injected, EIT reveals the internal conductivity distribution through boundary voltage measurements. However, EIT image reconstruction is an ill-posed problem due to the significant disparity between sparse boundary voltage measurements and the desired high-resolution conductivity images. Both conventional and deep learning approaches have been developed to address this challenge, primarily through spatial regularization and image regression techniques. While conventional methods employing regularizers can generate physically plausible conductivity distributions, their linear nature often limits reconstruction accuracy. Deep learning models achieve superior results but require substantial training datasets. In this work, we propose a novel iterative conductivity image reconstruction method for EIT, termed PnPEIT, which integrates both handcrafted and plug-and-play (PnP) priors within the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) framework. Specifically, the objective function of PnPEIT contains the voltage reconstruction error and a sparse constraint, a graph regularization, and a PnP prior to the conductivity images. Next, the PnP prior term is optimized by a denoising operator and implemented by block-matching and 3D filtering (BM3D) or pre-trained denoising networks. Through alternating iterations, the algorithm converges rapidly and the desired conductivity image is obtained. Moreover, we provide a simple proof that the graph Laplacian regularization is not only equivalent to the non-local means denoising algorithm, but also accelerates convergence. Experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets emphasize the advantage of the proposed method over traditional and cutting-edge EIT image reconstruction approaches. The source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/shuaikaishi/PnPEIT</uri>.

title: Recovery of JunoCam by Annealing in the Jovian Radiation Environment
authors: Jacob Schaffner, Michael Caplinger, Michael Ravine, Soren N. Madsen, Andrew Berkun, Bernard Rax, Matt Johnson, Erick Sturm, Candice Hansen, Leslie Lipkaman Vittling, Daniel Krysak, Jennifer Delavan, Halil Yonter, Scott Bolton
publish: IEEE Transactions on Nuclear Science
abstract: Juno’s JunoCam instrument has been exposed to the Jovian radiation environment for over nine years. It survived the Juno primary mission with little degradation, but during the extended mission has suffered two different radiation-induced problems, the first involving a start-up issue with a linear regulator and the second involving CCD image sensor performance. Both anomalies were overcome with high-temperature annealing. Here we describe the sequence of events and our subsequent responses to maintain instrument functionality, through orbit 57 and beyond. The JunoCam experience may inform the design of heating systems for future spacecraft headed to high-radiation environments, as well as the operations flows needed to call upon them quickly and flexibly for annealing in a spacecraft emergency or for periodic preventative annealing cycles.

title: An adaptive joint alignment method of angle misalignment and seafloor transponder for Ultrashort baseline underwater positioning
authors: Zhen Sun, Tengfei Wang, Zhenjie Wang, Mingquan Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Ultrashort baseline (USBL) underwater positioning techniques are widely used to provide location-based services for unmanned underwater vehicles. Angle misalignment is a primary source of error that reduces the accuracy of USBL positioning. The conventional least squares (LS) alignment method assumes that the position of the seafloor transponder, which is derived from global navigation satellite system/acoustic (GNSS/A) underwater positioning, can be determined without error and that the alignment observations are independent. However, errors inevitably occur in the estimation of the transponder position by GNSS/A positioning, and the precision varies in three dimensions. Owing to geometric constraints, the observations are statistically correlated rather than independent. Ignoring these assumptions significantly reduces the precision of angle misalignment estimation. In this contribution, we propose an adaptive joint alignment (AJA) method, where both angle misalignment and the position of the seafloor transponder are treated as unknown parameters. The raw USBL data, including the acoustic range and bearing angle, are treated as observations, whereas the position of the seafloor transponder is treated as a virtual observation. An adaptive weighting factor derived from the maximum likelihood estimator is introduced to balance the contributions of the real and virtual observations to parameter estimation. Simulation results show that the proposed method improves angle misalignment estimation accuracy by 61.61% and 48.06% relative to the LS and two-step nonlinear Gauss–Markov (TSNGM) methods, respectively. Sea-trial results, evaluated in terms of USBL positioning accuracy, show that the AJA method achieves improvements of 66.02%–68.15% over the uncalibrated USBL system and 8.07%–10.08% over the LS method.

title: A Multi-Kernel Higher-order Moment Matching Joint Domain Adaptive Network for Cross-Domain Mechanical Fault Diagnosis
authors: Jingya Yang, Limei Yan, Jianjun Xu, Weiming Zeng, Cheng Peng, Shuqi Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: With the deepening advancement of smart manufacturing, regular fault diagnosis plays a crucial role in optimizing productivity and maintaining equipment safety and stability. Joint domain adaptation (JDA) techniques for fault diagnosis have garnered significant attention; however, their ability to characterize nonlinear, high-dimensional features remains limited. Additionally, low pseudo-label confidence levels result in insufficient distribution alignment, leading to domain drift that compromises cross-domain fault diagnosis performance. Based on this, this paper proposes a multi-kernel higher-order moment matching joint domain adaptive network (MKHoJDA) for cross-domain mechanical fault diagnosis. Firstly, a multi-scale dilatable residual convolution (MDRC) module is proposed to extract transferable features from both the source and target domains more accurately. Secondly, to address the limitation of traditional JDA in statistically measuring higher-order features, a multi-kernel higher-order moment matching (MKHoMM) statistical metric strategy is designed. Multiple kernel functions are combined to create a more expressive composite kernel, enhancing the power of feature mappings, reducing distribution discrepancies between domains. Additionally, to address the dependency of conditional distribution alignment (CDA) on pseudo-label accuracy, a prototype-aware pseudo-label feedback (PPF) mechanism was developed. This mechanism evaluates sample confidence using Jensen-Shannon (JS) divergence, selects high-confidence target domain samples for pseudo-label generation, and dynamically updates prototype centers. This approach effectively mitigates the negative impact of pseudo-labels while improving CDA performance. Finally, multiple cross-domain fault diagnosis experiments were conducted on the JNU and PU datasets. The average accuracy significantly surpassed that of other advanced comparative models, demonstrating that the proposed algorithm effectively mitigates the impact of data distribution differences and exhibits exceptional cross-domain fault diagnosis performance.

title: Pill-MSVAE: A Multi-Scale Variational Autoencoder Based on the Internet of Things for Accurate Automatic Drug Identification and Monitoring
authors: Weihua Wang, Xiaoqian Jing, Songyao Jiang, Yi Han
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Pill recognition is critical for preventing medication misuse and ensuring patient safety, yet it remains challenging due to the growing number of pharmaceutical products and their highly similar visual appearances. Existing pill recognition methods often rely on single-scale feature representations and deterministic models, which limits their robustness and generalization under complex imaging conditions such as blur, illumination variation, and pill wear. To address these limitations, we propose an IoT-based Multi-Scale Variational Autoencoder (Pill-MSVAE) for automatic pill image recognition. The proposed framework integrates convolutional neural networks and Transformers to jointly capture local texture details and global structural information, while variational encoding with reconstruction constraints enhances feature robustness and generalization. Extensive experiments on a public pill image dataset show that Pill-MSVAE achieves an F1-score of 0.9718, Accuracy of 0.9716, Precision of 0.9727, and AUC of 0.9989, consistently outperforming state-of-the-art methods across all evaluation metrics. These results validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach for reliable pill recognition and highlight its potential for practical deployment in IoT-enabled healthcare and medication management systems.

title: LogBoost: Boost Log Anomaly Detection by Cherry-Picking Log Sequences
authors: Min Li, Xiaoyun Li, Pengfei Chen, Yuanhao Lai, Zibin Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Services Computing
abstract: Debugging and operating services always benefit from logs. Since logs provide rich information on events and render comprehensive execution traces, it is imperative to automatically detect faults from extensive logs through log-based anomaly detection. However, due to the ineffectiveness and complexity of log-based detection models, they have not been widely adopted in template evaluation and real-world detection. Therefore, we propose LogBoost, a lightweight framework to boost log-based anomaly detection by automatically reducing redundant log templates. Based on our proposed similarity measurement, it effectively sorts the importance of log templates and identifies templates that are ineffective in anomaly detection. In evaluation, we introduce Spark-SDA, a new dataset featuring more diverse log templates and excessively long sequences, alongside the HDFS log dataset. We further evaluate LogBoost using established log-based anomaly detection models. The results demonstrate that eliminating ineffective log templates via LogBoost improves feature efficacy while reducing computational overhead. For instance, RandomForest obtains an F1-score at 0.983 given only 500 training samples on an optimized frequency vector of the HDFS dataset. Meanwhile, the lengths of log sequences are reduced by 51% to 77%, and the prediction time of deep learning models is reduced by 55% to 81%. Our results show that LogBoost is an effective approach to accelerate log-based anomaly detection.

title: Integration of Distributed Localization and Formation of MASs Based on Local Bearing Measurement
authors: Yunkai Lv, Huaicheng Yan, Xiaofeng Zhao, Kai Rao, Youmin Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: This work investigates the localizability and controllability of local-bearing-based multi-agent systems under directed graph and develops the integrated distributed localization and formation scheme. Based on local-bearing measurement, a novel prescribed-time orientation estimation algorithm is designed to ensure that the local reference frame of the follower agent is aligned with the global one. The local bearing information is more easily obtained than global one. Therefore, the new orientation estimation result is expected to be more widely applicable. The orientation estimation result is then applied to the stationary and moving target formation with unknown initial positions, two prescribed-time distributed formation control schemes are developed. The distinctive advantage of this work is that only the local bearing information is used, the fast and controllable localization estimation and formation control are achieved simultaneously. The global convergence is derived based on the cascade system and the mathematical induction method. Numerical simulations and crazyfiles experiments are provided to prove the applicability of the theoretical results.

title: A Multi-Objective Optimization Method for UI Interfaces Integrating NSGA-II and Simulated Annealing
authors: Zhichao Ma, Xu Han, Zhuolei Wang, Diyu Zhou, Yuxuan Li
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Traditional user interface layout design heavily relies on designers' subjective judgment and lacks effective quantitative assessment methods. This study aims to overcome this shortcoming. Therefore, this paper proposes a multi-objective optimization (MOO) system designed for the low-fidelity prototyping phase to enable faster production of high-quality interface layouts. A hybrid algorithm (SNSGA-II) is designed in the system, which combines the Non-Dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) and the simulated annealing (SA) algorithm, along with a scoring system including both esthetics and usability. During the high-temperature phase, the SA algorithm is responsible for global exploration, while the genetic algorithm is introduced during the low-temperature phase for refined optimization, combined with an improved sigmoid function to dynamically balance the weights of each evaluation dimension. The experimental results show that this system achieved significant optimization effects across three UI design tasks with varying complexity levels. Compared with traditional NSGA-II algorithm, the SNSGA-II algorithm demonstrated approximately 50% improvement in convergence speed. Evaluation by 20 professional UI designers showed that system-optimized designs exhibited consistent improvements across all complexity levels: overall design quality enhanced by 3.0%, 6.7%, and 6.5% for simple, moderate, and complex tasks respectively; esthetic scores correspondingly increased by 5.6%, 5.7%, and 5.2%; learnability indicators improved by 4.1%, 6.1%, and 7.2% respectively. This study confirmed the effectiveness of this approach in balancing esthetics and usability, demonstrating its algorithmic performance and practical optimization potential.

title: Assessment of Capacitorless DRAM Based on Stacked Nanosheet Feedback Field-Effect Transistors With Tree-Type Channel
authors: Yuhao Zhou, Xinyu Zou, Yang Shen, Yuhang Zhang, Bingyi Ye, Xiaojin Li, Ziyu Liu, Yabin Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: In this study, a novel vertically stacked nanosheet (NS) feedback field-effect transistor with tree-type channel (Tree-FBFET) is proposed for one-transistor dynamic random access memory (1T-DRAM) application. Compared with the conventional NS channel structure, an additional SiGe interbridge (IB) channel is vertically integrated in Tree-FBFET. The enhanced performance of Tree-FBFET stems from additional SiGe storage region which is recognized as the SiGe channel. The Tree-FBFET based 1T-DRAM shows an improvement of 2.8 times in sensing margin (SM) (from 126 to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$351~\boldsymbol {\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>A/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>m) and extends retention time (RT) from 0.6 to 32 s compared to 1T-DRAM based on conventional vertically stacked NS-FBFET. Moreover, the energy consumption is 35 fJ/bit for the write “1” operation and 0 fJ/bit for the hold operation. Geometric parameters of IB and NS, along with Ge mole fraction, are evaluated with respect to SM and RT. Furthermore, reliable <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\times 3$</tex-math> </inline-formula> array operation of the proposed 1T-DRAM, free from disturbance of write operation, is also verified.

title: Virtual-Flux Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control for Four-Phase H-Bridge Based SRM Drives
authors: Raúl Intriago, Gabriel Intriago, João P. Carvalho Silveira, Rolando R. Caicedo Castro, Tárcio André dos S. Barros, Marcelo Vinícius de Paula
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper implements a Virtual-Flux Finite Control Set Model Predictive Control (VF-FCS-MPC) strategy for fourphase H-bridge-based Switched Reluctance Motor (SRM) drives capable of bidirectional phase current operation. The proposed method leverages virtual stator flux estimation while achieving precise speed control. Incorporating bidirectional phase current minimizes conduction and commutation losses on power devices with minimal effect on the system efficiency. The VF-FCS-MPC optimally selects switching states from the discrete space of the H-bridge inverter to maintain precise virtual stator flux control. Additionally, the adopted converter topology provides inherent fault tolerance, making it suitable for demanding applications such as electric vehicles. Simulation results confirm the proposed strategy's effectiveness in speed control performance and a reduction of torque ripple <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(36 \%)$</tex> when compared to hysteresis.

title: Automating Personalized Email Outreach: A LangChain–LLaMA Framework with ChromaDB and Groq Cloud
authors: Vijay M, T. Bhavana, C. Pranavi, N. Hasika Sethu, K. Prashsanth
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: In the modern sales ecosystem, email outreach remains a cornerstone for lead generation and client engagement. However, manually crafting personalized cold emails at scale is time-consuming and prone to inconsistencies. This study presents an end-to-end intelligent Cold Email Generator leveraging LLaMA 3.1, a state-of-the-art large language model (LLM), to automate and optimize the generation of cold emails. The system integrates LangChain for modular prompt chaining, ChromaDB as a vector store for context-aware retrieval, and Streamlit for a user-friendly front-end interface. This architecture enables real-time, contextually relevant, and customizable email generation tailored to specific industries, roles, and use cases. Furthermore, by deploying the model through the Groq Cloud, the system ensures high-throughput inference without local computational overhead. This paper outlines the system architecture, implementation, and performance evaluation, demonstrating the model’s effectiveness in generating high-quality personalized outreach content. The proposed solution offers a scalable and domain-adaptable tool for B2B marketing teams, significantly improving operational efficiency and response rates in cold-outreach campaigns.

title: Parameter Design of a DC-Link Inertia-Emulating Control Strategy for Grid-Connected Inverters
authors: Yunuo Yuan, Lingjun Yao, Yongheng Yang, Yinzhang Peng, Wenxin Li, Jinlong Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE 10th Southern Power Electronics Conference (SPEC)
abstract: This paper proposes a systematic parameter design method for a grid-forming (GFM) inverter adopting matching control. A small-signal model of the active power control loop is derived, and the control parameters are selected based on gain margin and phase margin (PM) requirements. By introducing analytical constraints, a feasible parameter region is identified, providing practical guidance for parameter tuning. More specifically, the Bode plot exhibits a low-frequency dou-ble-integrator ensuring zero steady-state error, a mid-frequency phase-lead introduced by the zero determined by the control coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K_{T}$</tex> that enhances dynamics, and a high-frequency region dominated by a real pole that introduces phase lag and strengthens high-frequency attenuation. This structure enables flexible shaping of the crossover frequency and PM, achieving the balance between stability, dynamics, and disturbance rejection. Simulations validate the inverter can accurately track active power reference steps and respond rapidly to grid frequency disturbances when adopting the designed parameters.

title: Generative AI-based Framework for Fraud Detection and Prevention in Online Payment Systems
authors: Rani Venkata Satya Praveen, Satya Subrahmanya Sai Ram Gopal, Harikrishna Vemuri, Sriharsha Sista, RaviTeja Aida, Srinikhil Saisatya Vemuri
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The escalating menace of financial fraud has emerged as a significant issue in the contemporary digitally interconnected landscape, particularly with the proliferation of e-commerce and online payment mechanisms. Fraudulent activities, especially in credit and payment card transactions, have increased significantly, leading both public and private sectors to invest substantially in research and development aimed at fraud detection and prevention in online transactions. This paper presents a comprehensive strategy that initiates with a rigorous data preprocessing pipeline to manage missing values, eliminate outliers, and normalise the dataset through undersampling approaches. Fraud indicators are derived using dimensionality reduction, and the Improved Red Piranha Optimisation (IRPO) algorithm is utilised to optimise feature selection. A hybrid spatial-temporal feature space is created by amalgamating datasets from several sources, including sensors and services. Multiple deep learning algorithms, such as LSTM, GRU, and a hybrid LSTGR model, are subsequently employed on time-series geographic data for the purpose of fraud detection. The hybrid LSTGR model exhibited exceptional performance, with an accuracy of 99.08%. The results underscore the efficacy of integrating advanced preprocessing, optimisation, and deep learning methodologies for precise and efficient fraud detection and prevention in online financial transactions.

title: Advancing Sleep Apnea Detection with Efficient and Multi-Scale Hybrid Deep Learning Architectures on Single-Lead ECG
authors: Mohamed Saajid S, Noel Biju Daniel, Mary Angeline J
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Sleep apnea is a common sleep disorder that requires accurate and accessible monitoring. Undiagnosed sleep apnea can lead to serious cardiovascular and metabolic complications, highlighting the need for efficient automated detection. But many deep learning solutions remain too computationally heavy for practical wearable deployment. This study proposes four novel, high-efficiency hybrid models for sleep apnea detection from single-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) signals. We designed custom 1D convolutional backbones inspired by InceptionNet and EfficientNet and combined them with Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) to capture multi-scale morphology and temporal dynamics. Inputs are minute-long single-lead ECG windows represented as R–R intervals and R-peak amplitudes, preprocessed to fixed-length sequences. Models were evaluated using a stratified 5-fold cross-validation framework on the public PhysioNet Apnea-ECG database. The InceptionNet-GRU architecture achieved the best detection performance (88.17% accuracy and F1 score of 84.53%), while model sizes remained lightweight (245k–795k parameters). These results demonstrate that customized 1D-CNN + GRU designs can deliver a strong accuracy–efficiency tradeoff suitable for accurate, real-time sleep apnea monitoring on resource-constrained devices.

title: From Structure to Behavior: Enhancing Criminal Network Analysis with Embedded Modus Operandi Graphs
authors: Lakshay Kumar A, Mohammed Aariz M, Hemalatha R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Criminal network analysis has predominantly relied on structural metrics to identify key actors and predict net-work vulnerabilities. However, behavioral patterns and modus operandi (MO) provide crucial insights that structural analysis alone cannot capture. This paper introduces a novel framework that combines graph embeddings with behavioral pattern analysis to enhance criminal network disruption strategies. We generate synthetic criminal networks with embedded ground-truth MO roles and demonstrate how machine learning-enhanced link prediction using SEAL (Subgraph Extraction and Augmentation) can improve MO detection accuracy. Our experiments show that MO-based disruption strategies achieve 23% faster network collapse compared to traditional degree-based approaches, while ML-augmented graphs improve MO classification accuracy by 18%. The framework addresses data incompleteness common in law enforcement scenarios and provides interpretable behavioral insights for strategic intervention planning.

title: Namma Carpool- Smart Ride Sharing System
authors: Pallavi Nayak, Anchal Ahalawat, Pratheek U Acharya, Praveen Patil
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Rapid urbanization has led to rising vehicle density, energy consumption, and travel delays in metropolitan cities, calling for intelligent and sustainable transportation alternatives. This work proposes SmartRideShare, an AI-assisted community-based ridesharing system that leverages ubiquitous computing to optimize peer-to-peer travel matching. The platform integrates React.js for responsive front-end interfaces, Firebase for real-time backend services, and Leaflet Maps for spatial visualization. The system introduces route scheduling and a credit-based fairness model for corporate and daily commuters, ensuring compliance with local vehicle-sharing laws. Experimental validation was performed using real user flow simulations under urban constraints, and results demonstrated an average 18–25% reduction in travel cost and up to 30% lower carbon emission proxy compared to conventional single-passenger services. The proposed architecture shows high scalability and modularity, supporting future integration of blockchain-based trust systems and IoT-based sensing. SmartRideShare contributes to the conference theme by enabling intelligent information systems for sustainable urban mobility through decentralized, adaptive, and community-centric design.

title: Swan Platform: Integrating Automation and Compliance for Smarter Social Work Operations
authors: Bijal Lalitkumar Dave
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Social Work Services (SWS) face increasing challenges with more complex client expectations, strict legislative requirements, and the need to be effective operation. Manual or traditional processes often lead to inefficiencies, delays in service provision and lack of transparency. Thus, the Social Work Administration Network (SWAN) platform is developed to acknowledge and respond to these barriers by delivering a multi-tiered cloud-based solution that offers case management, documentation, communication, and monitoring compliance. This article is about the design and implementation of SWAN, especially how the system uses role-based access controls, real-time audit trails and automated workflows to cut down administrative work and to improve service delivery. As a result of the implementation, there has been a significant increase in the speed of social workers to solve cases, a higher level of compliance capacity and deeper interaction between the clients and social workers. Some of the main features are that the system is completely tailored to the user's process, the use of scalable implementation methods to enhance access that is always-on and the automation of data collection for compliance reporting.

title: Research on Light Source Stability Control of Line Scan Camera
authors: Pengfei Jiang, Jinliang Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Wireless Communication, Networking and Internet of Things (WCNIoT)
abstract: In the field of industrial machine vision inspection, the high-precision imaging of line scan cameras depends on the high-frequency response capability and long-term luminance stability of the light source. As the mainstream light source, Light-Emitting Diodes (LEDs) suffer from issues such as aging attenuation, temperature drift, and the non-linear relationship between current and luminance, which severely restrict inspection accuracy and equipment reliability. To address these pain points, this research first analyzes the characteristic requirements and aging mechanisms of LED light sources under high-frequency driving, and identifies the core influencing factors of luminance attenuation. Subsequently, it proposed a collaborative solution combining “hardware circuit + closed-loop algorithm”. Meanwhile, designing an automatic correction scheme integrating luminance detection, data processing, and dynamic compensation; Finally, experimental verification shows that this scheme can control the LED luminance stability error ≤%, effectively solving the non-linear attenuation problem that traditional constant current control cannot address. It provides a reliable light source guarantee for high-precision scenarios such as electronic component defect detection and printed product quality control.

title: Auto Share Pooling Framework For Dynamic Ride-Sharing
authors: Mathivanan P, Kamesh P, Sathya S, Sudalai Eswaran V
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: The rapid growth of cities’ populations has made the need for efficient, long-lasting, and affordable ways to get around even greater. Ride-hailing services that are more traditional often have low vehicle occupancy, high operational costs, and more traffic. This paper proposes AutoSharePooling, a dynamic ride-sharing framework that uses Haversine-based nearest-neighbor matching, A* pathfinding, and insertion heuristics to improve real-time ride allocation. The system combines cloud-native microservices, blockchain-based security, and AI-driven analytics to make sure that it can be easily deployed, that fares are fairly distributed, and that privacy is well protected. Experimental testing shows big improvements in performance, such as a 92 percent accuracy in matching rides, a 28 percent drop in CO emissions, and a 22 percent rise in driver earnings compared to traditional platforms. Also, the system cuts down on ETA prediction errors from ±6 to ±2 minutes, which makes it more reliable and user-friendly. AutoSharePooling is a next-generation Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) solution that meets the goals of smart cities by combining efficiency, fairness, and environmental sustainability. It also opens the door for future improvements in intelligent transportation systems.

title: Explainable AI in Sustainable Water Quality Monitoring System: A Systematic Review
authors: Kalai Selvi T, Ajaykannan R, Boomika M, Dharunkumar B
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: Water quality plays a crucial role in safeguarding ecosystems and supporting human health. Traditional monitoring methods depend heavily on manual sampling and laboratory testing, which are time-consuming and lack scalability. Recent advancements in Artificial Intelligence (AI) and the Internet of Things (IoT) have transformed water quality monitoring by enabling automated, real-time, and predictive analysis. However, most AI models operate as black-box systems, limiting interpretability in environmental decision-making. This paper presents a systematic review of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) approaches applied to sustainable, AIoT-based water quality monitoring systems. The review critically analyzes sensing technologies, AI algorithms, explainability frameworks, and sustainability strategies adopted in recent research from 2020-2025. A comparison of methodologies highlights key progress in transparency, efficiency, and energy-aware design. The study identifies major gaps in interpretability evaluation, sensor reliability, and lightweight AI models for edge deployment. A conceptual framework is proposed integrating XAI with energy-efficient IoT architecture for real-time, transparent, and sustainable environmental monitoring.

title: An Attention-Enhanced Lightweight Deep Learning Approach for Automated Detection of Leukemic Blasts
authors: Pradeepan P, Gladston Raj S, Juby George, Neethunath M R
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Ubiquitous Computing and Intelligent Information Systems (ICUIS)
abstract: A timely and accurate diagnosis is vital for the prognosis of patients with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL). The conventional diagnostic method of manual blood smear inspection is labor-intensive and prone to human errors. To address this challenge, this study introduces a novel lightweight deep learning approach for the automated detection of leukemic blasts. The proposed model enhances the MobileNetV2 architecture by integrating an Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) mechanism after each of the core inverted residual blocks to improve the feature discrimination between healthy and cancerous cells. The proposed attention-enhanced model achieved an accuracy of 98.72%, an F1-score of 98.70%, a sensitivity of 97.44%, and a specificity of 100.00% on the ALL-IDB2 dataset, which contains cropped images of non-blast and blast cells. The technical significance of this study lies in demonstrating that a lightweight and attention-based architecture can achieve top-tier performance, offering a practical and efficient solution for clinical decision support. This approach holds great promise for accelerating and improving the reliability of leukemia diagnosis in the future.

title: Cross-Layer Optimization in AI-Powered Cognitive Radio Networks for Dynamic Spectrum Access
authors: T.Sheela, D. Kaleeswaran, Jeevitha S V, A L N Arun Kumar, G Sunil, Athiraja A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Despite obstacles including interference and resource limitations, Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs) are essential for optimizing wireless spectrum usage through dynamic spectrum access (DSA). An AI-powered cross-layer optimization framework for CRNs is presented in this research, improving cooperation between the network, MAC, and physical layers to facilitate intelligent and flexible spectrum management. Real-time spectrum sensing, allocation, and reconfiguration are accomplished by reinforcement learning, and power control and routing optimization are accomplished through resource-efficient models. In comparison to conventional CRN systems, simulations over a range of spectrum usage scenarios show a 25% decrease in interference and a 30% increase in network throughput. The framework tackles important DSA issues by guaranteeing smooth communication and maximizing spectrum consumption. These results highlight how AI-powered cross-layer optimization has the potential to revolutionize CRNs and open the door to more effective and scalable wireless communication networks.

title: Advanced Cloud Protection: OAuth and JWT for Secure API Access, Honeypots, and File Monitoring for Ransomware Prevention
authors: Bhagath Singh Jayaprakasam, Rohith Reddy Mandala, Charles Ubagaram, Narsing Rao Dyavani, Ignatious K Pious, S.Jayanthi
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The growing complexity of cloud-based infrastructures has made them prime targets for ransomware attacks and unauthorized access. Current security measures are often insufficient, leading to data breaches and financial losses. To address this, we propose an advanced multi-layered cloud security solution that integrates OAuth 2.0, JSON Web Token (JWT), File Integrity Monitoring (FIM), and honeypots for real-time threat detection and ransomware prevention. Our system ensures secure API access through OAuth 2.0 and JWT, while FIM continuously monitors and alerts for unauthorized file modifications. Honeypots are strategically deployed to attract and identify ransomware, enhancing early detection. Key results from performance assessments demonstrate a 30% reduction in ransomware impact, faster detection times, and lower false positive rates compared to traditional security methods. This approach significantly enhances cloud security by providing proactive, real-time defense against ransomware and unauthorized access, making it particularly valuable for organizations in sectors such as healthcare, finance, and Internet of Things (IoT), where data integrity is critical. Our research underscores the importance of integrated, multi-layered security frameworks in safeguarding cloud environments from evolving cyber threats.

title: Machine Learning for Safeguarding of UPI Scams
authors: Sandhya S, Granty Regina Elwin J, Absalom A, Darwin M, Martin Yokesh D, Gokulnath G
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The Unified Payments Interface (UPI) has revolutionized digital payments in India, but its sudden popularity has also been followed by a rise in fraud, which is challenging user security and trust. This study suggests a machine learning-based real-time UPI fraud detection approach that is scalable, accurate, and interpretable. Decision Tree, Random Forest, and Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifiers were trained on a labeled dataset of real and fake transactions and tested using stratified k-fold cross-validation. Random Forest ranked first consistently with an accuracy of 96.2% and was experimentally verified using real-time simulations with low latency. Geolocation discrepancy, frequency of transactions, and device change were identified as significant fraud markers by feature importance analysis. The contribution of this study is the creation of an interpretable, real-time fraud detection model particularly designed for UPI, with ease of deployment in live transaction monitoring systems. This provides financial security with guarantee of user convenience and trust in digital payment systems.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Demand Forecasting and Perishable Inventory Optimization in Multi-Echelon Supply Chain
authors: R. Dhivya, G.Thailambal
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Multi-echelon supply chains for perishable items are becoming increasingly complex and the tension between cost, service, and waste is becoming more pronounced and difficult to navigate in multi-echelon supply chains for perishable items. Inventory policies like (s,S) and (Q,R) do not consistently adjust to the uncertainty of demand and lead times and details on perishability and often do not yield a desired outcome. The purpose of this study is to create and deploy a complete AI–Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) model for adaptive demand forecasting and inventory control in a multi-echelon supply system for perishable products. The study offers a hybrid approach for probabilistic demand forecasting through a Transformer-based forecasting model, use hierarchical multi-agent DRL for control and a constrained optimization input layer for feasibility.The framework was compared to (S,s), (Q,R), MPC and single-agent DRL baselines using the publicly available FreshRetailNet-50K dataset. The results indicated a total cost reduction of 25%, a waste reduction of ~40%, and a fill rate increase of 2.6%, more than the existing methods. The proposed approach provided evidence for how AI-driven adaptive control can improve efficiency and sustainability of perishable multi-echelon supply chains.

title: A Review of Computational Modeling and Comprehensive CFD Analysis of Implantable Chemoports using ANSYS for Enhanced Reliability and Clinical Performance
authors: Vinoth Selvamani, S Abinaya, S Jayashree, Mohammed Mehshad V A, I Sudharshan
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Implantable chemoports are routinely utilized in oncology for the administration of intermittent chemotherapy infusion with constrained venipuncture. Routine chemoports are marred by complications such as leakage of fluids, displacement of the catheter, and reduced durability due to mechanical fatigue. In response, this work proposes an ideal design of the chemoport through Autodesk Fusion 360, simulated through ANSYS Workbench. Multiphysics simulation refers to structural, fluid, thermal, fatigue, and vibration simulations in the determination of mechanical integrity, uniformity of flow, stability in temperature, and lifecycle durability. This design, through simulation, aspires to enhance septum seeping efficiency, prolong operational lifespan, and offer better patient comfort.

title: Efficient and Secure Big Data Analytics via Federated Mining Techniques
authors: R.Gautham Goud, B.Vittal, A.Sadanandam, R.Banu Priya, G.Ganesh Kumar, S.P.Santhoshkumar
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: The exponential growth of large data provides huge opportunities for discovery of knowledge, but also increases important concerns about privacy, security and scalability. Traditional centralized data mining approaches increase the risk by collecting sensitive information in a single repository. To solve these challenges, this study proposes a data sources without highlighting raw data. Framework integrates secured multipratis computation, homomorphic encryption and differential secrecy to ensure privacy, reduce overhead and maintain efficiency. Healthcare, finance and image dataset displays that the proposed system only receives high future accuracy (92%) with high future-staging accuracy (92%) with only a minor trade-band compared to centralized learning (94%). Statistical results show a decrease of 80% in privacy leakage risk, 25% decrease in communication costs, and acceptable computational overhead (~ 1.5 ×). Strong tests confirm the flexibility against adverse hazards such as model inverted and data poisoning with a performance drop less than 5%. These findings validate the outline as a safe, accurate and scalable solution for real -world large data applications.

title: Exploring FSS Enabled IRS for 5G
authors: Sapna B A, K Ramasamy, P Kalaivani, Shameel H, Sivasanjai P, Abdul Ashfaaq Sathik A
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This article shows the study of an intelligent reflecting surface based on a Frequency Selective Surface (FSS) for sub-6 GHz wireless communication. Tall buildings and obstacles reduce the signal strength and coverage in 5G users falling under shadow areas. To address this issue, we created and simulated an FSS unit cell using the ANSYS HFSS tool. The strong reflection performance was ensured by optimizing the structure to resonate at 3.5 GHz. We analyzed the results by changing the phi and theta angles. The results show an improvement in the area where 5G coverage is limited due to the FSS’s stable resonance at 3.5 GHz under the selected theta and phi angles. This paper proposes the design, simulation, and experiment of an Intelligent Reflecting Surface (IRS) for enhancing wireless coverage in 5G communication systems. High-frequency signals in the sub-6 GHz frequency band in dense urban areas tend to get attenuated and blocked by tall buildings and other barriers, resulting in signal degradation. The geometry was optimized to operate at 3.5 GHz, a crucial band for 5G services. The performance was stable at phi and theta incident angles up to 100degree in both plane. The proposed FSS-based IRS demonstrated enhanced signal coverage and stable resonance at 3.5 GHz, act as a promising solution for practical deployment in urban 5G networks.

title: Semantic Kernel for Software Engineering: A Multi-Agent Framework for Autonomous Development Lifecycles
authors: Adithya B V, Raj Kumar.J.S., Nirmal Varghese Babu
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Software engineering automation remains constrained, with existing AI tools typically focusing on isolated tasks such as code generation, while still relying heavily on human intervention for integration, testing, and deployment. This paper presents a multi-agent system that will autonomously manage the whole software development process-including natural language requirements to deployed systems. The system leverages a Semantic Kernel for dynamic task decomposition and orchestrates specialized, role-specific agents for code generation, testing, debugging, and deployment. A vector-based knowledge retention engine allows for ongoing learning and reuse of solutions across projects. This will ensure high-quality code and consistent architecture. The framework works with professional tools like Docker and GitHub Actions. It supports results that are ready for production. In experimental tests, the end-to-end task success rate reached 65 percent. The average development time dropped to 35 minutes. There was also a decrease in human intervention compared to baseline systems like ChatDev and GPT-4, which relied on manual tools. This work creates a new approach in autonomous software engineering. It uses coordinated multi-agent systems that can handle complex projects with minimal human involvement.

title: NutriVision: Smart Food Recognition & Health Report
authors: S Rupashree Reshma, Lakshmi Raj Harsha.Y, Nayana.M, Bhavana V
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This is the developing field of study that combines computer vision and natural language processing is food recognition and recipe creation. There is still a gap in producing comprehensive and cohesive recipes straight from food photos, whereas previous methods primarily concentrated on food classification or ingredient estimation. We suggest NutriVision, an end-to-end deep learning framework that can generate ingredient lists, dish names, and detailed cooking instructions from a single image input to overcome this difficulty. By automating recipe discovery and bridging the gap between visual recognition and textual recipe knowledge, this work aims to increase accessibility to culinary exploration. An encoder–decoder architecture is used in the suggested system. The encoder for extracting fine-grained visual features is a pretrained DenseNet-161 model while a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network with attention acts as the decoder to generate structured textual outputs. However, to produce structured textual outputs, a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network with attention serves as the decoder. With its densely connected layers, DenseNet offers richer visual representations, and the LSTM efficiently captures sequential dependencies, guaranteeing that recipes are contextually accurate and coherent. Techniques like data augmentation, transfer learning, and hyperparameter optimization are used to further enhance performance. The extensive Recipe1M dataset is used to train and validate the model. These results demonstrate the system's dependability and usefulness. Potential uses for NutriVision include smart kitchen assistants, personalized meal planning, and nutrition monitoring, which could benefit both daily

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning Model with 1D-CNN and Transformer Encoder for Anomaly Detection in Large Scale IoT Networks
authors: Renjini Rani K. S, B. Ben Sujitha
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Anomaly detection is a fundamental aspect of securing expansive internet of Things (IoT) networks, which comprise billions of interconnected devices vulnerable to a wide spectrum of cyber threats. Effective anomaly detection is vital as it enables the early identification of malicious activities, thereby reducing the likelihood of service interruptions, information breaches, and potential safety risks. Traditional methods struggle to adapt to emerging threats and manage the complexity of large-scale IoT traffic. To address these limitations, this study proposes a hybrid deep learning (DL) model integrating a One-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN) with a Transformer Encoder for robust anomaly classification in IoT networks. The model processes traffic data from the CIC-IoT 2023 dataset, which includes benign traffic and seven major attack categories such as DDoS, DoS, Recon, Web, Brute Force, Spoofing, and Mirai. The 1D-CNN component extracts local temporal patterns and short-range dependencies crucial for detecting subtle anomalies, while the Transformer Encoder captures global context and long-range feature dependencies for improved classification accuracy. Performance evaluation using standard metrics demonstrates the model’s effectiveness, achieving an accuracy of 95.82%, precision of 95.20%, recall of 94.80%, F1-score of 93.95%, and a low misclassification score of 4.18%. These results confirm that the proposed hybrid architecture outperforms traditional methods in handling complex, large-scale IoT traffic, offering a scalable and adaptive solution for real-world anomaly detection and intrusion prevention systems.

title: Integrated 3D Packaging using Rigid Flex Technology – Novel Concept for Miniaturisation of Electronic Packaging in Small Satellites
authors: Jissy Varghese, Shriram N Bhat
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: Small satellites including micro and nano satellites are a preferred option for low earth orbit applications due to their quicker turn-around time, low cost and advanced technology adaptability. Miniaturization in space electronics packaging in terms of weight and volume is a key factor in realizing micro and nano satellites. It is majorly driven by advancements in components which in turn drives feature size reduction in PCBs. However, this approach is limited by the PCB realization and assembly capability coupled with reliability requirements. In addition, connectors and associated harness used for electrical interconnection add considerable weight and volume to the electronic packaging. Reliability also can be a concern due to wiring defects, connector interchange or reworks, signal interference etc. In this paper, a novel concept is proposed for electronics packaging in small satellites using three-dimensional architecture. The concept involves realizing a package using a single Rigid-flex PCB with multiple subsystems interconnected through flex layers. This removes the requirement for connectors and wire harnesses which are conventionally used for PCB-to-PCB interconnection. This concept can typically be applied to micro and nano satellites where limited number of PCBs are used to realize the entire subsystems and where the design is finalized and circuitry is proven. 3-D packaging using rigid-flex PCB technology offers considerable advantages in terms of weight and volume reduction while enhancing reliability and performance, and is a recommended solution for small satellite electronics.

title: Optimization and Error-Corrected Quantum Sensing with NV Centers in SiC: An Extension to EPR/ENDOR Characterization
authors: Pacha Lohith Chowdary, Balagala Chethan, Swaminadhan Rajula
publish: 2025 9th International Conference on Electronics, Communication and Aerospace Technology (ICECA)
abstract: This extension method advances the characterization of NV centers in silicon carbide (SiC) by incorporating optimization strategies, machine learning (ML), error correction, and advanced sensing protocols. While the base method validated NV centers in 4H-SiC and 6H-SiC as promising solid-state qubits, our extension aims to enhance their performance and scalability for quantum technologies. First, we identified an optimal NV ensemble density of 1.0 × 10¹⁶ cm⁻<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, balancing signal strength with minimized dipole–dipole interactions, thereby maximizing collective coherence. Second, a machine learning framework was developed to optimize experimental conditions, scanning laser power, excitation wavelength, and temperature to improve phase coherence time (T₂) by nearly two-fold. Third, advanced quantum sensing protocols were benchmarked, including Ramsey, Spin-Echo, CPMG, XY-8, and ML-optimized pulse sequences, achieving up to 3.5× higher sensitivity compared to conventional spin-echo. Fourth, dynamical decoupling (N=16) was applied to mitigate decoherence, extending T₂ up to ~60 μs at room temperature. Finally, error correction simulations at the NV ensemble level demonstrated logical error rate reductions by nearly two orders of magnitude, showcasing fault-tolerance potential. Overall, this extension transforms NV–SiC centers from characterized quantum defects into a practical platform with enhanced coherence, improved sensing capabilities, and integrated error correction. These results position SiC NV ensembles as a scalable candidate for next-generation quantum computing
